column2: More than a year after holding a well-attended media event on the site of the new Red Bull Park in Harrison, N.J., replete with local and state politicos, and other assorted luminaries, the club has finally begun construction on its redesigned 25,000-seat, $200 million soccer stadium.
Ryan Trecartin's video "I-Be Area." Video courtesy of Ryan Trecartin and Elizabeth Dee Gallery.

Hard to believe, but the A.S.O., the organizers of the Dakar rally, formerly known as the Paris-Dakar, decided to cancel the race after threats of terrorism in Mauritania led them to conclude it just wasn't worth it.
Nearly half of 10-year-olds may have tasted alcohol, although many of their parents don't know about it, a new study shows.

Will Okun is a Chicago school teacher who traveled with Nick Kristof in June to central Africa, on the win-a-trip contest. He blogged and vlogged as he went, and you can see his reports at www.nytimes.com/twofortheroad. He teaches English and photography in a Chicago school with many students from low-income and minority homes.
An excerpt from Tati's 'Jour De Fete,' part of the Dance on Camera Festival, courtesy Les Films de Mon Oncle.
Bear Stearns officials are expected to meet in the middle of January with U.S. prosecutors to discuss the failure of two of its hedge funds, CNBC television said on Friday.

MANCHESTER, N.H. - Rudolph W. Giuliani never expected to win the Iowa caucuses. But he returns here Friday afternoon as Iowa's sixth-place finisher, much lower than expected, having won fewer than half the votes cast for Representative Ron Paul of Texas.

A promotional video for MTV's Virtual Lower East Side.
Director, producer and writer: Annie Ok
Song: Tiny Masters of Today, "Hologram World" (featuring Karen O and Nick Zinner)

In his Web column today, Jeff Zeleny writes that an inspection of the results in Iowa's 99 counties also underscores some of the challenges that lie ahead for Senator Barack Obama as the presidential campaign continues beyond the early-voting states. Go to column

Steve Jobs and Jeff Bezos may be rivals in the music sales business, but between them they have forced the music industry to abandon digital rights management-the software that limits how you copy songs you buy and download.
With the Iowa caucus returns on cable and Orange Bowl college football coverage on Fox, NBC's "Celebrity Apprentice" still managed to earn Thursday night's top ratings among adults 18 to 49.

Will Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg enter the already tumultuous field of presidential candidates by mounting a third-party bid for the White House? The billionaire mayor -- who appeared on David Letterman's show on Thursday -- continued to stay mum this morning on his own political aspirations. But in a morning radio call-in program, Mr. Bloomberg continued to assert that the leading candidates for president had failed to be specific enough in their proposed solutions for the nation's problems. He also discussed a University of Oklahoma conference he plans to attend this weekend, at which participants expect to call for the candidates to renounce what the mayor called "partisan bickering."

The headline numbers on the monthly jobs report this morning were pretty scary. The unemployment rate took its biggest jump up in 12 years, to 5 percent, and only 18,000 nonfarm jobs were created in December, in an economy that needs more than 100,000 a month just to keep up with natural population growth. Take government workers out of the picture, and the economy actually lost 13,000 private-sector jobs.
Josh Ruxin is a Columbia University expert on public health who has spent the last couple of years living in Rwanda. He's an unusual mix of academic expert and mud-between-the-toes aid worker.

HOLLIS, N.H. -- With the full glare of the national media spotlight now focused squarely on New Hampshire, Senator John McCain wasted little time responding to the latest line of assault from his chief rival here, Mitt Romney.
Aired Thursday night on NBC: As you know, tonight was the big night in Iowa. It's easy to remember because this is the only big night in Iowa.

A scene from MTV's virtual Lower East Side.
Director, producer and writer: Annie Ok
Assistant director: Derek Lerner
Song: "Sonic" by Modrocket
To review the play-by-play commentary of the World Junior Championship semifinal match at the CEZ Arena in Pardubice, Czech Republic, click "more." Lew Serviss described the action.

Fox is moving two of its midseason dramas, "New Amsterdam" and "Canterbury's Law," to higher profile time slots. But because the writers' strike has led to a shortage of new episodes, the shows will be shown in sequence -- one will start after the other ends -- instead of at different times on the same night between February and May.

Kris Tapley, who you could call an veteran Oscar ninny if he wasn't so young and ungrizzled, has gone out on a limb and brought his saw with him, picking "Into the Wild" for best picture. As Mr. Tapley and others, including Pete Hammond, have pointed out, it is an hellaciously confusing year, with no movie making a clear break out of the pack.

Aired Thursday night on CBS: The Writers Guild strike does continue. Let me simplify this for you. Here's what the writers want. Tell me if you don't think this is fair. They want a share of internet revenues and four more years of President Bush.

Our provocative science columnist John Tierney endured a hailstorm of responses for a column and blog post this week on the tendency of some climate campaigners to focus on extreme weather as a selling point for cutting greenhouse gases. Today he's posted an explanation and defense of his view, echoing a lot of what I've been writing over the past several years.
This time around, Iowa doesn't seem to have produced its Howard Dean moment, so we'll just have to live with the original ...

The Village Voice and the Los Angeles Week, both of which are owned by Village Voice Media, polled film critics -- those still with jobs after the company, which has bought many city weeklies, dumped the local film writers in favor of syndicated ones -- and found out that serious film types are still basking in the brilliance of "There Will Be Blood."
Aired Thursday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: The Iowa caucus went on today. Whoever wins gets to be president of Iowa, I guess. I don't know.

Families today agonize over a bewildering array of deadlines and policies. How does early decision differ from early action, or single-choice early action? Does an honors course carry the same weight as A.P.? What's the best tack for an essay?
Clark Johnson plays a newspaper editor on HBO's "The Wire."

DES MOINES - There were many factors contributing to Barack Obama's decisive victory in Iowa Thursday night -- his efforts to reach out to first-time caucus voters, record turnout, and a willingness by voters to take a chance on a candidate who seemed improbable not long ago -- but was an agreement with the Bill Richardson campaign one of them?
Is Hasbro changing its game plan?

When leading industrialists warn that plans for cutting greenhouse gases may be too ambitious, it's hard to know whether they are giving an honest assessment or protecting their interests. That seems doubly true when the person making the comments is a leading representative of the fossil fuel industry like Jeroen Van der Veer, the chief executive of oil giant Shell.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H. - Just hours after his plane touched down here, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney congratulated Mike Huckabee on his win in the Iowa caucuses, saying he did a "real nice job." But he quickly added: "Things are different here in New Hampshire."

Kansas entered the Orange Bowl against Virginia Tech as the "least-respected 11-1 college football team in recent memory," writes Joe Posnanski of the Kansas City Star. The Jayhawks left with a signature victory that silenced their many critics.

In this week's Carpetbagger Video, the Bagger visits Arnie Sawyer Studios, an advertising firm that specializes in Academy Award print campaigns. And after being schooled by the masters, the Bagger team comes up with a campaign that turns someone who looks homeless into a movie star.

Some of Africa's brightest stars will miss or are likely to miss the African Cup of Nations later this month in Ghana. Egypt midfielder Mohamad Barakat was ruled out today due to a knee injury. The Egyptian sports site Fil Balad said Barakat, who helped Egypt lift a record 5th African Cup two years ago, was considered a replacement for winger Mohsen Hindawi, also injured. Barakat, who plays for Al Ahly in Cairo, will have surgery in Germany.
The Disney Channel bested USA to become the top-rated cable network of 2007, according to yearend data released on Thursday by Nielsen.
The following is a transcript of Fred D. Thompson’s remarks to supporters after the Iowa caucuses, based on audio provided by the campaign.
Alessandra Stanley reviews the Iowa caucus coverage and finds lots to like on MSNBC, where Chris Matthews co-anchored with Keith Olbermann:
A smaller field of candidates arrived in New Hampshire facing an upended campaign after the Iowa caucuses.

NASHUA, N.H. - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband Bill emerged here on Granite State soil Friday morning for a pep rally, as her campaign - and her ever-popular husband prepared to redouble their efforts after her loss in Iowa.

Rumors are flying fast and furious over what Steve Jobs will pull out of his blue-jean pocket a week from Tuesday at his annual speech at the Macworld Expo in San Francisco. These include a movie rental service for iTunes, a super small notebook computer perhaps with a solid-state hard drive, a notebook docking station, and new features for the iPhone. Shaw Wu, an analyst with American Technology Research, suggested that Apple will start shipping some computers with Blu-ray high-definition DVD drives.
How much did the Iowa results change the odds in the 2008 campaign?
The December jobs report provides more evidence of a sluggish economy. Employers have not resorted to large-scale layoffs, but they seem to be quite unwilling to hire.
David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) visits Arnie Sawyer Studios, an advertising firm that specializes in Academy Award print campaigns.
Countdown: 4 days until the primary.

Microsoft made a big splash with its $240 million deal to buy a sliver of Facebook. Now, some industry observers think the software giant should consider another social-networking deal. This time, the focus is on Plaxo, an early entrant into the social-networking field that was overtaken by rivals and is looking to fetch as much as $100 million in a potential sale of the company.
Here's a headline to get the little gray cells puzzling: The Malaysian government has "reminded" -- that is, ordered -- a Catholic newspaper published in the country not to use the word Allah.

The exploration of ways to create a "sellable" approach to the daunting task of establishing a firm ceiling on greenhouse-gas emissions is important enough that I'm adding another post on this for the weekend.

OK, that's enough celebrating. Iowa caucus kings Mike Huckabee and Barack Obama, thanks to this year's condensed primary schedule, have to translate their momentum quickly into a New Hampshire victory before their primary on Tuesday. And candidates who didn't get the results they wanted have limited time to convince Granite Staters that they don't have to follow Iowa's cue.

Having sampled the mediocre food that's the price of kid-friendly theatrics at Mars 2112, the Jekyll and Hyde Club and Max Brenner, I'd come to the sad conclusion that fun for children and decent grub for grown-ups wasn't a combination to be found in Manhattan.

To follow the play-by-play commentary of the World Junior Championship semifinal match, LIVE, as it happens at the CEZ Arena in Pardubice, Czech Republic, click "more" and then refresh like crazy. Jeff Z. Klein describes the action.

One of the most evocative short essays I've read in a while is Enid Stubin's "My Life in the Indexing Trade," available at moreintelligentlife.com. It pokes around in a part of book production most readers don't often think about - the worker bees who often compile the indexes in biographies and other nonfiction books.

This week's guest bloggers are Loden Dager, a men's wear collective based in New York City that launched in the Fall of 2006 and this week won the Ecco Domani Fashion Foundation award for new talent. Its members, pictured, are: Melissa Vail, Matthew Sandager, Oliver Helden, Paul Marlow, and Alex Galan. Today the gang is back at work on their upcoming Paris and New York shows. (Read previous blog entries written by Loden Dager and a profile of Alex Galan here.)
The Vulture, which knows a thing about large, ungainly avians that have trouble taking wing, has done a bit of databasing in search of the worst movie of the year.
Both Spoutblog and EW's Pop Watch are crushing on Michael Cera's knobby knees.
The Reeler had a spare 699 minutes on his hands and decided to watch every Paul Thomas Anderson-directed movie in existence. And, oh, he live-blogged along the way.
Samuel So, the pedicurist "sifu" (or "master") was waiting for me with hands on his hips. I had booked nearly a month in advance, and I was late.

For the moment, Dave Poland at The Hot Button and others are saying that the writers' strike may shut down a television show called "The Golden Globes." But even if the show doesn't go on, the parties will. Why, just last night one gatekeeper for an annual shindig told the Bagger that he couldn't come unless pledged to cough up coverage.
Wanted: Single dot-com Yenta seeks ambitious Mr. Big with deep pockets for a long-term relationship.

Carlyle Group is looking for ways to spend its new $1.5 billion infrastructure fund, and a Carlyle executive told The Washington Post it would consider backing the controversial Dulles Rail project, which does not take funds from private sources.
An interesting item from MSNBC on whether Titans Coach Jeff Fisher and Colts Coach Tony Dungy had an under-the-table understanding at the end of Sunday night's game. Here are some excerpts:
Liz Claiborne, the women's clothing giant, is in the process of selling some of its brands and may make an announcement as soon as Friday, Fortune's Suzanne Kapner reported.

Federal regulators, concerned brokerages may have sold clients money-losing securities tied to subprime mortgages, are seeking information about how the investments were marketed, Bloomberg News reported citing an unnamed source.

For hedge fund magnate Kenneth C. Griffin, 2007 was the best year ever. His Citadel Investment Group emerged as one of Wall Street's top opportunists, picking up the pieces of fallen peers on the cheap. With such deft moves, Citadel rang in 30 percent-plus gains last year, compared with with the industry average of 12 percent.

MANCHESTER, N.H. -- In the latest installment of Campus Voices, a few of the students from Harvard's Institute of Politics braved the single-digit temperatures today while on their break to visit the candidates' campaign headquarters, where preparations were under way for the big push here -- finally! -- toward next Tuesday. The students' academic project has produced both text and video dispatches throughout the fall and winter as they spent a lot of time in New Hampshire following the primary process and the candidates.
Investment bank Lazard has filed for an $800 million initial public offering for its blank check company Sapphire Industrial, in what would be the second-largest offering of its kind to date.
Bupa, the private health insurer based in the United Kingdom, has agreed to pay $640 million for Health Dialog, its first acquisition of a healthcare company in the United States.
Merrill Lynch's margin call on assets loaned to Bear Stearns may have been the catalyst for the decline in the value of collateralized debt obligations, according to a Bloomberg News report.
Happy New Year? Not for Wall Street deal makers.
Amidst the denunciations of my column and post on weather alarmism, there was a calm question from one critic, Annie Jia:
Combination drug developer Tempo Pharmaceuticals raised $8.1 million in a Series B round of venture capital, bringing total funding in a little more than a year to $22 million.
Is the Weather Channel over-shooting with its $5 billion price-tag?
American Industrial Partners purchased the Brooks Instrument division of Emerson Electric for about $100 million, Emerson said Thursday.
Have the floodgates on a new wave of securities fraud lawsuits been opened?

MidOcean Partners said Thursday that Mark A. Angelson, the former chief executive of printing giant R.R. Donnelley, would join the private equity firm as its new chairman. He will also take responsibility for the Executive Board at MidOcean, which was founded by Ted Virtue, a former executive from Deutsche Bank. MidOcean was spun out from Deutsche Bank in 2003.

Warren E. Buffett's new bond insurer is looking to expand to Rhode Island after hearing that the state's treasurer wanted it to apply for a license to operate in the state, according to a spokeswoman for the billionaire investor.
Britain's chancellor of the Exchequer is planning to push through sweeping new powers to intervene if banks fail, in an effort to prevent a future Northern Rock-style crisis.

A Silicon Valley start-up is said to be promising to blanket San Francisco with free wireless Internet service, reviving a crusade that crumbled last year after two much larger companies, EarthLink and Google, scrapped their plans to build a high-speed network for Web surfing.
A subsidiary of the body overseeing China's massive $1.4 trillion reserve stockpile has purchased stakes in three leading Australian banks, according to a report.

With the price of oil expected to hover near $100 a barrel or move higher still this year, investors should expect more deals to be made in the energy sector, a leading private-equity executive specializing in the oil and gas industry said Thursday.
National City Corp., Ohio's largest bank, had a rough start to the New Year.

In the latest twisted tale of Los Angeles dealmaking, lawyers for billionaire and former grocery store magnate Ronald W. Burkle and onetime Hollywood superstar agent Michael S. Ovitz are set to square off in court in February.
One year after signing a $30 million first round of venture financing, n2N Commerce is in the process of shuttering its business.

As Tata Motors begins detailed talks with Ford Motor about buying the Jaguar and Land Rover brands, The New York Times takes a look at Ratan Tata, for whom the takeover will cap 16 years of transforming one of the world's most diverse and unusual conglomerates, the Tata Group.
From a Times Op-Ed parody of in-flight instructions, from the vantage point of a single seat:
More of your "late night" humor (send via the comment link below):
Illustration found here.
The opening joke from Joel Osteen's podcast sermon of Dec. 13:
The world of “How to Look Good Naked” is a happy and optimistic place where no one is overweight, but everyone suffers from a curable form of body dysmorphia.
The inner workings of a single caucus, that of the second precinct in Nevada, Iowa.
A "villa" suggests something slightly regal, a palace in the country. Rich people escape to villas, estates of grand gardens, wide terraces and, perhaps, a vineyard or two.

Sorry not to have posted something here yesterday. We had some technical glitches here in Iowa. I know that some of you probably forgot to eat dinner and missed all the victory speeches because you were obsessively hitting your refresh buttons all night long, and for that I apologize.
Three exhibitions in New York pivot around one of modern art's most enduringly popular styles.
Photos and reviews of plays written by Christopher Shinn.
The Times's John Harwood analyzes Thursday night's Iowa caucuses and what lies beyond.

CNN's fifth-floor newsroom was gift-wrapped in shades of red and blue for the Iowa caucus Thursday evening, as the network deployed the latest electronic toys for the first votes of the 2008 presidential elections.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

A number of television personalities and producers won't get much sleep Friday morning. Correspondents are following presidential candidates to New Hampshire overnight, and several of them will be in position for Friday newscasts.
Television anchors and analysts swiftly anointed the Democratic candidate Barack Obama and the Republican candidate Mike Huckabee the frontrunners of their respective parties on Thursday.
Here's the next chapter of the Ben and Shauna Moffitt saga. Brett McMurphy of the Tampa Tribune digs deeper into the academic fraud aspect of the story in this article.

"CBS Sports took a firmer grip on CSTV, the college sports media company it acquired in late 2005, by announcing Thursday that it was taking over day-to-day control of it from the last of its three founders, Brian Bedol, who will soon leave CBS," Richard Sandomir reports in Friday's New York Times.
Mitt Romney comments on the results from the Iowa caucuses. (NBC  Video)
DES MOINES -- We just caught up with some numbers that you'll want to see. Turns out Barack Obama did better among women than Hillary Rodham Clinton did.
Instant analysis of the Iowa caucuses (that's the political event that was going on while the Kansas Jayhawks won the Orange Bowl) from around the Web:
Chaos and ethnic fighting has ignited in Kenya, destabilizing the country, just one week after Kenyans went to the polls to elect their president.
John Edwards comments on the results from the Iowa caucuses.(NBC Video)
John McCain responds to the results of the Iowa caucus. (NBC Video)

As noted by TV Decoder on Thursday, the late-night shows enjoyed an overall viewership bump Wednesday. But the strong ratings belie the sagging advertising market for late-night television. Before the strike began the late-night shows had shed approximately 10 percent of their viewers. Two months of forced repeats exacerbated the declines.
Jay Leno delivered a traditional full-length monologue without the help of his team of 19 writers on Wednesday night.
Mike Wallace’s interviewing skills will be demonstrated for the first time in seven months in a taped segment with Roger Clemens about the accusations that he used steroids.
You read Angela Thirkell’s Barsetshire novels, laughing, and want to do your best to protect her characters from any reality but their own.

Jose Padilla, the American citizen who was held in military detention for more than three years as an enemy combatant, filed a lawsuit against a lawyer who helped provide the legal justifications for the episode.
The Chappaqua lawyer accused of murdering his wife in Nov. 2006 admitted he had sent flowers just before the shooting to his longtime mistress, according to court documents released on Friday.
A transit agency approved 33 percent toll increases for millions of motorists driving between New Jersey and New York City.
An inspection of the results in Iowa underscores some of the challenges Barack Obama will face as the presidential campaign continues beyond the early-voting states.
Commuters who take the ferry from Rockland County have a fond attachment to their daily ride.
The storms are expected to bring high winds, heavy rains and snow in the higher elevations.
A smaller field of candidates arrived in New Hampshire facing an upended campaign after two one-time insurgents won the Iowa caucuses.
The new conventional wisdom of the race was set out within minutes of the first projections of the winners.
The chairwoman of a Democratic caucus in Iowa was nervous about the possibility of  high turnout. She also didn’t know for whom she would vote.
If Tim Russert of NBC News is the New Hampshire primary of political pundits, then Chris Matthews is the Iowa caucuses.
A New York City fire lieutenant died and eight people were injured in a fire in a high-rise apartment building.
The Huskies opened conference play on a high note Thursday night at the Prudential Center, in a game that turned into a mismatch in the second half.
Shan Foster had 24 points and 5 rebounds and No. 15 Vanderbilt remained undefeated with a victory over visiting Rice.
Boeing said that it had received orders for 1,413 commercial jets last year, setting a third consecutive annual record driven by demand from Asian and Middle Eastern airlines.

A sports article in some editions on Monday about running back Thomas Jones’s solid performance in the Jets’ 13-10 overtime victory against Kansas City misspelled the surname of the Chiefs player who stopped Jones on a fourth-down play in the third quarter. He is Tamba Hali, not Ali.

A sports article in some editions on Monday about running back Thomas Jones’s solid performance in the Jets’ 13-10 overtime victory against Kansas City misspelled the surname of the Chiefs player who stopped Jones on a fourth-down play in the third quarter. He is Tamba Hali, not Ali.

A Sports of The Times column on Sunday about the writer’s travels in covering sports in 2007 misidentified the team that defeated the Mets on the final day of baseball’s regular season. It was Florida, not Washington.

A sports article on Wednesday about the University of Southern California’s 49-17 victory over Illinois in the Rose Bowl reversed, in some editions, the surnames of two U.S.C. players involved in a scoring play. They are Garrett Green and Desmond Reed.

The Cases column in Science Times on Tuesday, about a doctor’s decision to apologize to a patient for a medical error, misstated the number of states that have enacted legislation encouraging such apologies. It is 29, not 17.

An article in Science Times on Dec. 25 about the information storage capacity of individual neurons referred imprecisely to the process by which brain cells communicate with one another. Although a cell does fire a chemical burst across a space called the synapse to stimulate the hairlike spines on the receiving cell, the part of the cell that sends the burst is called an axonal ending, not a spine.

The Findings column in Science Times on Tuesday, about the way severe weather is tied to predictions of global warming, gave an outdated academic affiliation for Timur Kuran. He is a professor of economics and political science at Duke University; he is no longer a professor of economics and law at the University of Southern California.
Polls showed that more than 8 in 10 of Mike Huckabee’s supporters described themselves as evangelicals.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former Gov. Mitt Romney were brought low in Iowa on Thursday.
King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia must understand that cruelty and censorship cannot be part of a country that wants to participate in the modern world.
The CSX Corporation, the third-largest American railroad by sales, paid $349,265 in fines for violating federal rail-safety violations, government railroad regulators said.
A 2-year-old New Ulm boy died after crawling out of bed next to his sleeping mother and wandering outside on a frigid night.
Several older residents of Coeur d’Alene are protesting plans for a funeral home across the street from a center for the elderly, saying it would be a little too close for comfort.
Health officials were searching for airline passengers who may have come in contact with a 30-year-old woman infected with a hard-to-treat form of tuberculosis on a flight from India.
Three former Chicago police officers were sentenced to decades in federal prison for using their guns, uniforms and badges to steal cocaine and marijuana from drug dealers and resell it.

The next effort to launch the space shuttle Atlantis could come as early as Jan. 24, but will probably slip into February as engineers test and repair a suspect fuel sensor connector, a NASA official said.
The United Arab Emirates will keep a 30-year link between its currency, the dirham, and the United States dollar, after completing a review of its currency regime.
China will allow only state-run Web sites to broadcast video or radio through the Internet, tightening the government’s regulatory grip over the media content offered there.
The Writers Guild of America moved to try to prevent Jay Leno from performing any more monologues.
Led by higher food and energy costs, inflation in Spain accelerated to the fastest rate in more than a decade in December even after economic growth slowed.
Hal Steinbrenner’s reluctance to add another huge contract to the Yankees’ payroll seems to be the crux of the debate over whether to trade for Johan Santana.
The Nets will play most or all of the 2009-10 N.B.A. season in New Jersey instead of in their new arena in Brooklyn, a team spokesman said Thursday.
Carole Leigh Hutton, the editor of The San Jose Mercury News, was replaced in a top-level shake-up at the newspaper.
Intel said that it had chosen to withdraw from the One Laptop Per Child educational computer organization due to what a spokesman called “philosophical” differences.
The home goods retailer Bed Bath & Beyond posted a lower fiscal third-quarter profit and warned that this quarter’s results would be lower than expected.

A state judge ruled that a state commission can continue to gather evidence related to Darren Dopp, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s former communications director, while a separate criminal investigation proceeds.
President Hugo Chávez said that he was replacing Jorge Rodríguez, the vice president, whom many blamed for the loss of the referendum, with Ramón Carrizales, a former housing minister.

The parent company of the popular Jewish online dating site JDate has put itself up for sale, people close to the auction said Thursday, and is already in talks with several prominent media companies.
Jassen Cullimore’s goal 1 minute 37 seconds into overtime Thursday night gave the visiting Florida Panthers a 4-3 victory against the Islanders, ending a three-game losing streak.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s proposal to revamp New Jersey’s formula for financing schools cleared two important legislative hurdles on Thursday.
State Street ousted a senior executive and said it would set aside $618 million to cover legal claims stemming from investments tied to mortgage securities.
Toyota beat Ford in 2007 in U.S. auto sales, putting it behind General Motors. Ford had held the No. 2 spot since 1931, according to the company’s historian.
A former Goldman Sachs associate who was accused of masterminding one of the broadest insider-trading conspiracies in years was sentenced to nearly five years in prison.
After a series of failed buyout deals, companies and their lawyers are likely to focus on strengthening the language in takeover contracts to help ensure that transactions are completed.
Nick Watney had a one-stroke lead over Daniel Chopra after the first round of the Mercedes-Benz Championship, the PGA Tour’s annual opening event for winners only.

The veteran principal of Herbert H. Lehman High School has agreed to step down after investigators found that two of his assistant football coaches had for years been paid overtime wages for time spent at home.
A man who said he mistook a bike path for the West Side Highway and fatally struck a cyclist while driving drunk was sentenced Thursday to 3 ½ to 10 ½ years in prison.

New Jersey’s state medical school has improved its accounting and billing practices during the two years it has been under federal supervision, but still lacks the ability to investigate allegations of fraud aggressively.
A suit charges I.B.M. with dumping industrial solvents that have contaminated hundreds of homes and businesses over several decades.
A former high school teacher was arrested Thursday after school investigators said he had made sexual and harassing comments to several 14-year-old students.
A virus killed hundreds of crows across the state in the last week, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
Reports on factory orders and the labor market  portrayed an economy that is skirting recession as attention shifts to government figures on employment to be released Friday.
The Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station received approval from New Jersey environmental officials on Thursday for the plant’s continued operation.
City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn on Thursday nominated Hector L. Diaz, the longtime Bronx County clerk and a former assemblyman, to fill the open position of city clerk.
The San Francisco Zoo reopened a little over a week after a tiger escaped and mauled three visitors, killing one.
Sales of pickup trucks, long a steady supplier of hefty profits to automakers, were slowed in 2007 by gas prices and housing ills.

China plans to expand the use of lethal injection to replace the current method of execution, a shot to the back of the head, the newspaper China Daily quoted Jiang Xingchang, vice president of the Supreme People’s Court, as saying.
A cousin of President Felipe Calderón was abducted at gunpoint, beaten and held for four hours on Wednesday in Morelia, in Michoacán State, newspapers reported.
A suicide bomber attacked an Indian road construction company’s convoy in Nimruz Province, killing six policemen and an Indian engineer, the provincial governor said.
A 17-year-old boy used a homemade gun to shoot a 14-year-old studying at the same school in Madhya Pradesh, the police said.
Germany surprised experts again with a larger-than-expected decrease in the number of unemployed.
Libya’s foreign minister, Abdel-Rahman Shalqam, met for an hour with Condoleezza Rice at her State Department offices. It was the highest-level visit by a Libyan to Washington in 35 years.
Ségolène Royal, the defeated Socialist candidate in last year’s presidential election, confirmed that she intended to run for leadership of her party this year.
When Ohio State takes the field Monday night, it will be trying to repair a reputation damaged by a blowout loss to Florida in last year’s national championship.
Himachal Pradesh in the north said it would use unemployed youths to capture and sterilize monkeys that have been raiding farms and attacking people.
In the aftermath of West Virginia’s stunning victory in the Fiesta Bowl, the university named the interim coach, Bill Stewart, as the replacement for Rich Rodriguez.
An 8-month-old Brooklyn boy was mauled to death by his family’s Doberman pinscher on Thursday as the boy played on the floor of his apartment.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Thursday that he would reduce by 20 percent the number of parking permits issued to city employees.
ConocoPhillips said on that its worldwide production of hydrocarbons probably rose in the final three months of 2007 from the third quarter, and oil and natural gas prices were also higher.
About 6,300 people, on average, on any given weekday, are watching the new Fox Business Network, according to early estimates compiled by Nielsen Media Research.
The Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Ticketmaster acquiesced to demands that fans outside Florida be allowed to buy tickets for Sunday’s wild-card game against the Giants.
Album sales in the U.S. plunged 9.5 percent last year from 2006, as the recording industry had another weak year despite a 45 percent surge in the sale of digital tracks.
CBS Sports announced Thursday that it was taking over day-to-day control of CSTV, the college sports media company it acquired in late 2005.
Bruce A. Barket is one of several lawyers who represented Martin H. Tankleff, charged with the murder of his parents, in his appeals.
The man who fell nearly 500 feet is now talking and may walk again, his doctors said.

Britain could soon hear the sound, familiar to “Law & Order” fans, of “dun-dun.” NBC Universal is close to signing a pact with a British production company to create a version of the long-running New York drama that would be set in London. Kudos Film and Television intends to produce the series for the British network ITV. Stephen Garrett, a managing director of Kudos, said he was in advanced talks to license the rights to the series. Variations of “Law & Order” are already produced in Russia and France, but the British show would be the first foreign English-language version of the NBC original. If a deal is signed, Kudos will start production in the summer, Mr. Garrett said.

Is it just my long-time Giants loyalty speaking, or is anyone else wondering how the initials “L.T.” were so easily transferred to LaDainian Tomlinson? Is it as simple as a decree from “SportsCenter,” or should the standard be higher -- say, like transforming the very way the game is played? That’s what the original L.T., Lawrence Taylor, did when he was terrorizing quarterbacks in the 1980’s. Tomlinson’s superb talent is unquestioned, and he seems sure to eventually join Taylor in the Hall of Fame. But he doesn’t have two Super Bowl rings, hasn’t willed his team to greatness, and most importantly hasn’t fundamentally altered strategy on the other side of the line of scrimmage. Let’s reserve those initials for their rightful owner!.

This house is bordered by the Morel trail. To gain access to it, owners simply step off the deck. The stone-and-timber home, completed in 2007, is about 4,150 square feet. It has a cedar-lined dry sauna in its ski locker room. A stream runs through the three-quarter-acre property, and during warmer seasons, the trail is groomed for hiking and mountain biking. In addition to the large deck, there is an upper covered patio; a hot tub will be installed in the spring. The upper level has a game room. It also has a master suite with a balcony and a built-in fireplace in its bathroom. And there are two additional bedrooms with a Jack-and-Jill bathroom. At the center of the house is a great room with vaulted ceilings, floor-to-ceiling windows with lightly wooded views and a stone fireplace. The open kitchen has custom native wood cabinetry, a Wolf range and Sub-Zero appliances. The house can be sold furnished. There is a three-car garage. Taxes: $15,793. 'FOCUS: ELLSWORTH KELLY' Few artists of the so-called Minimalist persuasion have applied the less-is-more aesthetic with the encompassing grace of Ellsworth Kelly. The point is marvelously made by a large, all-Kelly gallery in the Museum of Modern Art's Focus series. The 27 paintings and drawings on view -- many acquired during the past decade -- include several major surprises. Most of the works date from the 1950s, when Mr. Kelly planted many of the seeds of ideas he has explored ever since. They show him devising his severe but evocative vocabulary by studying the world, borrowing from pure geometry and looking at other art. ''Relief With Blue,'' made in 1950, while Mr. Kelly was living in Paris (and on display only through Monday), suggests a glimpse of a white building and blue sky seen through a window partly covered by the curving drape of a white curtain. In a series of 15 drawings from 1951, he enlivens geometric form with an exquisite sense of proportion, dividing modest squares of white paper with lines, grids and areas of black, and then expands these motifs in vivid color.

A tiny sketchbook believed to have belonged to Vincent van Gogh has surfaced in Athens. The sketchbook, revealed this week by its current owner, Doreta Peppa, features intricate renderings of figures from the masterpieces ''The Potato Eaters'' and, above, ''Portrait of Père Tanguy.'' (The sketch is above a detail from the painting.) No claim of original ownership has surfaced since Mrs. Peppa, a writer and daughter of a Greek resistance fighter, discovered the sketchbook while cleaning out her basement two years ago. Since then she has been trying to authenticate the book, believed to have been plundered by the Nazis during their occupation of Greece in World War II. A letter left by her father with the drawings suggests that the notebook was seized from a train after resistance fighters ambushed Nazi forces leaving Athens in 1944. It remains unclear how it fell into Nazi hands. Lawyers and art experts have contended that Mrs. Peppa is now the book's rightful owner.

GRACE--Natalie Watts, of Great Neck and East Hampton, LI, in her 99th year, died peacefully at her home, in Great Neck on Sunday, December 30, 2007. Beloved daughter of the late Mr. And Mrs. Edward Everett Watts, daughter-in-law of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morgan H. Grace (Ruth Eden) of Kings Point, beloved wife of Morgan H. Grace Jr., who died in 1995 at age 89, after 57 years of marriage; beloved sister of the late Edward Everett Watts, Jr., the late Louise Watts, and the late Maud Watts Grayson. Cherished mother of Natalie Grace Dejoux Brinckerhoff of Palm Beach, Locust Valley, and East Hampton, and Morgan Grace of Washington, D.C., and Southampton; loving sister-in-law of Robert M. Grace and his wife Jane, Lorraine Grace, widow of Oliver R. Grace, Nancy Erskine Grace, widow or David R. Grace, and Isabella Watts of Mattapoisett. Survived by many nephews and nieces including, on the Watts' side, Maud Grayson, Spence Watts Grayson, Elizabeth Watts Boileau, Edward Everett Watts III, and Isabella Watts Cunynghame. Adored grandmother of Edouard Henri Grace Dejoux (Blair Hopkins), Morgan Andre Grace Dejoux (Eleanor Acquavella), and Elizabeth Grace. Devoted greatgrandmother to Christine, Hope, Charlotte, William Jacques, and Isabelle Dejoux. A graduate of St. Agatha's School and The Spence School, Class of 1927, where she earned a Classical Diploma, Natalie Watts excelled in all her subjects including Latin. Her completed crossword puzzles in Latin were often posted on the bulletin board. She had a beautiful voice, loved to sing, and sang on the radio in the years before her 1938 marriage. In the early 1930's she was a member of the Blue Hill Troupe, singing in Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, and active as a Young Republican. She was Chairman of the LVIS Fair in East Hampton in 1968: Her first grandson was due the date of the Fair, and all the ladies thought he should be named ELVIS! For many years she was Chairman of Books at both the LVIS Fair in East Hampton (where she turned her small guest cottage into a temporary book store) and, with her dear friend, Eleanor Rawlings, at the All Saints Church Strawberry Festival in Great Neck. During these past few weeks, she hummed and sang Christmas carols, along with the radio and TV. A cheerful, kind, strong, resilient, and intelligent lady, she knew many of the answers on ''Jeopardy'', ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Millionaire'', which she enjoyed watching with her wonderful nurses, her children, grandchildren, and great - grandchildren, when they visited. Her household was always a happy one. She was loved and admired by both her sons-in-law, Jacques H. Dejoux, of Lyon and Albon d'Ardeche, France, adored grandfather of her great-grandchildren, and a former Vice-President of Marine Midland Bank, and the late William H. Brinckerhoff, whose great-aunts, the Misses Annie and Mary Brinckerhoff had been her English and Latin teachers at Spence. She loved and was loved by all her nurses, with whom she enjoyed tea and conversation: Brigid Corban, Margaret Burrascano, Catherine Byrne, Thelma Clarke, Caroline Grace Casler, niece, Ann De Marco, Anne Flynn, Kathleen Flynn, Helen Gately, Mary Gonzalez, Ginger Hoernig, Dymphna Horan, Debra Kennedy, Renate Low, Arlene Mongiello, Debora Myrick, Katherine Noone, Joan O'Brien, Helen O'Hara, Maureen Pesce, Barbara Palladino, Margaret Ryan, Sharon Schmiemann, Kathleen Tilney, Yvette Waryold, and Helga Woodard, and by her devoted housekeepers, Josefa Briceno, Ligia Florez, and Marta Stark. A former member of the Woman's Club of Great Neck, the Junior League, Devon Yacht Club, the Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach, she was a current member of Maidstone Club, which she joined with her husband in 1955. Funeral services will be held at All Saints Episcopal Church, 855 Middle Neck Road, Great Neck, on Saturday, January 5th 2008, at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations in her honor to The Spence School, 22 East 91st St., New York, NY 10128.

This property, categorized by the resort as an entry-level ski-in/ski-out chalet, is in a cluster of similar houses along the Buttercup Chairlift, and in view of the summit. To get onto the chairlift, owners step onto a covered deck and walk about 40 feet. The approximately 1,200-square-foot house is surrounded by woods, and is not on a main road to the lodge, which makes it more desirable than its main road counterparts. There is a hot tub outside the lower-level master suite. The house, which was built in 2007 and is fully furnished, has a stone entryway with an arched doorway. There are vaulted, raftered ceilings, and there is a stone fireplace flanked by built-in cabinets in the great room. For privacy, there are two full master suites, one on the upper level and one on the lower. The two and a half bathrooms are finished with granite countertops and tile. There are hardwood floors in the living area. The kitchen has custom cabinets and stainless steel appliances. Taxes: $3,384. MORSE--Jane H., M.D. We are deeply saddened by the death of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Jane Morse. A clinical rheumatologist and researcher at New YorkPresbyterian Hospital/Co lumbia University Medical Center for more than 45 years, she helped lead numerous scientific advances, including co-discovery of the genetic basis for familial primary pulmonary hypertension -a breakthrough that has opened new avenues for treating the disease. Beloved by patients, students and colleagues, she lived her life with grace and compassion. We offer our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President & CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital MORSE--Jane H., M.D. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the death of Jane Morse, professor emeritus of clinical medicine, who was associated with Columbia as student, resident, teacher, and researcher for more than 55 years. Since starting medical school at our College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1951, Dr. Morse contributed in many ways to the intellectual environment of our medical center. Dr. Morse will be remembered as a mentor, colleague, friend, and role model. She made many contributions to medical science and led a team that in 2000 co-discovered the gene responsible for familial primary pulmonary hypertension. Her research opened up a new area of study of this disease, a feat made even more remarkable by her being officially retired when she did much of the work. Dr. Morse's dedication to scientific inquiry, devotion to others, and commitment to high standards created a legacy we will uphold in her memory. We offer our sympathies to her children and grandchildren. Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive Vice President, Health & Biomedical Sciences Columbia University

HERSHSON--Evelyn Jahrmarkt, of New York and West Palm Beach passed away peacefully on January 2, at her New York home surrounded by her loving family. A beautifully woman, Evelyn lived her 90 years to the fullest. A ready smile, an infectious laugh, she has a capacity for lasting friendship that extended to all who crossed her path in life. Above all, however, she will be remembered by the extended family she left behind as a loving mother, grandmother, great grandmother and stepmother. Beloved mother of Michael (and his wife, Roberta) and Robert (and his partner, Lance), sons of Evelyn and her late husband, Irving Jahrmarkt; loving grandmother of John (and his wife, Pamela) and Chris (and his wife, Pamela); and adoring greatgrandmother of Samantha and Isabella, her legacy lives on in their collective heart and spirit. She is also survived by the children of her late second husband, Abraham Hershson; Harriet Levine (and her husband, Noel), Patti Gerber and Stephen Hershson and their children and grandchildren, a loving, loyal and supportive extended family. We were all blessed to have her in our lives and her grace, her humor and her inner beauty will forever remain a part of our being. Funeral services will be held on Friday January 4, 10am, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. in New York City.

CEDAR LAKE CONTEMPORARY BALLET No one has had a greater influence on classical dance over the last two decades than the choreographer William Forsythe. Recently that influence has been greatly amplified by a generation of choreographers that has sprung from the ranks of his Frankfurt-based companies, nourished by his highly collaborative, improvisational strategies. Much of their work is produced in Europe, but this month two former Forsythe dancers, Crystal Pite and Jacopo Godani, are showing pieces as part of Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet's winter season, which opens on Thursday. Ms. Pite, who is Canadian and danced with Ballet British Columbia for many years, had already created works for several companies when she joined Mr. Forsythe's Ballet Frankfurt in 1996. Since leaving and forming her own troupe, Kidd Pivot, in Vancouver in 2001, Ms. Pite has embellished her early reputation with quirky, angular dances that embrace the awkward and the beautiful in equal measure. A new work for Cedar Lake, ''Ten Duets on a Theme of Rescue,'' is set to music from the soundtrack of the 2002 feature film ''Solaris.'' In rehearsal some months ago, the series of duets was already invested with an arresting and poignant sense of fragility by the dancers.

The host Czech Republic routed Finland, 5-1, on Thursday to finish fifth at the world junior championship. In Friday's semifinals, the United States plays Canada and Sweden takes on Russia. In the relegation round, Switzerland defeated Denmark, 5-2, to finish ninth in a game between the bottom teams. They will be relegated and replaced by Germany and Latvia in next year's championship in Ottawa. In another relegation game, Slovakia routed Kazakhstan, 8-0.

O'NEILL FESTIVAL AT 10 When Eugene O'Neill was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1936 (he is the only American playwright who has been so honored), his speech, delivered in absentia because of health problems, acknowledged a debt to August Strindberg, whom O'Neill called ''that greatest genius of all modern dramatists.'' Many playwrights today would say the same about O'Neill, who wrote with grim candor about his own family and, somehow, a bit about everyone else's at the same time. The annual O'Neill Festival, presented by the Playwrights Theater of New York and the O'Neill at Yale project, celebrates its 10th anniversary, beginning on Friday at the Provincetown Playhouse. The location is certainly fitting: It was the Provincetown Players who produced O'Neill's first New York production, ''Bound East for Cardiff,'' in 1916.

THE League of Historic American Theaters, a nonprofit organization with more than 250 member theaters, provides a directory (www.lhat.org) listing over 1,200 historic theaters, with entries in all states. The league defines a historic theater as one that's been a place of public assembly for more than 50 years or has cultural, historical, social or architectural significance. Below is a selection from across the country. Astoria, Ore.

A drainage problem with the new synthetic track at Santa Anita could jeopardize its thoroughbred racing programs if the area is hit with predicted heavy rainfall in the coming days. ''It's designed to be an all-weather track,'' Mike Willman, the director of publicity at Santa Anita, said Thursday. ''At this point, it's anything but. If we get the heavy rain that is forecast, there is a very strong possibility we will have to cancel racing at some point.'' The new track, installed last summer at a cost of $11 million, was designed to ensure safety for horses and jockeys. But, Willman said, the drainage problem was discovered in September, while racing programs were being held at the Los Angeles County Fairgrounds.

'MAX & RUBY' Theatreworks/USA's latest production features an oversize lobster, a green alien gorilla, an electric eel and an enormous blue tarantula. But it isn't horror or science fiction. These creatures mostly inhabit the toy chest -- and the imagination -- of little Max, who happens to be an animal, too: a rabbit. He and his big sister, Ruby, star in this musical adaptation, based on Rosemary Wells's storybooks and the ''Max & Ruby'' television series they've inspired. Intended for ages 3 to 10, this show has replaced Ms. Wells's pudgy bunnies with lithe young actors in rabbit ears. (Lee Markham, above left, plays the mischievous Max, and Kelly Felthous, above right, is the motherly Ruby.) But while Glen Berger's script retains the essential sweetness of Ms. Wells's creations, it adds welcome spice. If the story threatens to become too cute, a huge lobster or a giant tarantula waits in the wings.

KATE NASH If this 20-year-old British singer seems a particularly fresh voice on her debut album, ''Made of Bricks'' (Geffen), which has its American release on Tuesday, that's because Ms. Nash, above, has had an unusually quick route to fame. Only 18 months passed from the time she began writing songs to her release of a No. 1 album in Britain. In between, Lily Allen added her as a friend on MySpace, the music press went crazy, and the record was reportedly rushed to completion. Was the hype justified? That's the topic of the second wave of chatter about Ms. Nash, already starting to look like a backlash. On the pro side, she can be winningly casual, singing about crushes and bad dates with the candor of a diarist (or, perhaps more aptly, blogger). She takes musical cues from Ms. Allen and Regina Spektor, writing sprightly and idiosyncratic songs that barely contain all her words. On ''Foundations'' she trashes a soon-to-be ex in public, then confesses: ''Yes, it was childish, and you got aggressive/And I must admit that I was a bit scared/But it gives me thrills to wind you up.''

So it appears that none of the nominees or presenters for the Golden Globes will have to worry about what to wear on Jan. 13. Alan Rosenberg, the president of the Screen Actors Guild, said members would not cross the picket line to attend the awards event, at the Beverly Hilton. There had been some thought, or hope, that the ceremony would go on, without being televised, and we could at least see the peacock display and the nominees could have their moment. But of course that would mean a tremendous loss of revenue. Anyway, it looks like Wanda McDaniel of Armani was on the money when she characterized the appointments she has scheduled with actresses for this weekend as "faux fittings." Fashion houses and stylists are going through the motions. But what choice do they have? Come tomorrow or Monday, it could be a different story. The SAG statement, on the face of it, was pretty blunt. The next move seems to belong to NBC. Meanwhile, designers are facing deadlines of their own: the Paris couture starts in two weeks, and the N.Y. shows on Feb. 1.

An article on Page 8 of Arts & Leisure this weekend about Jock Soto’s transition to teaching dance after a career as principal dancer with the New York City Ballet misstates the given name of his father. He is Jose Soto, not Joseph.

A picture caption with an article on Sunday about the motivations of the C.I.A. in taping some interrogations and then destroying the tapes misidentified the position held by John A. Rizzo at the intelligence agency. He serves as the acting general counsel; he was never confirmed by the Senate as general counsel. (The White House withdrew his nomination because of mounting opposition from Democrats over Mr. Rizzo’s role in the harsh interrogation of C.I.A. detainees.).

An article on Dec. 27 about the sentencing of six French aid workers who were convicted in Chad of trying to kidnap 103 children in a campaign to aid Sudanese orphans misstated the outcome of negotiations by President Nicolas Sarkozy of France during a trip to Chad in early November. He negotiated the release of three French journalists and four Spanish flight attendants, but did not secure the release of the aid workers.

An obituary on Dec. 19 about the record producer Joel Dorn, using information provided by a spokesman for a record company with which he was affiliated, referred incorrectly to a survivor, Faye Rosen. She was Mr. Dorn’s wife, not his companion. The obituary also misstated the relationship of the recording executive Nesuhi Ertegun, whom Mr. Dorn wrote to as a young man, to Atlantic Records in its early days. Mr. Ertegun joined Atlantic after it was founded by his brother, Ahmet Ertegun, and Herb Abramson. He did not found it with his brother.

A picture caption with an article on Sunday about the motivations of the C.I.A. in taping some interrogations and then destroying the tapes misidentified the position held by John A. Rizzo at the intelligence agency. He serves as the acting general counsel; he was never confirmed by the Senate as general counsel. (The White House withdrew his nomination because of mounting opposition from Democrats over Mr. Rizzo’s role in the harsh interrogation of C.I.A. detainees.).

An article on Dec. 10 about the ways New York has changed in the 20 years since the publication of the Tom Wolfe novel “Bonfire of the Vanities,” which depicted a city in decline, referred imprecisely to the Tawana Brawley case, an example of the racial tension of the times. Although a special prosecutor had been appointed to lead the investigation of claims that Ms. Brawley, a black teenager, had been sexually assaulted by white men, the prosecution did not later collapse because there was in fact no prosecution of any suspect. (A grand jury investigation concluded that there was no evidence that Ms. Brawley had been sexually assaulted.).

An obituary on Dec. 28 about Benazir Bhutto, the former prime minister of Pakistan, misstated the location of her detention at the time her father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the former president and prime minister, was hanged by the military authorities in April 1979. It was a deserted police training camp at Sihala, Pakistan, a few miles from the Rawalpindi District Jail where her father was hanged; she was not under house arrest.

A sports article on Friday about the pressure facing Ohio State as it prepares to play for the college football national championship after losing in last year’s title game misstated the team’s 2006 and 2007 regular-season records. They were 12-0 and 11-1 — not 11-0 and 10-1.

An article on Dec. 23 about a newly declassified plan by J. Edgar Hoover, when he was director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to suspend the writ of habeas corpus and imprison Americans suspected of disloyalty misstated the process by which the Internal Security Act of 1950, also known as the McCarran Act, became law. President Truman vetoed the measure as unconstitutional, but Congress voted overwhelmingly to override his veto and the measure then became law; Truman did not sign the bill.

Thousands of people across Britain have been sickened by the biggest outbreak of a norovirus, or stomach bug, in five years, and dozens of hospital wards have been closed to stop its spread. Local reports said 200,000 people had contracted the highly contagious virus, which causes vomiting and diarrhea, between Christmas and New Year’s, and doctors predict that hundreds of thousands more may be affected in the coming days.

The British Academy of Film and Television Arts has announced its nominees for the best foreign film of 2007, the BBC reported. They are: “Lust, Caution,” “La Vie en Rose,” “The Lives of Others,” “The Kite Runner” and “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.” The Bafta ceremony will be held on Feb. 10 at the Royal Opera House in London.

Richard West Jr., the founding director of the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of the American Indian, spent $48,500 in museum funds to commission a portrait of himself, The Washington Post reported. The painting, by Burton Silverman, a New York artist whose portraits have appeared on the cover of Time and in The New Yorker, hangs in the patrons’ lounge of the museum. Mr. West, 64, whose last day on the Smithsonian payroll was Monday, also spent more than $250,000 over four years on travel and hotels, the Smithsonian has confirmed. Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the senior Republican on the Finance Committee, and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California and chairwoman of the Rules Committee, have asked for independent investigations of the expenses. The Smithsonian said it did not comment on former employees. Similar questions about personal spending by the Smithsonian’s secretary, Lawrence M. Small, led to his resignation last March.

Radiohead has signed with iTunes to allow its latest album to be downloaded from the online music store, Agence France-Presse reported. The band was one of the few major acts not to have its songs on the service. In October Radiohead left the EMI record company after its contract expired. The band made its new album, “In Rainbows,” above, available on its Web site, radiohead.com, asking fans to pay whatever they thought it was worth. Radiohead has not said how many times the album was downloaded or the average price paid. ... The concert producer Live Nation said it had reached a two-year deal with the Jonas Brothers band, under which that New Jersey group would play more than 140 concerts around the world, starting in Tucson on Jan. 31, Reuters reported. In October Live Nation lured Madonna from Warner Brothers with a multi-album touring and merchandising partnership.

Tommy Tune, right, will direct “Turn of the Century,” a new musical comedy written by Rick Elice and Marshall Brickman, the writers of “Jersey Boys,” at the Goodman Theater in Chicago, The Associated Press reported. “The basic premise involves a young songwriter-piano player and his girl singer who find themselves through mysterious, supernatural, ‘Twilight Zone’-ish activities thrown back to the turn of the century, the 20th century,” said Robert Falls, artistic director of the Goodman. The score will consist of standards by Irving Berlin, Rodgers and Hart, George Gershwin, Rodgers and Hammerstein and others, Mr. Tune said. The show is scheduled to open in September or October. The Goodman’s 2008-9 season will also feature Brian Dennehy in a revival of Eugene O’Neill’s “Desire Under the Elms.”.

China has pulled Li Yu’s “Lost in Beijing,” a movie whose sexually explicit scenes were already censored, from theaters and banned its producer from the film business for two years, The Associated Press reported. The ruling against “Lost in Beijing” accused the filmmakers of publishing unapproved pornographic scenes from the movie on the Internet and on DVDs, the official China News Service Web site reported. The film’s producer, Fang Li, said he believed that Chinese officials faced political pressure to act amid the rapid spread of uncensored versions of “Lost in Beijing” and another sexually explicit film, Ang Lee’s “Lust, Caution,” on the Internet and in pirated DVDs.

Salzburg, Austria, which was the host for Mozart’s 250th-birthday celebrations in 2006, will commemorate the 100th birthday of another famous native son, the conductor Herbert von Karajan, above. The festivities will begin with a concert by the Berlin Philharmonic on Saturday at the Grosses Festspielhaus hall in Salzburg, Agence France-Presse reported. The orchestra, which von Karajan conducted from 1955 until his death in 1989, will also play in Berlin, Paris and Tokyo, and there will be a Karajan Festival in Lucerne, Switzerland, among other festivities in 2008. The birthday itself, on April 5, will be honored with a ceremony in the Mozart House museum in Salzburg. Von Karajan joined the Nazi Party in 1935, a move that greatly helped his career until he fled Germany for Milan in 1944. He was the favorite conductor of Hermann Goering, Hitler’s second in command. After the war the Allies banned him from conducting. The ban was lifted in 1947.

NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” won Thursday night’s ratings among adults 18 to 49. Nielsen estimated that the premiere of the latest edition of the reality show, with celebrities including the boxer Lennox Lewis, below, had 11 million viewers in the 9 o’clock hour, an improvement of almost 2 million over last season’s debut. NBC tied Fox for No. 1 over all, leading at 8 with “Deal or No Deal” (13.3 million) but trailing at 10 with “ER” (9.6 million). CBS ranked third, despite drawing the largest audience of the night with a repeat of “CSI” at 9 (13.5 million). ABC was a distant fourth.

This is the best matchup of the weekend because the Jaguars may be the most dangerous and the hottest team in the playoffs. And they are built for games in cold weather, so they cannot automatically be discounted simply because they come from Florida. They can run with Fred Taylor and Maurice Jones-Drew -- the Jaguars have the second-best run offense in the league -- and they can stop the run, which could be a problem for the Steelers, who will be without the ironman Willie Parker for the playoffs. That will force Pittsburgh's offense into the hands of quarterback Ben Roethlisberger. Considering that the Jaguars struggle against the pass, that may not be a bad thing.

A subheading in some editions on Thursday with a sports article about the resurgent Tampa Bay Buccaneers misstated the team's recent playoff history. It last reached the playoffs after the 2005 season; this is not its first appearance since winning the 2003 Super Bowl. Rob Ryan will apparently keep his job as the Oakland Raiders' defensive coordinator despite recent reports that he would be fired after a disappointing season. Coach Lane Kiffin said Monday that he would evaluate Ryan's status quickly, and a team spokesman said Friday that Ryan would return.

CUTS IN STUDENT LOANSSallie Mae said Friday that it planned to cut back on its core business of making student loans, setting off a 13 percent decline in its share price. Sallie Mae, the nation's largest student lender, has suffered in recent months from higher borrowing costs and the collapse of a $25 billion buyout. It has sharply cut its earnings forecast for the year and held a special sale of stock to raise $2.9 billion in cash. Sallie Mae, formally known as the SLM Corporation, said in a regulatory filing on Thursday that it planned to ''be more selective'' in making student loans, both those backed by the federal government and the higher-rate private loans The company said in its filing that it was retrenching in the business because of market conditions and the landmark student-loan law that took effect in October, cutting billions of dollars in federal subsidies for student lenders. Stock in Sallie Mae fell $2.47, or 13 percent, to $16.69 a share. (AP)

When TV manufacturers tout their excellent picture, they often refer to the display's resolution, the number of pixels it can put on a screen. Breaking bread is easy at Arepas Paisas, a luncheonette in Morristown that serves Colombian and Mexican food. The hard part is deciding between a tortilla and an arepa, a flatbread that’s shaped like a pancake.
An exhibit in Hartford assembles the work of 16 artists exploring shadows and concepts of shadowing in contemporary culture.
An astonishing exhibition in Riverhead features a dense array of outsider art — work by self-taught artists, or those with mental disabilities.
Traditionally, Epiphany, or Jan. 6th, is the day that homes are stripped of Christmas greenery. In my house, I drag out the tree and bring in fresh greens — in the form of salads.

The Next Stop column on Dec. 23 about Adelaide, South Australia’s capital and a culinary hub, misidentified its coastal location. It is on the Gulf St. Vincent on the Indian Ocean coast; it is not along the Pacific coast.

An article on Dec. 23 about the Galápagos Islands misstated the rate for a multiday cruise and tour offered by Lindblad Expeditions. Prices for a trip to the Galápagos alone, double occupancy, start at $4,320; they do not start at $7,580, which is the rate for the Galápagos cruise and a week in Peru.

To the Editor: Your article “Sailing Toward Paradise” (Dec. 23) does sailors and the Galápagos a disservice. While mentioning that private boats are restricted to two anchorages, it fails to point out that they are forbidden from sailing or motoring around the islands without a permit, held only by local operators who also carry a licensed guide. And that would prohibit their stated activities of “cavort[ing] with baby sea lions” and “snorkel[ing] with hammerhead sharks and sea turtles” from their sailboat.

QOn Nov. 19, my landlord told me that he was raising the rent $100 and that the increase would take effect with the new lease. Our lease was up on Nov. 30, giving us only 11 days to respond. We decided we didn't want to pay the higher rent, so within 24 hours of being notified of the increase, we let our landlord know that we would not be renewing. We just received our security deposit with a letter stating that the landlord had withheld 37 percent of our deposit for ''failure to provide 60 days' notice of moving out, as stated in the lease.'' Can the landlord do this?

San Diego (11-5) and Tennessee (10-6) meet today in an A.F.C. wild-card game. The teams played a bruising game four weeks ago that the Chargers won in overtime. Since both teams like to run the ball and both have physical defenses, you can expect a similar contest today. An edge for the Chargers: they are the higher-scoring team, and the Titans are decimated by injuries to their offensive line. A look at how the teams fared this season.

There is no question that volatility on Wall Street increased last year, and many analysts expect the rockiness to continue in 2008. But 2007 may have seemed especially tumultuous only because the years before it were remarkably calm. There was only one day from 2004 to 2006 when the Dow Jones industrial average moved up or down by more than 2 percent. Last year, amid concerns about the subprime mortgage sector and credit markets in general, swings that large occurred 14 times.

Beards are big on campus, from lumberjack-full to sculptured. During ''No-Shave November,'' students banish razors for a month, sometimes to raise money for charity, sometimes just as ''a fun thing to do together,'' says Eric Rall at Syracuse (No. 1, far right). At Bates, beards are sprouting for next month's Mustachio Bashio, an annual party celebrating fanciful facial creations. Apparently, mustache wax isn't sexy: ''Everyone goes home alone that night,'' says Alexander Martin (No. 7), whose bristles keep him warm during outdoor club activities. It's not too hot for fuzz even at the University of Hawaii, where Alex Toth (No. 10) gets overheated over a football victory.

All recruits must sharpen their metaphorical No. 2s for the Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery. The tests, developed by the Department of Defense, determine qualification for the military (basic math, verbal) and aptitude for certain jobs (mechanical, electronic, automotive). High schools also administer the battery to provide students with guidance on potential careers. The newest section, ''Assembling Objects,'' is used by the Navy to identify recruits with a good sense of spatial relations who can work fast under pressure. Test takers get nine minutes to identify the 16 shapes created when the illustrated fragments are properly fitted together. By that math, you should be able to do the following assemblages -- from the Arco prep guide published by Peterson's (top) and from Barron's ''How to Prepare for the Asvab'' -- in under six. Answers are on Page 36.

As a resident fellow at the American Enterprise Institute and former speechwriter for President Bush, you're surprisingly critical of him in your new book, claiming he has appointed ''consistently mediocre people'' to important jobs and made ''a shambles'' of the Iraq war. Do you see the book as a mea culpa? No. Mea culpa is a kind of hand-wringing, breast-beating, woe-is-me attitude that I don't share. What I am saying is that there is exhaustion, intellectual exhaustion on the part of Republicans and conservatives. And that their long winning streak in Congress has ended? What I am terrified of is that the Republican Party is heading into a period of political defeat. We lost the election in 2006. I am terrified that we can lose the election in 2008. We can lose in 2012, and it will take us half a dozen years to do the rethinking we need to do.

THE NEWS The Justice Department elevated its inquiry into the destruction of Central Intelligence Agencyinterrogation videotapes into a criminal investigation. BEHIND THE NEWS C.I.A. officials long feared becoming entangled in a criminal inquiry of secret counterterrorism programs. Now Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey has directed prosecutors to examine whether C.I.A. officers obstructed justice or committed other criminal acts in destroying tapes of interrogations of two operatives from Al Qaeda. Top Bush administration lawyers debated whether to destroy the tapes but it is unclear if anyone outside the C.I.A. endorsed the idea.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Clemens Says Trainer Gave Him Injections,'' Jan. 4: Roger Clemens's claim that he received injections of vitamin B12 and lidocaine should probably be viewed as damaging to his credibility. Lidocaine is a local anesthetic and not a systemic pain reliever, like acetaminophen, with bodywide effects. If given as an injection in someone's rear end, for example, the likelihood of it having any effect on knee pain, as he contends, is practically zero.

This month, the Smart Fortwo, a cuddly Japanese cartoon character on wheels (except it's German), goes on sale in the United States. Ten years after its debut in Europe, about 800,000 of the tiny two-seaters zip through mostly urban areas there and in Mexico, Canada, the Middle East and elsewhere. Among urban drivers, Romans seem the most smitten with it. For now. Will New Yorkers, Chicagoans or -- stretching here -- Detroiters take to this lastest import? So far, more than 30,000 have been reserved by Americans.
INTERNATIONAL 3-10 U.S. Role in Pakistan Debated

ORDERING FOOD ON THE TRAIN TO KASHGAR, JUNE 1, 2007 Craig Todd, a tour guide from Noosa, Australia. ''I was on a train following the Silk Road through western China. I work as a tour guide and hence spend the summer either along the Silk Road or the Trans-Mongolian Railway. This trip was special, though -- within a week I was about to be celebrating the milestone birthday of 40 with a group of tourists and locals in a village in Kyrgyzstan, with a bottle of Russian champagne, some Australian chocolate and many laughs. In this photo, I am paying for some bony chicken-neck chili. It was one of those moments of 'I can't understand this menu, let's just point and try whatever comes.' Usually it's a rewarding experience; this time it was educational. Your average Texas chili is a picnic compared to this scary hot, spicy murder session.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

(HBO) THE WIRE This Peabody Award-winning drama begins its fifth and final season by reflecting on the state of the news media and trends that David Simon, the series's creator and a former reporter for The Baltimore Sun, says make high-end journalism vulnerable: out-of-town ownership, a focus on the stock-market value of newspaper companies rather than on their product, and a newsroom culture that values prizes and personal ambition above detailed coverage of complex issues. Tonight Gus Haynes (Clark Johnson), a city editor struggling with a limited staff because of corporate cutbacks, uses three reporters -- Alma Gutierrez (Michelle Paress), Jeff Price (Todd Scofield) and Scott Templeton (Tom McCarthy) -- to break front-page news that links a politician to a drug dealer. (Above, from left, Mr. Johnson, Brandon Young, Ms. Paress and Mr. McCarthy.) 7 P.M. This year, the licorice-black down coat with the shaped waistline is a favorite when temperatures plummet. The practical down coats no long resemble the shapeless sleeping bags that inspired the early 1970s designs that were an alternative to fur. Last week, even some dogs wore hooded down coats.

The Wild Side Some years ago, a friend suggested that I play a practical joke on the British public. His idea was that I should mix the popular dislike of biotechnology with the widely held suspicion that other Europeans are swindling the system, and write an April Fools' Day article in which I would claim that the French had genetically engineered a breed of tiny sheep -- sheep the size of rabbits. With such small sheep, you could keep many more on one field; and since European farm subsidies are calculated per sheep.... He and I amused ourselves with the thought of indignant readers spluttering into their coffee. But I'm no longer tempted to make up stories about biotechnology: reality is weirder than anything I'm likely to invent. For example, the other day I met a man -- his name is Goro Yoshizaki -- who wants to breed bluefin tuna from mackerel.

WHEN President Bush signed the Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act into law late last month, the move touched off a now-familiar debate among housing advocates and analysts: will it have much impact? Bankruptcy lawyers said that the measure, which grants tax relief to people trying to save their homes, would have limited effect in the New York area and beyond. But housing counselors were far more optimistic.

In July, to trumpet the results of a campaign to urge people to call a police counterterrorism hot line to report suspicious activity, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority proclaimed on posters and in television ads, “Last year, 1,944 New Yorkers saw something and said something.” William Neuman, who covers transit for The Times, asks what, exactly, did those 1,944 New Yorkers see, and what did they say?

In what is probably its most alarming forecast in recent memory, the city’s Independent Budget Office today projected a $3.1 billion budget deficit in the 2009 fiscal year, rising to $4.6 billion in 2010 and $6.3 billion in 2011 — largely as as result of the weakening in the housing market and higher labor costs. The office warned that the “the city’s fiscal picture could become even darker” if Wall Street’s economic woes worsen or if the housing market, which in Manhattan has remained strong, further declines. The conclusions in the five-page report suggest that whoever succeeds Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will be saddled with fiscal problems as serious as the ones Mr. Bloomberg inherited when he took office in 2002 as the city was still reeling from 9/11.
