What we’re reading elsewhere…

Would-be new voters in New York who are head-over-heels for Huckabee or committed to Clinton had better hurry. The deadline is looming for new registrants who want to vote in New York’s Feb. 5 presidential primaries. The state Board of Elections says that all new registrations must be mailed to county boards with a postmark of Friday or earlier. People who choose to register in person also must do so by Friday.

The cherished Moondance Diner, transplanted to its new home in La Barge, Wyo., went through a trying experience last week that would have been impossible so far this year in New York City. Yes, while in New York, it dodged a wrecking a ball. Yes, a serendipitous online dating moment put it in the loving care of a Wyoming couple. And yes, it survived a perilous 2,100-mile trek cross-country behind a semi to a town with a population of 600 people. But on Thursday, the 75-year-old, yet-to-be-renovated diner simply crumpled under the accumulated weight of snow on its roof.“It’s pretty much in a heap,” said Candy Kjar, the La Barge town clerk, who saw the building as she was driving in and out of town.

More so than any credit card, library card or health insurance card, the MetroCard is the one piece of plastic that most unites New Yorkers. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority distributes 180 million of them — that’s not a typo — every year. The MetroCard is a fixture of anyone’s pocket, wallet or purse, a mainstay for any commuter, and — ever since the last tokens were phased out in 2003 — the only one way to (legally) ride a subway in New York City. And yet, few people spend much time looking at or thinking about the humble, homely MetroCard.

Rafael Nadal, fatigued from a nearly four-hour match the previous day, was routed by fourth-seeded Mikhail Youzhny, 6-0, 6-1, Sunday in the final of the Chennai Open in India.The 19th-ranked Youzhny clinched the fourth title of his career. The second-ranked Nadal held his service only once.The 57-minute match turned out to be a letdown for Nadal, who needed 3 hours 54 minutes to overcome his fellow Spaniard Carlos Moyá in what was the longest three-set match on the ATP Tour in 15 years.“Rafa was not Rafa,” Youzhny said. “I did not win today, it was Rafa who lost. I did not expect it to be so easy.”.

Mario Matt of Austria won the men’s World Cup slalom Sunday, and Ted Ligety and Bode Miller of the United States failed to finish.Matt, a slalom specialist, finished with a total time of 1 minute 48.45 seconds at the Kuonisbaergli course in Adelboden, Switzerland, a tenth of a second ahead of his teammate Benjamin Raich.Ligety had tied for third in the first run in soft snow conditions. He straddled a gate and went out in the second run. Miller made an error at one of the first gates, then lost his footing a second time and failed to finish the first run.Jimmy Cochran was the only American to finish. He came in eighth, 1.27 seconds behind the leader.

Janne Ahonen of Finland became the first ski jumper to win the prestigious Four Hills tournament for a fifth time.Ahonen, 30, won the final stop in rainy conditions in Bischofshofen, Austria, with jumps of 126 and 136 meters, earning him 251.6 points in the World Cup event.His main competitor, Thomas Morgenstern of Austria, finished third with 242.7 points. Ahonen also won the Four Hills tournament in 1999, 2003 and 2005. In 2006, he shared the victory with Jakub Janda of the Czech Republic.

The Brandon (Fla.) High School wrestling team’s national record of 459 consecutive dual victories dating to 1973 has ended. South Dade High School topped Brandon, 32-28, on Saturday night in the finals of the Jim Graves Beat the Streak Tournament at Brandon High. Brandon’s streak began after Jim Graves, for whom the tournament is named, took over as the Eagles’ wrestling coach. Graves coached the team for nine years. The streak included 66 individual state champions and 18 team titles.

MARAH ''Angels of Destruction!'' (Yep Roc) A rock tour becomes a pilgrimage -- ''passin' through this wilderness, searchin' for our home'' -- or possibly vice versa on Marah's latest album, ''Angels of Destruction!'' Both a beefy, bluesy, rock-and-soul bar band and a hand-clapping, guitar-strumming folk-rock band are at the core of Marah, which formed in Philadelphia in the early 1990s and resettled in Brooklyn. Although Marah got started in the heyday of grunge, the band's two songwriters, singers and guitarists, the brothers Dave and Serge Bielanko, reach back to the same roots as Bruce Springsteen does. At times Marah can sound like Elvis Costello leading the E Street Band.

KING--Bayard LeRoy, died in Albuquerque, NM on January 1, 2008. Born in NYC, 1922. Attended St. Paul's School and Harvard. An ambulance driver in the American Field Service, in North Africa during WWII. Served in the OSS, awarded the Croix de Guerre. Following, served as a U.S. Foreign Service officer in Baghdad, Australia, Latin America, Africa. Deputy Chief of Mission in Bamako and Kinshasa. Survived by wife Joyce, two children from first marriage, Alexandra King-Nastase and George Gordon King, four grandchildren. Donations to St. Chad's Episcopal Church, Albu querque or Newport Reading Room, RI.

SALTZMAN--Michael I., of NYC, age 67, died in the early hours of Saturday, January 5th, 2008 with his wife of 34 years, Sandra Gabrilove Saltzman by his side at the Mt. Sinai Hospital. Son of Frances of Lake Worth, FL who survives him and the late Edward H. Saltzman. Survived as well by his loving brother Alan and his wife Joane, his beloved niece Lauren, his beloved sister-in-law Dr. Janice Gabrilove and her husband Michael Dirzulaitis, his adored and adoring nephews Mark and Matthew and his beloved and loving fatherin-law Dr. J. Lester Gabrilove. Service Tuesday, January 8th, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Cambell on Monday, January 7, 68pm.

O'MALLEY--John Dancer and choreographer, died on December 26 after a fourteen-year battle with AIDS. Born, 1961 in Fort Worth, TX, he trained at the Chamberlain School of Ballet in Dallas before receiving scholarships to the Joffrey Ballet School and the School of American Ballet. In 1982, he joined ABT II and was later in the corps de ballet of the Metropolitan Opera Company, Zurich Ballet and Bejart Ballet. Over the course of his career, John danced with Rudolf Nureyev, Natalia Makarova, Mikhail Baryshnikov, Twyla Tharp, and was a soloist with Eglevsky Ballet, Colorado Ballet, Dinosaur Dance Company, Keith Young Dance and Garden State Ballet. In 1989, he and Michele Elliman founded Neo Labos Dancetheater, for whom John choreographed and performed in numerous works including ''Certain Measures'', ''Ten Ten Spin'' and ''Angel Ash.'' He choreographed several pieces for TWEED TheaterWorks, including ''Hotel Martinique'' and ''Atomic Opera'', and worked on many film and video projects, including the acclaimed short film ''Lillies''. He regularly returned to Dallas as a guest teacher and choreographer for the Chamberlain Ballet until health problems forced him to stop dancing in 1994. He became an ardent audiophile until he lost his hearing several years later, and was an enthusiastic reader and correspondent, writing dozens of letters weekly to his family and friends. He is survived by his partner and collaborator, Kevin Malony, his mother Jean O'Malley, his sisters Cass O'Malley, Elizabeth McCoy, and Patricia Delgado, many cousins, nieces and nephews, as well as a large, international circle of devoted friends. An incandescent presence and neighborhood fixture in the West Village, John's second home was the Cowgirl Hall of Fame Restaurant on Hudson Street. He will be remembered as a brother, son, friend and dancer, but most of all as someone who never considered surrendering to AIDS, turning every painful step he took into a tenacious and graceful dance. A memorial service is planned for Saturday, March 8th, location to be announced. For more information go to www.johnomalley.org

FRANK KIMBROUGH ''Air'' (Palmetto) Frank Kimbrough has a great deal of experience playing solo piano; in the liner notes to his latest release he recalls a five-year stretch early in his career when the format sustained him. Yet somehow ''Air'' is his first solo album. Fittingly, rewardingly, it's a mature and personal reflection.

An article on Tuesday about a negative advertisement that Republican presidential candidate Mike Huckabee played for the news media even though he said he did not intend to use it against Mitt Romney misspelled the surname of Mr. Huckabee's campaign manager, who said the campaign would maintain a positive tone. Because of an editing error, a sports article on Friday about West Virginia's hiring of Bill Stewart as its new head football coach misidentified the location, in some editions, of the team's Fiesta Bowl victory against Oklahoma. It was Glendale, Ariz. -- not Scottsdale.

An article in Business Day on Thursday about a partnership between Netflix and LG Electronics to send movies directly to televisions misstated the amount of free-streaming video Netflix subscribers were entitled to under its $17-a-month plan. They are allowed 17 hours of viewing a month, not 17 movies.

RIVERS CUOMO ''Alone: The Home Recordings of Rivers Cuomo'' (Geffen) The title of ''Alone: The Home Recordings'' is both an excuse and a boast from Weezer's main songwriter, Rivers Cuomo. The tracks are generally homemade and crude sounding, without the gleam that Weezer would have brought to them. The point of pride is that from guitar licks to layered vocal harmonies, Mr. Cuomo did them all on nearly every song.

9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) CARNEGIE HALL CELEBRATES BERLINSimon Rattle, above, has compared conducting the Berlin Philharmonic to driving a Rolls-Royce. In November, halfway through his 10-year contract as the orchestra's music director, he brought it to Carnegie Hall for the 17-day Berlin in Lights Festival. Viewers of this ''Great Performances'' special can judge how the orchestra handles in a presentation of Mahler's Ninth Symphony. ''Mr. Rattle drew an incisive and impassioned performance of this touchstone Mahler work, which the fatalistic and terminally ill composer assumed would be his farewell symphony,'' Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times, calling the poignant final Adagio ''glowing.'' The broadcast also features the Simón Bolívar Youth Orchestra of Venezuela, conducted by Gustavo Dudamel, the music director-elect of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, performing Bartok's Concerto for Orchestra. 8 P.M. (Discovery Health) NATIONAL BODY CHALLENGE: TWINS EDITION The channel's fifth annual weight-loss and wellness campaign enlists four sets of twins in the hope of showing that there's power in numbers.

SIA ''Some People Have Real Problems'' (Monkey Puzzle/Hear Music) Sia comes out of the shadows on her fourth studio album, ''Some People Have Real Problems.'' Sia Furler is a singer and songwriter who was born in Australia and works in London; between making her own albums she has sung and toured with the down-tempo band Zero 7. Her 2003 album, ''Colour the Small One,'' just about perfected a hushed, moody approach, as Sia sang about regrets in a breathy voice amid slow-motion drumbeats and subtle electronic burbles.

ROSENTHAL--Samuel, originally of Brooklyn, NY, passed away on January 3, 2008 at the age of 94, after 67 years of marriage to his beloved wife Molly. This week, I want to look at a figure in the history of biology: Alfred Russel Wallace. January 8th was his birthday. And 2008 is the 150th anniversary of one of the most important events in the history of biology. In 1858, Wallace wrote to Charles Darwin from the Moluccan Islands, in what is now Indonesia, where he was collecting birds, beetles, butterflies and anything else he could catch. The letter contained a manuscript in which Wallace outlined the idea of evolution by natural selection.

(Daniel Barillot/Masterfile)When I learned that an outpost of Barbuto - a stylish restaurant around the corner from my West Village apartment - had opened on the French Caribbean island of Guadeloupe, I scratched my head. What was the chef Jonathan Waxman, known for his seasonal take on traditional Italian dishes, doing on an island that not only has no Italian connection but is also pretty well overlooked by Americans? Turns out the explanation is a fairly simple: when one of Barbuto's partners, Phil Scotti, was visiting Guadeloupe, he happened to meet Valerie Robein, a well respected local restaurateur who was looking to open a new place, and hatched the idea to back her in a Caribbean-inflected version of Barbuto, with Robein helming the stove and Waxman developing the menu. While Barbuto Guadeloupe's lasagna with conch or roast chicken with curry aren't reason enough to make a trip, the restaurant's opening got me thinking again about an island that is said to combine the typical Caribbean assets of sun and sand with what is, let's face it, a real rarity in the region: a vibrant food scene, and one that intriguingly blends both Creole and European influences. Guadeloupe is one of the few major islands I haven't been to, but friends who have tell me the food's unusually good, from excellent morning pastries in the cafés to fresh grilled fish on the beach to more ambitious fare in the restaurants of Deshaies, the cute town where Barbuto is based. What's more, although French tourists in high season do pack the coastal resorts of Grand-Terre, Guadeloupe's eastern half, over on Basse-Terre you can supposedly still get some peace and quiet on the beach in January and February. Even in deepest darkest winter I'm always discouraging my better half from planning Caribbean getaways, in large part because a week without great eating is not my idea of a vacation, but in 2008 I think I'm voting for Guadeloupe. (For an overview of the island, and some hotel and restaurant advice, go here. Been to Guadeloupe? Let me know how you liked it here

MANCHESTER, N.H. -- It's primary day here in New Hampshire. No more rallies, no more town halls, no more Ron Paul sign-holders standing in the middle of Elm Street. (Where do these people come from? And why do they think that's working?) Unlike in Iowa, where you can actually go see the caucus process play out somewhere, primary day in New Hampshire means that we are mostly reduced to hanging around and awaiting the voters' verdicts. Four years ago, I passed the afternoon playing pool with a couple of other journalists. This time, I might just stop by the mall.

As the official blog of T: The New York Times Style Magazine, The Moment works hard to come off like one of the cool kids. Yesterday we blew our cover when we arrived in Las Vegas for the Consumer Electronics Show (C.E.S.), arguably the preeminent geek convention of the year. Our mission over the next few days will be to indulge our obsession with sexy electronics, browsing millions of doodads in search of good design. More on that later - you see, we aren't kidding about millions. The show sprawls for miles inside the mother of all convention centers. The crush of business men, cheesecake spokesmodels and high-tech signage has us thinking we're in Tokyo, not Nevada. It's an infamously brutal ordeal, and yesterday we saw people passed out on the floor by day's end. According to our buddies at Bits, the Times's technology blog, there's a big microbe scare at C.E.S. this year: Everybody's wiping down with Purell, and one company is even handing out sanitary gloves for germ-free handshakes. Lest we'd forget our surroundings, upon registration all journalists were issued blue and silver backpacks complete with external mesh pockets for water bottles, a waist belt, reflective coating (safety first) and a handy internal organizer that looks awfully pocket-protector like. Rather than wearing it, The Moment opted for the ghetto-chic boom-box shopping bag (above) we snagged at the Lasonic booth. But when the paper started to give, we saw the error of our ways, donned the backpack and accepted the inevitable. Today, we're jumping in again, but this time we're bring the new leopard-print Taser to clear the way.

Kansas State set two N.C.A.A. records and tied another by holding visiting Savannah State to 4 points in the second half in an 85-25 rout Monday night. Kansas State (10-4) hounded the Tigers on the perimeter and pushed them away from the basket inside from the opening tip. Savannah State was held without a field goal during a seven-minute span of the first half as Kansas State built a 16-point lead.Savannah State (8-13) missed its first 15 shots of the second half to fall behind by 72-25 as Kansas State opened with a 35-1 run. Joseph Flegler finally ended the drought with a 3-pointer with 5 minutes 48 seconds left. The Tigers finished the second half 1 for 23 from the field to set N.C.A.A. records for the worst shooting percentage and the fewest points in a half since the shot clock was introduced in 1986. The one field goal also tied the mark for fewest in a half.

Matt Howard scored 19 points, and No. 16 Butler won its sixth consecutive game, pulling away for a 66-55 victory over Loyola of Chicago on Monday night. The visiting Bulldogs (3-1 Horizon League) improved to 14-1 over all for the second season in a row and the fifth time in the team’s history. J. R. Blount scored 16 points for Loyola (5-10, 1-4). The Bulldogs fell five games under .500 for the first time since 2004-5, when they lost 16 of their first 23 games and finished 13-17 in Coach Jim Whetsell’s first season.

A front-page article on Dec. 31 about the elevation of Benazir Bhutto’s 19-year-old son, Bilawal, to succeed her as chairman of the Pakistan Peoples Party three days after her assassination misstated the name of the college he attends at Oxford University, Ms. Bhutto’s alma mater. It is Christ Church, not Christ Church College.

A film review in Weekend on Dec. 21 about “Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street” referred imprecisely to the story on which the film is based. It was originally serialized in Britain in the 1840s, and was the basis of a play written by Christopher Bond and of Hugh Wheeler’s book for the stage musical. While Stephen Sondheim wrote the music and lyrics for the musical, from which the film was adapted, the story is not his.
Shawn Marion scored a season-high 27 points, blocked 6 shots and made 5 of Phoenix’s 20 3-pointers to lead the Suns to a 137-115 victory over the visiting Denver Nuggets.
Ales Hemsky, Shawn Horcoff and Jarret Stoll each had a goal and an assist Monday night and Mathieu Garon made 35 saves for the Edmonton Oilers.

Ryan Hall, the United States marathon champion, will tune up for the Olympics by running in the London Marathon on April 13. Hall will be joined by the former world-record holder Paul Tergat and the defending champion Martin Lel.

Robby Gordon said Monday that the cancellation of the Dakar Rally cost him approximately $4.5 million, and he disagreed with the decision not to race at least a portion of the event. Gordon, who won stages of the race the past three years and led the event in 2005, was in Portugal and preparing for the start when organizers canceled it because of threats of terrorism from militants linked to Al Qaeda. Gordon said his team had more than $1 million invested in each vehicle.

Two former British police officers who fought corruption in horse racing and cricket are going to head tennis’s efforts to prevent matches from being fixed. Ben Gunn, who has worked for the British Horseracing Authority, and Jeff Rees, who retired in November from the International Cricket Council’s security unit, were appointed Monday by tennis’s governing bodies.

Major League Baseball eliminated a 24-hour notice of drug testing and imposed background checks on clubhouse personnel, adopting recommendations in the Mitchell report on drugs in the sport. A statement from Commissioner Bud Selig also said clubhouse personnel would be subject to random drug tests and teams would be required to log all packages sent to major league clubhouses. Personal trainers were banned from locker rooms.

A federal judge Monday dismissed an antitrust lawsuit filed against Nascar by a Kentucky track that was left off its premier racing circuit. Kentucky Speedway said that Nascar had conspired to leave it and other tracks out of the Sprint Cup series — formerly known as the Nextel Cup series — despite their superior amenities.
An effort to change the way states carry out executions by lethal injection appeared to founder before the Supreme Court.

President Bush is expected to sign into law a measure that will make it harder for people with a history of dangerous mental illness to purchase firearms. That is good news, but there is more work to be done.
China said it would launch 15 rockets, 17 satellites and its third mission with astronauts in 2008.

The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, appealed for “substantive” results from deadlocked talks brokered by the United Nations between Morocco and the pro-independence Polisario Front over the future of the resource-rich Western Sahara annexed by Morocco in 1975 after the colonial power Spain withdrew. A closed-door round of negotiations, the third in seven months, begin on Tuesday in Manhasset, N.Y., amid fear that failure to settle the dispute in the region, already victimized by violence linked to Al Qaeda, could lead to the resumption of a guerrilla war that lasted until 1991, when the United Nations sent peacekeepers.
The festive awards dinner will be replaced on Sunday night by a news conference to announce the prize winners.

Plans to exhume the body of Padre Pio, left, Italy’s favorite saint, to commemorate the 40th anniversary of his death have been met with fierce opposition from followers. The priest is said to have borne the bleeding wounds of the crucified Christ on his hands, feet and side for 50 years. Over the weekend, Archbishop Domenico Umberto D’Ambrosio announced his intention to lift the saint from his crypt in southern San Giovanni Rotondo and put the body on display for several months for pilgrims to venerate, starting in April. But other Roman Catholics, among them Francesco Traversi, who heads an association of Padre Pio devotees, are threatening to block the exhumation in court. The popularity of Padre Pio, who was also credited with thousands of miraculous cures during his life, is hard to overestimate. A Catholic magazine found that more Italian Catholics pray to him than any other icon of the faith, including the Virgin Mary or Jesus. Pope John Paul II made him a saint in 2002, four years after his death at 81, at a ceremony that drew one of the biggest Vatican crowds ever.

Fire tore through a refrigeration warehouse under construction in Ichon, south of Seoul, killing 40 workers. A local fire official said all the dead were found in the basement. More than 500 firefighters fought the blaze. The cause was undetermined, although the workers were injecting urethane foam into basement walls at the time. Among the dead were 13 ethnic Koreans from China, the Yonhap news agency reported. China has a sizable ethnic Korean minority and in recent years some have migrated to South Korea to seek employment. Like other foreign migrants, they often end up doing difficult and low-paying work.

The Dutch, thought to be the world’s tallest people, appear to have stopped growing, the Central Bureau for Statistics reported. It said growth rates for men and women had increased scarcely or not at all since 2001. The average Dutch man is 5 feet 11 inches tall. The average woman is 5-foot-6.

Prosecutors in British Columbia asked an appeals court to set aside six second-degree murder convictions against Robert Pickton, and order a new trial on 26 charges of first-degree murder. Relatives and friends of many of the victims were disappointed that Mr. Pickton, a pig farmer arrested in 2002, was found guilty by a jury last month only of second-degree murder, which does not require proof of premeditation. The prosecutors said the judge made errors, including his decision to split the case and put Mr. Pickton on trial on 6 counts of first-degree murder last year, with a trial on the remaining 20 counts to be held this year. Even if the government appeal is successful and Mr. Pickton is convicted on all 26 counts of first-degree murder, it will not change his sentence of life in prison without the chance of parole for 25 years. The remains of the victims, mostly prostitutes, were found buried on his farm in a Vancouver suburb.

The government sent troops to Naples to start clearing festering piles of rubbish from the streets, many blocking entry to the city’s schools, which reopened Monday after the Christmas break. Mountains of trash, too much for garbage collectors to cope with, built up after municipal dumps overflowed Dec. 21. Residents of Naples have taken to burning their own refuse, creating blazes that in some cases have had to be put out by firefighters. The city’s effort to move the garbage to a previously closed dump brought a revolt by residents, who blocked garbage trucks’ access to the area. Naples has faced periodic trash emergencies for the past 14 years.

Israeli soldiers shot dead three armed Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank, including a woman, an army spokeswoman said. The armed woman, 23, identified by Islamic Jihad as one of its members, and a man approached the border fence near the Erez Crossing in northern Gaza at noon, the spokeswoman said, and opened fire on soldiers nearby before being shot. In a village near the West Bank city of Jenin, soldiers fired at armed men who approached a checkpoint, the army spokeswoman said, killing one. Palestinian officials identified the dead man as a member of Islamic Jihad.
The most realistic change in format would be the so-called Plus One postseason model, which would essentially have the top two ranked teams play after the five B.C.S. games.
Comedy Central’s Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert returned to the air Monday pointing barbs at their own management and at the striking union.
A new car from Tata Motors of India would likely fail Western emission and safety standards, but it could be an affordable car for the developing world.
James E. Cayne, the embattled chief executive of Bear Stearns, will step down after the deepest losses in the firm’s history, according to people who have been briefed on the situation.
Records raise new questions about the business practices of the giant mortgage lender at the center of the subprime mess.
To win election in Arkansas, a state twice as rural as the national norm, is to study at a deeply challenging school of tactile politics.
If the ever-interesting Dolan clan, the power behind the Cablevision Systems empire, can be seen as a modern-day version of the Corleones, then James Dolan is Fredo.
The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce fired two executives at its CIBC World Markets unit as it grapples with a $9.8 billion exposure to subprime debt.
Genzyme has agreed to pay at least $325 million to win the hotly contested rights to a potentially powerful cholesterol-lowering drug.
John Lilly, the chief operating officer of Mozilla, the developer of the open-source browser Firefox, will succeed Mitchell Baker as the firm’s chief executive.
The beleaguered student lending giant appointed a longtime banking executive as chairman as it struggles with tighter credit markets and a failed buyout.
For all the criticism of the presidential election process, the early stages of this presidential race have been both compelling and heartening.
Rudolph W. Giuliani’s long-held lead in national polls has evaporated and he has drawn small crowds, scant news media coverage and somewhat muted enthusiasm in New Hampshire.
President Bush is likely to respond to recession fears much as he did on entering office in 2001, but this time around Democrats are planning to push back.
If you’re a chief executive under siege, Martin Lipton is the lawyer to call.
The E.P.A.  is launching a public education campaign aimed at getting consumers to recycle their old phones.
Mr. Harrison was the owner and editor of The New Republic, an influential though rarely profitable publication, from 1953 to 1974.
Representative Rahm Emanuel of Illinois, the fast-talking, hard-charging leader of the House Democratic Caucus, spent the day with President Bush in Chicago.
A federal judge cleared the way for a long-running dispute over unpaid life insurance claims for Holocaust victims to move a step closer to a settlement.
Mikael Silvestre said he liked the United States “because everything is big.” But apparently the soccer is not yet big enough to entice him to relocate across the Atlantic.
The popular doughnut-making company said Daryl G. Brewster was leaving his position for personal reasons.

As the race for the Democratic presidential nomination has turned upside down, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama have revised their approaches of exposing themselves to public view and questioning.
Hong Kong adopts a new regulatory system that could some day be a model for mainland China’s giant power industries.
The momentum of Barack Obama’s campaign seemed to steal energy from an event that had the potential to be a big moment for Michael Bloomberg’s potential presidential bid.
The company is expected to increase spending in India by $500 million, as it focuses on making the country a regional hub for small-car manufacturing.
A plan aims to offer Comcast subscribers a nearly limitless supply of movies and TV shows that can be viewed on demand and through the Internet.
The Aeon Company of Japan, cut its full-year outlook after poor results at Talbots cut deeply into its operating profit.

Two men who the authorities said dabbled in satanism have been arrested in connection with a rash of arson and vandalism at rural churches in east Alabama. Satanic graffiti was scrawled at or near some of the churches. The two men, Geoffrey Parquette and James Clark, both 21, pleaded not guilty. Fires were set at three churches over four days beginning last Tuesday, and one of the buildings was destroyed.
A founder of GiveWell admitted that he promoted the nonprofit research organization on a Web site by posing as a prospective charitable donor seeking information.

A judge in Miami delayed the start of jury selection in the retrial of six men accused of plotting to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago, citing an emergency involving the family of a defense lawyer. Ana M. Jhones, the lawyer for the defendant accused of being the ringleader, requested the delay, and Judge Joan Lenard of Federal District Court scheduled a hearing Wednesday to decide whether jury selection would begin this week or next. The first trial ended last month in a hung jury for the six men and in an acquittal for another.

Crime dipped slightly for the first half of 2007, the F.B.I. reported, signaling a stop to a two-year increase in violence nationwide. Violent crime, including murders, rapes and robberies, dropped by 1.8 percent from January to June last year, according to the preliminary data from the bureau. Property crimes also decreased, including a 7.4 percent drop in car thefts and a 10 percent drop in arsons. But in small cities and rural areas, violent crime appears to be rising, if only slightly, the data show.

The United States Transportation Department will investigate the work conditions of Chicago-area air traffic controllers amid an increasing frequency of errors, the agency said. The department’s Office of the Inspector General announced the audit in response to a request last month by Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois. That request came after the General Accountability Office released a study showing that O’Hare International Airport had the second-highest number of near-collisions on runways from 2001 to 2006.

Prosecutors are reviewing whether a 12-year-old boy should be charged as an adult after the police accused him of fatally beating his toddler cousin Friday afternoon with a baseball bat for interrupting a cartoon show. The boy, whose name was not released, was being held in juvenile custody in the death of his cousin, 17-month-old Shaloh Joseph, who the police said enraged the suspect by crying.

Environmental groups sued the Shell Oil Company and several of its affiliates, claiming that the oil giant has for years released pollutants from its suburban Houston refinery that are well above state and federal limits. In the federal lawsuit, the Sierra Club and Environment Texas claim that the excess air pollutants, including the toxic chemicals benzene and 1,3-butadiene, are a violation of the federal Clean Air Act.
A government panel recommended that prices be set for greenhouse gas emissions.
Less than a week after Hawaii’s appearance in the Sugar Bowl, which was a high point in the state’s sporting history, Coach June Jones accepted the coaching job at Southern Methodist.
Salvatore (Bill) Bonanno was remembered in a modest but elegant funeral on Monday in Tucson, where his family moved after a violent Mafia power struggle.
The idea, which Gov. Eliot Spitzer has rejected before and which has often met resistance among fellow Democrats, is still being debated within the administration.
While the Giants are enjoying their re-inherited underdog status, the Dallas Cowboys are dealing with the pressures that come with being expected to go to the Super Bowl.

A federal appeals court gave new life to a 2005 lawsuit saying that school districts have been justified in complaining about lack of federal money to carry out the No Child Left Behind education law.
Sony BMG is the last major record company to do away with the programs, which prevent illegal copying and distribution of songs on the Internet.
Safety Bob Sanders’s impact on the vastly improved Indianapolis defense earned him the Associated Press N.F.L. Defensive Player of the Year award Monday.
Microsoft announced partnerships with Walt Disney, NBC Universal and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to boost online video sales.
A rift is emerging between President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Iran’s supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
Norv Turner has guided the Chargers to their first playoff victory since January 1995, succeeding where many other San Diego head coaches had failed.
The Consumer Product Safety Commission is expanding inspections of imports after the recalls of toys, toothpaste and pet-food ingredients from China.
A study has found that autism cases continued to climb even after thimerosal, which some people blame for the disorder, was removed from routine childhood shots.
The author of  a cookbook of healthy comfort food for children sued Jessica and Jerry Seinfeld on Monday, charging copyright infringement and defamation.
For some, the fear of bridges is paralyzing; for others, it becomes simply a somewhat embarrassing, highly uncomfortable backdrop to their lives.
With the price of gasoline and home heating oil no longer comfortably affordable, the benefits of living in rural New Hampshire have also become burdens for many people.
Dr. P. K. Sethi invented the affordable prosthesis called the Jaipur foot, which has helped millions of amputees in developing countries to lead normal lives.
For more than 50 years, Rabbi Berenbaum led a major Orthodox yeshiva in Brooklyn known as the Mir Yeshiva.

Unless hundreds of writers experienced stunning reversals in the past year regarding their feelings about Mark McGwire, he is not expected to be voted into the Hall of Fame when the announcement is made today at 2 p.m. ET.
Jimmie Johnson will try to join Cale Yarborough as a winner of three consecutive titles in Nascar’s premier racing division, now called the Sprint Cup.
Lawyers for three police detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell say publicity surrounding the case has “incurably poisoned” the pool of prospective jurors.
The Rev. Al Sharpton said he recently received a request to broker the surrender of one of the men who escaped from a New Jersey county jail last month.
Investors grew more confident that the Fed will lower interest rates again to ward off recession, but they also wrestled with worries about the coming earnings season.

The Long Island Rail Road said Monday that 2007 was its best year for on-time performance since it began keeping records. The railroad president, Helena Williams, said 94.07 percent of its trains were on time last year, the best since record-keeping began in 1979. The previous record came in 2002, when it hit 94.04 percent.
North Korea’s failure to meet a deadline to declare its nuclear activities should be confronted with patience and perseverance, a senior American envoy said on Monday.

A panel of three federal judges has approved the extension of a consent agreement through which Westchester County provided bilingual assistance at the polls for Spanish-speaking voters, Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, announced on Monday. The agreement, between federal prosecutors and the county, was signed in 2005 and set to expire last summer, but federal prosecutors asked to extend the agreement to December of this year. In a Jan. 3 opinion, the judges found that the county had made progress in complying with the agreement, but that the extension was still justified, the prosecutors said.

A federal judge on Monday approved a settlement among Holocaust victims, their heirs and an Italian insurer. Saying the settlement was “fair, reasonable and adequate,” Judge George B. Daniels of Federal District Court ended more than a decade of litigation over the claim that the insurer, Assicurazioni Generali, refused to honor the victims’ policies. The lawsuit was among nearly two dozen that were thrown out in 2004. The cases were eventually settled, with Generali agreeing to pay $175 million to survivors and their relatives through the International Commission on Holocaust Era Insurance Claims and other channels.

A former New Haven police detective convicted in a Police Department drug scandal was sentenced on Monday in Federal District Court to 90 days in jail. The former detective, Jose Silva, 36, pleaded guilty to depriving an individual of his constitutional rights in October. Federal prosecutors said Mr. Silva knew that another detective, Justen Kasperzyk, had moved suspected narcotics from the basement to the back bedroom of a first-floor apartment in New Haven, resulting in an unlawful arrest in November 2006. Mr. Kasperzyk pleaded guilty to one count of civil rights conspiracy, a felony, and one count of theft of government property, a misdemeanor. He is scheduled to be sentenced March 27.

The state has awarded the first grants from its $600 million stem cell research program, Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced on Monday. The $14.5 million in grants were awarded to 25 medical institutions to support stem cell research and training, the governor said. The one-year grants will provide $6.1 million for research, $7.4 million for equipment purchases and $1 million for training, state officials said.

Nineteen months after a Mastic Beach man was reported missing by his relatives, Suffolk County police detectives have found a body in a cesspool behind his house, the police said on Monday. The man, Nicholas Caietta, 59, was reported missing on May 30, 2006, and several months later, the investigation of his disappearance was transferred to the homicide squad, the police said, without elaborating why. On Saturday, the police excavated the cesspool behind Mr. Caietta’s home at 275 Forest Road West, and found the body. The body had not been identified Monday evening, and an autopsy has been scheduled, the police said.

Barbara Bruno, the wife of the State Senate Republican majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, has died after a long battle with Alzheimer’s disease. She was 77. The senator’s office announced the death Monday evening. Barbara and Joseph Bruno were married for 57 years, and had four children and seven grandchildren.
A powerful Pacific storm system that slammed into the western half of the country last week wreaked havoc throughout the weekend and Monday.

A city police officer who was arrested last month on charges of raping a 14-year-old girl was charged in federal court on Monday with bringing her and a second teenage girl across state lines to engage in illegal sex, officials said. The officer, Trent Young, 39, had been a martial arts instructor to both victims and, on separate occasions in 2006 and 2007, took them from his hometown, Middletown, N.Y., to his martial arts school in New Jersey, according to a statement by the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan. Officer Young was arrested on Dec. 27 by the Middletown police. The second girl came forward on Jan. 3, according to a federal compliant. Officer Young was held without bail on Monday, officials said. Officer Young’s lawyer, Gary Greenwald, said, “His defense is it never happened.”.
Political tourists — people who head to early primary states to witness the spectacle — are out in full effect this election cycle.
A federal judge rejected a request by a defense lawyer in the case of Jose Padilla to disclose any recordings that might bear on Mr. Padilla’s recruitment into a terrorist organization.
National health spending soared above $2 trillion for the first time in 2006 and has nearly doubled in the last decade.
The announcement came in response to the threat of pickets from the Writers Guild of America.
Condé Nast Publications announced a management shake-up, including the departure of Mitchell B. Fox, one of the company’s highest-ranking executives.
Yale’s announcement came in the wake of questions from Congress and donors as to why wealthy universities raise tuition faster than the rate of inflation while the value of their endowments soars.
A former coast guard officer found dead last month in before an expected verdict in his trial for torture may have been killed to keep him silent, a judge concluded Monday.
Macmillan Publishers has agreed to buy Hayden-McNeil Publishing, a publisher of custom textbooks, for an undisclosed sum.

BUSINESS TRAVEL DEMAND UP IN 2008 Any weakening in the economy apparently has not yet affected most business travelers’ plans this year. According to Access America, an insurance and travelers’ assistance company, 26 percent of business travelers surveyed said they expected to be on the road more this year than last, and 61 percent said they expected to travel about the same amount. Among other findings in the survey of 1,000 travelers: Nearly 78 percent cited high gasoline prices as one frustration of travel, 55 percent named poor airline service, and 41 percent cited airport security and passport and border procedures. By far the least frustrating part of travel was booking the trip. Only 16 percent said they found making travel arrangements frustrating.
The trip comes at a time of renewed efforts by the United States to keep the pressure on Iran on the nuclear issue.
Gender is probably the most restricting force in American life, whether the question is who must be in the kitchen or who could be in the White House.
Some parts of New Hampshire remain untouched by politics.
Automobile traffic is a problem plaguing many airports, but some have found a simple partial solution -- cellphone parking lots away from the terminal.
Flying provides a mobile office for everything from writing to arranging the Stones’  set lists.
Charles Taylor, 59, has pleaded not guilty to the 11 charges against him, which include murder, rape, enslavement and conscripting child soldiers.
A motion filed on Monday said that publicity surrounding the Sean Bell case has “incurably poisoned” the pool of prospective jurors for the trial next month.
Eli Broad, who has a private collection of 2,000 works of Modern and contemporary art, will retain permanent control of his works in an independent foundation.
To the Editor:.
A musical based on “The Diary of a Young Girl” by Anne Frank is to open next month at the Calderon Theater in Madrid.

On Sunday, 40 years to the day after Johnny Cash performed at Folsom Prison in Northern California, his longtime drummer Fluke Holland will lead a celebratory concert there. The Columbia recording “Johnny Cash at Folsom Prison,” released in the summer of 1968, appeared on the country music charts for 90 weeks and on Billboard’s Top 200 for 122 weeks. Sunday’s performance will feature several members of Cash’s original band, and, according to an announcement, “A special guest vocalist will be introduced at the show.” Although no inmates present at the 1968 concert will attend the new one, one former guard, now 80, will be there, as well as several guests who were present at the time, said the show’s producer, Jonathan Holiff, son of Saul Holiff, the Canadian entrepreneur who managed Cash from 1960 to 1973. The “40th Anniversary of ‘Johnny Cash at Folsom Prison’ ” concert will be filmed and streamed worldwide over the Internet at iClips.net.

The name is Arterton, Gemma Arterton, and before the next James Bond film reaches its conclusion she’ll probably be shaken and stirred. Ms. Arterton, 21, has been cast as the “Bond girl” opposite Daniel Craig in the production with the working title “Bond 22” now being filmed in London, Reuters reported. Ms. Arterton, above, will play a character named Fields, a representative for the film’s producer said, adding “It’s a nice-sized role.” No further details were disclosed. Citing reports, the BBC said the film picks up where “Casino Royale” left off and is loosely based on “Risico,” a short story by Ian Fleming that pits Bond against a drug ring flooding Britain with heroin.

A triptych by Francis Bacon, appearing at auction for the first time, is expected to set a record for a British or Irish work when it leads Christie’s Post War & Contemporary Art Evening Sale in London on Feb. 6. Held by a private collection, “Triptych 1974-77,” above, is the last in a series painted by Bacon (1909-1992) in response to the suicide of his lover, George Dyer, in their room in Paris. Bacon’s “Study From Innocent X” (1962) sold in May for a record $52.6 million.

Suzy Welch, a former editor of the Harvard Business Review and the wife of John F. Welch Jr., the former chief executive of General Electric, has agreed to sell the rights to her book “10-10-10” to Scribner, an imprint of Simon & Schuster. A person involved in the negotiations said that Scribner paid Ms. Welch a price in the seven figures for world and audio rights to the book. Based on an article Ms. Welch wrote for O, the Oprah Magazine, in 2006, the book offers strategies for making decisions in which people think about what the consequences of a decision will be in 10 minutes, 10 months and 10 years. Robert Barnett, a Washington lawyer, negotiated the deal on behalf of Ms. Welch. Nan Graham, editor in chief of Scribner, will edit the book with Samantha Martin. Ms. Welch, who wrote the best-selling “Winning” with Mr. Welch, said she originally thought there wasn’t a book beyond the article. But, she said, “I began to encounter this hunger for people who were using it to play out its nuances.” She said the book would include examples from her own life as well as others she has observed using the “10-10-10” process. Susan Moldow, publisher of Scribner, said that although Ms. Welch’s article might seem sufficient for those who wanted to know about the strategy, Ms. Moldow believed the book would sell well. “The Scarsdale Diet fit on a Xerox-ed sheet that you could fit on the front of a refrigerator,” Ms. Moldow said. “And it sold millions and millions of copies. It’s often true that when something strikes an immediate ‘Aha!,’ you really want to have time to meditate on it and try to get to know more about it.”.

Damian Woetzel, a principal dancer at the New York City Ballet, said Monday he would retire at season’s end, making official what he had predicted a year ago. Mr. Woetzel’s final performance will be on June 18 after 23 years with the company. He earned a master’s degree in public administration from Harvard University last year and is artistic director of the summer Vail International Dance Festival. Mr. Woetzel said it was fitting to leave as the company commemorates the 10th anniversary of the death of Jerome Robbins by featuring his choreography. “His presence was the reason I joined” the company, Mr. Woetzel said. He said he will focus his energy “beyond the limited space of performing” in “areas where I hope to make an impact in the second part of my life.”.

NBC’s remake of “American Gladiators” muscled to a strong start on Sunday. The amateur athletic tournament, based on the early 1990s series, delivered the highest ratings among adults 18 to 49 of any new show this season on any network, matching the debut of “Heroes” in September 2006, Nielsen estimated. In total viewers, however, “American Gladiators” was less impressive, drawing an average of 12 million from 9 to 11 p.m. ABC’s “Cashmere Mafia,” by comparison, which made its debut on Sunday at 10 p.m., attracted 10.7 million viewers but markedly lower ratings in the 18-to-49 set. “Cashmere Mafia” also benefited from a plum time slot following ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” (19.8 million), the only show to outpace “American Gladiators” on the night among adults 18 to 49. ABC, NBC and CBS finished in a virtual tie for first in that demographic over all on Sunday. CBS, buoyed by an overrun of its afternoon football coverage during the 7 p.m. hour that was followed by one of the highest rated editions of “60 Minutes” in recent years (19 million), won the race in total viewers.
In the best of circumstances silence during a good performance becomes something palpable, not just an absence of noise. Involved audiences can shout approval without making a sound.
A new study investigated the effects of changes to labels on antidepressant use nationwide.

The two most haunting stories in the volume — “Lélé” by Edwidge Danticat and “Donal Webster” by Colm Toibin — unfold, like elaborate origami flowers, into complex portraits with the emotional density and historical depth of field of a novel.
The Museum of Modern Art has commissioned five architects to erect their own prefab dwellings in a vacant lot on West 53rd Street, adjacent to the museum.
The statue “Venus Victorious” is the centerpiece of “Canova and the Venus Victorious,” the second of a series of special exhibitions at the Borghese Gallery in Rome.
Nicky Gottlieb,  the subject of “Today’s Man,”  has Asperger syndrome, a form of autism, and his sister, Lizzie Gottlieb, spent six years committing his life to film.

To the Editor:.
Opioid medications are increasingly being given in emergency rooms — but white patients are more likely to get them than minorities, a new study finds.
Despite the well-established danger from urinary catheters, a new study finds that hospitals are doing very little to reduce the risks of infection.
Children with disorders in what is known as the autism spectrum tend to be less irritable and hyperactive after a period of high temperature, a new study suggests.
Frank M.  Davis and other experts have developed an entire technology to breed large numbers of insects for a variety of exotic jobs.
A new study suggests that doctors may devote too little time to talking with elderly patients about mental illnesses.
At a scary time for patients, too few doctors ask about feelings, a new study finds.
Fifty years ago, a paper appeared in the journal Physical Review with an answer to a physics puzzle: superconductivity.
“An Affair to Remember,” reissued in a beautifully remastered two-disc 50th-anniversary edition, is one of the best and best-loved films of classical Hollywood.
Implantable stimulators can blunt pain with electrical impulses, but they may come with negative side effects.
The move came a day after Roger Clemens filed a defamation lawsuit against Brian McNamee, his former trainer.
I am taking niacin for high cholesterol. How does it work?
If your identity is being used by someone else, then his overdose is not your business.
At least 14 people were killed in the latest attack on nationalist Sunnis who have allied themselves with American troops.
It was the place to be seen over the weekend, the bedside of Indonesia’s former strongman, Suharto, who was driven from office 10 years ago and is now near death.
Antibiotics and steroids may be the standard medications for a sinus infection, but are they effective?
The search for new treatments can be tricky when the disease is fearsome but nearly forgotten because its victims are poor and obscure.
New findings are some of the first strong evidence that the ancient Maya civilization had a market economy similar in some respects to societies today.
With the stock plummeting and competitors on the attack, Starbucks Coffee said Monday that it was bringing back its top barista to help turn the company around.
Xerox is retiring the staid red capital X that has dominated its logo for 40 years in favor of  “a brand identity that reflects the Xerox of today.”
Baltimore’s mayor and City Council contend that Wells Fargo’s lending practices discriminated against black borrowers and led to a wave of foreclosures.
President Nicolas Sarkozy’s romance with a singer has fueled criticism that he is ignoring the country.

LAST week, I spent most of an afternoon trying to get a cogent explanation of a confusing news release issued late on the Friday before New Year’s by a mouthful of an agency called the United States Department of Transportation Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.
After-school programs offered through the Children’s Aid Society helped Sonia Gayle and her husband buy their children winter coats and talk to them honestly about sex.
The theme of championship week has been curiosity; concern over the healing process of New Orleans, a great city that was turned inside out by Hurricane Katrina.
The Roger Clemens on Monday, the one you get in a foul mood, was more riveting than the comparatively polite Clemens who appeared opposite Mike Wallace a night earlier on “60 Minutes.”

Following is an excerpt from a news conference by President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, as translated by The New York Times, who responded to questions from Roselyne Febvre, a French television reporter, about his relationship with the pop singer Carla Bruni:.
As a redshirt freshman four years ago, Louisiana State quarterback Matt Flynn stood on the sideline in the Superdome and watched his team win a national championship.
The No. 2 L.S.U. Tigers stole the final scene on the sport’s grandest stage, blowing out top-ranked Ohio State to win the program’s third national championship.
Owners of off-road vehicles are transforming some of America’s most sensitive public lands into their personal playgrounds.
From his parched, pursed lips to the jut of his shoulders, three body-language experts who watched Roger Clemens over the past two days said he was holding something back.
Brian McNamee told SI.com that Roger Clemens was simply part of a widespread steroid culture within baseball.
In a bizarre news conference thet featured a 17-minute telephone call between Roger Clemens and his accusatory former personal trainer, Brian McNamee, no eureka moment emerged.
For the first time since Kenya exploded into election-related violence that killed more than 400 people, the president and the top opposition leader have agreed to meet.
Microsoft bid $1.2 billion for Fast Search and Transfer, based in Oslo, in an effort to add more tools to its lucrative Office products.
A scientific scramble is under way to clarify whether the erosion of the world’s most vulnerable ice sheets can continue to accelerate.
Five Iranian boats took aggressive actions around three U.S. naval vessels in the Strait of Hormuz, an official said.
Both Barack Obama and John McCain offer a politics that is grand and inspiring. But they are very different men.
Notable research studies now enrolling patients.
Physical activity has been held out as a cure-all for everything from heart disease to cancer. But evidence shows the picture is not so clear.
Talking points for patients and physicians.
An exercise prescription from public health expert Steven Blair.

LOVEMAN--Lester Edward, of Pound Ridge, NY, passed away on January 4, 2008. He will forever be missed by his beloved wife, Penny, his children, Sara, John and Kate, and his grandchildren, Jack, Lindsay, Katherine and Riley. Services will be private with a memorial at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Horace Mann School. LOVEMAN--Lester Edward. He had a great run, but not nearly long enough. He will be sorely missed by family, friends and everyone whose life he touched. 54 years of true friendship. Paul, Linda, Jennifer and Steven Karan

To the Editor: Reading William Kristol's Jan. 7 column, ''President Mike Huckabee?,'' one would come away thinking that President Bush was an outstanding president and that America is enthusiastic to continue his course, with Mr. Huckabee at the helm. In reality, Bush policies and the conservative agenda -- from abortion, Iraq and judicial appointments -- are widely opposed. Most voters want the next president to undo Mr. Bush's legacy, not extend it.

Major League Baseball eliminated a 24-hour notice of drug testing and imposed background checks on clubhouse personnel, adopting recommendations in the Mitchell report on drugs in the sport. A statement from Commissioner Bud Selig also said clubhouse personnel would be subject to random drug tests and teams would be required to log all packages sent to major league clubhouses. Personal trainers were banned from locker rooms.

In a bizarre news conference in which reporters in Houston and fans on television listened in suspense to a crackling 17-minute telephone call between Roger Clemens and his accusatory former personal trainer, Brian McNamee, no eureka moment emerged from the dissonance. As Clemens repeatedly asked for ''someone to tell the truth'' about McNamee's claims to federal and baseball investigators that he injected Clemens with performance-enhancing drugs from 1998 through 2001, McNamee neither insisted he had been truthful nor indicated he had lied.
GOLD--Beatrice. Jan. 8, 1994. Memories of you Mother are always in our hearts. Your loving Daughter and family

GOLDMAN--Richard, January 6, 2008, in his 65th year after a valiant 15 month struggle with pancreatic cancer. He leaves his heartbroken wife Susan, his daughter Heather, brother Larry, nephew Morgan, and many relatives and friends who loved him. He will be greatly missed. Funeral service: Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, NY, Tuesday, January 8, 2008 at 12:00pm. Shiva will begin following interment on Tuesday through Monday at the family residence.

A federal judge Monday dismissed an antitrust lawsuit filed against Nascar by a Kentucky track that was left off its premier racing circuit. Kentucky Speedway said that Nascar had conspired to leave it and other tracks out of the Sprint Cup series -- formerly known as the Nextel Cup series -- despite their superior amenities.

Robby Gordon said Monday that the cancellation of the Dakar Rally cost him approximately $4.5 million, and he disagreed with the decision not to race at least a portion of the event. Gordon, who won stages of the race the past three years and led the event in 2005, was in Portugal and preparing for the start when organizers canceled it because of threats of terrorism from militants linked to Al Qaeda. Gordon said his team had more than $1 million invested in each vehicle.

Ryan Hall, the United States marathon champion, will tune up for the Olympics by running in the London Marathon on April 13. Hall will be joined by the former world-record holder Paul Tergat and the defending champion Martin Lel.

To the Editor: Re ''In 2008, a 100 Percent Chance of Alarm'' (Findings, Jan. 1): John Tierney criticizes climate change activists for being unbalanced reporters of the scientific evidence on global warming. If democracies were known to respond wisely to distant, intangible threats, his call for a more nuanced activism would be warranted. What makes global warming such a challenge is precisely the fact that political action is required decades before the effects will be unequivocally disastrous. Should we not therefore be realistic and let environmental activists indulge in a little politically motivated rhetoric?

For further details: jwinokur@mindspring.com.

MORSE--Jane H., age 78, died peacefully at home on New Years Day after a valiant struggle with pancreatic cancer. She was Professor Emeritus of Clinical Medicine, starting her career at Columbia Presbyterian 50 years ago as a medical student. During her retirement, she discovered the gene responsible for familial primary pulmonary hypertension. She was defined by her career, but she was also mother, grandmother, mentor and friend. Loyal to a fault, and brutally honest, Jane enjoyed life with zeal. She was an avid tennis player, golfer, and an accomplished abstract artist. She is survived by her children Carol Holtby (Markus), her son Ken Morse (Liz) and her four granddaughters. Interment private, memorial to follow on February 26th, 4:30pm, at the chapel at CPMC. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to be made to the Jane Morse Primary Pulmonary Hypertension Fund, c/o Jeane Ford at 212-342-0093.

Kristine Lilly, captain of the United States women's national team for the past three years, is expecting her first child and will miss the Olympics. Lilly, who has been part of all eight United States Women's World Cup and Olympics teams, said she would not play international soccer in 2008.

LESLIE--Seymour. The AntiDeformation League mourns the passing of Seymour Leslie, a Honorary Life Member of our National Commission. Cy and his wife Barbara were longtime enthusiastic and generous supporters of the League. We extend our sincerest condolences to Barbara, and the entire family. Glen S. Lewy, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director LESLIE--Seymour M. A native and lifelong New Yorker, passed away on Sunday, January 6, 2008, at the age of 85, after 60 years of marriage to his beloved wife, Barbara. The man known to the world as ''Cy'' is survived by his loving daughters Ellen, Janie and Carol, and his adoring grandchildren Julie (Dan), David (Ariana), Sara and Ben. As an entrepreneur from start to finish, Cy helped shape the music and entertainment world and was recognized as a pioneer of the home video industry. His first business was a prerecorded greeting card service that turned into Voco Records; he went on to become Founder of Pickwick International, President of CBS Video Enterprises, Founder and Chairman of MGM/UA Home Entertainment, Founder of The Leslie Group, and Co-Chairman of Leslie/Linton Entertainment. Cy has been recognized as one of the 20th Century's most influential and outstanding leaders in the video industry: he was the Record industry's Man of The Year in 1975; he received the Presidential award from the National Association of Record Manufacturers in 1976; and Time magazine presented him with the Home Viewer/Time Magazine Man-ofThe-Year Award for special achievement in 1987. Cy was also Vice Chairman of the Songwriters Hall of Fame and an active member of the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences. In his professional life, Cy never stopped giving to the entertainment world, and in his personal life, he never stopped giving to those he loved, serving as the tower of strength to those who knew him intimately. He and Barbara had also dedicated their lives to supporting various organizations and institutions such as The JCC of the Greater Five Towns, Five Towns College, Parker Jewish Institute, B'nai B'rith, New York State Council on Humanities, Friars Foundation and the T.J. Martell Foundation. As a proud graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School, Cy received his Bachelor's degree from Syracuse University, before being deployed by the Army in World War II. Later, he received a degree from Harvard Business School, and has also received an honorary doctorate from Syracuse University. Cy will be remembered as a man of integrity, loyalty, and passion, and as a man who loved life and lived it fully. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The JCC of the Greater Five Towns, 207 Grove Avenue, Cedarhurst, NY, 11596 or the Anti - Defamation League, Department: RL, P.O. Box 96226, Washington, DC 20090. Services will be held on Tuesday, January 8, at 11:30 at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Shiva to follow at the home of Barbara Leslie at 810 Channel Road, Woodmere, NY. LESLIE--Seymour (Cy). Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst records with sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President LESLIE--Seymour (Cy). The Woodmere Club deeply regrets the passing of our longtime member and good friend. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his family and friends. Board of Governors The Woodmere Club LESLIE--Seymour. With deep sorrow, we regret the passing of our friend, colleague, and Vice Chairman of the Songwriters Hall of Fame. He will be greatly missed. JUNGHANS--Charlotte T. (nee Loeser), January 8, 1908 -January 28, 2003. You always wanted to celebrate being 100. How sad I am without you here to mark this milestone. You were my guiding light, always clear and focused. How grateful I am to have had your special presence and influence for so many years. Without your intuition and keen instinct for survival our family history would have ended with a train ride from Theresienstadt to Auschwitz in September 1944. You were the ultimate survivor and the most selfless, giving and caring person ever. I am truly honored to be your daughter and fellow survivor. Fortunately, your unique spirit remains in us always. Eva Brill

A chart in Business Day on Friday about annual sales of vehicles in the United States misstated the month for which the most recent sales were being reported. It was December, not November. A corrected chart is at nytimes.com/business.

The director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service said his agency would not meet a Wednesday deadline for deciding whether polar bears merited protection under the Endangered Species Act because Arctic sea ice is melting. The questions involved in deciding whether to list the bears as a threatened species, based on the effects of climate change on their fishing grounds, were too complex to finish the analysis on time, said the director, H. Dale Hall. The decision will be made in a month, Mr. Hall said, if not earlier.

Kansas State set two N.C.A.A. records and tied another by holding visiting Savannah State to 4 points in the second half in an 85-25 rout Monday night. Kansas State (10-4) hounded the Tigers on the perimeter and pushed them away from the basket inside from the opening tip. Savannah State was held without a field goal during a seven-minute span of the first half as Kansas State built a 16-point lead.Savannah State (8-13) missed its first 15 shots of the second half to fall behind by 72-25 as Kansas State opened with a 35-1 run. Joseph Flegler finally ended the drought with a 3-pointer with 5 minutes 48 seconds left. The Tigers finished the second half 1 for 23 from the field to set N.C.A.A. records for the worst shooting percentage and the fewest points in a half since the shot clock was introduced in 1986. The one field goal also tied the mark for fewest in a half.

LURIE--Boris. A founder of the No! Art movement, died January 7, 2008 after having suffered a massive stroke over a year earlier. He was born July 18, 1924 in Leningrad and taken to Latvia as an infant. At the age of sixteen, he, along with his father, was put into a concentration camp. Most of his family was murdered during the war. Upon his liberation by the Soviets, he assisted the American occupation forces and then emigrated to the U.S. Here, he became a painter, writer and poet. He remained the Zionist he'd been since childhood and his experiences during World War II only strengthened his radical politics. His art reflected a distaste for the easy consumerism of the post-war boom, the advertising which prodded it, and its effect on American art and culture. His multiple exhibitions culminated in one at the inaugural of the Buchenwald Museum.

An article on Sunday about fund-raising by the presidential candidates referred incorrectly to the status of federal matching funds for Senator John McCain. Although Mr. McCain has qualified for such funds, he has not accepted them and therefore is not subject to a $45 million limit on his primary campaign spending.

A front-page article on Dec. 31 about the elevation of Benazir Bhutto's 19-year-old son, Bilawal, to succeed her as chairman of the Pakistan Peoples Party three days after her assassination misstated the name of the college he attends at Oxford University, Ms. Bhutto's alma mater. It is Christ Church, not Christ Church College.

A headline on Dec. 29 about a drive-by shooting incident in the West Bank referred imprecisely to the circumstances. As the article reported, two Israeli settlers hiking with a friend near Hebron while on leave from army duty were shot by Palestinian gunmen who drove by, but the two Israelis managed to return fire before they died, and two of their attackers died as well. All four were not killed in a drive-by shooting while on a hiking trip.

Matt Howard scored 19 points, and No. 16 Butler won its sixth consecutive game, pulling away for a 66-55 victory over Loyola of Chicago on Monday night. The visiting Bulldogs (3-1 Horizon League) improved to 14-1 over all for the second season in a row and the fifth time in the team's history. J. R. Blount scored 16 points for Loyola (5-10, 1-4). The Bulldogs fell five games under .500 for the first time since 2004-5, when they lost 16 of their first 23 games and finished 13-17 in Coach Jim Whetsell's first season.

Because of an editing error, a Playbill report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Dec. 29 about plans for Kristin Chenoweth to play Cunegonde in a production of ''Candide'' in London misidentified the organization with which she will perform. It is the English National Opera, not the English National Orchestra.

The TV Watch column in Weekend on Friday, about the return of some late-night talk shows that had been in reruns because of the writers' strike, misstated part of the title of a segment on David Letterman's show. It was ''Hal Gurnee's Network Time Killers,'' not ''Time Wasters.'' Because of an editing error, the column also misstated the position Mr. Gurnee held on Mr. Letterman's show in 1988, when the segment was introduced during the writers' strike that year. He was the director, not the producer.
What we’re reading elsewhere…

Not as swiftly as Paul Revere, but with no less determination, Francine Ravitz made her way along Madison Avenue on Tuesday, sounding the alarm from East 65th Street, where she and her husband live, all the way to 64th Street.At one stop, Mrs. Ravitz pulled an envelope from a bag hanging on her walker. She presented it to Karen McAdoo, the manager of the Morgane Le Fay women’s clothing store in the two-story building at Nos. 746-48. Inside was a “Dear Neighbor” letter from her husband, Robert J. Ravitz, a principal in the David J. Greene and Company investment company.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to strike a more conciliatory note with the Legislature in his annual address to lawmakers today — the first political step of the embattled governor’s second year in office. But lawmakers on both sides of the aisle remain wary and in many cases openly critical of the governor, and some fellow Democrats are troubled by reports he may propose imposing a ceiling on property-tax increases.

Updated, 2:41 p.m. | Judging from excerpts released this morning, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s second State of the State address this afternoon will strike a conciliatory tone and focus heavily on meat-and-potato issues like schools, property taxes and health insurance as he seeks to regain his political footing, turn attention away from the multiple and potentially crippling ethics investigations he still faces, and build the foundation for his second year in office.Such a speech would not be so different from Mr. Spitzer’s first such address a year ago, despite the decline in the governor’s fortunes since then. Mr. Spitzer’s first state of the state address mixed broad reform proposals unpopular with Albany lawmakers (campaign finance reform and non-partisan redistricting) with a large platter of proposals that offered something for everyone, whether more education spending for Democrats or worker’s compensation reform for Republicans.

How’s this for uncertainty? A majority of New York City voters — 52 percent — think Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would make a good president, and a nearly equal proportion believe it is likely that he will run, but only 16 percent would actually like him to do so, according to Quinnipiac University poll results released today.But perhaps because of dissatisfaction with Gov. Eliot Spitzer, whose poll numbers have plummeted, New York City voters would be far more enthusiastic if Mr. Bloomberg were to run for governor in 2010.

Putting New York City within the forefront of a growing movement to curb plastic bag use, the City Council overwhelmingly passed a sweeping measure today that would require stores to collect, transport and recycle the plastic bags they issue to customers.

Updated, 8 p.m. | Robert Vinci pointed at a spindly tree chart that laid out an evolutionary ancestry. It was not dissimilar, he said, to the hierarchical diagrams, known as cladograms, of dinosaur families that he used to work with at the American Museum of Natural History.Only this one laid out the elaborate ancestry of the Bank of America, stretching back to names now relegated to history, including Massachusetts Bank (founded 1784), the Providence Bank (founded in 1791), and, more recently, Fleet, and BayBank.

Officials at Columbia University were taken aback on Tuesday when the Mehr News Agency, a government-sponsored news outlet in Iran, reported online that a delegation of professors and deans planned to travel to Tehran to apologize for the behavior of Columbia’s president, Lee C. Bollinger, during the visit to New York by Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, last September.

The race for the Democratic presidential nomination, as it moves to Nevada and South Carolina, remains as unsettled as ever. Senator Barack Obama visited New Jersey and New York on Wednesday for a rally and a fund-raising event, while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton gave interviews from her home in Chappaqua, N.Y., in Westchester County. We took the occasion of their visits here to ask several self-identified Democrats in Harlem which candidate they supported and whether the results on Tuesday in New Hampshire had affected their decisions.

His intensity matched the soaring oratory and suddenly found voices of the presidential campaign season, but the Democratic mayor of Newark, Cory A. Booker, was thundering about local crime earlier today, and trying to convince 72 police department recruits — some looking dazed, and all the men with their heads shaved — that they were most important people in the world. In a previous post from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, we mentioned the aesthetic advantages of wireless technology. Now we're wondering if seeing wires might be a good thing. It's an idea that runs completely against the trends of technology and home design - and that's exactly why we were intrigued by the tiny booth of Shenzhen Kechenda Technology. This obscure Chinese company was showing a collection of HDMI cables (commonly used with high-fidelity TVs and DVDs) that have the same graphic impact as a pair of sneakers from A Bathing Ape. Our favorites were a glittery emerald and yellow HDMI, a glossy purple one that looks like a jump rope from the Eighties and a wonderfully baroque silver cord with flashy gold plugs. Hook these babies into your home theater and it'll be business in the front, party in the back.

Aired Tuesday night on NBC: I love how the government keeps telling us how the weather affects gasoline prices. For example, when the weather was rainy and cold, well, it takes more fuel to heat our homes. So of course the price of oil goes up. Then when it's sunny out, well, we take more vacations. We drive around. The price of oil goes up. In fact, the only time weather makes the price go down, I believe, is when it snows in hell.

Bean's Kingfield Sweater," which was the initial installment of a feature on chic, affordable goods. First of all, we goofed and published an incorrect image - the author, our fashion associate Melissa Ventosa Martin, liked the sweater in ivory, not the deep red color we showed. The correct color is shown here. [UPDATE: The sweater has sliver buttons, not a zippered neck; photo corrected.] Secondly, a couple of readers commented that they saw the L.L. Bean sweater and immediately thought: "blatant product placement advertising." We don't do that. The Times has a policy that keeps advertising separate from editorial content. There is not, however, a Times policy on stylishness - though there should be - so readers should feel free to blow the whistle when they've spotted a fashion violation. AIRPORTS: Barajas International Airport has won deserved renown for its vast, wavy-roofed Terminal 4, designed by award-winning architects Richard Rodgers and Antonio Lamela. Inaugurated in February 2006, the airy, luminous terminal is an impressive introduction to Madrid -- though confusing signs, long walks from gates and problems with the luggage sorting system have become familiar gripes among Madrileños. If you fly to Spain on Iberia airlines, you will probably have the good fortune to come to T4. Far less prepossessing are Terminals 1 to 3, which share many of the inadequacies that have become emblems of international air travel: dim lighting, grim cafés and endless construction. But they are functional, check-in and security lines are manageable and access to taxi ranks and the subway system is simple.

AIRPORTS: If you are like most of the people coming to Frankfurt, you are well on your way to going as well, which is to say you are changing flights at the mammoth Frankfurt International Airport. Most people at Frankfurt airport are transit passengers, but if you are not, then fear not: transportation into town is as good as anywhere in the world.
