A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about a musical based on Anne Frank’s diary, scheduled to open in Madrid next month, misstated the history of such musicals. There is at least one other, “Yours, Anne,” which was produced Off Broadway in 1985. The one in Madrid will not be the first.

A sports article on Saturday about the prospect of Roger Clemens testifying under oath before a Congressional committee misidentified the Texas town where he lives with his family. It is Piney Point Village on the west side of Houston — not Katy, a suburb farther to the west where he once lived. (The error has appeared in numerous articles and Sports of The Times columns in recent years.).

An obituary on Thursday about Salvatore (Bill) Bonanno, a member of the Bonanno crime family, and an article on Tuesday about his funeral in Tucson, referred incorrectly to his role in the publication of “Honor Thy Father,” a 1971 account of the Bonanno family by Gay Talese. Although Mr. Bonanno was extensively interviewed by Mr. Talese, he did not collaborate with him on the writing.

A Military Memo article on Monday, about the current relationship between the military and the news media, referred incorrectly to Rear Adm. Greg Smith, director of communications for the top military command in Iraq, who commented on coverage of the war. He is the first public affairs officer of such rank to hold this post; he is not the first one-star public affairs officer in Baghdad. (From mid-June to mid-November of 2004, a Navy Reserve officer, Rear Adm. Greg Slavonic, served in Baghdad and held that distinction.).
Hillary Rodham Clinton’s victory was a surprising show of strength after her loss in Iowa. John McCain reprised his 2000 primary win, beating Mitt Romney.
Registered Democrats and women solidly supported Hillary Rodham Clinton in her primary victory.
The Supreme Court can strike a blow for democracy by standing up for an obvious principle: that the right to vote cannot be taken away to serve the electoral purposes of a political party.
President Bush’s refusal to engage Iran diplomatically makes it hard for American officials to deconstruct Iran’s motives and increases the risk of future miscalculation on both sides.
The New Hampshire primary has done Americans a service by leaving both parties’ nominating contests open and giving voters a chance to weigh in on these important choices.

China will ban retailers from giving free plastic shopping bags to consumers starting in June to curb waste and reduce pollution. China’s cabinet, the State Council, calling the excessive use of plastic bags a “serious” waste of resources, also said it would ban production of ultra-thin plastic bags measuring less than 0.025 millimeter thick. Retailers will be able to sell plastic bags, but will have to clearly display the price and may not include the cost in the price of merchandise, the State Council said.
The G.O.P. battle now shifts to states where each leader believes he has advantages.
The battleground now shifts to states where each of the leaders believes he holds advantages.
In contrast to polling results in Iowa, Democratic women in New Hampshire rallied around Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

A 15-year-old Boy Scout foiled an assassination attempt on President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom, grabbing a man’s knife as he leapt from a crowd and lunged at the leader, a government spokesman said. The president was unhurt, although the knife ripped his shirt. No motive was given. The boy, in his scout uniform for the event on the northern island of Hoarafushi, suffered a hand injury.

Sohail Qureshi, a London dental technician who was arrested at Heathrow Airport in 2006 boarding a flight to Pakistan, was sentenced to four and a half years in prison in the first conviction under a new law against planning terrorism. The prosecutor said Mr. Qureshi, originally from Pakistan, planned a “two- to three-week operation” either in Pakistan or Afghanistan, possibly against Western troops. He was carrying nearly $18,000, a telescopic night sight and a computer hard drive loaded with militant Islamic tracts, the court was told. Prosecutors said that he had trained with jihadist groups in Pakistan linked to Al Qaeda and that his skills included encrypting e-mail messages. The court was also told of e-mail exchanges he had with Samina Malik, known as the “lyrical terrorist,” who received a suspended sentence in November for keeping a library of terrorist material. Ms. Malik, a clerk at a Heathrow newsstand who wrote poetry limning her passion for Islamic militancy, received an e-mail message from Mr. Qureshi asking about security arrangements at Heathrow. According to the prosecution, she replied, “The airport security is as tight as ever.”.

The State Council, China’s cabinet, banned the production of thin plastic bags and will forbid China’s supermarkets to offer them free beginning June 1, saying they cause pollution and waste resources. The council said shoppers should return to using cloth bags. The Chinese use up to three billion plastic bags a day and the country has to refine 37 million barrels of crude oil every year to make plastics used for packaging, according to a report on the Web site of China Trade News.

Pojaman Shinawatra, the wife of the ousted prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, returned to Thailand to fight corruption charges. She was met by the police after her flight arrived from Hong Kong, arrested, quickly released on bail, and ordered not to leave the country. Analysts said her return — the couple have been living mostly in London and Hong Kong since a military coup in 2006 — signaled confidence that the political situation, still unsettled after a victory by Mr. Thaksin’s allies in elections last month, would turn in their favor once a new government has been formed. Noppadol Pattama, a lawyer for the family, said Monday that Mr. Thaksin planned to return by mid-April. He is charged in the same cases as his wife, charges brought by the generals who carried out the coup.

Bilawal Bhutto Zardari, the 19-year-old son of Benazir Bhutto, Pakistan’s assassinated opposition leader, said at a news conference in London that the United States would have to stop “supporting dictators” in Pakistan for Islamic extremism to be defeated there. Returning to Britain from Pakistan two weeks after his mother’s death to resume his first-year studies at Oxford, he gave a battery of feisty answers to reporters who questioned the Pakistan Peoples Party’s decision to pick him as his mother’s successor as party chairman. To a reporter who suggested he had been appointed to the post “like a piece of family furniture,” he said he had not sought it, but added, “It was recognized at this moment in crisis the party needed a close association with my mother through the bloodline.” Asked if he feared for his life, he replied: “How many Bhuttos can you kill? From every house a Bhutto will come.” Noting that the party had selected his father, Asif Ali Zardari, as the party’s co-chairman until he finishes his university degree, he said he would step “gradually and carefully” into politics. He renewed the family’s demands for a United Nations inquiry into his mother’s death and spoke out against American support for the generals who have ruled Pakistan for more than half its 60-year existence. “The problem is that dictatorships breed extremism, and once the U.S. stops supporting dictators, we can successfully tackle extremists,” he said.

Prime Minister Romano Prodi announced emergency measures to deal with Naples’ mounting garbage crisis, including three new incinerators, a special garbage czar, and an attempt to get other regions to volunteer to take the trash. The northern Valle d’Aosta offered to help, reports said.
As the Knicks prepared to play the Chicago Bulls Tuesday night, Isiah Thomas talked about why he keeps plugging away as coach, despite the losing, the stress and the “Fire Isiah” chants.

A woman accused of leaving her children with little food and no money while she traveled to Nigeria to marry a man she met on the Internet has been charged with child endangerment and child abandonment.
The Energy Department is cutting operations at the desert site where the government plans to build a national nuclear waste repository.
A group of prisoners filed a class-action lawsuit contending that corrections officers have systematically beaten restrained inmates in prisons throughout Georgia.
The Bush administration has dropped its appeal of a 2007 court decision that overturned new management rules for 191 million acres of national forests.

President Bush signed legislation intended to prevent the severely mentally ill from buying guns, in a rare bipartisan agreement with the Democratic-led Congress after the shooting massacre last April at Virginia Tech.
James E. Cayne ended his tumultuous 14-year run as chief executive of the battered Bear Stearns, passing the baton to Alan D. Schwartz.

New Jersey’s former boxing commissioner is suing the state’s attorney general, Anne Milgram, claiming that she ousted him for exposing errors by a subordinate. The former commissioner, Larry Hazzard Sr., filed a whistle-blower protection lawsuit against Ms. Milgram and others in Federal District Court on Friday. Mr. Hazzard, a former boxer and referee, was commissioner of the State Athletic Control Board from 1986 until he was fired in November. The board oversees boxing in Atlantic City, one of a handful of cities where big prizefights are often fought. A spokesman for the attorney general declined to comment on Tuesday.

A city police officer shot and wounded a man during an attempt to stop the man’s car on Tuesday morning, the police said. The officer fired three times as he and his partner struggled with the driver, who continued driving, the police said. Both officers, who were working as part of a plainclothes unit, saw the car being driven erratically, stopped it and approached on foot, the police said. The driver sped away and the officers followed in their car, the police said. At West Kingsbridge Road and Aqueduct Avenue about 11:33 a.m., the officers again approached the suspect’s car on foot, and the struggle ensued, the police said. Both officers, who were not identified, were slightly injured, the police said. The suspect, who was not identified, suffered a gunshot wound to his leg and was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, the officials said.

A former computer administrator at Medco Health Solutions was sentenced on Tuesday in Federal District Court to 30 months in prison for tampering with the company’s computer systems. The administrator, Yung-Hsun Lin of Montville, pleaded guilty in September to one count of transmitting computer code with the intent of causing damage in excess of $5,000. The prosecutors said Mr. Lin was angry at the possibility of losing his job. The tampering, aimed at a database used by pharmacists to track potential drug interactions, failed to work because of a programming error.

A homeless man who had been taken in by a Queens family pleaded guilty on Tuesday to charges that he fatally stabbed a family member during a botched burglary attempt, the prosecutors said. The man, Emmanuel Polanco, 22, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to manslaughter in the stabbing of David Higgins, 19, on Oct. 30, 2006, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Polanco previously stayed at Mr. Higgins’s home in Hillcrest, and later attacked Mr. Higgins when he came home and found Mr. Polanco burglarizing the residence, the prosecutors said. Mr. Polanco was also charged with beating Mr. Higgins’s mother with a bat when she arrived a short time later. He faces 30 years in prison when he is sentenced next month, the prosecutors said.

An undetected break in a section of rail jarred a CSX train from its tracks last year just outside Oneida, triggering an explosion of four liquid propane tankers, a federal report said on Tuesday. The explosion on March 12 forced the evacuation of 200 residents and temporarily shut down the New York State Thruway, according to the Federal Railroad Administration’s report. There were no injuries. The administration said that the crew had been operating the 80-car train in compliance with federal standards and that the track had been inspected and tested regularly. Inspectors determined that the rail was broken before the train passed over it.
For more than three decades, Mr. Vrinat was the owner of the Taillevent restaurant in Paris, which is regarded by many as the pinnacle of elegance in French cuisine.
Corporations and shoppers in the United States spent more than $54 million in 2007 on carbon offset credits, but where exactly is that money going?

A body found in a backyard cesspool in Mastic Beach has been identified as that of a man who has been missing for nearly 19 months, and a former tenant was charged on Tuesday with murder in the death, a Suffolk County police detective said. The tenant, Jaime Rosario, 38, a nursery worker from Center Moriches, pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree murder and was ordered held without bail at his arraignment in Suffolk County’s First District Court. Mr. Rosario had been renting a room for $100 a week from the victim, Nicolo Caietta, 59, in his Mastic Beach home, Detective Sgt. Edward Fandrey said. He said Mr. Rosario was accused of beating Mr. Caietta to death with a baseball bat in May 2006, dumping his body in the cesspool and stealing $800 that Mr. Caietta had withdrawn from the bank to buy a counterfeit driver’s license. The body was found on Saturday when officers excavated the cesspool behind Mr. Caietta’s house, at 275 Forest Road West.
A new JPMorgan Chase campaign aims to overcome cluttered airwaves, nervous customers and cuts in marketing budgets.
Failing to raise the $14 billion needed to bid in government auctions of wireless spectrum later this month, Frontline Wireless has left.
Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger on Tuesday proposed amending the California Constitution to give governors new budgetary powers.
Nathaniel Travers, who operated last year in Afghanistan, said Tuesday that his comrades appeared to have needlessly killed civilians after their convoy was attacked by a suicide car bomb.
For all the complex leaps of financial logic needed to grasp Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s plan to leverage New Jersey’s toll roads, several crucial components remain unchanged.
Savannah State set N.C.A.A. records for fewest points and worst field-goal percentage in a half in the shot-clock era in a 85-25 loss to Kansas State Monday night.
Silver Lake, the largest technology-focused private equity firm, has reached a deal to sell a 9.9 percent stake to the California Public Employees’ Retirement System.
Texas District Attorney Charles A. Rosenthal Jr. faced questions about hundreds office of E-Mail messages containing racy jokes, racial slurs and political campaign materials.
A longtime friend and former teammate of Roger Clemens, Andy Pettitte may be asked questions regarding Clemens’s possible use of steroids before a Congressional committee.
The other big winner in Monday night’s national title game was the SEC, which reaffirmed its status as the best league in college football.
The McGraw-Hill Companies said  it was cutting 611 jobs, or 3 percent of its staff, and taking an after-tax charge of $27.3 million, or 8 cents a share, in the fourth quarter.
Badly bruised by the sharp downturn in the housing market, Citigroup is bringing its mortgage-related activities under one roof.

The New Mexico State freshman Herb Pope waived his right to a preliminary hearing on a drunken driving charge filed by police officers who said they found Pope passed out in a running car on a western Pennsylvania highway. The decision to waive Tuesday’s hearing means Pope will be scheduled to stand trial in Allegheny County Common Pleas Court. Officers found Pope, 19, unresponsive in the driver’s seat with the engine running in the Pittsburgh suburb of Moon Township on Dec. 28. Pope, a heralded recruit, had been academically ineligible at New Mexico State until a New Mexico judge ordered an end to the N.C.A.A. ban based on an alternative-education program he took in high school.

The wife of Arizona Coach Lute Olson filed a court challenge to his attempt to divorce her. The petition said Christine Olson “denies the marriage is irretrievably broken” and “remains committed to preserving the marital relationship.” The petition was filed in Pima County Superior Court in Arizona last Friday and seeks marital counseling. Olson, a 73-year-old Hall of Fame coach, filed for divorce Dec. 6, the same day he announced his leave of absence would be extended for the rest of this season. He began his leave for unspecified personal reasons Nov. 4, shortly before he was to have opened his 25th season at Arizona.Christine Jack Olson, 50, is a prominent business executive and a member of the Republican National Committee from Pennsylvania. She married Olson in 2003 and is Olson’s second wife. His wife of 47 years, Bobbie, died of ovarian cancer in 2001.

Fordham punter Benjamin Dato and linebacker Earl Hudnell, both seniors, were named Football Championship Subdivision All-Americans by the Sports Network. Dato was named to the first team and Hudnell was an honorable mention.

A group of Seattle women, led by the former deputy mayor Anne Levinson, will buy the Seattle Storm of the W.N.B.A. from the SuperSonics’ owner, Clay Bennett, for $10 million. The purchase option for the franchise was completed in the last few days, ensuring the Storm would remain in Seattle, while Bennett continues his push to move the SuperSonics to his hometown of Oklahoma City. The group, calling itself Force 10 Hoops, has until the end of February to close the sale and would need approval from the W.N.B.A. Board of Governors.
When Hillary Rodham Clinton choked up in New Hampshire, she prompted one of the most debated moments of the campaign.
There is no better place to absorb New Hampshire on Primary Day than on Elm Street, the main thoroughfare in downtown Manchester.
Shares tumbled late in the day after AT&T’s chief  suggested consumers might be cutting back and Countrywide Financial denied it was tumbling into bankruptcy.
Reflecting a highly uncertain and divided outlook on monetary policy, regional Federal Reserve banks supported three options for the discount rate last month.
Barclays Capital said its co-president, Grant Kvalheim, had resigned and would leave at the end of the first quarter.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to strike a more conciliatory note with the Legislature in his annual address to lawmakers on Wednesday.
Pending home sales dipped in November, a trade group for real estate agents said, but the association expects sales to pick up in the second half of 2008.

European retail sales fell the most in at least 10 years in November as rising food and energy costs sapped consumer confidence. Retail sales declined 1.4 percent in November from a year ago, the biggest drop since at least 1997, the European Union’s statistics office in Luxembourg said. From the previous month, sales fell 0.5 percent, the third decline in four months. Higher gasoline and food costs are eroding purchasing power in the euro area and restraining spending even as unemployment falls to a record low.
The Pentagon also released video showing Iranian speedboats maneuvering around the American convoy.

Manufacturing orders in Germany unexpectedly surged for a second month in November as domestic companies increased spending on goods such as factory machinery. Orders, adjusted for seasonal swings and inflation, gained 3.4 percent from October, when they rose 4 percent, the Economics and Technology Ministry said. Domestic orders rose 4.2 percent from October and export sales increased 2.8 percent. Orders from the euro area gained 6.8 percent, the report showed. Capital goods orders rose 3.6 percent and sales of intermediate goods advanced 4.3 percent, while demand for consumer goods slid 1.1 percent.

A. P. Moeller-Maersk, the world’s largest ocean cargo carrier, will cut as many as 3,000 jobs in the container division after the unit posted a loss in 2006 for the first time in at least three years. The division, Maersk Line, will reduce its 25,000-member work force by 2,000 to 3,000 people, or as much as 12 percent, the company said. Maersk Line, which owns more than 500 vessels that carry 1.7 million containers, posted a $568 million loss in 2006, its first since Maersk began breaking out division figures in 2003. Moeller-Maersk is based in Copenhagen.

Alliant Techsystems, a maker of weapons and space systems, said it had agreed to buy a unit of MacDonald, Dettwiler & Associates for 1.33 billion Canadian dollars ($1.34 billion) to build complete satellite systems. Alliant agreed to buy MacDonald’s information systems and geospatial information services group in its biggest acquisition ever and its first outside the United States, said Alliant’s chief executive, Daniel Murphy. The purchase will be complete by the end of March and will add to Alliant’s profit starting in the 2010 fiscal year. Alliant, based in Edina, Minn., will be able to build and operate full satellite systems as sales slow in its main business, supplying bullets to the United States Army. MacDonald is based in Richmond, British Columbia.
Shares of the Countrywide Financial Corporation plunged 28.4 percent after it denied rumors that it was planning to file for bankruptcy protection.
In the aftermath of last summer’s grisly home invasion in which a mother and her daughters were killed, Gov. M. Jodi Rell proposed measures intended to bolster Connecticut’s criminal justice system.
Some prominent advertisers have pulled their sponsorships for NBC’s strike-subdued Golden Globes coverage, media buyers said.
After dealing with health problems, fractured relationships and homelessness, Sylvia Harris now has relative peace of mind and a successful career as a jockey.
Michael Adams, the president of the University of Georgia, said he would use his position as the chair of the N.C.A.A.’s executive committee to push for an eight-team playoff.

Constellation Brands, the wine and spirits company, said on Tuesday that third-quarter profit rose 11 percent, lifted by strong liquor sales, a growing wine business in North America and the acquisition of Svedka vodka.
A woman eating lunch at an Arby’s fast-food restaurant in Queens was killed on Tuesday when a van crashed through the front of the restaurant.
The San Francisco 49ers hired Mike Martz as their offensive coordinator Tuesday, landing one of the N.F.L.’s top offensive minds to fix a unit that floundered last season.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine argued Monday to drastically increase highway tolls over the next 15 years to help the state pay off half of its debt and finance transportation improvements.
Brian Gionta and Patrik Elias scored in a shootout Tuesday night to lift the Devils to a 2-1 victory over the visiting Buffalo Sabres.
The Federal Communications Commission will investigate whether Comcast is interfering with its subscribers’ attempts to use a popular online file-sharing program.
Jason Richardson scored 25 points and the hot-shooting Charlotte Bobcats overcame Jason Kidd’s third consecutive triple-double to beat the Nets on Tuesday night.
American commanders believe it is essential to hobble the extremists in order to sustain recent security gains and ultimately pacify Iraq.
A plan is being developed to alleviate the growing pressure from pedestrian and vehicle traffic in Times Square.
After three years of litigation, two groups denied permits to use the lawn for antiwar demonstrations have won their case against the city.
At 7 feet 7 inches and 360 pounds, some things come easily on the court for North Carolina-Asheville center Kenny George. But such size does bring serious drawbacks.
Warren Buffett’s new firm, Berkshire Hathaway Assurance Corporation, takes its first steps into the bond insurance market.
Thousands of mourners gathered on Tuesday to say farewell to Lt. John H. Martinson who lost his life last  week in a smoky Brooklyn blaze.
Unusual January tornadoes swept through Arkansas, Illinois, Missouri and Wisconsin, which recorded its first January twister since 1967.
Individuals and companies who wish to buy detectors to warn them of a biological, chemical or radioactive attack may require a city permit to do so.
A perilous spot for surfers off the coast of Southern California had been surfed only a handful of times in the past decade. Four of the most experienced big-wave surfers in the world were not fazed.
Work was halted in August after two firefighters died fighting a blaze in the contaminated tower.
FairPoint Communications reached an agreement with the Vermont Public Service Department that would allow it to buy Verizon phone lines in the state.
The attack was the latest challenge for the United Nations force, which has been heralded as having the ability to quell the violence in Darfur.
The snub opens the way for the parent of the nation’s largest carrier, Air China, to make an offer of its own.
Three Americans were part of a well-armed gang that waged a gun battle with soldiers and police officers in Rio Bravo on Monday, Mexican authorities said.
The oldest affiliate of Habitat for Humanity International has filed suit to protest a new agreement that the nonprofit housing organization is imposing on its 1,600 local chapters.
Christmas ends late in Dyker Heights, land of the 20-foot snowman, but eventually it’s time to pull the plug on those elaborate holiday lawn decorations.
Methamphetamine-laced Ecstasy is flowing across the Canadian border into the United States.
The new principal, Holly Anne Reichert, 42, has a "working knowledge"of Arabic and has worked in the city public schools for more than nine years.
Microsoft’s $1.2 billion bid for a Norwegian search software company is seen as an effort to add tools to its lucrative Office products and fend off Google.
KB Home, the large home builder, said that its fourth-quarter loss swelled as the housing slowdown led to fewer sales and lower revenue.
It’s a casino in a trailer on an empty lot, set up  for the sole purpose of retaining the valuable zoning designation needed to conduct wagering.
Ms. Stodelle had a multifaceted career in modern dance as a performer, author and teacher.
A federal magistrate has ordered the White House to reveal whether copies of missing e-mail messages concerning the disclosure of the name of a C.I.A. operative are stored in computer backup files.
Ogilvy & Mather has leased an 11-story building on Manhattan’s far west side, becoming one of the first corporate tenants to embrace the neighborhood.
The government blamed Tamil rebels for the assassination, the first of a top Sri Lankan official in 19 months.
The City University of New York School of Law has launched program for it’s graduates that teaches them how to run a business.
Sharpe  James will be tried alone on improper credit card charges, and in a second trial with a businesswoman whom prosecutors say was his companion, on land fraud charges.
Amazon.com, the world’s largest online retailer, will soon finally have one place to call home.
The oldest affiliate of Habitat for Humanity has filed suit to protest an agreement that the nonprofit housing organization is imposing on its 1,600 local chapters.
Three days after Ray Rice ran for a school-record 280 yards in the International Bowl, Rutgers said Tuesday that he would forgo his final year of eligibility to enter the 2008 N.F.L. draft.
An off-duty Miami police detective was shot and killed early Tuesday morning, and the authorities speculated that he may have stumbled on a drug transaction in progress.
Looking ahead, America needs a military centered not on occupying another country but on denying potential adversaries the ability to attack our interests.
Sderot, Israel, a working-class town less than two miles from Gaza, has been repeatedly hit with rockets.

Taylor Hicks, below, the 2006 winner of “American Idol,” has followed Ruben Studdard, the 2003 winner, out the door of J Records, The Associated Press reported. “Taylor is going to record on his own for the next album,” said Liz Morentin, a public relations representative for J, a label within Sony-BMG. Mr. Studdard left his contract with the label late last year but remains under contract with 19 Entertainment, a company managed by Simon Fuller, creator of “Idol.” Mr. Studdard’s last album, “The Return,” sold only 236,000 copies. Mr. Hicks’s self-titled album, released in December 2006, reached No. 2 on the Billboard chart and sold 699,000 copies, failing to reach the million mark achieved by the debuts of previous “Idol” winners, Nielsen SounScan reported.

Oh, that James Bond. Sometimes it’s just about impossible to keep up with him and his women. A day after announcing that the British actress Gemma Arterton will be the new “Bond girl,” Reuters revised its call, reporting that 007’s sidekick will be the Ukrainian actress Olga Kurylenko. The news agency, citing “a source close to the film,” said that although Ms. Arterton has a role in the forthcoming film, it is not as extensive as that of Ms. Kurylenko, above, a former model seen recently in “Hitman.”.
Michael Govan considers Eli Broad’s decision to keep his art collection in a private foundation to be a positive development.

The Directors Guild of America has announced its nominees for directorial achievement in feature film: Paul Thomas Anderson for “There Will Be Blood,” Joel and Ethan Coen for “No Country for Old Men,” Tony Gilroy for “Michael Clayton,” Sean Penn for “Into the Wild” and Julian Schnabel for “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.” The winner will be announced on Jan. 26. ... The Oscar-winning actress Nicole Kidman and her husband, the country singer Keith Urban, are expecting a baby, Reuters reported. The birth is expected in mid-2008.

The pay-what-you-choose initiative begun by the British art-rock band Radiohead has crossed over to the realm of classical music. The British violinist Tasmin Little plans to offer her next recording, “The Naked Violin,” free as a digital download in an effort to popularize such music, Reuters reported. “Just the fact that people can listen to it on a computer means that hopefully they won’t feel a need to have an education or be from a particular background or a certain sector of society,” she said. The album, featuring three pieces for unaccompanied violin and a commentary from Ms. Little, will be available on Monday from tasminlittle.net.

“Dance War,” a spinoff of ABC’s popular series “Dancing With the Stars,” attracted only modest interest in the ratings on Monday, drawing 11 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., Nielsen estimated. Among adults 18 to 49, the reality competition between the choreographers Bruno Tonioli and Carrie Ann Inaba earned about half the ratings of the most recent premiere of “Dancing With the Stars” in September. The dancers also fell well short of NBC’s “American Gladiators” during the 8 p.m. hour. That new reality show, despite drawing just 10.9 million total viewers, would have led the night among the 18-to-49 set but for Fox’s football coverage, the Bowl Championship Series, which averaged more than 20 million viewers total. NBC ranked second for the night behind Fox, earning solid numbers from “Deal or No Deal” at 9 (10.7 million) and the premiere of the fourth season of “Medium” at 10 (9.6 million). ABC’s “October Road” drew a disappointing five million viewers at 10.

For the first time since television’s late-night shows returned to the air last week, David Letterman was able to nose out Jay Leno in the ratings. It was just for one show, Monday night, and Mr. Letterman’s lead was not sizable, but Mr. Leno had won the first three nights. Their competition resumed last Wednesday, when most of the late-night hosts came back after supporting the writers’ strike for two months. Mr. Leno is working without his writing staff, which is still on strike against his “Tonight Show” on NBC, while Mr. Letterman, above, was able to return with writers to his CBS show because of a separate deal his production company made with the Writers Guild of America. Mr. Letterman has also been able to book the normal roster of movie-star guests; on Monday night he had Tom Hanks, while Mr. Leno had the upstart Republican presidential candidate Ron Paul. In the overnight ratings, measuring the country’s 65 largest cities, Mr. Letterman had a 4 rating on Monday to Mr. Leno’s 3.8. (Each point is worth 787,659 households.) But in their shows’ first half-hour, when Mr. Leno is performing a monologue over the opposition of the writers’ guild, he still beat Mr. Letterman, with a 4.5 rating to a 4.3. CBS’s thin victory margin continued on the 12:35 a.m. shows, where Craig Ferguson enjoyed a rare ratings victory over NBC’s Conan O’Brien, with a 1.9 rating to a 1.8 for Mr. O’Brien.

Alycia Lane has been dismissed by KYW-TV, the CBS-owned station in Philadelphia, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lane, 35, was arrested in Manhattan on Dec. 16 and arraigned on a felony charge of assaulting a police officer. The police said she punched an officer in the face, and a police complaint said she used a sexual slur. Ms. Lane has denied the charges. She had been off the air since the incident and had been scheduled to return on Monday. But in a statement that day, the station said she “has been released from her contract effective immediately.” Ms. Lane was previously the subject of reports that she had e-mailed images of herself in a bikini to a married ESPN sports anchor. Michael Colleran, the president and general manager of KYW-TV, said, “After assessing the overall impact of a series of incidents resulting from judgments she has made, we have concluded that it would be impossible for Alycia to continue to report the news as she herself has become the focus of so many news stories.” In a statement, Paul Rosen, Ms. Lane’s lawyer, declared the termination to be contrary to the terms of her contract.
Robyn O’Brien has looked deep into the perplexing world of childhood food allergies and seen a conspiracy.
To the Editor:.
Jon Stewart’s return on “The Daily Show” was a jarring display of solipsism from a performer famous for tweaking the vanity of others.
Lorin Maazel conducted a lucidly textured, rhythmically incisive and strongly conceived account of this touchstone opera.
He has been a Yugoslav and a Serb and worked under  Tito and Milosevic. So it makes  sense that the place where Goran Paskaljevic really likes to work is Ireland.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
Joe Gibbs, who twice built the Washington Redskins into a playoff team, ended his toughest season as a coach by retiring for a second time.
To the Editor:.
Zarah Ghahramani’s rage at the Iranian government was a matter of personal style as much as of principle.

Private clinics in Spain, which perform most of the country’s abortions, began a five-day strike on Tuesday to protest what they said was persecution by anti-choice activists and government inspectors.
Rich Gossage was elected in his ninth year on the ballot while Jim Rice, Andre Dawson and Mark McGwire, a slugger who has been suspected of using steroids, fell short.
Should a motorcade be allocated to Carla Bruni, the girlfriend and possible fiancée of the French president?
Depending on how you look at it, “Three Lost Chords” is a single work in three loosely related acts, or three short, single-character operas yoked together.
A mother makes the gently spiced foods of Iran, rife with cheese, fresh aromatic herbs, nuts and fruit.
Doctors struggled to stabilize the health of former President Suharto of Indonesia after a setback in which there were new signs of internal bleeding and fluid in his lungs.
Distilled Apples.
Now that maki rolls rule American sushi bars, chefs are seeing nori as more than something to wrap fish in.
Donatella Arpaia and Michael Psilakis will open Mia Dona on the Upper East Side, Dani on Hudson Square closes, and more.
Clafoutis, a classic French dessert most often made with cherries, gets a citrusy makeover.
A decision by minority shareholders of China Eastern to reject a tie-up with Singapore Airlines and a Singapore government investor has set the stage for an unusual corporate battle in China.
The Israeli and Palestinian leaders authorized the start of negotiations on the sensitive core issues of the conflict.
The romance between President Nicolas Sarkozy and the Italian singer Carla Bruni has intrigued France.
The wife of the ousted Thai prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra returned from exile Tuesday to face charges of corruption.

MOORHEAD--Clare Fahnestock, 80 years old, died of heart failure on January 7, 2008. Architect, Conservationist, tireless supporter of small museums worldwide. She is survived by son Jay Moorhead, daughter Peggy Williams, sister Lee Leggett, and grandchildren Hayden, Katherine, Dolly and Quellie. Born in NYC, childhood spent in New York, Newport, RI, and Washington, D.C. She attended the Chapin, Potomac, and St. Timothy's schools and later graduated cum laude from Bryn Mawr College. She is remembered for her devotion to family, strength of character, and passion for volunteer and environmental causes. A childhood diabetic, she fought the disease throughout her life, only recently suffering from its debilitating encroachment. A memorial service will be held at St. Thomas Episcopal Church Friday, January 11, at 10:30am. TRAININ--Isaac N. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Rabbi Isaac N. Trainin, a treasured friend and esteemed colleague whose devotion to the field of Jewish communal service for 60 years, 55 of them at UJA-Federation, has left an indelible legacy. Among Ike's many accomplishments, he was instrumental in founding the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty, the Jewish Community Relations Council of New York, the Coordinating Council on Bikur Cholim, and organizing the Jewish Alcoholics, and Chemically Dependent Persons, and Significant Others (JACS) program. Both as our house rabbi and through his deep caring and commitment to our agency network, Ike's vision for the Jewish people continues to inspire and guide us today. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Ike's wife, Frances; his son, Eugene; his daughter, Barbara and her husband, Stephen Blank; to his grandchildren; to his great-grandchildren; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. TRAININ--Rabbi Isaac N. The Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services and its Rabbi Isaac N. Trainin Bikur Cholim Coordinating Council grieve the loss of Rabbi Isaac N. Trainin, the founder and long-time Director of BCCC named in his honor. Rabbi Trainin was a visionary Jewish communal service professional whose passion for righting wrongs and refusal to accept no for an answer helped the Jewish community address such issues as poverty, substance abuse, and conditions surrounding those who are ill or isolated. Rabbi Trainin was instrumental in the creation of JACS, another JBFCS program. He was a doer who inspired and expected others to do the same. He has left a rich legacy and will be sorely missed. John A Herrmann, President Joseph S. Kaplan and Jean L. Troubh, Co-chairs of the Board Paul Levine, Executive Vice President and CEO

The University of Hawaii fired Athletic Director Herman Frazier on Tuesday after he failed to re-sign the football coach June Jones. In a statement, the university said the move was made ''in the best interest of the athletics program.'' It came a day after Jones accepted a five-year deal to coach at Southern Methoidist.

A woman died after being shot and stabbed and her live-in companion was found with gunshot wounds and a gun in his hand on Monday at their home, the police said on Tuesday. The woman, identified as Maribel Hernandez, 26, died from her gunshot and stab wounds and the man was found with a pistol in his hand at their home, at 1392 Madison Street, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said. The man was taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center in critical condition, the police said. Four children who also lived at the home saw the two adults argue but not the violence that led to the death and injuries, Mr. Kelly said. The children, ages 6, 3, 2 and 1, have been placed with the city's Administration for Children's Services, said Sheila Stainback, a spokeswoman.

BUSCH--Mary E., was born December 30, 1917 and raised in Brooklyn, NY, the only child of John F. McKenna, the owner of the McKenna Lumber Company and President of the old Kingsboro Savings Bank, and his wife, the former Elizabeth Farrell. She attended St. Anselm's School in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and then Marymount Academy and Marymount College in Tarrytown, NY. She possessed rare artistic talent, being able to paint well in watercolor, pastel, and charcoal. She was married in 1941 to James B. Donovan, a New York attorney, who negotiated successfully in 1962 for the release of U-2 pilot Francis Gary Powers from the Soviet Union and of the 1,350 Bay of Pigs prisoners from Cuba. They lived in Bay Ridge and then Park Slope, Brooklyn until Mr. Donovan died in 1970, often vacationing at the Lake Placid Club in the Adirondacks. In 1972, she married Navy Capt. Thomas O'Connor, an executive at the old New York Telephone Company, and they were together until his death in 1984, living in Spring Lake, New Jersey, where they belonged to the Spring Lake Bath and Tennis Club and the Spring Lake Golf Club. In 1986, she was married to Herbert H. Busch, a retired jewelry and real estate executive, and they were together in Spring Lake until his death in 1995. Survivors include two daughters, Jan (Mrs. Edward L.) Amorosi, of Manhattan; Mary Ellen Fuller (Mrs. David Fletcher), of South Carolina; and a son, John B. Donovan, of Larchmont, NY; a stepdaughter Georgia B. (Mrs. Foster) Nostrand, of Stamford, CT, a stepson, Roger L. Busch, of Greenwich, CT; seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Visiting will be held Thursday 2 to 4 pm and 7 to 9 pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Friday, 12 Noon at St. Anselm R.C. Church, Brooklyn. Interment to follow at St. Agnes Cemetery, Lake Placid, NY.

For the last few years there's been a deluge of seasoning oils tricked up with chemicals and called white truffle oil. But now there is a pleasant, more authentic alternative. Rosario Safina, who has been in the truffle business for many years, has developed a white truffle oil using delicate organic Italian extra virgin olive oil with bits of white truffle and extracted essences of truffle, called ''truffle flavor'' on the label. There's a whiff of honest white truffle aroma and a subtle flavor of truffles. ''I could make it stronger,'' Mr. Safina said. ''It would just take more truffles and much more money.''

9 P.M. (Sci Fi) GHOST HUNTERS INTERNATIONAL A crew of paranormal investigators applies its weird science to some of Europe's most infamous haunted locations in this ''Ghost Hunters'' spinoff. First: explorations of Chillingham Castle, billed as ''the most haunted castle in England,'' and Mary King's Close, an underground warren of vaults and tunnels that housed the destitute in 19th-century Scotland. The world travelers include the veteran sleuths Robb Demarest, Andy Andrews, Brian Harnois, Donna LaCroix (above, at Chillingham) and Barry Fitzgerald, as well as a newcomer, Shannon Sylvia. In ''Ghost Hunters: Return to St. Augustine Lighthouse,'' at 8, the original Taps squad performs another investigation on the historical St. Augustine Lighthouse in Florida.

FEERICK--Raymond J., 65, BS, MA, is remembered by a grateful community. Generations of Saint David's School boys, their parents and his colleagues will remember Mr. Feerick as a man of deep faith, loyalty, subtle humor, and admirable intellect. He was an educator of incredible compassion and unyielding kindness who served with the highest levels of distinction from September 1967 until his death, December 22, 2007. Mr. Feerick began his distinguished career at Saint David's School, NYC, as a teacher, later serving as Head of Middle School and more recently as Chair of Religion and Assistant to the Headmaster. As keeper of the school's most important traditions, Raymond Feerick represented and defined, in word and deed, the very essence of the mission of the School. He was patriarchal, a teacher of teachers, humble and wise. We will miss him deeply. We believe that Ray is now in the great house of our Father--his suffering done, fully prepared for his new life. We hold his family, especially daughters Abby and Hillary, in our prayers.

Looking at these exquisite scarlet plum-size strawberries gave me a Snow White moment. Would I slip into a magical coma after just one bite? Unlike a lot of picture-perfect fruit, including giant strawberries, these Amaou strawberries (pronounced ah-ma-oh), flown in from Japan, offer a heady perfume and an uncommon depth of rich flavor in each juicy mouthful. They are grown in greenhouses in Fukuoka Prefecture in southern Japan. Their name is a kind of acronym for red (akai), round (marui), big (ookii) and delicious (umai). The plants are pruned to encourage the largest berries, which are then tended so they do not touch the ground. But such care comes at a price. The berries, which arrive on Thursdays or Fridays until late February, are $43 for a box of 7 to 12, depending on the weight, at Butterfield Market, 1114 Lexington Avenue (78th Street), (212) 288-7800.

Salvatore Bklyn Ricotta sounds tough, but it's actually a delicacy, from the kitchens of Lunetta in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. Betsy Devine, far left, a sous-chef at the restaurant, and Rachel Mark, near left, who works for a wine importer, learned the craft in Tuscany from Salvatore Farina, who makes it for his wine bar in San Gimignano. His recipe uses only whey, but their version of it mixes local cow's milk with some whey. Ms. Devine heats the milk, curdles it with lemon juice and drains it for a few hours. The result is light but has a mouth-filling creaminess, more like fromage blanc than ricotta, with a hint of salt and acidity to enhance its sweetness. Adam Shephard, Lunetta's chef, uses it in dishes in both his Brooklyn and Manhattan restaurants, often on toast with honey.

BOARDMAN--Cantor Joseph, 84, of Charlottesville, VA, died at home January 7, 2008. Born in Brooklyn, NY, on June 27, 1923, Joe was the son of the late Harry and Rose Boardman. He was preceded in death by sisters, Beatrice and Mildred, and brothers, Cy and Nathan Boardman. Joe received his Masters Degree in Sacred Music from Hebrew Union College and was invested as a Cantor in 1963. He served as the Cantor for Huntington Beach Congregation before becoming the founding Cantor with Rabbi Jack Stern at Westchester Reform Temple in the late 1960s. Cantor Boardman retired from Westchester Reform Temple in 1988. Joe enjoyed many roles including tennis professional at Kutcher's Country Club, singing opera in Europe after studying on a Fulbright Scholarship, mastery of eight languages, distinguished service in World War II in India as an entertainment specialist, basketball at City College, gourmet cooking and yearly travel to Italy. Joe is survived by his widow, Dr. Sharon L. Hostler of Charlottesville, VA; his stepchildren: Kathleen Dimock and Dylan Dimock. Also, nieces Leslie Defren Gussin of Great Neck, NY; Fran Defren of Boston, MA; Shira Boardman of Los Angeles, CA; Joel Boardman of Sherman Oaks, CA. A funeral service is scheduled for 11:30am on Wednesday the 9th of January at Westchester Reform Temple, 225 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. Burial will be at Wellwood Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY. A memorial service will be scheduled later in Charlottesville, VA. In lieu of flowers, please consider honoring Joe through contributions to the Rockfish Wildlife Sanctuary in Schuyler, VA, or the Rabbis' Discretionary Funds at Congregation Beth Israel in Charlottesville, VA, or Westchester Reform Temple. An article in The Arts on Tuesday about ''Today's Man,'' a film about a man with Asperger's syndrome, misidentified the organization that added the syndrome to its diagnostic reference in 1994. It was the American Psychiatric Association -- not the American Psychological Association, which does not publish such a reference.

A Military Memo article on Monday, about the current relationship between the military and the news media, referred incorrectly to Rear Adm. Greg Smith, director of communications for the top military command in Iraq, who commented on coverage of the war. He is the first public affairs officer of such rank to hold this post; he is not the first one-star public affairs officer in Baghdad. (From mid-June to mid-November of 2004, a Navy Reserve officer, Rear Adm. Greg Slavonic, served in Baghdad and held that distinction.)

LURIE--Boris. A founder of the No! Art movement, died January 7, 2008 after having suffered a massive stroke over a year earlier. He was born July 18, 1924 in Leningrad and taken to Latvia as an infant. At the age of sixteen, he, along with his father, was put into a concentration camp. Most of his family was murdered during the war. Upon his liberation by the Soviets, he assisted the American occupation forces and then emigrated to the U.S. Here, he became a painter, writer and poet. He remained the Zionist he'd been since childhood and his experiences during World War II only strengthened his radical politics. His art reflected a distaste for the easy consumerism of the post-war boom, the advertising which prodded it, and its effect on American art and culture. His multiple exhibitions culminated in one at the inaugural of the Buchenwald Museum.

An article in Business Day on Dec. 31 about Nintendo's hand-held DS video game player referred incorrectly to capabilities planned for the device. In the future, the Nintendo DS will be able to receive demonstration versions of some DS games from Wii, Nintendo's latest game console; it will not be able to receive the entire game. (The demonstration version will be erased once the Nintendo DS is turned off.)

ROSSI--Henry F., age 91, passed away at New York Presbyterian Hospital on January 7, 2008. Born in West New York, NJ, he was the former Administrative Vice President of St. Johns University in New York. Married to Margaret Gregory Rossi for 65 years, he was the beloved father of Margaret Rossi, Dennis Rossi, Stephen and Marianne Rossi, Cathleen Rossi-McLaughlin and Larry McLaughlin, Jean Rossi and Les Helmers, Thomas and Joan Rossi, and Eileen and Joseph Mastricova. He was a loving grandfather to 16 grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. After graduating from Memorial High School in 1934, he attended New York University while working as a full time employee in the mail room at NYU. He received his BA in 1940. While working there he met Margaret Gregory and they married in May of 1942. He attended the U.S. Naval Academy at Annapolis as part of the V-7 program in 1942 and after being commissioned served in Motor Torpedo Boats in both the North Pacific and the Mediterranean areas from 1942-45 as a lieutenant (j.g.). He became the assistant Registrar at NYU in 1945 and later was promoted to Registrar until 1958. He received his MA in Higher Education from NYU in 1951. He was appointed Dean of Admissions and Registrar at St. Johns University in New York and eventually was promoted to Administration Vice President. He retired in 1991 at the age of 75. Throughout his career he taught one class in either mathematics or education so that he would be more aware of the students who were attending the universities. He served as President of the Middle States Association of Collegiate Registrars and officers of Admissions in 195960 and as the President of the Association of American Collegiate Registrars and Admission Officers in 1974-75. He served on several College Entrance Examination Board Committees and as a consultant to the Georgetown University Registrars Office, US Department of Health, Education and Welfare, the Manhattan School of Music and on Advisory Committees in Albany. He was also a guest speaker at several regional and national education meetings. He was a member of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Tenafly, NJ. The viewing will be 2-4 and 7-10pm this Wednesday, January 9, 2008, at The Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, across the street from The Clinton Inn. Mass will be at 10:00am at Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Tenafly on Thursday, January 10. Interment, Mt. Carmel Cemetery Tenafly. In lieu of flowers, Office of Concern C/o St. Cecelia, 55 W. Demarest Avenue, Englewood, NJ 07631 or the National Veterans of Foreign Wars. For directions go to: www.barrettfuneralhome.net

After his roommate, Virgilio Cintron, died, James O’Hare, 65, and another friend, David Daloia, 65, dressed Mr. Cintron’s corpse, carried him down a flight of stairs and heaved his body into a computer chair with wheels. Outside, they rolled him over the uneven sidewalk, pulling the chair toward Pay-O-Matic, a check-cashing shop on Ninth Avenue, seeking to cash Mr. Cintron’s Social Security check. A crowd gathered, a police detective eating his lunch called the authorities and soon the men were arrested.

Few toilets — if any — have ever received the level of government and media fanfare that greeted the new public pay potty that opened today in Madison Square Park. First, the full force of New York City’s newspapers, television and radio were there to tape, record and take notes on the first flushes. Second, the toilet is the product of an on-and-off decades efforts (detailed below) by city officials to, uh, serve the needs of New Yorkers.So it was understandable that the city officials reveled in the toilet paper roll-cutting ceremony (which, fittingly, they did with their hands) on Madison Avenue, between 23rd and 24th Streets. But they couldn’t resist the temptation of scatological humor: “No. 1!” (Janette Sadik-Khan, transportation commissioner), “in loo of” (Adrian Benepe, parks commissioner), “doesn’t block pedestrian movement” (Daniel L. Doctoroff, outgoing deputy mayor for economic development).

If you think the mania surrounding a Marc Jacbos show is the ultimate in fashion insanity, then try getting into Colcci, Brazil's popular high street label and the hottest ticket in town at Fashion Rio, which is underway this week in Rio de Janeiro. On Tuesday night the scene outside the Centro Cultural da Açäo was sheer chaos, as a conga line of gawkers, guests and gorgeous girls and boys tried to gain access. The show started more than an hour late and when Brazil's perpetual top model, Gisele Bundchen, took to the rotating circular catwalk, the crowd went as wild as any soccer mob at Maracanã stadium. As an outsider, it was confusing why such banal clothes (imagine a Dsquared and Cavalli collaborative capsule collection for H&M) could inspire such a frenzied reaction.

The story in New Hampshire this week was, of course, all about the stunning revivals of Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain. Buried a little further down the scoreboard, though, was another sign of just how fluid and unpredictable presidential politics can be. After winning just 5 percent of the vote in Iowa, Rudolph W. Giuliani managed a fourth place finish in New Hampshire, barely edging out Ron Paul (who had edged him out in the caucuses). To put this another way, the hero of September 11, the man they call "America's Mayor," is now battling to put some distance between himself and the former standard-bearer of the Libertarian Party, who would abolish most of the federal government.

There are perfumes built in the classic French fashion, with shiny exteriors of gold and titanium. Wearing them is like wearing a brilliant Cartier ring inlaid with diamonds. You wear these fragrances to show them off. (The French value: the brilliance and ego of the artist.) There are American perfumes that smell like a handsome, showered baseball player, sporty, young and relaxed, and you wear these to assume that identity, as you might wear a polo shirt with a country club logo. (The American genius: self-invention.) Then there are perfumes in the Italian style - often lemon/bergamot citrus scents - that serve as luxury ID badges, and one wears these as one would a beautifully-made Italian dress shirt, to say, "Admire my level of comfort and elegance." (The Italian obsession: status and the identification of one's social group.)
