The hedge fund manager William Ackman has raised his stake in the Borders Group, the bookstore chain, to 22 percent, even as the company's shares languish near 52-week lows.

In a long-expected move, Target, the discount retailer, said on Wednesday that its chief executive, Robert J. Ulrich, will retire May 1 and will be succeeded by the company's president, Gregg W. Steinhafel.
Time Warner is joining media heavyweights like Walt Disney, Viacom and Sony in making financial bets on online virtual worlds, The New York Post reported.
The parent of the New York Stock Exchange is reportedly in talks to acquire a longtime rival, the smaller American Stock Exchange, in a deal that may fetch as much as $350 million.
Aruba Networks, the wireless-networking company, announced on Wednesday that it would buy a multi-vendor network management company, AirWave Wireless, for $37 million in cash and stock.
Affiliated Computer Services said Wednesday that it had purchased Syan Holdings Limited, an information technology outsourcing firm based in England, for about $60 million.

Egged on by $100-a-barrel oil and consumers going green, venture capitalists plan to pour ever more cash into environmentally friendly technology this year, prompting talk of a bubble reminiscent of the dot-com era.

In what may be John Thain's latest housekeeping effort since taking the helm at Merrill Lynch, the world's biggest brokerage reportedly fired at least eight bankers in London from a group that sold asset-backed debt and invested the firm's money.

Bayhill Therapeutics said Wednesday it plans an initial public offering of its common stock, but the biopharmaceutical company did not disclose any terms in its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief executive of the American International Group, said on Wednesday that a group he represents did not intend to solicit proxies from A.I.G. shareholders, buy more A.I.G. shares or start a tender offer for the company.

The former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, Gregory L. Reyes, who was convicted in August of stock-options manipulation, is not entitled to a new trial, a federal judge ruled Wednesday, rejecting arguments that new evidence had emerged.
Federal communications regulators on Wednesday cleared the way for Verizon Communications to sell its phone lines in three New England states for $2.7 billion to FairPoint Communications.
The former prime minister of Britain, Tony Blair, will join the banking giant JPMorgan Chase as a part-time adviser, the bank said.

Reddy Ice on Wednesday announced that it was in price renegotiations with respect to its pending $1.1 billion purchase by GSO Capital Partners. The announcement comes as the February 3, 2008, termination date for the transaction fast approaches. GSO must decide prior to that date whether to commit to the transaction if it can obtain financing, or terminate on that date and pay a $21 million termination fee. In the latter event, GSO may claim a material adverse change to Reddy Ice under the terms of the merger agreement in order to escape even paying the $21 million reverse termination fee.
The new Tom Cruise bio by Andrew Morton may face legal action, but not for spreading gay rumors about his schoolboy years. From our review of the book:
Image found here.
Drew Gelinas, nordic skier, tests cross-country skis.
From Reuters:
Images from the group show.
The discount brokerage and banking firm disclosed that it had sold an additional $3 billion of mortgage-backed securities.
“Celebrity Rehab With Dr. Drew,” a new series on VH1, is a searing, unflattering but still celebratory look at eight worst-case-scenario addicts.
The vest has divorced itself from the three-piece suit.

Bob Clarke, the Flyers senior VP, went on TSN's "Off the Record," where he told the host Michael Landsberg that Steve Downie's hit on Dean McAmmond wasn't so bad and that Jason Blake deserved to be sucker punched for saying Downie deserved a lifetime ban for the McAmmond hit.

Will the horrors of the slumping U.S. market never end? The latest tale of suffering: actor Burt Reynolds, best known for the epic "Smokey and the Bandit" movies, is having trouble selling his Florida home.
While the players were brawling in Kazan, in St. Petersburg the fans were doing the brawling. This was the scene Tuesday at the SKA St. Petersburg-Spartak Moscow match at the Ice Palace:

Wisconsin's Kyle Turris (Phoenix Coyotes) and Denver's Rhett Rakhshani (Islanders) and Tyler Ruegsegger (Maple Leafs) are going to get sick of seeing one another. Last week they faced off wearing the jerseys of Canada and the United States, when Turris's Canadian squad drubbed Rakhshani, Ruegsegger and their fellow Americans in a 4-1, semifinal win at the World Junior Championship in the Czech Republic.

We're filing this under "Championship Week" because Ak Bars Kazan are techinically a championship team, having won the Continental Cup last weekend in Riga. But look what happened upon their return to the Russian Superliga on Tuesday night -- they started a full-fledged '70s-vintage, bench-clearing brawl with Traktor Chelyabinsk, which you can see in its entirety on the Telekanal web site here, or, if you prefer, below:
Rich Gossage will wear a Yankees cap when he enters the Baseball Hall of Fame. Gossage will be the 25th Yankees player inducted, the most among major league teams.
Much like man’s best friend, the rough-hewn Filipino movie “The Bet Collector” chases its protagonist from step to step, misery to misery, all but nipping at her heels.
Sir Edmund Hillary was the mountaineer who, with Tenzing Norgay, his Sherpa guide, was the first to scale the 29,035-foot summit of Mount Everest.
Andrew M. Cuomo issued a wide-ranging subpoena to Intel as part of an investigation into whether the company violated federal or state antitrust laws in the way it priced and sold microprocessors.
Bank of America is in talks with the troubled mortgage lender, according to people briefed on the situation.
A new report adds to the mounting evidence that relationships between plant and animal species can be far more complex than had been thought.
The chief of Delta Air Lines plans to ask the company’s board for permission to enter into formal merger talks with both Northwest Airlines and United Airlines, a person close to Delta said.
A woman found in her home with the decomposing bodies of four children will face murder charges, authorities said.
The body of Virgilio Cintron, the 66-year old man whose corpse was wheeled up to a check-cashing store in Manhattan, was identified by his sister, according to a criminal complaint made public today.
Researchers at Harvard Medical School have identified 273 proteins that the AIDS virus needs to survive in human cells, opening up new potential targets for drugs.
The British government approved plans to refresh the country’s fleet of nuclear reactors, signaling new enthusiasm for the technology and giving a lift to the industry.
The G train has a reputation as the stepchild of the subway system.
Ben S. Bernanke sent a strong signal that the central bank will lower interest rates again this month as it attempts to stave off a recession.
Representative John Doolittle of California was once a rising star in the Republican Party until he came under investigation in a scandal involving Jack Abramoff.
Senator John Kerry said Senator Barack Obama “had the greatest potential to lead a transformation, not just a transition.”
Despite calls from politicians and businesses that it cut borrowing costs among fears of slowing growth in Britain, the central bank left its benchmark rate unchanged.
After the European Central Bank left its benchmark rate unchanged Thursday, the bank’s president suggested that its next interest rate move was most likely to be an increase.
The nation’s big retail chains, a closely watched barometer of economic health, reported dreary December sales, which may stoke fears of a recessionary downtown.
The Knicks had no antidote for Yao Ming, who finished with a game-high 36 points, but Coach Isiah Thomas, who was ejected in the fourth quarter, did not go down without a fight.
Britain’s former prime minister, Tony Blair, will join the banking giant JPMorgan Chase & Company as a part-time adviser, a person with knowledge of the decision said Wednesday night.
One night after a 115-99 loss at Charlotte threatened to halt their momentum, the Nets rebounded against the Seattle SuperSonics, their sixth victory in their last seven games.
The actor Steven Seagal and his former business partner, Julius R. Nasso, have agreed to settle a long-running legal battle, a lawyer and a spokeswoman said on Wednesday.

A man who mailed a cow’s head to his wife’s lover was sentenced Friday to probation and community service. The man, Jason M. Fife of Hunker, “understands that in a civilized society a person cannot send a severed cow’s head to anybody,” said his lawyer, Henry Hilles. The police said Mr. Fife, 31, obtained the cow’s head from a butcher’s shop, claiming he wanted the dried skull for decoration. Instead, he mailed it, frozen, so as not to alert parcel carriers to the contents, the police said.

The Miami police have a man in custody who they believe inadvertently killed an off-duty police officer while firing an assault rifle at a couple in an apparent jealous rampage, a police spokesman said. The man, Ricardo Ajuste, 21, was charged with two counts of attempted murder for allegedly opening fire on a car parked near the vehicle of the officer, Detective James Walker. Detective Walker was found dead Tuesday in his unmarked police cruiser in an alley in North Miami Beach. Mr. Ajuste has not been charged with the killing but is a “prime suspect,” the police said.

The government is readying 102 court cases against landowners in Arizona, California and Texas for blocking efforts to select sites for a fence along the Mexican border, a Homeland Security Department official said. The Bush administration wants to build 370 miles of fencing and 300 miles of vehicle barriers by the end of the year. Some property owners have granted the government access to their land, but others have refused. The agency sent letters to 135 of them last month, warning they had 30 days to comply or face court action. Thirty-three complied. The deadline for many of the owners passed on Monday and should expire this week for others.
National Guard troops bolstering New Orleans’s hurricane-depleted police force will remain in the city through June.

Chicago’s City Council approved a nearly $20 million settlement with former death row inmates who claim they were tortured by the police. The settlement ends lawsuits brought by Stanley Howard, Aaron Patterson, Leroy Orange and Madison Hobley. All have been exonerated in their death-penalty cases and claim that members of the Chicago police tortured them under the leadership of former Lt. Jon Burge.

A rural school district’s longstanding practice of allowing the distribution of Bibles to grade school students is unconstitutional, a federal judge ruled Tuesday. For more than three decades, the South Iron School District in Annapolis, 120 miles southwest of St. Louis, allowed representatives of Gideons International to give away Bibles in fifth-grade classrooms. The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit two years ago on behalf of four sets of parents. The district then altered its policy to allow distribution before or after school or during lunch break, but not in classrooms. Judge Catherine D. Perry of Federal District Court in St. Louis ruled that both practices were illegal and granted a permanent injunction.
Brooks Laich and David Steckel each scored in the third period, and Olaf Kolzig made 18 saves in the Washington Capitals’ 2-1 home victory over the Colorado Avalanche on Wednesday night.

The Weekend Explorer column on Dec. 14, about the Upper East Side, misstated the history of the name of the Yorkville area. Historians believe it was named for the Duke of York (later King James II), as were New York City and State. It was not named for Sgt. Alvin C. York, the World War I hero. (York Avenue was named for him.) The column also misidentified the borough in which Woody Allen, a longtime Upper East Side resident, was born. It was the Bronx — not Brooklyn, the borough in which he grew up.

A film review in Weekend on Dec. 21 about “National Treasure: Book of Secrets” referred imprecisely to a scene in the film “North by Northwest” that takes place at Mount Rushmore, as does a scene in “National Treasure: Book of Secrets.” While Eva Marie Saint dangles near George Washington’s face in “North by Northwest,” she is not shown dangling from his nose.

Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption on Tuesday about troubles at Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta misidentified one of the medical schools that supply the hospital’s doctors. It is Morehouse School of Medicine — not Morehouse College, which has no school of medicine.
Former State Senator Wayne R. Bryant of New Jersey, who is facing criminal corruption charges, is hoping to tap a new source to help pay legal bills: his campaign account.
Maya Moore scored 25 points and top-ranked Connecticut continued to roll, winning its Big East home opener by 84-48 over No. 16 West Virginia on Wednesday night.

An article on Wednesday about President Bush’s criticism of Iran for confronting American warships over the weekend misstated the conclusion of a recent National Intelligence Estimate on Iran, which Mr. Bush also discussed. The intelligence estimate, issued in December, concluded that in 2003 Iran halted its program to develop a nuclear weapon; it did not say that Iran had abandoned its efforts to enrich uranium.
Tyler Hansbrough scored 23 points and Wayne Ellington added 19 to lead top-ranked North Carolina past visiting North Carolina-Asheville, 93-81, on Wednesday night.
Jason Richardson scored 34 points and grabbed 9 rebounds, Gerald Wallace had 15 points and 10 rebounds, and the Charlotte Bobcats defeated the host Boston Celtics, 95-83, on Wednesday.
An Australian fisheries ship has begun pursuing Japan’s whaling fleet near Antarctica to gather evidence for an international court challenge to halt the yearly slaughter.

An Irish leasing company, AWAS, said it had signed a contract for 75 Airbus aircraft from the single-aisle A320 family, with an option on another 25 planes. The deal is worth $6.9 billion at list prices, though customers usually negotiate substantial discounts. The order gives a lift to Airbus, which is owned by European Aeronautic Defense and Space, as analysts predict that its fortunes and those of its rival, the Boeing Company, will dip this year as airlines delay orders until their finances and the economy show signs of recovery. With the new order, AWAS will have 145 Airbus single-aisle and long-range planes, Airbus said.

Embraer, the Brazilian aircraft maker, said it delivered a record 169 planes in 2007, helped by surging demand for its regional and executive jets. Embraer’s previous delivery record was 161 planes in 2001, before the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States led to a prolonged slump in air travel. Embraer delivered 130 aircraft in 2006. Embraer, short for Empresa Brasileira de Aeronáutica, also finished 2007 with the largest firm order backlog in its history, $18.8 billion. At the end of 2006, its backlog was $14.8 billion. The company said it had improved its assembly line in 2007 to help speed production.

Marks & Spencer reported that Christmas season sales declined, confirming fears that consumer spending in Britain has weakened. The announcement set off a 19 percent decline in the company’s share price. Marks & Spencer reported a 2.2 percent drop in sales in the 13 weeks ended Dec. 29, compared with the equivalent period a year earlier, even though the chain reduced prices. It said that sales of general merchandise in what is the company’s third quarter were down 3.2 percent at stores open for at least a year and that food sales decreased 1.5 percent. Gross sales of merchandise declined 0.7 percent and food sales rose 5.1 percent.

Bang & Olufsen, the Danish maker of stereos and television sets, posted a 37 percent decline in first-half pretax profit and lowered its full-year outlook, setting off a 28.5 percent decline in its share price. Bang & Olufsen’s pretax profit for the six months ended Nov. 30 was 150 million Danish kroner ($29.6 million), down from 238 million kroner in the comparable period a year earlier. Sales rose 5 percent, to 2.2 billion kroner, in line with the expectations of analysts. Sales were 8 percent higher in North America, but they were flat in Germany and declined 6 percent in Britain. The company said that a recent disappointing trend in retail sales had led it to cut its full-year pretax profit outlook to 360 million to 400 million kroner, compared with a previous forecast of 540 million to 570 million kroner. “It is clear that some markets have come under pressure in relation to consumer investments,” the chief executive, Torben B. Sorensen, above, said in a statement. “We must be realistic and say that the economy in certain places looks like it will weaken, especially in parts of Europe and the United States.”.

Mexico’s top retailer, Wal-Mart de Mexico, plans to cut prices as part of a government plan to help low-income earners struggling with inflation. A spokesman for the company said the announcement would be made Thursday afternoon. Mexico’s leading retailers have agreed to temporary discounts on some staple goods beginning this month. The government is expected to provide details on the deal on Thursday during a news conference with the retail association. Wal-Mart also said December sales rose 0.5 percent, which was above analysts’ expectations.
The Port Authority asked an appellate court to throw out a verdict declaring that the authority was 68 percent responsible for the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center.
John McCain and Mitt Romney headed toward another showdown, while Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama readied for a nationwide battle.
Bob Franks said at a news conference that he had agreed to become the chairman of a campaign to promote Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s highway and finance plan.
The W.H.O. published a study that estimated the number of deaths was at least twice as high as the oft-cited Iraq Body Count,  which put the number at 47,668.
Hillary Rodham Clinton’s teary-eyed exchange with a voter and her sharpened argument on experience were among the turning points in New Hampshire.
Jose A. Rodriguez Jr., who in 2005 ordered the destruction of videotapes of harsh interrogations, will not offer testimony that might subsequently be used against him.
By losing in Iowa, Hillary Rodham Clinton may have gotten more women to see her as a candidate trying to break a glass ceiling.
A wave of anti-Tutsi sentiment is sweeping Congo, driven by deep anger over a Tutsi general tied to Rwanda.
The Innocence Project has proposed some important reforms that states should use in upgrading their criminal justice system.
Mr. Spitzer’s new style is a better one, but even a more diplomatic governor should not back away from the fights that really matter.
Justice Minister Brian Lenihan said he would set up an advisory group to examine current laws on the sale and consumption of alcohol and report back to him by March 31.

Judge Paul C. Huck of United States District Court in Miami denied a request by lawyers for the former Panamanian strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega to block his extradition to France to face money laundering charges.

“I thought I was dreaming,” a Warsaw man told the newspaper Super Express after he visited a brothel and saw his wife among the establishment’s employees. The paper said she had told her husband that she worked at a store in a nearby town. The couple, married 14 years, are divorcing.

Dr. Ashraf al-Hazouz, a Palestinian imprisoned for more than eight years in Libya along with five Bulgarian nurses, all accused of deliberately infecting hundreds of Libyan children with H.I.V., has filed a complaint with the United Nations Human Rights Committee in Geneva charging that he was tortured in captivity, his lawyer said.
Gerrie Nel, the regional head of the elite anti-graft unit known as the Scorpions who was leading an investigation into the national police commissioner, Jackie Selebi, left, has been arrested.

President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela said Colombian guerrillas had provided him with the location of two captives, Clara Rojas, a former aspirant to Colombia’s vice presidency, and Consuelo González, a former Colombian lawmaker.
TV makers at the Consumer Electronics Show boast their sets are thin, sharp and rich in content.
Dawn Taubin, the head of domestic marketing at Warner Brothers for six years, has been ousted in a shake-up that the movie studio did little to conceal.
It is imperative that President Bush and Congressional leaders begin a serious discussion about how to help revive the economy.

Peace talks between Morocco and the pro-independence Polisario Front ended in stalemate on Wednesday, with the two sides agreeing to try again in March to resolve a 32-year dispute for control of Western Sahara.
Despite his disappointing finish in New Hampshire, John Edwards seems determined to stick around.

Pirate attacks rose by 10 percent globally in 2007, the first increase in three years, as pirates stepped up attacks off the coasts of Nigeria and Somalia, an international maritime monitoring organization said.
For 30 years, Mr. de Montebello has been as iconic, in his own way, as the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Fifth Avenue facade.
The witnesses in a Marine Corps inquiry offered the first public description of the unit’s reaction immediately after the bomb attack near one of their vehicles last year.
When Bob Knight, a Hall of Fame coach, gets victory No. 900, he will join the former Texas coach Jody Conradt and Tennessee’s Pat Summitt as the only members of the N.C.A.A. Division I club.
The proposal has not yet been presented to Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, whose very public efforts to get NATO nations to increase troop commitments in Afghanistan have yet to succeed.

If the Patriots can defeat Jacksonville on Saturday, their winning streak will reach 19 -- the jersey number transposed of Marquise Hill, the team’s 24-year-old reserve defensive lineman who drowned in late May.
A recent incident in which two men wheeled a corpse to a check-cashing store was reminiscent of the days when Hell’s Kitchen was known for its crime.
The Treasury Department imposed strict economic penalties on a top Iranian military commander, a Syrian-based television station and three Iraqi militants in the region.
Pollsters and news organizations asked themselves how they failed to foresee Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s New Hampshire victory.
A day after his surprise defeat in New Hampshire, Senator Barack Obama addressed a largely enthusiastic audience in Jersey City.
A previously undisclosed incident has raised new questions about private security contractors in Iraq.
The arrest ended a nearly four-week search that began with a nighttime jail break and ended with two arrests in two countries within 24 hours.
The House committee investigating steroids in baseball has postponed its hearing to Feb. 13, making it a major distraction at the start of camp for Andy Pettitte and the Yankees.
The subpoena is in connection with the suicide of a 13-year-old Missouri girl after she received cruel messages from people posing as a teenage boy on the site.
The West Virginia team that Bob Huggins takes into Freedom Hall on Thursday to face Louisville is a hybrid of sorts.
At Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s State of the State address, not even his conspicuous and deliberate praise of individual Republican lawmakers could ease the chill in the air.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer kicked off his second year with warm words for his friends and foes alike, offering a less combative tone in his State of the State address.
After around four decades with little to show, has the gambling train pulled out of the station and left the Catskills behind?
A federal panel of judges granted San Francisco the right to require businesses with more than 20 employees to pay a fee to help cover employees’ health care costs.
Philip Agee was a former Central Intelligence Agency officer who turned against the agency and spent years exposing undercover American spies overseas.
Apple said it would bring the prices on its iTunes digital music store in Britain in line with those on the Continent to settle an antitrust case.
A judge has ruled that an energy company may drill for natural gas on a sprawling Montana ranch owned by the billionaire candy magnate Forrest E. Mars Jr.
Terrell Owens, who participated in a walk-through on Monday, has a sprained ankle and did not practice Wednesday, and his availability for Sunday’s game is unlikely to be known.
Toy makers are instituting tougher quality controls in China and elsewhere to try to avoid repetition of the  recalls that damaged the industry last year.
The New Jersey Institute of Technology men’s basketball team has not been able to overcome substantial obstacles and has lost more games than all but two N.C.A.A. Division I teams.
The aluminum producer Alcoa said its fourth-quarter profit rose 76 percent as revamping and tax benefits helped offset lower aluminum prices.

The company, which makes products ranging from automotive coatings to genetically modified seeds, said it expected 2007 earnings to be at the upper end of its previously announced range of $3.15 to $3.20 a share.
A federal judge ruled that Gregory L. Reyes, convicted in August of stock-options manipulation, is not entitled to a new trial.
The discount retailer said its chief executive, Robert J. Ulrich, will retire May 1 and be succeeded by the company’s president, Gregg W. Steinhafel.
Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief executive of the American International Group, said a group he represents did not intend to solicit proxies from A.I.G. shareholders.
MBIA said it would sell $1 billion of debt to preserve capital and the triple-A ratings it needs to operate in a mortgage market under siege.
Lam Luong, a Vietnamese immigrant who has been working in Alabama as a shrimper, told investigators that he threw his four young children off a bridge.
Nevada was vaulted into the position of tie-breaker after the victory of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in New Hampshire Tuesday.
Reddy Ice Holdings, a producer of packaged ice, said it was in talks to revise a $1.1 billion deal to be bought by GSO Capital Partners.
The Coors Brewing Company is offering consumers a chance to win tickets for the 2008 or 2009 Super Bowl by submitting video clips to its Web sites.
After two seasons as the apprentice to Tiki Barber, Brandon Jacobs now shares his playing time with rookie Ahmad Bradshaw, was a long shot even to make the team during camp.
The victims were among an estimated 300,000 ethnic Koreans from China who now live in South Korea and pursue their “Korean dream” at the lowest rung of South Korea’s labor market.
Prosecutors said 499 gravestones were knocked over at a Jewish cemetery in New Brunswick, N.J., in two separate instances on Jan. 1 and Saturday night.
LaDainian Tomlinson and Randy Moss were unanimous selections to the Associated Press’s All-Pro team Wednesday.
“Bike boxes” will be laid out on roadways to provide a clearly designated place for cyclists to wait for traffic lights to change, in front of and in full view of drivers.
A Vermont court has ordered William Krasnansky to stop posting what he calls a fictionalized account of his marriage to Maria Garrido on his blog.
Regulators  cleared the way for Verizon Communications to sell its phone lines in three New England states for $2.7 billion to FairPoint Communications Inc.
A former chairman of the Manhattan Republican Committee was sentenced on Wednesday in State Supreme Court to five years’ probation for violations of tax and state ethics laws, prosecutors said.
A fire that damaged buildings at Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Roman Catholic Church on Dec. 30 was arson, the Suffolk County police said on Wednesday.

Residents and community groups in the Catskills filed a lawsuit on Wednesday in State Supreme Court charging the state with a conflict of interest in the way it is handling its review of a proposed resort near the state-owned Belleayre Ski Center in Ulster County.
Two Queens teenagers pleaded guilty to manslaughter on Wednesday, admitting that they choked and fatally beat John Canora, 55, in his Howard Beach home in October 2006, prosecutors said.
A state judge ordered on Wednesday that parties to a lawsuit filed by Dan Rather against CBS, Viacom and executives of the companies prepare to share evidence.
A windstorm packing hurricane-force gusts whipped across upstate New York on Wednesday, felling trees and power lines and knocking out electricity at more than 125,000 homes and businesses.
Under the edict, prices of oil products, natural gas and electricity will be frozen in the near term along with  public water bills and transportation tickets.
Despite coming up short in New Hampshire, a race that many people considered his best opportunity, Ron Paul indicated that his campaign would go on.
Ken Nelson was the record producer behind the twangy Bakersfield Sound made popular by Buck Owens and Merle Haggard.
Kosovo’s Parliament voted 85 to 22 to approve a coalition government with Hashim Thaci as prime minister in order to try to steer the province through a declaration of independence.
A presidential advisory board released a report Wednesday with recommendations to reform the way the government declassifies documents.
It is unclear whether Gov. Bill Richardson’s supporters will gravitate to Sen. Barack Obama or Sen. Hillary Clinton.
The Nasdaq composite index showed its first gain in nine sessions, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained more than 200 points at the end of the day.
The groups filed papers in support of a suit seeking to have the police make public a database of officers’ recordings on more than 850,000 stops of civilians in 2006 and 2007.
Gender and age patterns tend not to be as confounding to pollsters as race, which to my mind was a key reason the polls got New Hampshire so wrong.
The rare genetic flaw occurs spontaneously near or during conception and may sharply increase the risk that a child will develop autism.
A day after the city rescinded a regulation that had limited the size of the crowds allowed on the Great Lawn in Central Park, parkgoers seem to be pleased with the deal.
CBS News and a union representing 500 of its employees resolved a dispute that contributed to the cancellation of a presidential primary debate last month.
A boy with a propane torch and other weapons slashed a girl with a knife before other students jumped on him, disabling him before school officials disarmed him.
Dr. MacLean developed an intriguing theory to explain the brain’s evolution and to try to reconcile rational human behavior with its more violent side.
The soldiers died in the volatile Sunni heartlands north of Baghdad as the U.S. military launched its third offensive in a year to dislodge Sunni guerrillas from Diyala Province.
The justices’ questioning on indicated a majority does not accept the basic argument brought by challengers to Indiana’s voter-identification law.
Thankfully, photo-recovery technologies have blossomed along with the growing digital camera market.
The advocate tells Congress taxpayers should receive up to $1,000 in “apology payments” if the Internal Revenue Service mishandles their case.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,901 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday and Tuesday:.
To the Editor:.

Burning calories in the snow doesn’t always have to burn a hole in your wallet. This Saturday, Jan. 12, is Winter Trails Day, when rookies can try out cross-country skiing and snowshoeing for free at nearly 100 cross-country centers, parks and recreation areas in 24 states.

“Studies have shown that listening to music during exercise can improve results, both in terms of being a motivator (people exercise longer and more vigorously to music) and as a distraction from negatives like fatigue,” Steven Kurutz writes in The Times today. “But are certain songs more effective than others?”.
Many argue that with the stock market falling and the economy flirting with recession, the Fed’s chairman should be more aggressive than he has been so far.
Consider using a password-management program to organize and store all the passwords you pick up on your Internet travels.
Is it true that you lose VoIP phone service if there’s a power failure? What can you do if it happens and you don’t have a mobile phone to fall back on?
I sometimes check mail on the Web version of Gmail, but I notice that messages I download don’t show up in my online in-box. Is there a way to keep all the mail on the Web, too?

The plummeting United States dollar is not something most sports fans think about -- that stuff is for economists and politicians. But next week in New York, American sports executives will have to deal with a consequence of the greenback’s weakness, as National Hockey League executives meet with European hockey officials to hammer out a new agreement governing international player transfers.
The Celestron LCD Digital Microscope has a built-in digital camera with 128 megabytes of storage for taking pictures of minuscule subjects.
The Sony A200, boxed with an 18- to 70-millimeter zoom lens, will sell for $700.
Canon’s latest entry-level video camera, the ZR950, is smooth-edged for popping out of a pocket to capture the moment when Junior suddenly comes in goal range.
The ReadyNAS Duo is part of the home or office network, so it can be reached by all of the network’s PCs or media players.

Tiger Woods said on his Web site last week that winning all four professional majors in a single year, a feat never accomplished, is “easily within reason." Do you expect him to win the Grand Slam this year? If not, who or what will stop him?.
To the Editor:.

The new study found flaws in Beijing’s “Blue Sky” system of air-quality monitoring and noted that the city changed its formula for measuring pollution in 2006, using less polluted locales than before.

In a slow week for the Billboard chart, Alicia Keys reached No. 2 with 112,000 sales of “As I Am” (J); Mary J. Blige moved 89,000 of “Growing Pains” (Geffen) to reach No. 3; “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 26 is at No. 4 with 54,000; and the 18-year-old country singer Taylor Swift rose three spots to No. 5, though sales of her self-titled album, on the Big Machine label, dropped 39 percent last week to 47,000, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Radiohead reached No. 1 with the conventional release of “In Rainbows,” through the ATO label, on CD and other formats. The indie-rock “Juno” soundtrack (Rhino), popular online, opened at No. 8 with 38,000.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art is the new (if temporary) home of “Artemis and the Stag,” below, the 2,000-year-old classical bronze sculpture that sold last year for a record $28.6 million at a Sotheby’s auction in New York. The sculpture, sold by the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo to an unidentified private collector for the highest price ever paid for a sculpture or antiquity at auction, will be on view for six months in the Leon Levy and Shelby White Court (the central atrium in the new Greek and Roman Galleries).

A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that Anthony Pellicano, the Hollywood private investigator facing trial on wiretapping and conspiracy charges, can represent himself at trial next month. Judge Dale S. Fischer of United States District Court said she was bound by Supreme Court case law to let Mr. Pellicano do so, but urged him to reconsider. The ruling raises the prospect that Mr. Pellicano, who often grabbed the limelight in his career as an investigator to the stars, would again take center stage at his trial, set to begin Feb. 27. By acting as his own lawyer he will cross-examine prosecution witnesses like Anita Busch, the former journalist who the authorities say was wiretapped by Mr. Pellicano and was threatened in a scheme he orchestrated, as well as other cooperating witnesses who prosecutors say hired Mr. Pellicano to wiretap their adversaries.

The Royal Academy of Arts in London announced on Wednesday that it had received official approval from Russia for the loan of its art for the exhibition “French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925 From Moscow and St. Petersburg.” The show is scheduled to run from Jan. 26 through April 18. Russia had cast the show in doubt while seeking assurances that none of the 120 paintings would be seized to satisfy possible claims that they had been confiscated by the state after the 1917 revolution.

State police in Brazil have recovered two paintings, above, including a Picasso valued at $50 million, that were stolen last month in a predawn break-in at the São Paulo Museum of Art, Reuters reported. The museum’s president, Julio Neves, said Picasso’s “Portrait of Suzanne Bloch” and the Brazilian artist Candido Portinari’s “Coffee Worker,” valued at $5 million, were in perfect condition when found at a house on the city’s outskirts. The police arrested one suspect, Francisco Laerton Lopes de Lima, on Dec. 27, and his capture led them to Robson de Jesus Jordao, who was arrested on Tuesday. Police Chief Mauricio Freire said the two men had long criminal records, including participation in previous robbery attempts at the museum. Mr. Neves said both paintings would be on view in their previous locations when the museum opens on Friday.

The two-month-old writers strike took a significant toll on the “People’s Choice Awards” on Tuesday as the taped, scaled-down version of the awards show on CBS lost nearly half its audience compared with a year ago, attracting just 6 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., Nielsen reported. A year ago, the show’s live broadcast averaged 11.3 million. For the night, CBS ranked third overall, trailing second-place Fox with its all-repeat lineup. NBC finished first, leading every hour of the night among adults 18 to 49 with a two-hour episode of “The Biggest Loser” (10.2 million), followed by “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” at 10 (15.2 million). CW delivered its best Tuesday ratings since March thanks to “One Tree Hill,” which averaged 3.5 million viewers from 8 to 10 in its fifth-season debut. ABC trailed CW in last place among adults 18 to 49.

AFTER seeing ''An Inconvenient Truth'' two years ago, Daniel Heuser, a second-grade teacher who is now 43, put compact fluorescent bulbs in nearly every light fixture in his two-story house in Chapel Hill, N.C., to the dismay of his wife, Jane. When the bulbs were installed, ''the color was a little bit off,'' said Ms. Heuser, 41, making things look dull, especially in the beige-wallpapered kitchen. Even worse, she said, was the upstairs bathroom, where the buzzing common to many compact fluorescents was particularly noticeable. ''You wake up and you're kind of groggy, and then you see these curly light bulbs, and it's buzzing, and you're like -- ugh.'' Mr. Heuser said he, too, is bothered by the way the bulbs he's installed in the upstairs hallway ''make everyone look greenish.'' Their children, Katie, 11, and Benji, 8, dislike the slight delay when they switch on a light. Nonetheless, he is happy with the decision to use compact fluorescents, and he believes it's a morally correct choice.

8 P.M. (13) I CAN'T BELIEVE IT'S SCHOENBERG! ''Live From Lincoln Center'' veers from the expected in this special featuring Rob Kapilow, left, the composer and conductor, and the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in a lecture about and performance of Arnold Schoenberg's voluptuous ''Verklärte Nacht.'' Considered one of the last great Romantic masterpieces, it musically depicts a poem about two lovers' walk through the woods. Mr. Kapilow, whose exuberant ''What Makes It Great?'' series can be heard on National Public Radio, applies that question to Schoenberg's work. The violinists Erin Keefe and Arnaud Sussmann, the violists David Kim and Teng Li, and the cellists David Finkel and Priscilla Lee perform. For the first time, ''Live From Lincoln Center'' will be shown online at pbs.org for a week following this broadcast, with a performance by the society of the Brahms Sextet in G. 8 P.M. (21) ABSOLUTE ZERO Part 2 of a ''Nova'' installment based on Tom Shachtman's book ''Absolute Zero and the Conquest of Cold.'' Tonight, the journey from the late 19th century, when researchers began their race to the bottom of the temperature scale, and a recent Nobel Prize-winning breakthrough: a new form of matter that Albert Einstein predicted would exist within a few billionths of a degree above absolute zero.

The first fabric collection from Of the Young & the Restless, a Charleston, S.C., company, is filled with oversize birds, roses and shells. Pearce Williams, the creative director, who runs the company with her childhood friend Courtney Loadholt, calls it Southern regional design. ''Courtney and I have an affinity for the Southern landscape and way of life,'' Ms. Williams said. The collection includes Nesting Shells, a linen-and-cotton blend covered with nine-inch seashells that recall the ''big gorgeous whelks'' on the South Carolina coast, she said, and Thorny Rose, above left, a linen printed with four-by-four-inch roses in full bloom, ''before they keel over and wilt.'' Houndstooth, above right, is one of the few departures from the Southern theme. The prints are $140 to $168 a yard; the solids, $70 a yard. Information: (843) 416-2189 or oftheyoungandtherestless.com.ELAINE LOUIE

HAVING only recently retired from more than two decades working for the United Nations' division for sustainable development, where he focused in part on issues of personal energy consumption, Ralph Chipman, 62, knows the stakes involved in cutting down on his own energy use. With these in mind (along with a desire to minimize his monthly Con Edison bill), Mr. Chipman used a living room renovation a year and a half ago as an opportunity to experiment with compact fluorescent lightbulbs in every room of his Greenwich Village town house. A result: nearly all incandescent bulbs have been replaced by compact fluorescents, and the family has happily adjusted to the change, he said. In the living room, for example, where there are four recessed lights along one wall, Mr. Chipman tested six dimmable bulbs and determined that one made by Greenlite with the same hue as incandescents worked best in certain spots, attractively lighting an exposed brick wall and maple bookshelves. A Satco brand bulb with a slightly whiter hue made a limestone-tiled fireplace in the middle of the wall look best, so he installed one above it.

The Seattle Storm hired Brian Agler on Wednesday as its head coach and director of player personnel, replacing Anne Donovan, who resigned Nov. 30. Agler's hiring completed a busy two days for the franchise. On Tuesday, it announced that the owner Clay Bennett intended to sell the W.N.B.A. team for $10 million to a group of four Seattle women, who intend to keep the team in the city. Agler was an assistant with the San Antonio Silver Stars for the last three seasons. He was also the first coach and general manager of the Minnesota Lynx from 1999 to 2002.

A chart on Wednesday with a sports article about Rich Gossage's election to the baseball Hall of Fame omitted a distinction for Bruce Sutter in a comparison of Gossage's career statistics with those of several Hall of Fame pitchers and ''notable others.'' Sutter is also a Hall of Famer.

Because of an editing error, an art review in Weekend on Dec. 21 about ''Bhutan, the Sacred Within: Photographs by Kenro Izu,'' at the Rubin Museum of Art in Chelsea, misstated Bhutan's population. While some reference works use the figure of ''about 2.3 million'' cited in the review, the Bhutanese government says its census in 2005 counted 672,425 people. The review also misidentified the mountain shown in one of Mr. Izu's photographs. It is Mount Jomolhari in Bhutan, not Mount Kailash in Tibet.

Switzerland's dressage team will not take part in the Beijing Olympics. The move followed the withdrawal of the team's top rider, Silvia Ikle, who did not want to expose her horse, Salieri, to travel-related stress and the humid conditions in Hong Kong in the summer. Switzerland said it had qualified because of the performance of Ikle and Salieri.

MURPHY--John J. (''Jack''), passed away on January 8 after a brief illness. Jack died peacefully at the home of his brother Jim in Garden City. Jack, a life-long resident of Rockville Centre, was the son of James F. and Margaret Murphy (nee O'Brien). Following his graduation from the U.S. Naval Academy at Annapolis, he served as an officer in the United States Navy. After completing his military service, he embarked on a 50-year career as Secretary Treasurer of U.S. Dredging Corporation. During that time, he served as a former director of the National Sand and Gravel Association. He was an active parishioner of St. Agnes Cathedral and a member of the Bishop's Development Committee. He was also a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem and a member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick of New York. Jack is survived by his siblings James F. Murphy III of Garden City, Rosemarie (and Bill) Codus of Potomac, MD, and Edward (and Joan) of Rockville Centre, as well as 13 nieces and nephews, 17 grandnieces and nephews, and countless friends. He is predeceased by his sister-in-law, Helen Marie Murphy (nee Fagan) and nephew, James F. Murphy IV. Jack was a loyal and caring brother, uncle and friend. His quiet acts of kindness and generosity spoke volumes of his character. This true gentlemen will be sorely missed by his devoted family and friends. Reposing Thursday 79pm and Friday 2-4pm and 79pm at Macken Mortuary in Rockville Centre. Funeral Mass Saturday at 10am at St. Agnes Cathedral in Rockville Centre. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, NY. Donations may be made to Little Flower Children's Services, Wading River, NY 11792, would be appreciated. mackenmortuary.com.

After a year's absence from the New York culinary scene, Alain Ducasse is back. But at his new spot, Adour Alain Ducasse at the St. Regis hotel, wine is the star. Designed by the Rockwell Group, in the former Lespinasse space, Adour successfully walks the line between old (walls of seeded glass and silver leaf, burled-wood wine cases) and new (at the bar, guests will order using a computerized, motion-sensitive and interactive wine list projected from above). The bar is covered in stretched goatskin, a seemingly odd choice for a surface doomed to colorful spills but one that was repeatedly tested and found up to the challenge, David Rockwell said. The 2,500-square-foot library-like space seats 80, mostly in banquettes. But for those who occupy a chair, Mr. Rockwell added a pull-out tray that acts as a stylish perch for a handbag. RIMA SUQI

The Golf Channel suspended the anchor Kelly Tilghman for two weeks Wednesday for saying last Friday that young players who wanted to challenge Tiger Woods should ''lynch him in a back alley.'' Tilghman was laughing during the exchange with the analyst Nick Faldo, and Woods's agent at IMG said he did not think there was any ill intent. But the comments became prevalent on news shows Wednesday, and the Rev. Al Sharpton joined the fray by demanding Tilghman be fired immediately. ''There is simply no place on our network for offensive language like this,'' the Golf Channel said in a statement.

A prosecutors and a defense lawyer told a federal judge Wednesday that the former Olympic champion Marion Jones should not be sentenced to more than the six-month maximum they had agreed upon. Michael J. Garcia, a United States attorney, and Henry DePippo, a defense lawyer, told Judge Kenneth Karas that legal precedent argues against departing from the zero-to-six-month range for Jones, who is to be sentenced Friday in White Plains for lying about steroid use and a check-fraud scheme. Karas suggested last week that he might impose a sentence of more than six months.

AN ornithologist who carries her own canvas bags to the grocery store, telecommutes to save fuel, keeps her home thermostat set at 60 degrees and calculates her carbon emissions when she travels overseas to go birding, Ellen Paul of Chevy Chase, Md., considers herself ''a total greenie.'' Despite her concern for the environment, however, Ms. Paul, 52, said she cannot bring herself to switch to compact fluorescent light bulbs. She and her husband, Tim Boucher, who works for the Nature Conservancy, have tried more than half a dozen compact fluorescents over the last four years. In every case, the light was too dim or the color seemed off.

Michael Sieger, a product designer and a partner at Sieger Design, a design agency in Münster, Germany, has created 15 printed beanbag covers for the Original Sitting Bull, a German company known for its solid-colored, utilitarian floor cushions. Introduced in the United States this month, Mr. Sieger's designs include polka dots, stripes and photorealistic images of orange and white koi on a black background, as well as the baroque Marie Antoinette, above. A floor cushion is ''quite cheap furniture,'' Mr. Sieger said, ''so the idea was to give it a more luxurious appearance by using this very complex and rich decoration.'' The polyester-covered beanbags, $219, measure 71 by 55 by 12 inches. Information: (866) 208-7149 or pippinmcgee.com. ELAINE LOUIE

The two electric power companies here have agreed to a new regulatory system that sets their annual rate of return, based in part on how much pollution they emit, a carrot-and-stick approach that could some day be a model for mainland China's giant power industries. The 10-year agreement reached this week between the Hong Kong government and the territory's two companies -- Hong Kong Electric and CLP -- authorizes the companies to charge electricity rates that will give them a 9.99 percent return on assets.

OSHIN--Saul, formerly of New York City and Ridgewood, NJ, died peacefully January 6, 2008, at age 86 in Gwynedd, PA. A beloved and caring man, he is survived by his wife Edith, sons Mark, David (Joanne Foulkrod), and John, and two grandsons. Private family memorial.

MacELREE--Lawrence, age 87 years, of Newtown Square, PA. Husband of Jane (nee Cox), married 30 years, also survived by one son John MacElree, three daughters Ellen DeVegh (Pierre), Diana MacElree and Mary MacElree, eight grandchildren, seven stepchildren and 10 stepgrandchildren. Memorial services will be held Saturday, January 12, 11am in St. Alban's Episcopal Church, Newtown Square. Contributions may be made in his memory to St. Alban's Episcopal Church, 3625 Chapel Road, Newtown Square, PA 19073 or a charity of the donors choice. Stuard Funeral Home -Ardmore, PA.

LURIA--Sydney A. P.E.F. Israel Endowment Funds mourns the passing of Sydney A. Luria, Chair of our Board of Trustees. In 1929 he hiked from Dan to Beer Sheva, which gave him strength to his 99th birthday, at all times faithful to Israel.

IN the late 1980s, when Cynthia DuBose considered herself a fanatical environmentalist, she switched to compact fluorescent bulbs, buying them through the Real Goods catalog, the only place she could find them. ''I was really amazed to find out how much less energy they use than regular light bulbs,'' she said. But it wasn't until five or six years ago that she learned that the bulbs contain mercury and shouldn't be discarded with household trash.

The largest building the architect Kevin Kennon has built in Manhattan is the massive Lehman Brothers headquarters on Seventh Avenue and 50th Street in Midtown, at 1.5 million square feet. This week, he finished his smallest: an 800-square-foot lozenge, right, tucked into an atrium at 100 William Street in the financial district. Topped with spiky aluminum ''fur'' and clad in a sleek metal skin, this new home for Booster Juice -- a Canadian juice bar and smoothie chain -- is part Airstream, part Chia Pet, as Mr. Kennon, below at far right, said recently. ''I don't know where the idea came from originally,'' he said, referring to the latter part, ''probably something to do with juice and wheat grass, but in any case we realized that when Booster Juice closed at night the place needed to do something. We needed to animate the space.''

KAPLOWITZ--Norma. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, Mrs. Norma Kaplowitz and extend our Deepest Sympathy to her husband Ralph and family. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Charles Miller, President Steven Tolman, Secretary

LITTMAN--Nanette R., passed away peacefully on January 8, 2008. Devoted wife to the late Sidney. Beloved mother to Robert R. Littman and Jane L. Ritter. Constant friend to their companions Sulley Bonnelly and Edwin I. Radlauer. Dear friend to Edith Levin and Vicki Bilski. The family is grateful to her care givers Monica and Betty. Always a Lady, she will be missed by all. Funeral services Thursday 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Interment private. Donations in her memory can be made to: Dort at the New York Philharmonic.

Madison Square Garden, the mayor's office and the Public Schools Athletic League have agreed to continue to hold the P.S.A.L. championships at the Garden, 10 months after 21 people were arrested in a melee that broke out during the title game. No one was seriously injured last March, the police said, but hundreds of people were involved and shots were fired. It was not the first time the event was marred by violence. Garden officials said at the time that they might refuse to have the championship game there in the future.On Wednesday, the Garden announced that it would play host to this season's championships after a comprehensive evaluation. The boys and girls title games are scheduled for March 16 and will be held earlier in the day, starting at 11 a.m. There will be no public sale of tickets. A maximum 5,000 tickets will be distributed -- each school will receive 750 tickets, the P.S.A.L. will receive 1,000, and the Garden will receive 1,000.

Monday, Jan. 7

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s flirtation with the idea of running for president has stretched on and on, with his enthusiastic approval despite his public denials. But even before actually entering the contest, Mr. Bloomberg may have already risked losing people’s patience, Diane Cardwell and Ray Rivera write in a front-page article, noting signs of an emerging backlash. Editorial pages from The Wall Street Journal to The New York Post, The Village Voice and The New Yorker have taken him to task. Members of the administration have been rolling their eyes and referring to Kevin Sheekey, Mr. Bloomberg’s political architect, as the deputy mayor for presidential politics.

Some City Room readers were understandably perplexed by the 14 gallons of water consumed by each use of the spiffy new pay toilet at Madison Square Park. So we will break it down for you, according to what Cemusa, the Spanish advertising conglomerate that runs the toilets, told us:

It takes certain qualities — patience, resilience, even stoicism, perhaps — to survive in New York City. That explains the selection criteria that were used to select specimens for an unusual program that will produce genetic reproductions of some of the oldest and sturdiest trees in the five boroughs.Some of the trees go as far back as the creation of Central Park in the 19th century; others are believed be even older. That’s particularly remarkable given that urban trees typically don’t survive longer than 50 years in parks and less than decade on city streets.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg deflected speculation this morning that the city could be headed for higher property taxes in the face of a weakening economy. “I don’t know that they’re going to go up,” the mayor said on his weekly call-in radio program on WABC-AM (770). “The first thing we’re going to do for the city is try to reduce spending.”
Maybe because the show never seems to win any of the awards it deserves, but fans of HBO’s “The Wire” can tend to take on a certain evangelical fervor.

We'll be the first to agree that the NHL All-Star Game is completely meaningless and a good excuse to take a short holiday from hockey. But it's still astonishing just how wrongheaded some of the selections can be.

Hong Kong's downtown galleries (which you can read about here) have become increasingly commercial and expensive, largely because of the boom in contemporary Chinese art prices overseas. On a recent tour, a friend and I saw works by local artists in small upstairs galleries retailing for a quarter-million or half-million Hong Kong dollars, or tens of thousands of U.S. dollars.

EAST LOS ANGELES -- Sometimes it's not easy being a candidate for president - particularly if you want to do something like have lunch. Hillary Rodham Clinton found that out Friday afternoon at a lunch (O.K., a photo opportunity) at King Taco, a well-known if tiny taco spot in East Los Angeles, a Mexican-American enclave here.

The Clinton campaign moved Friday to try to quell a potentially damaging backlash over recent comments by Bill and Hillary Clinton that have drawn criticism from African-Americans just as the presidential primary campaign reached Southern states with significant blocs of black voters.
The wedding of Sabeen Ali and Hashim Mian in Coral Gables, Fla., offered a colorful mix of ancient Pakistani and Muslim religious traditions and contemporary customs.

No doubt women came out strong for Hillary Rodham Clinton in New Hampshire, but the youth demographic still rallied behind Barack Obama. A new video segment on her Web site reaches out to those younger voters.

Now, we're not sure just what use this will be for most Giants fans, presumably watching the Cowboys-Giants game thousands of miles from Texas, but that is not the point. Yes, Sir Edmund Hillary is dead. But before you start muttering into your Darjeeling about how they don't make chaps like him anymore, men with pluck and courage and the daft compulsion to test the limits of human achievement at the extreme edges of the Earth, consider these odd words: Cortes Bank and Billabong.
Merrill Lynch's move to accelerate vesting on previously awarded stock-based pay to employees could add to the huge fourth-quarter loss already expected by analysts, Reuters reported Friday.
Several readers have asked whether we know what color we will be painting the exterior of the house. I've been spending most of my spare time this week contemplating the answer.

There may not be a lot of agreement among the world's religions on exactly what constitutes humans "playing God," but you never hear a preacher or rabbi suggesting such behavior is wise or laudable. So you would think they might have a lot to say about nanotechnology. After all, nanotech involves rearranging not just DNA and the other building blocks of life -- already a source of controversy in biotechnology -- but the very atoms and molecules that make up all matter. If that is not messing around in God's closet, what is?

It's a bit weird to outsiders, but a well-drafted merger agreement is something treasured by any deal lawyer. They will read through and collect these agreements over the years, pointing out the "good" and "bad" provisions to younger deal lawyers in training and referring to them in deal negotiations.

The dewy and innocent milkmaid at the center of Thomas Hardy's tragic novel "Tess of the d'Urbervilles" is destroyed not by rape or heartbreak; what does her in is genealogy. The problems start on the book's first page, when a troublemaking parson calls Tess's bumpkin father "Sir John."
Everyone knows John Edwards's dad, Wallace, fed his family on a modest millworker's salary. The Democratic candidate brings it up in nearly every speech he delivers.

Former Nebraska Senator Bob Kerrey was candid about his endorsement of Hillary Clinton, despite what he admitted was an affinity for Barack Obama's less doctrinaire politics. This was at a breakfast with some fellow-transplanted Cornhuskers (two of us, to be precise).
Some of the reviews of the fifth and final season of HBO's inner-city Baltimore drama "The Wire" practically pleaded with viewers to watch.

The Reading Room returns from its holiday hiatus next week with a discussion of "The Moviegoer," the 1962 National Book Award winner by Walker Percy. We've put together a great panel: Julia Reed, a journalist and author of a forthcoming memoir about New Orleans; Jonathan Galassi, the publisher of Farrar, Straus & Giroux; and Dean Baquet, the Washington bureau chief for The New York Times. I'll be moderating the discussion, and will kick things off next Friday with an introductory post. We'll begin in earnest on the week of the 21st.
The woman chosen to be the next leader of the New York City Bar Association has a stellar record as a trial lawyer, a federal prosecutor, and a history of pro-bono good works, to boot.

This week, Rick Wagoner, chief executive of General Motors, was at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas talking about driverless cars and the Cadillac Provoq, a concept vehicle powered by a fuel cell.

Finding enough qualified jurors to keep the justice system running has been a nagging problem in American courthouses for decades. Legislatures and court administrators have tried all kinds of angles to attack the problem, from eliminating exemptions (so more people are called) to making jury duty more convenient (so fewer people skip out) to streamlining voire dire and lopping years off the time before a juror can be called again (to make the most use of the people who do show up).

Thursday night's Republican debate in South Carolina in the wake of John McCain's comeback victory in New Hampshire and Mike Huckabee's surprising win in Iowa emphasized what a difference one week can make in the nomination process. And in terms of who will get the nod, it raises more questions than answers.

Sovereign wealth funds -- huge government-backed investment firms that control about $3 trillion -- are on a roll these days, investing huge chunks of money at a time when their capital is sorely needed. Funds based in the Middle East and Asia recently purchased stakes in Bear Stearns, the Carlyle Group and Advanced Micro Devices, just to name a few deals. Sometimes the deals seem to materialize in a matter of days.

According to a very good source, the Williams team last night sold one third interest of the team to the Baugur Group, an Icelandic investment company that specializes in retail, media and finances. Among other properties, Baugur owns a supermarket chain in Iceland, a retail chain in Denmark, and in the UK the Hamleys toy store and the House of Fraser department store.

Bank of America announced Friday that it would buy Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender, for $4 billion in stock, confirming reports that circulated the night before. But one thing remained up for debate: who was getting the better end of the deal.

One of the great Serie A rivalries will be renewed on Sunday when Napoli visits the San Siro to take on the struggling AC Milan. It was 18 years ago that Napoli, led by the irrepressible Diego Maradona and aided by Daniel Fonseca and a young Gianfranco Zola, edged Milan for the scudetto. It was the azzuri's last title before Maradona's tragi-comic, drug-fueled downfall and before Napoli suffered financial disaster.

Jesse Ausubel, who studies, well, everything at Rockefeller University's Program for the Human Environment, has long been exploring patterns of development and their broader consequences. He's a quirky, sometimes prickly, thinker who, for example, sees a fossil fuel, methane, as a keystone -- and greatly neglected -- resource serving as a bridge to a climate-friendly energy future.

The Writers Guild of America, showing good manners and an ear for the moment, announced that they will not hold their awards show on Feb. 9. The thought of holding their own fete while shutting down others seemed a little too, too, the Bagger guesses. It puts all the more attention on the Screen Actors Guild awards, which will be held on Jan. 27. So far, only SAG's awards show is expected to go off as planned, and with the consent and participation of the A-List.

New Yorker film critic David Denby has turned into the thinking man's Pete Travers, the master of breathless reviews at Rolling Stone. Mr. Denby not only suggested that Paul Thomas Anderson fumbled the end of a "There Will be Blood" on purpose, he took the froth on the latte by declaring that "The Diving Bell and the Butterfly" "feels like nothing less than the rebirth of cinema." The signs point increasingly to an imminent, or perhaps already begun, recession. Ben Bernanke has in effect pledged to do whatever is necessary. But does the Fed have what it takes?
In fending off a potentially hostile bid from Sun Capital Partners, Kellwood, the apparel maker, is using a tactic straight from the great takeover battles of the 1980s.
Standard Chartered signed an agreement on Friday to buy a mutual savings bank from South Korea's government restructuring agency for a reported 150 billion won ($160.3 million).

UBS began its campaign to win support for plans to raise $17.6 billion in new capital following the consequences of the United States subprime crisis, but warned shareholders 2008 was "likely to be another generally difficult year," The Financial Times reported.

Britain's troubled Northern Rock has sold a 2.2 billion pound ($4.3 billion) portfolio of mortgages to JPMorgan Chase, a first step to help the troubled lender repay loans from the Bank of England, Reuters reported.

London is full of hidden secrets, one of which is Temple, an area steeped in history. Here, you can find the hall where Shakespeare premiered "Twelfth Night" in 1602 (Middle Temple Hall), as well as Temple Church (built by the Knights Templar in 1185) which is featured in Dan Brown's "The Da Vinci Code." Hedge fund managers are stepping up their campaign to break up or sell the Canadian energy giant Nexen, whose stock has gone sideways over the past year, The Globe and Mail reported.

A $1 billion initial public offering planned by the tycoon Stanley Ho's Macau flagship company is giving investors a rare chance to bet on a casino boom that has been financed mostly by loans, but more raising of capital on public markets is in the cards.

A New York investment bank plans to inject $1.5 billion into Southeast Banking, a company that's been in bankruptcy for more than 16 years but still has $800 million worth of unused net operating "loss carry-forwards," which apply past losses to future profits.

Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital Partners appear to have jumped one significant regulatory hurdle for their deal to buy Clear Channel Communications, but investors still seem jittery about whether or not the deal will actually close.
