Despite News Corporation's denial of rumors that it was in talks to buy online recruiting giant Monster Worldwide for $4.8 billion, Breakingviews thinks such a deal could make sense for Rupert Murdoch's media company.

NYSE Euronext, the merged trans-Atlantic stock exchange, is lobbying the Chinese government to raise standards of corporate governance and loosen rules on where companies can raise capital as part of an effort to win business from rival markets in cities like London and Hong Kong.

Amid signs that China may be opening its securities market to more foreign investment banks, Credit Suisse announced Thursday that it was seeking to form a joint venture with a Chinese brokerage firm, Founder Securities.
Highlights from your "late night" jokes (send via the comment link below):
India, home of the world's cheapest car -- and millions of buyers who've never been behind the wheel, like the Sharma family:
Afghanistan's police force, lightly equipped, marginally trained and undermined by corruption, struggles to police a country that lacks the rule of law.

Buyers in Spain are looking inland for genuine Spanish settings and better deals, according to the latest trends report from Kyero.com, the property site. Country homes accounted for 27 percent of the searches on the site, compared to only seven percent for apartments.
"I had been an intern less than an hour, and already I was running late."

“Comanche Moon,” like “Lonesome Dove” before it, upends the classical code of the film western, one that prizes the hero’s commitment to chastely maintaining the social order as the ennobling alternative to intimacy.

On Thursday night the last two N.H.L. teams reached the regular season's halfway point (for the record, Philadelphia and St. Louis, and they both won), enabling us to bring you the league's halfway standings.
An auction for doomed horses in Shipshewana, Ind.

The unfocused spectacle that is "The Little Mermaid," more parade than narrative, achieves the dubious miracle of translating an animated cartoon into something that feels like less than two dimensions.
Livestock far outnumber humans in “Times and Winds,” Reha Erdem’s transporting vision of life in a mountain village in northwest Turkey.
“The Pirates Who Don’t Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie” is a rather ordinary film with faith at its core.
In “First Sunday,” Ice Cube departs a bit from the upright-citizen persona, playing a man driven to crime by desperate circumstances.
The drugmaker signed a deal to authorize a generic form of its osteoporosis drug Fosamax, which has annual sales of $3 billion, making it the world’s top-selling drug for osteoporosis.
Tiffany’s holiday slowdown was unexpected and sent jitters through the luxury-goods industry, which had seemed invulnerable, even as the housing market began to sputter.
As the Fed signaled it would likely cut interest rates, the  U.S. central bank and its European counterpart are  showing diverging readings of the economic tea leaves.
The candidates from both parties were trying on Friday to generate momentum for policies designed to keep the country from sinking into recession.
Lance Cpl. Maria Lauterbach, who disappeared on December 14, is believed to be dead, authorities said.
The company, whose shares fell more than 13 percent, said it was analyzing sales expectations for the next fiscal year, given uncertain consumer spending.
More so than “normal” commuters, reverse commuters are locked into their schedules.
Detectives were still trying to sort out what happened when a transit worker walking home converged with a bystander and three muggers armed with a curved knife.
The deal will bolster Bank of America’s position in the mortgage market while rescuing Countrywide from possible bankruptcy.
Markets fell on Friday as  losses stemming from subprime home loans  struck two prominent players in the financial industry.
There are signs in the last two weeks of an imbalance of public excitement that favors Democrats.

Northern Rock, one of Britain’s biggest casualties of the credit crisis, sold part of its mortgage portfolio to JPMorgan as it seeks to repay about £25 billion, or $49 billion, in emergency financing.
Chrysler and Nissan of Japan took the first step toward a possible broader alliance Friday, reaching agreement for Nissan to supply Chrysler with a small car to be sold in South America.
Bank of America will pay in stock for Countrywide Financial, the lender that became a symbol of the excesses that led to the subprime mortgage crisis.
China’s global trade surplus soared nearly 50 percent last year to a record despite an avalanche of safety warnings and recalls of Chinese-made products abroad.
A former biology teacher at a Catholic preparatory school in Manhattan has admitted sexually assaulting five students in his car and at a movie theater, prosecutors announced on Thursday.
The Rangers’ list of otherwise accomplished players sinking into inexplicable funks grew longer and more baffling on Thursday night.
Patrik Elias scored the go-ahead goal in the second period, and Martin Brodeur made 20 saves in the visiting Devils’ 4-1 victory against the Carolina Hurricanes on Thursday night.

The Well column in Science Times on Jan. 1, about excessive clutter and compulsive hoarders, omitted the names of two authors of a book on the subject. Besides David F. Tolin, the book “Buried in Treasures” was written by Randy O. Frost and Gail Steketee.

An article in Science Times on Dec. 11 about the effort to develop a malaria vaccine using live, weakened parasites grown in mosquitoes referred imprecisely to the financing of a rival vaccine invented by Dr. Pierre Druilhe, a malaria expert at the Pasteur Institute in France. Dr. Druilhe and the Gates Foundation broke off discussions over a grant for vaccine development; his project was not “rejected” by the foundation.

Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about the controversy over a plan by a Roman Catholic archbishop in Italy to exhume and place on display the body of Padre Pio, the popular Italian saint, misstated the number of years that elapsed between his death in 1968 and his canonization in 2002. It was almost 34 years, not four.

The Nice Journal article on Wednesday, about a struggle between the Russian government and local Russian Orthodox leaders over the Cathedral of St. Nicholas in Nice, France, described incorrectly the visit of Patriarch Aleksei II of Moscow to Notre Dame, the Roman Catholic cathedral of Paris. The Russian prelate went to Notre Dame to venerate the cathedral’s celebrated relic, the Crown of Thorns. He did not celebrate Mass there.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about the coming Republican Party caucus in Michigan misstated the title of Craig DeRoche, shown speaking with Mitt Romney on board a plane. He is the minority leader of the Michigan House of Representatives; he is not the speaker.

The Nice Journal article on Wednesday, about a struggle between the Russian government and local Russian Orthodox leaders over the Cathedral of St. Nicholas in Nice, France, described incorrectly the visit of Patriarch Aleksei II of Moscow to Notre Dame, the Roman Catholic cathedral of Paris. The Russian prelate went to Notre Dame to venerate the cathedral’s celebrated relic, the Crown of Thorns. He did not celebrate Mass there.

Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the men’s college basketball East roundup on Dec. 16 about Niagara’s upset victory at St. John’s misstated the year that Niagara last beat St. John’s. It was 2004 — not 1963, which was the last time Niagara won at Carnesecca Arena (formerly Alumni Hall).

A music review on Wednesday about “Three Lost Chords,” at the Zipper Factory Theater, misstated the surname of the composer at one point. As noted elsewhere in the review, he is Lance Horne, not Holmes. The review also referred incorrectly to the song in the section “The Girl I Left Behind Me.” It was written by Mr. Horne; it was not the British song of the same name. And schedule information gave an incorrect telephone number for the Zipper Factory Theater. It is (212) 352-3101.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Federal Trade Commission’s hearings on green marketing misspelled the surname of the general manager of Gaiam, a yoga equipment company that offers carbon offsets to its customers. He is Chris Fisher, not Fischer. The article also misidentified the organization that U-Haul works with to provide carbon offsets. It is the Conservation Fund, not Carbonfund.org.

A report in the Observatory column in Science Times on Tuesday, about research on ocean acidification, referred incorrectly to the experiments. They were intended to determine whether lower ocean pH, not higher pH, affected a certain type of algae. (On the pH scale, which runs from 0 to 14, the lower the number the greater the acidity.).

An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the filmmaker Goran Paskaljevic, who is the subject of a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, misstated the effect of the 9/11 terror attacks on the scheduled showing of his film “How Harry Became a Tree” at the Toronto International Film Festival in September 2001. Although Mr. Paskaljevic remained in Paris after the attacks and did not travel to Toronto, the film was in fact shown at the festival.

A report in the Metro Briefing column in some copies on Tuesday about the discovery of a body in a cesspool behind the home of a Long Island man missing for 19 months misspelled the given name of the man. He was Nicolo Caietta, not Nicholas.
Some residents of the rural neighborhood of Maromas are asking the Army Corps of Engineers to find another site for a 200,000-square-foot training center.
Crystal Langhorne had 18 points and 18 rebounds to break Len Elmore’s university rebounding record and No. 4 Maryland cruised to its ninth consecutive victory, beating host Boston College.
Earl Clark returned from a one-game suspension to post his seventh double-double of the season with 11 points and 12 rebounds Thursday as host Louisville defeated West Virginia, 63-54.
A Manhattan judge on Thursday sharply questioned the city’s decision to turn over primary use of the athletic fields on Randalls Island to a group of 20 private schools in Manhattan.
A man accused of tossing his four young children off a coastal bridge denies killing them and says the police harassed him into making a false confession, his lawyer said.
Gov. Jim Douglas proposed leasing the state lottery to a private company to raise more than $50 million for schools and for property tax reduction.
A tanker truck crashed into a concrete barrier on an Interstate 75 overpass in Detroit, causing the tanker to plummet 30 to 40 feet to the ground, where it exploded and caught fire near a home.
Two teenagers led the police on a high-speed chase and hit a parked sheriff’s cruiser, killing a deputy and a K-9 dog inside, the authorities said.

Two teenagers have been indicted on charges including attempted murder in a shooting at a school bus stop in Las Vegas that wounded six people. The teenagers, Dresden M. Williams, 18, and Franklin Jackson, 17, were indicted Wednesday and are scheduled for arraignment next week in Clark County District Court. No pleas have been entered, but lawyers for the two said their clients intended to plead not guilty in the shooting, which took place on Dec. 11.
The State Department says it will begin accepting applications for passport cards as alternatives to passports for Americans who travel to Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean.
Ed Jew resigned from the San Francisco Board of Supervisors as part of a legal settlement with the city for lying about living in the district he represents.
Telephone companies have cut off F.B.I. wiretaps used to eavesdrop on suspects because of the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s repeated failures to pay phone bills on time.

At the request of the international war crimes court in The Hague, Bosnian Serb police seized the passports of the wife, son, daughter and son-in-law of Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader during the country’s  war.

President Nicolas Sarkozy’s ex-wife Cécilia asked a Paris court to block release of a book that quotes her describing the president as a philanderer, a skinflint and “a man who loves no one, not even his children.”
Christopher R. Hill, the State Department’s point man on North Korea, urged it to give a full accounting of its nuclear weapons programs before the new president of South Korea takes office.
The Constitutional Court cleared the way for a special prosecutor to start an investigation into allegations of links by President-elect Lee Myung-bak to a 2001 stock manipulation scheme.
The deadly H5N1 strain of avian flu has reached one of England’s most famous swan breeding grounds, the Abbotsbury Swannery on the Dorset coast.
Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender that became a symbol of the excesses that led to the subprime mortgage crisis, is negotiating a sale to Bank of America.
We hope immunity will not be granted to Jose A. Rodriguez Jr. if he testifies about his decision to order the destruction of C.I.A. interrogation tapes.
Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina says he may abandon his neutral stance in his state’s primary, based in part on comments by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Michael Bloomberg’s dalliance with the idea of running for president is suddenly sparking a backlash.
An escalating labor dispute with the Archdiocese of New York closed 8 of its 10 high schools when two-thirds of teachers failed to report for work.
Some writers wonder whether the guild’s militant tactics are actually doing more damage than good.
Sir Edmund Hillary was the mountaineer who, with his Sherpa guide, was the first to scale Mount Everest.
Three linemen on the North Carolina football team are the alleged victims of kidnapping and sexual molestation in a case that has drawn uncomfortable reminders of the Duke lacrosse scandal.
Hillary Rodham Clinton’s team is hoping that her new campaign style — appealing more directly to voters — will help her in the Nevada caucuses.
Scores of investors have sought to profit by buying into troubled financial firms at low prices: so far their investments have failed to make much of a profit.

After a period of experimentation with sleeker fashion and upscale merchandise Wal-Mart, in 2007, returned with a vengeance to the strategy that built it into the world’s largest retailer: low prices.
Representatives for Major League Baseball and its players union met this week to discuss the recommendations in the Mitchell report that require the consent of both sides.
A real-life debate of the terrorism issue is lacking — one that should focus on the messy reality of the Department of Homeland Security.
Mayor Michael Bloomberg should take a strong stand on free speech and support opening up the Great Lawn to more public political expression.
A federal judge in Pennsylvania on Thursday blocked the government’s efforts to deport a Coptic Christian who said he would be tortured if he were returned to Egypt.
Fans who are not worried about the Knicks are scarce in Manhattan, but N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern is one of those rare birds.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s plan to contain the rising property taxes that support New York’s schools could mean a confrontation with the state’s largest teachers’ union.
Mr. Taylor’s projects helped shape skylines in several Southern metropolitan areas.
A huge underwater oil field discovered late last year has the potential to transform Brazil into a sizable exporter and win it a seat at the table of the world’s oil cartel.

Giant glaciers formed about 90 million years ago during a warm period when alligators thrived in the Arctic, researchers said, calling into question the belief that all ice melts in a “super greenhouse” climate.
The timing of the endorsement was intended to send a message that some Democratic leaders are coalescing around Barack Obama’s candidacy.
A wealth of nostalgia was up for auction recently at a company which has been renting kitchen supplies as props for television shows since the 1950s.
Several of the biggest, most powerful sports organizations in the United States announced Thursday the formation of a joint antidoping research program.
Merrill Lynch is expected to suffer $15 billion in losses stemming from soured mortgage investments, almost double its original estimate.

Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo’s staff spent much of Thursday explaining Mr. Cuomo’s use of “shuck and jive,” a term with racial overtones, during a radio interview on Wednesday about the presidential race.
Mr. Gruppuso was the founder of Kozy Shack Enterprises, a company in Hicksville, Long Island, that sells millions of four-ounce cups of pudding, particularly rice pudding.
When United States marshals went to evict Banita M. Jacks from her Washington, D.C., home they discovered the decomposed bodies of Ms. Jacks’s four daughters.
A local prosecutor and the Rev. Al Sharpton ratcheted up their verbal sparring match over his efforts to broker the surrender of an inmate who escaped from a New Jersey jail last month.
Brett Favre is leaning toward returning for another season with the Green Bay Packers, according to comments he made to his hometown newspaper.
Marion Jones, who became a household name after winning five medals in the 200o Olympics, will be sentenced Friday after pleading guilty to two counts of perjury.
The British government on Thursday approved plans to refresh the country’s fleet of nuclear reactors, and invited companies to offer plans to build and operate the plants.
More than a year after it convicted a black trash hauler of murder, a jury returned to court for an extraordinary hearing on whether racism influenced its verdict.

A former supervisor with the federal Citizenship and Immigration Services office in New York was sentenced in Federal District Court on Thursday to 42 months in prison for taking bribes in exchange for granting citizenship to ineligible applicants, prosecutors said. The defendant, Jimmie Ortega, 59, of Lindenhurst, N.Y., admitted that from 2004 to 2006, he used his position as an adjudications officer to obtain citizenship for at least 20 immigrants in exchange for payments of $1,500 to $4,000, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Ortega, who retired in April 2006, pleaded guilty last July to conspiracy and soliciting bribes, prosecutors said.

A 32-year-old Queens man was fatally shot early Thursday outside a West Side nightclub, the police said. The man, Brione Schneider, was shot once in the back about 3:45 a.m. after a dispute with another man that began inside the club, Stereo, and spilled into the street, the police said. He was taken to St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan and pronounced dead about 4:40 a.m., the police said. Detectives are investigating reports that the dispute was over a woman and say they believe that the assailant, who was still being sought Thursday, left the club first and may have retrieved a 9-millimeter gun from a car, the police said. Brad Zeifman, a spokesman for the club, on West 29th Street, said in a statement that the club was not aware of any prior altercation inside. The police said they brought nuisance abatement proceedings against the club last year because of drug activity, assaults and under-age drinking.

A survey by the City Health Department has found that 18 percent of the city’s adults are at increased risk for H.I.V. infection because of multiple sex partners or drug injection, but that 92 percent of that group believe they are safe. The survey also found that among the group with multiple sex partners, 60 percent do not use condoms all the time.

The companion of a man who was a former tour manager for the musicians Billy Joel and Paul Simon was sentenced Thursday in State Supreme Court to 23 years in prison for stabbing the man to death 26 months ago during a fight in their apartment. The companion, Kathleen Connors, 39, was sentenced on her guilty plea to a reduced charge of first-degree manslaughter in the slaying of the former manager, Daniel L. Harrison, 57, on Nov. 20, 2005. The police said when Ms. Connors was arrested that she and Mr. Harrison had argued violently in their Manhattan apartment, near Gracie Mansion, before the stabbing.

City health officials are investigating the death of a 17-year-old arrested on sexual misconduct charges who apparently committed suicide while jailed at Rikers Island. Jessica Scaperotti, a Health Department spokeswoman, told El Diario/La Prensa on Wednesday that the city would undertake a thorough investigation of the death of the teenager, David Mercado of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Mr. Mercado, who was arrested on Dec. 17, was placed in a dormitory with 50 other prisoners even though a state judge in Queens flagged the youth as a “suicide risk,” the newspaper reported. Correction officials said Rikers Island medical staff did not deem it necessary to place Mr. Mercado under observation. Mr. Mercado’s lawyers said he hanged himself with a sheet less than 24 hours after arriving.

About two dozen people suspected of being gang members were removed from Newark streets in a two-day sweep by F.B.I. agents and local law officers, the authorities said Thursday. Those arrested are believed to be members of a violent Bloods subset called 793 Bloods, and face weapons and drug-trafficking charges, the F.B.I. said. The gang controlled the sale of heroin and cocaine in part of the South Ward, officials said. The 23 people arrested this week are in addition to 16 arrested in the past two years as part of the same investigation, the F.B.I. said. Three others remain at large. Compiled by John Sullivan.

The federal trial of Brian M. McLaughlin, the former president of the New York City Central Labor Council, was pushed back on Thursday and is now scheduled to begin on March 10. Mr. McLaughlin, left, who is accused of illegally obtaining $2.2 million through embezzlement, fraud and bribes, was to have gone on trial in Federal District Court at the end of the month, but in court on Thursday, Judge Richard J. Sullivan said scheduling conflicts required a delay. Mr. McLaughlin, who is free on $250,000 bail, has been charged with stealing from his own organization, the State Assembly and a Little League team in Queens.

The federal government will not override New Jersey’s chemical security laws, which are tougher than the national standard, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg announced Thursday. A measure, promoted by Senator Lautenberg and recently signed by President Bush, insulates all states from federal pre-emption, and allows them to pass laws protecting their residents from an attack on chemical facilities within their borders. The co-chairmen of the Sept. 11 Commission, former Gov. Thomas H. Kean and former Representative Lee H. Hamilton, joined the National Governors’ Association and the National Conference of State Legislatures in supporting the measure.
Executives of the carrier want to engage in merger discussions with United Airlines and Northwest Airlines as a way to cut costs and stay profitable.
Edward “Buddy” LeRoux was a former trainer for the Boston Red Sox who rose to become a controversial part owner of the team while amassing a fortune in real estate.
Next year in California, state regulators are likely to have the power to control individual thermostats, overriding customers’ wishes in times of emergency.
With an economic boom in developing countries, established stock exchanges are increasingly dependent on attracting business from companies based far from their home countries.
Mr. Uemura, a Japanese makeup artist, won acclaim in Hollywood and then built an international cosmetics brand under his name.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would call for quick enactment of a $70 billion emergency spending package and for a possible $40 billion tax rebate later if economic conditions worsen.
Rep. John T. Doolittle, a California Republican, has suggested he is almost certain to face criminal charges in a Congressional lobbying scandal.
Nicholas Sprayregen is relishing the tangle with Columbia University over four of his properties that are in the path and the plans of the university’s 17-acre expansion.
For a team with few detectable flaws, the Patriots’ run defense, ranked 10th in the league, has occasionally been suspect, populated by an over-30 set of linebackers.
The only United States Army officer to face a court-martial over the scandal at Iraq’s Abu Ghraib prison has been cleared of any criminal wrongdoing in the case.
Investors found renewed confidence in a report that Bank of America is close to buying the struggling mortgage lender Countrywide Financial.
Two men who the police say wheeled the corpse of their friend up to a cash-checking shop to try to cash his Social Security check face criminal charges.
Despite a mild winter so far, New Yorkers’ heating bills are up as a result of the rising price of oil and natural gas.
The police say that the toppling of nearly 500 tombstones does not appear to be a bias attack, based on preliminary evidence.

The deal contains provisions that will allow it to be superseded by any agreement ultimately reached with the major companies through their bargaining group, the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers.
Rudolph W. Giuliani began an ad in Florida urging voters not to discount him based on news media coverage of his losses in Iowa and New Hampshire.
New York’s shiny new public toilet calls to mind not a Port-O-Let, but rather the sort of room one imagines adjoined the personal quarters of Capt. James T. Kirk on the Starship Enterprise.
The N.B.A. will not suspend Coach Isiah Thomas after he was ejected Wednesday night but the way things are going for the Knicks, a suspension would have almost seemed kind.
Ben S. Bernanke sent a strong signal that the central bank will lower interest rates again.
Faced with large deficits, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger announced a stark state budget on Thursday that included early release for thousands of inmates and closing dozens of state parks.
Mr. Grant was the avuncular honorary mayor of Hollywood who traveled the world as its No. 1 cheerleader for more than a half-century.
The Blackstone Group agreed to buy GSO Capital Partners as it seeks to build its credit operations amid tough market conditions.
Jeff Raikes, a 26-year veteran of Microsoft, plans to retire later this year and the company announced that it was reaching outside its ranks for his successor.
Mr. Keppler was a publisher and columnist at leading photographic magazines who advised amateur photographers on everything from lenses and shutter speeds.
Cowboys receiver Terrell Owens, who declined to speak to reporters Thursday, returned to practice for the first time since sustaining a high left ankle sprain on Dec. 22.
The $19.5 billion deal will take Clear Channel Communications, the nation’s largest radio broadcaster, private.
The Brooklyn district attorney’s office announced Thursday the seizure of 75 pounds of nearly pure cocaine and the indictment of seven Panamanians on drug conspiracy charges.

Badri Patarkatsishvili, a bitter rival of President Mikheil Saakashvili and a losing presidential candidate in the election last Saturday, was also charged with conspiring to overthrow the government.
The Texas attorney general’s office will investigate whether the district attorney of Harris County should lose his job for sending and receiving inappropriate e-mail messages.
Inventories at wholesalers rose more than forecast in November and sales increased, reflecting rising prices for oil and farm products.

The House and Senate Judiciary Committees are seeking details of contracts that the department directed to outside lawyers who are monitoring companies in out-of-court settlements of criminal allegations.
The company will take a $275 million fourth-quarter charge as more cardholders fail to repay their debts.
Credit Suisse announced Thursday that it was seeking to form a joint venture with a Chinese brokerage firm, Founder Securities.
Only three casinos in Atlantic City, the gambling resort which for years has known nothing but growth, reported increasing revenue for the year.
Tide, the biggest detergent brand in America — sold by the biggest advertiser in America — will appear for the first time on the biggest day for advertising in America.
Lance Stephenson, a point guard from Coney Island who is considered a top national prospect, was suspended from school and will miss three games for his role in a fight with a teammate.
When elephants were removed from a research site in Kenya, a mysterious decline in the colonies of good ants and a growth in the colonies of bad ants emerged.
Researchers at Harvard Medical School have identified 273 proteins that the AIDS virus needs to survive in human cells, which could lead to new strategies for combating the disease.
Kenyan democracy has failed because ordinary people were encouraged to believe that the process in and of itself could bring change.
Poland’s new government intends to press the United States to pay for positioning 10 interceptors in Polish territory, expecting negotiations to continue until after the U.S. presidential elections.

Eras will end at the New York Philharmonic next season as Lorin Maazel finishes his seven-year run as music director and Stanley Drucker, the principal clarinetist, retires.
The $461 million performing arts center in Miami, entering its second year and struggling financially, has received a $30 million infusion.

The outcry from London theater professionals has been growing in response to proposals by Arts Council England, the government arts-development agency, to cut or eliminate financing for nearly 200 arts organizations.
Katharine McPhee has left RCA after a single album, Billboard reported.
Tina Brown, the former editor of Vanity Fair, The New Yorker and Talk magazine, has signed with Doubleday Broadway Publishing Group to write a portrait of the Clinton era.
Five winners of Costa Book Awards, formerly the Whitbread Book Awards, have been chosen from 553 entries to compete for the 2007 Costa Book of the Year Award.
The maverick Chinese filmmaker Zhang Yuan was arrested after he was found taking drugs in his Beijing home, Reuters reported.
Steven Monder, the president of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, will retire in June after 37 years, the orchestra announced.
A new novel by Salman Rushdie, will be published on June 3 by Random House.
The Metropolitan Museum is bidding goodbye to the Euphronios krater, a 2,500-year-old vessel that has been a showpiece of its collection for more than three decades.
NBC won a slim victory over second-place CBS in the ratings on Wednesday, largely because of its game-show programming at 8.
Sony BMG announced that it would become the fourth and final major music label to sell digital music on Amazon.com.
This sprawling show of historic masks and contemporary works at the James Cohan Gallery is filled with interesting cross-references and juxtapositions.
Sex, death and religion, art’s old stand-bys, its holy trinity, are alive, weird and living, at  “Keith Edmier 1991-2007” at Hessel Museum in Bard College.
Wednesday’s performance of “What if Saori Had a Party?,” about dreams versus reality, is surprisingly intricate but more artful than engrossing.
“The Hand-Drawn Negative” at Peter Freeman, “Art & Project Bulletins: 1968-1989” at Specific Object/David Platzker and “Drawing in Space” at Richard L. Feigen & Company.
Fiona Shaw is indisputably the queen of the mountain in Deborah Warner’s blazing production of Samuel Beckett’s “Happy Days.”

What exactly is a family film, anyway? The rating doesn’t always tell the story.

Wednesday’s program at the Joyce Theater ended with  “Shining Star,” a snazzy-looking, funny and sexy group dance that captures the sound and spirit of songs by Earth, Wind & Fire, to which it is set.
Andrew J. Nemr’s disciplined, likable ensemble manage  to be appealing without being particularly engaging in “Where the Music Lives” at the Julia Miles Theater.
The European Central Bank left its key interest rate unchanged on Thursday but signaled that it could raise it pre-emptively if generous wage deals threaten to ignite inflation.

Jordan Harrison’s brash play turns fragments from the life of Leni Riefenstahl, the filmmaker who made movies for Hitler, into a story that is funny and thought provoking.
In charting such a precise path from Mr. Serra to brand-new work with a YouTube following, the Whitney Museum’s new show historicizes a medium that is still in transition.
The African Union announced that Kofi Annan, the former secretary general of the United Nations, will try to broker a truce in Kenya.
This season the most talked-about Americana sale is probably the personal collection of the veteran dealer Marguerite Riordan of Stonington, Conn.
One of Hollywood’s biggest independent film companies is expected to announce an agreement with striking writers.
AROUND TOWN.
Colombian guerrillas freed two politically prominent hostages on Thursday, handing them over to emissaries of President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela.
An independent prosecutor will investigate whether President-elect Lee Myung-bak engaged in financial misdeeds.
The United States urged North Korea on Thursday to rethink its position and give a “complete and correct” accounting of its nuclear weapons programs.
Here’s an apt attraction for the start of the new year: “The Art of Time” at the Metropolitan Museum, a wonderful presentation of about 90 European timepieces from the museum’s permanent collection.
Rarely has a more conflicted or unpromising candidate entered the field of medicine, and this mismatch gives “Intern” its offbeat appeal.
As incomes rise and cheap cars proliferate, Indians are developing a new affection for the automobile.
Human rights groups have condemned the amputation punishments and the 23 disclosed executions this year.
President Bush outlined a two-state peace treaty he is hoping to broker between Israel and the Palestinians.

Put me squarely in the minority, among the people who do not view Bill Belichick as the walking manifestation of evil or the Nixon White House or whatever those barking dogs are telling ESPN.com’s Gregg Easterbrook to write these days. I care little about the New England coach’s cinematography, less about his habit of running up points until the scoreboards say “tilt,” and least of all about his churlishness with the same media scolds who reckon a postgame handshake a glimpse into a man’s soul. He may not be the National Football League’s warmest presence, but he is a very good coach of what may be the very best football team ever concocted, and once upon a time that would have been enough.
American aircraft attacked an area known as a haven for militants linked to Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.
An explosion, apparently detonated by a suicide attacker, was aimed at police officers protecting a rally in Lahore.

Horse slaughter virtually ended in the United States last year, but there have been unintended consequences.
The weakest holiday shopping season in five years ended dismally for most retailers, stoking fears that the economy is tipping into a recession.
The New York State attorney general issued a wide-ranging subpoena as part of an investigation into whether the Intel Corporation violated federal or state antitrust laws.
The United States and Germany have agreed to recognize Kosovo after it declares independence and to urge the rest of Europe to follow suit, say senior European Union diplomats.
As the mortgage mess grows, we are learning more and more about just how sloppy things were in the mortgage-issuing business.

BROADWAY PLAYHOUSE Children may not seem like an audience that would fall in love with Cole Porter's music. But Kaufman Center's concert on Sunday is intended to help them do it, with a natural ease that might be appreciated even by birds, bees and educated fleas. Titled ''Cole Porter: Anything Goes,'' the program opens the second season of Broadway Playhouse, a series Kaufman Center officials believe is the first to introduce elementary school listeners to musical theater classics. ''Years ago we were thinking about a series for children about classical music,'' said Sean Hartley, the director of Kaufman Center's Theater Wing and the creator of Broadway Playhouse. ''I realized there were a lot of those, but hardly anything that examined theater music.''

One is ''The Ten Steps,'' Brendan Muldowney's brief and bloodless but deliciously spooky thriller from Ireland. RUBIN--Harvey, M.D., 89, of La Jolla, CA, died January 2. NYC born, son of Dr. I.C. Rubin, world famous OB/GYN, infertility expert. Grandparents Israel and Bella Unterberg helped establish the NYC 92nd Street Y. Graduated Yale, University of Chicago and earned his M.D. at NYU Medical College. Served as a naval officer in WWII. In 1961 moved his family to California and established his psychiatric practice. Published 32 research papers on protein synthesis. Survived by wife Donna, children Harvey Jr., June (Tom Gingell) and Linda of San Diego

Rarely do people work so hard to drum up votes for no one in particular. Because Michigan's Jan. 15 primary violates Democratic National Committee rules, Senator Barack Obama and John Edwards withdrew from the state's race, leaving Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as the party's only major candidate on the ballot. (Mrs. Clinton has pledged not to campaign here.) But a last-minute campaign by supporters of Mr. Edwards and Mr. Obama urges voters to vote ''uncommitted'' to help them gain momentum and to deal a setback to Mrs. Clinton.

The Magazine Antiques and Brant Publications mourn the inconceivable loss of Allison Eckardt Ledes, the esteemed editor of Antiques, who died in New York on January 8. She was 53. Allison came to Antiques right after graduating from Vassar in 1975 and became its editor in 1990. Her passion for its contents and the integrity with which she approached the material will forever be part of the magazine's history. Admired throughout the world of art and antiques, she served on the boards of numerous organizations in the field and of Miss Hall's School in Pittsfield, MA. She is survived by her husband George M. and daughters Meredith A. and Abigail E. Ledes, as well as by her mother, June M. Doyle of Redding, CT, and sisters, Lynne A. Eckardt of Brewster, NY, and Anne E. Demas of Hanover, NH. A private funeral will be held at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, NY, on Saturday. A memorial and celebration of her life will be held at the Park Avenue Armory in NYC on January 23. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in her name to the American Friends of Attingham NYC or Miss Hall's School.

MERLIN JAMES: 'PAINTINGS OF BUILDINGS' Rarely bigger than the front of a microwave oven, Merlin James's paintings may seem at first too slight to keep you in a gallery for long. This show's 26 semi-abstract paintings of houses and buildings, dating from 1993 to 2007, may resemble dutiful exercises made under the tutelage of an old-fashioned British formalist. (Mr. James, born in 1960, is British.) Look closer, however, and you'll be hooked. Mr. James is not a finicky representational painter. Following painters like Matisse and Klee, he simplifies his subjects into flat planes or matrices of gridded lines. Some pictures, like views of a Roman aqueduct or of a street corner that Edward Hopper might have painted, look as if they were copied from photographs.

UNDER THE RADAR If you wander into Veselka restaurant anytime between noon and midnight these days, you may not realize that the folks sitting at one table are both actors and audience members for an unusual two-person production, courtesy of Rotozaza, a London theater company. The show, ''Etiquette,'' which opened in London almost a year ago, has visited several countries since and was presented at the Theater Communications Group conference at the Guthrie Theater last June (with Sunder Ganglani and Anne Erbe, above). It is being presented at Veselka, a Ukrainian diner in the East Village, by the Foundry Theater as part of the fourth annual Under the Radar festival. Only two at a time perform in this show (tickets must be bought in pairs) by wearing headphones that transmit recorded instructions. They need only listen and obey.

10 P.M. (13) TODAY'S MAN From the time Nicky Gottlieb was an infant, his family knew he was not like other children. He had stellar math skills as a small child, yet couldn't carry on a conversation or connect with his peers. When he was 21, his condition was diagnosed as Asperger's syndrome, a high-functioning form of autism that was not recognized in the United States until 1994. In this ''Independent Lens'' documentary Lizzie Gottlieb, Nicky's sister (above, with Nicky), tries to make sense of his life and learn how to help him, as he struggles to venture beyond the security of his family home -- which he shares with his father, the editor Robert Gottlieb, and his mother, the actress Maria Tucci -- and his favorite television shows to become a functioning adult with a job, an apartment and friends. 8 P.M. (CBS) GHOST WHISPERER Melinda (Jennifer Love Hewitt) maneuvers through a tangle of gossip and romance as she tries to get to the bottom of the haunting at the new high school of Ned (Christoph Sanders).

RICHARD SIEGAL In 2004 Richard Siegal choreographed ''Stranger,'' a solo to be seen by a single spectator by appointment only. That viewer was led down a labyrinth of corridors at the Frankfurt Opera House, where Mr. Siegal was part of William Forsythe's Frankfurt Ballet. Then, in a darkened room, the observer was offered a whispered narrative of espionage and intrigue, punctuated by the choreographer's slippery, disembodied movement. The American-born Mr. Siegal -- who danced with Doug Elkins, Zvi Gotheiner and Janis Brenner before joining the Frankfurt Ballet in 1997 -- has long been interested in the disjunctions between performance and reality. In ''Stranger'' his confessions about spying and lying took on an unsettling, all-too-plausible resonance that notably undermined the comfortable space between audience and artist. Mr. Siegal's work has been presented primarily in Europe, and his company, the Bakery, is based in Paris and Frankfurt. Last year the second installment of his ''Stranger'' series, ''Stranger/Stranger Report'' (with Mr. Siegal, above), had its premiere at the Théâtre National de Chaillot in Paris. But on Thursday Mr. Siegal will show the premiere of the third ''Stranger'' work, ''As if Stranger,'' at Danspace Project.

LeMASTER--Jay, Jerome Lloyd, Jr., (Jay), 80, beloved husband of Jane, December 27 at Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home after a long illness. The son of a professor of Business Law at Oregon State University, Jay had an abiding love for the rule of law and put that love to work for the International Association of Laryngectomees. As a member of the Board of Directors, he was a longtime member and chairman of the Bylaws Committee. In addition to working on year-toyear changes, he was responsible for a comprehensive revision of the bylaws several years ago. It was a massive undertaking since, over the years, inconsistencies had developed and Jay worked hard to clean up this essential IAL document. Before becoming a laryngectomee in 1991 he was a self employed artist and illustrator, a graduate of both Oregon State University and the Arts Center College of Design in Pasenda, CA. Jay was a pillar of his local support club (Nu Voices of Mount Sinai Hospital) and was involved in all aspects of its work. Especially active in Tobacco Awareness, he spoke to thousands of students over the years, primarily at Washington Irving High School. The mounds of letters from students who wrote him saying they would never smoke and would encourage family members to stop smoking was a source of great pride and joy for him. Also active in working to make New York's public places smoke-free, he participated in the famous demonstration with activist Michael Moore at the corporate headquarters of the Philip Morris Tobacco Company to protest their advertising, particularly to young people. The demonstration later moved to the home of the CEO of Philip Morris where demonstrators decorated trees with empty cigarette packages. Jay and his wife Jane loved the theater. When they attended the IAL's Annual Meeting and danced at the banquet, people loved to refer to them as ''Fred and Ginger.'' Jay helped new laryngectomees and their families learn that there is a life, and a full one, after a laryngectomy. Memorial Sloan - Kettering awarded Jay a Certificate of Recognition in honor of his constant devotion for his many years of compassionate service and expertise as a patient-to-patient volunteer. We celebrate the entire life of Jay LeMaster, especially his unselfish attention to his fellow laryngectomees whenever he found one in need of help, answers or inspiration. Donations may be sent in his honor to Post Treatment Resource Program, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021.

Roger Federer, recovering from a stomach virus and out of competition since November, landed in the same half of the Australian Open draw as No. 3 Novak Djokovic and four former finalists Friday. The tournament will start Monday. Bidding for a third consecutive Australian title and 13th Grand Slam victory, Federer will open against Diego Hartfield of Argentina and could meet the veteran Frenchman Fabrice Santoro, in his 62nd major, in the second round.James Blake and Tomas Berdych are in Federer's quarter and, if seeded players progress on rankings, Federer will meet No. 7 Fernando González in the quarterfinals -- a rematch of last year's final. Djokovic looms in the semis if he can get past a tough quarter that includes the former Australian Open champions Marat Safin and Thomas Johansson, both unseeded, and the former finalists Marcos Baghdatis (2006) and Lleyton Hewitt (2005).

In his years as a diplomatic negotiator, Bill Richardson learned to never offend anyone and to look for something positive in each individual. So as Mr. Richardson, New Mexico's governor, ended his presidential bid Thursday, before about 300 well-wishers at the Statehouse in Santa Fe, he had a nice word for the candidates in the Democratic field. Yes, even for former Senator Mike Gravel of Alaska, who is still in the race. Mr. Richardson paid tribute to two former candidates, saying of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware that his ''passion and intellect are remarkable'' and calling Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut ''the epitome of selfless dedication, public service and the Democratic Party.''

'SCREEN TEST' For six years in the 1990s Rob Roth, a downtown video director and designer, promoted a ''cyber-fetish-nightlife spectacle'' called Click + Drag at the Chelsea club Mother. The party was famous for its over-the-top costumed crowd and raunchy attitude. When the club closed, Mr. Roth didn't pack up his latex and strobe lights. He simply went legit. One result is ''Screen Test,'' a rock opera starring Theo Kogan, formerly of the all-female punk group Lunachicks. Ms. Kogan, above, and her new band, the Skyscrapers, composed the music for the show, which blends theater, performance art, dance and video installation as a meditation on artifice, old-school Hollywood glamour and new-school politics. ''It's a statement about facade, about what's real,'' Mr. Roth said. ''A lot of the dialogue is about submerging yourself in a fantasy world. Especially in a political climate like today, I just feel like we have to create our own fantasy world; it's a survival mechanism to guard against the ugliness that's outside.'' The hourlong show had its premiere last year as part of Performance Space 122's multimedia Coil Festival, and is featured this year as well.

NYC WINTER JAZZFEST For the next five days the Association of Performing Arts Presenters converges on New York for its annual conference, a gathering of industry types who share (among other things) a pressing need for new artists and ideas. And for the fourth consecutive year the producer Brice Rosenbloom is courting that constituency with the NYC Winter Jazzfest, spread throughout the three floors of the Knitting Factory. For conference attendees as well as the nearly two dozen participating groups, the aim of this marathon, or smorgasbord, is exposure. But since it's open to the public and a bargain ($25 for the night), it also translates into one of the more exciting jazz events of the season. As in previous years Mr. Rosenbloom's lineup favors slightly experimental artists, often in working bands. This includes ensembles led by the Iraqi-American trumpeter Amir ElSaffar, the Israeli bassist Omer Avital and the South African tenor saxophonist Zim Ngqawana. (Internationalism is another hallmark of the festival, which was partly supported this year by the French Embassy and the Mexican Institute of Culture.) Chamber music will be represented by Magic Circle, a trio organized by the trumpeter Dave Douglas; and another trio consisting of the Czech violinist Iva Bittova, the Australian pianist Lisa Moore and the Bronx-born clarinetist Don Byron. The bassist Ben Allison will lead Man Size Safe, a quintet with a new album releasing this month. Other groups will reflect the ambitions of the saxophonists Donny McCaslin, J. D. Allen, Matana Roberts and Jerome Sabbagh; the guitarists Brad Shepik and Doug Wamble; and the keyboardists Wayne Horvitz and Eldar, among others.

A University of Washington booster offered $200,000 for law school scholarships if Coach Ty Willingham and Athletic Director Todd Turner were fired, The Seattle Times reported Thursday. The offer made by Ed Hansen, a multimillionaire lawyer and former three-term mayor of Everett, to Mark A. Emmert, the university president, was included in about 1,000 e-mail messages obtained by The Times in a public-records request. The e-mail messages were sent to Emmert, Willingham and Turner over the past four months. Emmert said he routinely disregarded financial threats or offers based on personnel decisions as ''grossly inappropriate'' and ''the kind of commentary I don't take seriously at all.''

BIJUR--Marion E., died peacefully on January 8, 2008. A Barnard graduate, a woman of intelligence, beauty and grace, combined love of family with a career as author, managing editor of the United Nations Association's Vista Magazine, editor of publications, Bruce Museum. Loving wife of the late Herbert Bijur, proud mother of Peter, Priscilla and Polly and beloved grandmother to her eight grandchildren.

ALBERT--Floyd Benjamin, age 86, died on January 9, 2008 from complications of Parkinson's Disease. Economist, poet, loving husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife Louise, children Elizabeth, David and Alice, son-in-law and daughter-in-law, Alan and Muriel, and grandchildren Jacob, Zoe, and Alexander, and sisters Rita and Jackie. He was deeply loved by everyone. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday, January 13, 12pm, at Ballard Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168th Street, NY, NY 10032.

Crestone is a 220-mile drive from Denver International Airport. There are also daily flights to Alamosa Municipal Airport, which is 50 miles south of Crestone, on Great Lakes Airlines (www.flygreatlakes.com). Round-trip fares start about $165. While Crestone is a second-home haven, there are inexpensive places for visitors to stay. Golden Harmony B & B (1361 Chaparral Way; 719-256-4810; www.kiaraperkins.com) is a comfortable and private New Age guesthouse in the Baca Grande area. DeMARTINO--Anthony. The medical staff of Lawrence Hospital Center in Bronxville, NY, mourns the passing of Dr. Anthony G. DeMartino on January 7th, 2008. A member of the staff for more than 30 years, Dr. DeMartino was a respected and beloved colleague. His wisdom and generosity of spirit was unparalleled. He was a good friend and a wonderful teacher. He was a superb physician and we all benefitted from our relationship with him. His patients, his colleagues and all who knew and worked with him will remember him always.

Ante Jazic, a 31-year-old defender for the Los Angeles Galaxy, could miss up to three months of the Major League Soccer season after having right ankle surgery, the club announced Thursday. Jazic was not expected back until May at the earliest after an operation that removed and repaired cartilage.

BRODSKY--Samuel, age 95, died January 8th with family by his side. He leaves behind his devoted wife Margery Bach Brodsky, whom he married when he was a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy during World War II. He dedicated himself to the practice of the law from which he fully retired at 88. He began his career as clerk to Federal Circuit Court Judge Julian W. Mack and then as assistant U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York. As a lawyer in private practice he specialized in taxation and corporate law serving as chairman of the tax section of the New York State Bar Association and lecturer on taxation at NYU School of Law. He was past president and trustee of Central Synagogue in New York City where he resided. His steadfast love enriched the lives of his daughters, Joan Brodsky Schur and Alice B. Forcier, their husbands and his three granddaughters. He was a loyal and loving brother of Marion Brodsky and the late Leon Brock. Memorial service February 15 at 11:00am at the Harvard Club. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Congregation Ahavas Achim, 84 Hastings Ave., Keene, NH 03431. BRODSKY--Samuel/d, Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of our longtime member and past president. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Howard F. Sharfstein, President

SHAND--Dena Louise, loving and generous wife and mother died on Sunday, December 30, 2007 from cancer. She is survived by husband Ian, children Kevin and Megan and their spouses Jordin and Zak. Memorial services will be held at Grace Church, 254 Hicks St., Brooklyn Heights, NY on Saturday January 12, at 3pm. For Directions and Information call Heights & Hill Funeral Directors 718 797-3248. In lieu of flowers, donations are preferred to Calvary Hospital in memory of Dena Shand, 718-518-2077.

RUBER--Olga Barbara, nee Goldstein, 103, January 5, 2008 at her home in Manhattan. Born Botosani, Romania. Widow of beloved Arthur Ruber, died 1934, Galati, Romania. Loving sister of Fiamette Kopolovitz, Doris Vineanu, Sonia Weber, Maurice Goldstein, John Garrett; aunt of Jean Coppot, and Eugen Weber; all predeceased. Witnessed Romanian fascism's ugly rise. Fled with her two young daughters, traveling a circuitous route during WWII before settling in NYC. Worked many years at J. Berle, then, as a volunteer at St. Vincent's Hospital. Survived by loving children Miorica (Warren) Demlin and Nadia (Jerome) Miller; nephew, Ernest Schor; grandchildren Arthur (Marjorie) Miller and Richard (Karen) Miller and four greatgrandchildren. Olga loved life, family, friends. Always had a positive outlook. An inspiration!

An obituary by The Associated Press on Tuesday about Rabbi Shmuel Berenbaum, leader of the Mir Yeshiva in Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to its policy on music, song and dance, and referred imprecisely to the Torah, the sole subject of the yeshiva’s curriculum. As defined by Orthodox Jews, the Torah can include the Old Testament, commentaries upon it and the oral tradition known as the Talmud — not just the first five books of the Bible. And the yeshiva does in fact permit music, song and dance; they are not shunned.

The Sports of The Times column on Thursday about Oscar Pistorius, who runs world-class times on artificial lower legs, referred imprecisely to Lou Brissie, a World War II veteran who nearly lost a lower leg in combat and went on to pitch in baseball’s 1949 All-Star Game. He was a left-hander, not a righty.

An article in some editions on Thursday about the Knicks’ 101-92 loss to the Houston Rockets misidentified the referee who ejected Coach Isiah Thomas after there was incidental contact between them. It was Eric Lewis — not Dan Crawford, another official working the game. Because of an editing error, an article on Friday repeated the error. And a picture caption in some editions with the article on Friday, using information from the European Pressphoto Agency, misidentified the referee shown with Mr. Thomas. It was Mr. Lewis, not Mr. Crawford.

An obituary Friday about Sir Edmund Hillary, who with Tenzing Norgay became the first to scale Mount Everest, misidentified the route they took to the summit. It is the South Col, not the South Tor. In comparing the feat to one by Charles A. Lindbergh, the obituary misstated Lindbergh’s accomplishment. Though he was the first to make a solo nonstop trans-Atlantic flight, in 1927, he was not the first aviator to make the nonstop crossing; John W. Alcock and Arthur W. Brown did so together in 1919, from Newfoundland to Ireland. In addition, the precedents for Sir Edmund’s reaching the South Pole in 1957-58 were referred to incorrectly. Robert Falcon Scott reached the pole in 1912, and the United States built a base there in 1956; Sir Edmund was not the first to reach the pole since Roald Amundsen in 1911.

Picture captions with an article on Tuesday about the aftermath of a disputed presidential election in Kenya misspelled the name of the president’s ethnic group, whose members were targets of much of the violence by opposition supporters. They are the Kikuyus, not the Kiyukus.

An article in some editions on Friday about Thursday’s Republican presidential debate in Myrtle Beach, S.C., referred incompletely to the sponsors of the debate. In addition to the South Carolina Republican Party, Fox News Channel sponsored the debate.

An article in some editions on Jan. 2 about construction of a park on the site of the High Line elevated tracks in Lower Manhattan misidentified the employer of Gerard Zimmermann, a chief inspector, who said the elevation of the project was not a problem for workers. He works for the LiRo Group, a construction consulting firm, not Kiska Construction, the general contractor.

Visits to Sweden’s national museums dropped nearly 20 percent last year after they ended their free admissions policy, Agence France-Presse reported. The culture ministry said that Sweden’s 19 national museums, 16 of them in Stockholm, recorded some 6.5 million visits in 2007, down from around 8.0 million a year earlier. The decline came after Sweden’s government pushed through new admission fees to the museums starting on Jan. 1, 2007, two years after the previous government had removed the fees.

With new episodes of ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” and CBS’s “CSI” at 9 p.m. on Thursday, both networks surged to the top of the night’s ratings. “CSI” attracted the largest audience, 18.1 million, Nielsen estimated. But “Grey’s Anatomy” (17.6 million) led among viewers ages 18 to 49, putting ABC on top in that demographic. CBS’s "Without a Trace" won at 10 p.m. in total viewers (13.8 million), while “ER” on NBC (9.1 million) ranked first in the hour among the 18-to-49 group. For the night, NBC ranked third in that age group, with “The Celebrity Apprentice” at 9 (8.1 million), “My Name is Earl” (7.7 million) and “30 Rock” (6 million).

Ringo Starr, above, returned to his hometown of Liverpool, England, on Friday to help kick off the city’s year as a European Capital of Culture, The Associated Press reported. The ex-Beatle joined Dave Stewart of Eurythmics in headlining an outdoor concert that included about 600 local musicians. On Saturday Mr. Starr is to appear in “Liverpool, the Musical,” a tribute to the city’s musical heritage, which features the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra and local rock groups. Each year two cities in the European Union are designated culture capitals.

A man who tried to extort $1.3 million from Tom Cruise in exchange for stolen photographs of his wedding to Katie Holmes was sentenced to two years probation, The Associated Press reported. Marc Lewis Gittleman was also fined $3,000 after pleading guilty on Sept. 21 to interstate transportation of stolen property. Mr. Gittleman, a computer technician, obtained thousands of photos from a damaged hard drive that was brought to his workplace by a photographer. He then contacted David Hans Schmidt, 47, who was known for peddling nude pictures and sex tapes of celebrities, and sent Mr. Cruise an e-mail message demanding $1.3 million to keep the pictures private. The authorities set up a sting operation to catch the two men. Mr. Schmidt pleaded guilty to transmitting threatening communications with intent to extort and hanged himself in September.

A giant sculpture of a spider by Louise Bourgeois, similar to one, below, that has been luring the crowds to Tate Modern on London’s South Bank, has been donated to the gallery, the BBC reported. Vicente Todoli, the museum’s director, called the gift of the almost 30-foot-tall work, titled “Maman,” a “historic moment.” The steel and bronze sculpture was given to the Tate by Ms. Bourgeois and an anonymous benefactor. It is the largest of a series of spiders made by Ms. Bourgeois, now 96. The artist, who lives in New York, has described the piece as “an ode to my mother, my best friend.” She added: “Like spiders, my mother was very clever. Spiders are friendly presences that eat mosquitoes.”.

The Norwegian Supreme Court on Friday increased the sentences of two men convicted of stealing two masterworks by Edvard Munch, “The Scream” and “Madonna,” right, and ordered a new trial for a third convicted man, The Associated Press reported. The paintings were stolen in August 2004 in a daylight raid on the Munch Museum in Oslo. They were recovered by police nearly two years later, and are undergoing repairs for scrapes, punctures, loose paint and moisture damage. Last month the three men appealed their 2006 sentences. In answer, Norway’s highest court unanimously ruled that the prison terms for two of the men, Petter Tharaldsen and Stian Skjold, were not long enough, considering the “irreplaceable national cultural value” of the paintings. The court increased Mr. Tharaldsen’s sentence by one year, to 10 ½ years, and Mr. Skjold’s sentence by six months, to six years. The court did reject the conviction of a third man, Bjoern Hoen, saying that testimony in his trial may have been tainted, and sent his case back for a new trial.

Two hundred years after it was pulled from the silt of the River Thames, a bronze head of the Emperor Hadrian, below, ruler of the Roman Empire from 117 to 138, will leave the British Museum for the first time, bound for sites along the 73-mile wall he ordered constructed in Northern England to mark the Roman frontier, the BBC reported. The head, once part of a statue thought to have been displayed in London in 122 to commemorate Hadrian’s visit, is to be exhibited at Tullie House in Carlisle next month and at the Segedunum Roman Fort, Baths and Museum in Wallsend in April, before returning for the exhibition “Hadrian: Empire and Conflict” on July 24.

Aidan Quinn completes the cast of the new history play by Richard Nelson, “Conversations in Tusculum,” at the Public Theater. Mr. Quinn is to play Brutus alongside Brian Dennehy as Cicero, Joe Grifasi as Syrus, Gloria Reuben as Porcia, David Strathairn as Cassius and Maria Tucci as Servilia. Previews begin Feb. 19.

LESLIE--Cy. National Council of Jewish Women, Peninsula Section, mourns the loss of the husband of our esteemed past President, Barbara Leslie. Together, their devotion and support has made a difference to our organization. We extend our sympathy to the entire Leslie family.

WOLF--Diane R. The Wolf Family is deeply saddened by the sudden loss of Diane R. Wolf on January 10, 2008. She was 53. Loving daughter of Erving and Joyce Wolf. Cherished sister of Daniel and Mathew Wolf. Dear sister-inlaw to Ann Wolf and Maya Lin. Adoring aunt to Daisy, Henry, Benjamin, Rachel and India Wolf. Diane was a woman of intelligence, beauty, grace and compassion. She was a philanthropist who served locally and nationally. Diane was on the boards of the U.S. Senate Preservation Board of Trustees, the Library of Congress Madison Council, the Foundation for the National Archives Board of Trustees, the National Public Radio Foundation Board of Trustees, the National Trust for Historic Preservation Council, the Georgetown University Law Center Board of Visitors, the Kennedy Center National Committee for the Performing Arts and the International Committee on the Arts, the National Symphony Orchestra National Trustees, the Washington National Opera Board of Trustees, and the Smithsonian Council of American Art. She was the past president of the Federal Bar Association, Capitol Hill Chapter. Diane was appointed by President Reagan to the U.S. Commission of Fine Arts, where she served as Commissioner from 1985 to 1990. She served on the Rockefeller University Council and was a benefactor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Diane received her undergraduate degree cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania, received a masters degree in education from Columbia University and obtained her juris doctorate degree from Georgetown University Law Center. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, January 13, 2008, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, the Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York. Burial services will be held on Monday, January 14, 2008, in Ridgway, Colorado. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Diane Wolf Fund at the New York Cornell Hospital

Every time the Packers and the Seahawks meet, it is like a small family reunion. For starters, Seahawks Coach Mike Holmgren once led the Packers to a Super Bowl title, and lest anyone forget the impression he left on the city, he will cruise to the game down Holmgren Way. Seahawks quarterback Matt Hasselbeck started his career in Green Bay. His mentor? The Packers' ageless quarterback, Brett Favre, he of the 4,155 passing yards and 28 passing touchdowns this season. The last time these teams met in the playoffs, in January 2004, Hasselbeck famously shouted during the overtime coin toss: ''We want the ball. And we're going to score!'' He threw an interception that the Packers returned for the winning touchdown.

Cy -you will be missed by all of us and your myriad of friends. Tony Martell Chairman and Founder T.J. Martell Foundation

LAYOFFS AT ENGINE MAKER Rolls-Royce Group, a leading manufacturer of aircraft engines, said that it would trim nearly 6 percent of employees from its payroll. The company aims to cut up to 2,300 managerial, professional and clerical staff in Britain, the United States, Germany, the Nordic countries and elsewhere. In July, Rolls-Royce reported a net profit for the first half of £306 million ($597 million at current exchange rates), half the amount reported for the same period in 2006. (AP) CIT REPORTS A LOSS The CIT Group, the independent commercial finance company, had a fourth-quarter net loss of $125 million to $135 million as it wrote down its student-loan business and added to reserves for bad mortgages. The write-off at the student lending business will probably reduce net income by $300 million, the lender said. The increased reserves for credit losses, primarily in its home lending portfolio, will reduce net income by about $190 million. CIT is exiting the mortgage-lending business, which once accounted for about 10 percent of the company's income.

Just three days after Tuesday's primary election, the New Hampshire secretary of state's office says it will conduct a hand recount of the votes in both the state's Republican and Democratic primaries starting next Wednesday after receiving formal requests from two candidates this week. On Friday, Albert Howard, a candidate from Ann Arbor, Mich., who was on the Republican ballot and received 44 votes in the presidential primary, delivered his recount request and a down payment of $2,000 to the statehouse in Concord.

The home of the Cleveland Indians will be called Progressive Field as part of a naming rights deal that is worth nearly $58 million over 16 years. The car insurance company Progressive Corp. and the Indians on Friday announced the terms of the agreement for the downtown ballpark, which had been known as Jacobs Field since it opened in 1994.

MORSE--Jane H., M.D. The Board of Directors of the S.L.E. Lupus Foundation mourns the passing of a keen and devoted scientific advisor to the lupus cause. Brilliant, direct, and approachable, Dr. Jane Morse supported our organization from its earliest days and as Chair of our Medical Advisory Board, played an integral role in shaping and enhancing lupus research. She was a prominent clinical rheumatologist, a gifted researcher, and a champion of our mission to serve the patients and families who suffer with lupus. We will miss her very much. Board of the S.L.E. Lupus Foundation New York, NY

8 P.M. (HBO) NORBIT (2007) Eddie Murphy, left, with the help of the makeup artist Richard Baker, summons some alternate personalities -- Norbit, a henpecked husband; Rasputia, his monstrous wife; Mr. Wong, a Chinese man whose restaurant doubles as an orphanage -- in this raucous comedy directed by Brian Robbins. ''To play Rasputia, Mr. Murphy appears to have been encased in foam rubber and dressed in Dolce & Gabbana for Elephants,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''It is when Rasputia goes out in a bikini (and, later, for a bikini wax) that the full extent of Mr. Baker's virtuosity becomes evident.'' 8 P.M. (TCM) THE BRIDGE ON THE RIVER KWAI (1957) British soldiers in a Japanese prison camp during World War II build a railway bridge for the enemy in this Academy Award-winning drama from David Lean. Alec Guinness, above, won the best-actor Oscar for his role as Colonel Nicholson, the prisoners' deluded leader; Sessue Hayakawa earned a best-supporting-actor nomination as the camp's commandant. In another prison-camp drama, Jean Renoir's Oscar-nominated ''Grand Illusion'' (1937), at 9 on Ovation, Jean Gabin and Pierre Fresnay play French prisoners from disparate backgrounds being held in a German camp during World War I.

Jerry Lewis , Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Michael Gyure, Executive Director

The New England Patriots put up numbers that would make statisticians' heads spin. They set N.F.L. records for points (589) and touchdowns (75), quarterback Tom Brady set the single-season record for touchdown passes with 50 and wide receiver Randy Moss set the single-season record for touchdown receptions with 23. The Patriots finished the season 16-0, the first undefeated regular season in the league since 1972. For those who counter that those numbers mean nothing in the playoffs, here are a few that do. The Patriots last lost a home playoff game in December 1978. That marks nine straight playoff wins at home. They will also be playing their 22nd playoff game since 1994, the highest total in the N.F.L. in that period. The Patriots face a popular upset pick in Jacksonville. The Jaguars run the ball with Maurice Jones-Drew and Fred Taylor. They boast a stout defense, especially up front. And they have won five of their last six games, including a victory against the Pittsburgh Steelers in a wild-card game.

The Chicago Fire promoted the longtime assistant Denis Hamlett to head coach Friday, ending a search to find a successor to Juan Carlos Osorio. Osorio left the team last month to coach the Red Bulls.

A nephew of the former heavyweight champion Trevor Berbick was sentenced Friday in Jamaica to life in prison for his murder. Harold Berbick, 21, will be eligible for parole in 20 years. His accomplice, Kenton Gordon, was sentenced to 14 years in prison after being found guilty of manslaughter. The police said the two beat Trevor Berbick, 54, to death in October 2006 and left his body in a church courtyard.

As the New Hampshire primary recedes, I find myself thinking, with the wisdom that hindsight affords, of a Barack Obama event in Salem a few days before the primary. The police turned away 4,000 people at the door because there was room for only 1,000 inside the hall. Senator Obama asked, as he often does, how many of the voters in the auditorium were undecided. Maybe a third of the people raised their hands. Then the candidate proceeded to give the same inspiring, rally-type speech he had been giving in Iowa.

Shawn Johnson and Jonathan Horton were named Friday to the United States team for the Tyson American Cup competition March 1 in Madison Square Garden.At last year's world championships, Johnson, from West Des Moines, Iowa, won the all-around gold medal for women. Horton, from Houston, finished fourth in the men's all-around. Both won American Cup titles last year in Jacksonville, Fla.

The ice dancers Melissa Gregory and Denis Petukhov, husband and wife, withdrew Friday from the 2008 United States Figure Skating Championships, which begin Jan. 20. Gregory and Petukhov have been sidelined since a fall during a lift at Skate Canada two months ago. Petukhov said the loss of practice time was a factor in their withdrawal, in addition to the need to rehabilitate his injured knee.

Roger A. Pielke Jr. has done some further checking of the IPCC's predictions, the subject of the last post. You can see the graphs here. Now he's gone back to 1990 and checked out four different predictions by the U.N.'s climate panel. He concludes, among other things:

The views expressed here on human-caused climate change run the gamut. It's a hoax. It's a catastrophe. It's a crisis. It's a manageable trend. It can be fixed with a rising tax on carbon. It can be fixed by making people rich. It can be controlled by dumping something in the air or oceans.

The results are in. The evening was a downright weird one and contained its share of competitive surprises. "Atonement," which had been considered to be losing luster in the awards race, stormed back to life with a win as best motion picture drama. The audience of journalists and press agents gasped a bit when it was announced. "Sweeney Todd" bested "Juno" in the best motion picture musical or comedy, also a surprise to some. Cate Blanchett won a best supporting actress for her role, with the HFPA choosing her over Amy Ryan from "Gone Baby Gone," who has been the much chattered about favorite. And the directors win for Julian Schnabel for "The Diving Bell and the Butterfly" came completely out of left field when the only directors being talked about have been Paul Thomas Anderson and the Coen brothers so far this year. A full recap of the evening is already available as well. In case you were wondering, the Bagger got slaughtered in his picks. More details on the debacle later.

Jeremy Piven was on a movie set shooting a film for Paramount Vantage, "The Goods: The Don Ready Story," and happened to step into his trailer just about the time that it was announced he won best television actor in a supporting role.

In a poem titled "Matins," the 17th century Anglican poet George Herbert says to God, If you will "teach me thy love to know . . . Then by a sunbeam I will climb to thee." But the dynamics of the proffered bargain - if you do X, I'll do Y - are undercut by the line that proposes it, and especially by the double pun in "sunbeam."
Political wisdom this week runs smack into economic reality. It is not yet clear which force will prove more powerful.

The Bagger is in position, up close, stage right, at a table George Clooney probably would have been sitting at if he were coming. The Bagger is always stuck in dreary press rooms at these events, so he is used to it, and the golden motif of the stage for the announcement is actually quite lovely. Carpenters are still hammering stuff together on stage, which gives the room an air of expectation, but its not like there is going to be a sudden starburst of wattage when the programming begins. It will be a nice, dry press conference, which brings the Bagger back to his salad days as a government reporter. Nothing like a couple of crisp announcements to report on deadline to get the old journalistic juices flowing. And speaking of getting juiced, don't forget to make your predictions. There's still time.

Postgame: Anyone expect that to happen? Cowboys looked pretty solid in the first half, but they got bit by penalties in the second. ...Manning finishes 12 of 18 for 163 yards and 2 touchdowns. Brandon Jacobs rushed for 54 yards, Bradshaw for 34. The totals are a little anemic for the Giants' offense, but, as I was telling a friend of mine, yards are overrated. ...Romo does not come through in the end; he was 18 of 35 for 201 yards with a touchdown pass and a pick. Let the debate begin: How well would he have played if he'd spent last weekend in Dallas, eating chicken wings at a Hooters? ...Keep those comments coming. I am turning this thread over to you. How will the Giants fare in Green Bay? Anybody for the Cowboys going to lose his job over this? And are you ready to accept Eli Manning as the Giants' quarterback?

It's tempting to claim, based on recent polling data, that the central issue in the 2008 presidential election will be the U.S. economy. In the Iowa Republican Caucus entrance poll, more voters chose the economy as the most important issue (26 percent) than the Iraq war (17 percent). And in the Iowa Democratic Caucus entrance poll, the economy and the Iraq war were tied for most-important-issue status, with each drawing 35 percent support.

Between the tributes - Sidney Lumet is God! - and the extended spoken word performances of many of the critics - all the was missing was the bongos - the Los Angeles Film Critics Association event on Saturday was a night when movies and the people who make them received big ups ... and a little bit of an endurance test. According to David Poland of Movie City News, when Paul Thomas Anderson, the director who was honored for "There Will Be Blood," finally got to the podium three hours into the night, he checked his watch and said, "If another [charming, but nonetheless redacted profane adjective] film critic criticizes one of my movies for being too long, I'm going to remind them of this ceremony."

Well, well, well. All those anticipating an epic Colts-Patriots rematch in a Super Bowl-esque A.F.C. championship game next week will have to find some film of last year's game. Don't look for George Clooney or any of his A-list siblings during the Globes press conference tonight even as the Writers Guild of America has removed the threat of pickets. By the time the word came down on Friday that it was okay for actors to participate, most had made plans that did not include hair and make-up. Said one publicist, "We'd all like the Globes to save a little face, but with so little time, there really wasn't much we could do about it."
