Tourists heading to the Acoma Pueblo reservation in New Mexico come over a hill that overlooks a valley that surrounds a 367-foot sandstone mesa rising to the sky. The village rests on top, with its breathtaking views and ancient traditions and houses made from adobe clay.

DETROIT - General Motor's announcement that its Saab brand would introduce a crossover four-cylinder capable of running on E85 ethanol was made with a pair of skiers dressed in white hopping out of the vehicle under a gentle fall of shaved-ice snow. The melting flakes made the stage sticky, but G.M. Chief Executive Rick Wagoner found to his delight that his speech, which he had left on the podium moments before, was protected when he resumed the stage. "There's snow on the podium now; somebody thought of this plastic shield to cover the rest of the script. Good thinking, guys!" he said, smiling.

With new episodes of ABC's "Grey's Anatomy" and CBS's "CSI" at 9 p.m. on Thursday, both networks surged to the top of the night's ratings heap. CBS averaged more total viewers as "CSI" attracted the larger audience of the two hit shows: 18.1 million viewers compared to 17.6 million, according to Nielsen's estimates. "Grey's Anatomy," however, trounced all competition for the night among adults 18 to 49, making ABC No. 1 in that demographic despite a weak showing at 10 p.m. for "Big Shots" (6.8 million).

Elisabeth Görgl of Austria won a World Cup giant slalom in Maribor, Slovenia, for the first victory of her career. Görgl, who led after the first leg, finished in a two-run combined time of 2:38.49. Manuela Moelgg of Italy took second, 0.49 behind, and Denise Karbon of Italy finished third.

Jean-Baptiste Grange of France won a World Cup slalom Saturday in Wengen, Switzerland, capturing his second victory in two days. He easily held off Jens Byggmark of Sweden, finishing with a combined time of 1 minute 34.81 seconds. Grange won Friday’s super-combi for the second World Cup victory of his career.

Ronny Ackermann of Germany won his third Nordic combined World Cup event of the season ahead of Bill Demong of the United States in Val di Fiemme, Italy. Ackermann completed the two jumps and cross-country race in a combined time of 41:52.2. Demong finished 34.1 seconds behind.

Chelsea closed the gap on Arsenal at the top of the English Premier League on Saturday by beating Tottenham Hotspur, 2-0, as Arsenal was held to a 1-1 draw by Birmingham City. Arsenal leads with 51 points from 22 games, followed by United with 48 from 21 and Chelsea with 47 from 22.

The Milwaukee Brewers have a tentative agreement on a one-year contract with the free-agent outfielder Mike Cameron, pending a physical, Major League Baseball’s Web site said. Brewers General Manager Doug Melvin said Cameron, 35, would start in center field. Cameron will be suspended the first 25 games of the season without pay for testing positive for a banned stimulant.

Greg Ellis made a major impact for the Dallas Cowboys at outside linebacker and Saturday was named as The Associated Press’s N.F.L. Comeback Player of the Year. Ellis went from a nonfactor in Dallas to a Pro Bowl player in his new position after spending most of his career as a defensive end. He had 12 ½ sacks, forming a dynamic pass-rushing force with the All-Pro linebacker DeMarcus Ware.

An article last Sunday about Pakistan’s history of difficulty in sustaining democracy misstated the crime for which the former prime minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was hanged in 1979. Mr. Bhutto was found guilty of conspiring to murder a minor political opponent, not of murdering him. (The opponent survived an assassination attempt, in which his father died.) The article also misstated the opponent’s home region. It was the Punjab, not Baluchistan.

The Career Couch column last Sunday, about presidential politics in the office, referred incorrectly to comments by Daniel I. Prywes, a partner in the Washington offices of the law firm Bryan Cave. When Mr. Prywes said that soliciting participation in political events might be permissible, he was referring to both employers and employees, not just employees. In addition, he said that employers who coerce employees to make political contributions would be violating federal election laws; he was not referring to employees who solicit contributions.
The Stocks in the News on the DataBank page last Sunday contained incorrect labels for the stocks’ estimated price-to-earnings ratios. They were for 2008, not 2007.

The Off the Shelf column last Sunday, a review of “A Nation of Counterfeiters,” a book about the history of American counterfeiting, referred incorrectly to a practice in Britain, where counterfeiting was once considered a treasonable act. It was punishable by death without “benefit of clergy,” meaning the special protections once granted to clergy members and certain others to be tried in separate church courts and to avoid some types of punishment; it did not have to do with “access to clergy” for absolution rites.

WALTON--Barbara J., of New York City on January 10, 2008 at age 83. Beloved wife of the late Ernest Walton. Adored and cherished mother of Frances A. and Thomas H. Walton. Dear grandmother of Charles and Henry Walton, caring sister of Richard T. Johnson. Warmly remembered by daughter-in-law Deborah Fortune Walton and son-in-law David C. Katz. A pacifist, an educator, a writer and a philosopher. Her empathy and generosity were abundant, a source of inspiration to all who knew her. A service in her memory will be announced at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or Teachers College at Columbia University.

ACKLEY--Sheldon C., died peacefully on January 9, 2008 after a brief illness. Father of Joan and David, and cherished companion of Suzan Carrington. He was a Ph.D. philosopher who pursued humanism and ethical living throughout his life with an unswerving rigor recognized by all who knew him. After college he held academic posts at Gettysburg College. In 1950 he became the first leader of the Ethical Humanist Society of Long Island. During the period 1960 to 1981 he worked in academic administration at New York University and State University of New York at Stony Brook. He was a founding member of the New York Civil Liberties Union as well as its chairman for many years. Retiring to New York City, he became the leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture. After retiring a second time he was involved with writing and speaking on philosophical and ethical issues. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, we suggest friends consider a donation in his name to The American Civil Liberties Union.

BRODSKY--Samuel, age 95, died January 8th with family by his side. He leaves behind his devoted wife Margery Bach Brodsky, whom he married when he was a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy during World War II. He dedicated himself to the practice of the law from which he fully retired at 88. He began his career as clerk to Federal Circuit Court Judge Julian W. Mack and then as assistant U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York. As a lawyer in private practice he specialized in taxation and corporate law serving as chairman of the tax section of the New York State Bar Association and lecturer on taxation at NYU School of Law. He was past president and trustee of Central Synagogue in New York City where he resided. His steadfast love enriched the lives of his daughters, Joan Brodsky Schur and Alice B. Forcier, their husbands and his three granddaughters. He was a loyal and loving brother of Marion Brodsky and the late Leon Brock. Memorial service February 15 at 11:00am at the Harvard Club. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Congregation Ahavas Achim, 84 Hastings Ave., Keene, NH 03431.

JOGGING THROUGH THE INCAN RUINS OF SACSAYHUAMÁN OUTSIDE CUZCO, AUG. 7, 2007 Mark Golan, 47, a Cisco Systems vice president from San Jose, Calif. ''I was on a two-week trip with my eldest daughter, Shelby. I told my children that when each of them got to be 16, I'd go somewhere in the world with them. She's a pretty hard-core distance runner and would go run every day. That day, she chose to run way the heck up the road, probably 10 miles, while I chose to run around the ruins. I remember running through there and stopping to look at the workmanship. It was early morning, and there were plenty of places the light would be coming through doorways or striking at interesting angles that made some amazing patterns. As a parent, it's fun -- this kid is fully capable, more capable than me, to do physical stuff. That run particularly is an example where I think it enhanced our trip -- getting your exercise but doing it in a special place and at a time of day that's really pretty and calm.''

RESIDENTS of a sleepy SoHo block aren't sure what to make of the Wreck Center, a store/performance space/art installation that has invaded their neighborhood like a post-apocalyptic circus. Decorated with graffiti, gold paint and 5,800 feet of Day-Glo masking tape, the space, designed by Rafael de Cárdenas, pops, to say the least. ''Finally one came up to me,'' said Aaron Bondaroff (above), the project's ringleader, ''and told me it was about time someone did something cool in the neighborhood again.''

HARPER--Dorothy Schmid (Johns), a resident at The Highlands at Pittsford senior living community in Pittsford, NY, died on December 23, 2007 at her home. She had celebrated her 100th birthday on November 28th. Born in Butler, Pennsylvania, in 1907, she grew up in Erie. She attended Oberlin College and graduated from the University of Wisconsin with a B.A. in journalism. After working briefly in that field, she became a homemaker. In 1954, upon divorcing her first husband, she re-entered the workplace and -as a single mother -continued raising her two children. She worked for a year as a secretary and attended nightschool to acquire a degree in education, then became a teacher of history and English at secondary schools in suburban Cleveland. After obtaining a certificate in guidance counseling, she served for many years as college counselor and dean at Laurel School in Shaker Heights, Ohio. From 1973 to 1978, she sat on the board of trustees at Ohio University. In 1975, she attended her fiftieth highschool reunion in Erie and got reacquainted with William T. Harper of Rochester. Two months later, they married and Dorothy moved to Rochester. She joined the Century Club, renewed her interest in ballroom dancing, played bridge avidly, traveled abroad frequently and served as a volunteer at several charities. She embraced life, and endured its setbacks stoically and with a dry wit. She took a serious interest in civic affairs and occasionally sent her opinions to Rochester's Democrat and Chronicle; in 1991, that newspaper honored her with its Golden Pen Award. Dorothy Harper is survived by her daughter, Elizabeth Stillinger of Westport, Connecticut; her son, Richard Johns of Remsenburg, New York; her stepson, William Thayer Harper of Rochester; seven grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Her husband died in 1997. A memorial service was held Saturday, January 12th at The Highlands at Pittsford. Donations may be made to the Fisher Center for Alzheimer's Research Foundation, Planned Parenthood of America, or to a charity of the donor's choice.

ROSENBLUT--Linda (nee Liebhaber) on January 12, 2008 at age 67. Beloved wife of Alan. Devoted mother to Michael (Hedy) and Joanna (Nathan). Adored grandmother of Lucy, Joshua, Jacob, and Emily. Loving sister to Carolyn. A beautiful person both inside and out, she was taken from this world too soon. Funeral today, noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Simon Wiesenthal Center.

THE legendary clotheshorse Nan Kempner was a force to be reckoned with. One night in 1968, as the oft-told story goes, she arrived at La Côte Basque wearing Yves Saint Laurent's ''le smoking.'' When the maître d' forbade her to dine in pants, she promptly took them off, handed them to her husband and walked into the restaurant wearing nothing but the tuxedo jacket. Four decades later, the woman in a tuxedo jacket is still the most confident, subversive, soigné one in the room. ''It allows her to be very sexy, while leaving space for the imagination,'' said the London designer Jens Laugesen, who opened his spring show with an unforgettable metallic jacket.

McCUE--Ramon E., 86. Born in Windsor Locks, CT on December 31, 1921. Died January 9, 2008 after a year and a half long battle with cancer that he fought with grace and dignity. A model and actor known for many commercials in the 1950s and the 1960s. Owned and operated Chuck's Composite Restaurant in the 1960s, located on East 53rd St. Mr. McCue lived most of his life in Manhattan until he moved to Florida eight months ago to live with his devoted daughter and son-in-law, Cheryl and Raymond Parker. Preceded in death by his second wife and best friend, Geraldine Toohey McCue. Survived by four children from his first wife; one brother; 10 grandchildren; two great-grandchildren; three nieces and one nephew. Services are set for January 16, 2008 at Fred Hunter's, 954989-1550.
GOODHUE--Sarah Parker. 1828-1917. A great lady and a great benefactor. The NY Society Library

RICE--Joan J., of Briarwood, Queens, passed away in Forest Hills Hospital on Monday, December 17, 2007 at the age of 82 and was buried on Friday, December 20, 2007 at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla, New York. Ms. Rice had a long career at the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation and will be remembered as one of the foundation's most valued staff members. Ms. Rice's first love was travel and she did so extensively throughout the world during her lifetime. She will be missed by cousins, Florence and Jack Wolfe, their daughters, Nancy and Frances as well as Robert Fischer. Her life long friend, Ethel Dubow will miss her too, as will the Dolan family.

USDAN--Karen Beth, passed away unexpectedly at age 39 on January 11th in Columbia County, upstate New York. She is survived by her beloved and nurturing mother, Tova Friedler Usdan, devoted sister Jane Meroney and Jane's husband Bart and their children Sam and Rebecca, and devoted brother Robert and Robert's wife Amy Yenkin and their children Cole and Dora Usdan. Karen is also survived by her father, Michael Usdan of Washington, DC. Karen was an exceptionally beautiful, intelligent, literate, artistic, kind, caring and compassionate human being. She will be profoundly missed and mourned by her grieving family and countless friends. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, January 15th at 11:45am at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street in Manhattan. Interment will follow at Mount Eden Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Karen's memory to the Austen Riggs Center in Stockbridge, MA or to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City.

Author: ''NonGovernmental Organizations at the United Nations.'' Daughter of Chiang TingWen (father) and Chiang Tsai Ven-Yuen (mother), who predeceased her. Memorial Service in New York on January 12, 12:00-2:00pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, (212) 288-3500: and also later in Vermont. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Carter Center, CARE, World Wildlife Fund, UNESCO, and/or the Nature Conservancy most welcome.

THE NEWS President Bush acknowledged that the nation faced ''economic challenges'' because of rising oil prices, the home mortgage crisis and a weakening job market. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Bush's remarks to business leaders were a marked shift from his usual upbeat economic assessments. While the president argued that the economy's fundamentals remained strong, he acknowledged that ''many Americans are anxious'' and that ''jobs are growing at a slower pace.'' Both the White House and Congressional Democrats are evaluating whether tax cuts may be needed to stimulate the economy. ''We cannot take growth for granted,'' Mr. Bush said.

I'm a college student who will be studying in St. Petersburg for the month of January. Can you recommend any daytime and nighttime activities, especially things off the beaten path? -- H. J. Parnes, South Windsor, Conn.

DINCSOY--Hosoon Park, M.D., on January 9, 2008. My colleague and friend for a quarter century: indomitable in the face of personal afflictions. Dr. Dincsoy was an extraordinary medical pathologist. She made numerous original contributions to her field, particularly in the early recognition of the pathology of AIDS. She contributed importantly to the various institutions in which she worked by her superbly presented case conferences. But above all, Dr. Dincsoy's legacy is in the generations of residents and fellows at New York Medical College, SUNY Downstate, and North Shore University Hospital who were her students. She cared for them deeply and personally and was unstinting in her work to teach anatomic pathology according to her own meticulous and demanding standards. Dr. Dincsoy was a rare and dedicated professional, whose like we shall not see again. John D. Broome, M.D.

FEDER--Morris Louis, New York City, respected leader of the maritime industry. Died almost 91 years young on January 10, 2008. Born in Czechoslovakia on March 28, 1917. Beloved father of Harry and Karen. Husband of beloved Lucy. Grampa to Jean, Laura, Ali, and Emi. Fatherin-law to Ross and Gilli. He was the most special person on this earth; nobody else came close with his generosity, kindness, integrity, and love for life. Everybody loved him; he was an invaluable friend to countless people throughout the world. We are deeply saddened by our loss; our lives will never be the same without him. We will always be thinking of him. Memorial Service 11:45am on Sunday, January 13th, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

KLEIN--Arthur R., (Art) died on January 9 after a battle with pancreatic cancer. Beloved husband, father, fatherin-law, grandfather, son, brother and uncle. The Funeral Service will be Monday, January 14 at 1:00pm at Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester, 220 South Bedford Road, Chappaqua, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network.

HAMMER--Ingrid, died the evening of December 27, 2007 at the age of 68. Born Ingrid Weniger and raised in Innsbruck, Austria, she earned her masters of architecture at the Academy of Fine Arts, Vienna (Akademie der bildenden Kunste). She moved to NYC in 1967 and began working at Haines Lundberg Waehler, where she met, and later married Theodore Hammer. With the birth of their son, Gregory, Ms. Hammer decided to retire and devote her time to raising him in Ringwood, New Jersey. She became an American citizen in 1992, of which she was very proud. Ms. Hammer's marriage to Mr. Hammer ended in 1999, and she moved back to NYC full time. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. She is survived by her son, Gregory S. Hammer, daughter in law Tamara Hammer, and beautiful granddaughter Olivia. Memorial February 2, 2008, 2pm, Blue Water Grill, Union Square-NYC.

PARRY--Joan K., DSW, ACSW, LCSW, a native New Yorker, died January 9th, in her La Jolla, CA home. She received many awards and honors including Social Worker of the Year (2005). WEARING body-conscious chiffon and ''Blade Runner'' shades, Burberry's lean, mean ''Luxury Warrior,'' as the label's spring collection is called, is quite a woman. Like Lucy Lawless with unlimited credit. But you don't need to be a fearless fashion crusader to wear her Celtic concho belt. Made of ruched black leather, decorated with wrought silver medallions, it adds a heavy-metal edge to an otherwise basic cardigan, or a one-two punch to a pretty cocktail dress. And with the cinched waist being the silhouette of the season, surrendering to it is almost imperative.

COLLIGAN--John A., beloved brother, teacher and friend, died January 1, 2008 at age 52. He was Chair of the Music Department at St. Hilda's & St. Hugh's School on W 114th St. for 10 years. RUBIN--Harvey, M.D., 89, of La Jolla, CA, died January 2. NYC born, son of Dr. I.C. Rubin, world famous OB/GYN, infertility expert. Grandparents Israel and Bella Unterberg helped establish the NYC 92nd Street Y. Graduated Yale, University of Chicago and earned his M.D. at NYU Medical College. Served as a naval officer in WWII. In 1961 moved his family to California and established his psychiatric practice. Published 32 research papers on protein synthesis. Survived by wife Donna, children Harvey Jr., June (Tom Gingell) and Linda of San Diego

BLUMENTHAL--Meryl. The Columbia Grammar & Preparatory School community is deeply saddened by the recent death of one of its most respected and beloved members. Meryl Blumenthal was an outstanding and muchloved Dean of Grades 5 and 6 for most of her 271/2 years at our school. She was loved and respected by students, faculty and parents alike for her unique combination of the highest expectations for behavior and responsibility on the one hand and for her caring and sensitivity towards each students needs on the other. She will be deeply missed and always remembered by the entire school community. A memorial service will be held at the school at 4 West 93rd St. on Wednesday, January 16th, at 6:30pm.

KELLNER--Dorothy. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Dorothy Kellner of Los Angeles. A visionary pioneer whose judgment and ideas were sought and admired, Mrs. Kellner was an ardent advocate, together with her husband Martin, of the Technion and Israel since the 1950s. A Technion Guardian who had reached the highest level of support, Mrs. Kellner was awarded the Albert Einstein award, the highest ATS honor, in 1988, and an Honorary Fellowship from the Technion in 1999. She was a member of the Technion International Board of Governors, the ATS national Board of Directors, and past president of the Southern California Chapter and the Western Region. Some of the many projects the Kellners supported include the Dorothy and Martin Kellner Amphitheater, the Dorothy and Martin Kellner Fund for Multidisciplinary Programs in Gerontology, and the Coler-California Visitors Center. Active in civic affairs, she was president of the California League of Women Voters and a member of the California Commission on Aging, and was appointed by California's governor to the chairmanship of the State Committee on Long-Term Care. Recently, Mrs. Kellner earned a Ph.D. from UCLA in gerontology. With her enthusiasm and intelligence she attracted many new supporters to the organization, including national officers. One of her passions was developing new leaders, and at the time of her death she had been serving for many years as chair of the national Leadership Development Committee. To her husband Martin, we offer our heartfelt condolences. American Technion Society Joan Seidel, President Stephen A. Laser, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Charles E. Levin, Southern California Chapter President Diane Siegel, Western Region Director

LeMASTER--Jay, Jerome Lloyd, Jr., 80, beloved husband of Jane, December 27 at Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home after a long illness. The son of a professor of Business Law at Oregon State University, Jay had an abiding love for the rule of law and put that love to work for the International Association of Laryngectomees. As a member of the Board of Directors, he was a longtime member and chairman of the Bylaws Committee. In addition to working on year-toyear changes, he was responsible for a comprehensive revision of the bylaws several years ago. It was a massive undertaking since, over the years, inconsistencies had developed and Jay worked hard to clean up this essential IAL document. Before becoming a laryngectomee in 1991 he was a self employed artist and illustrator, a graduate of both Oregon State University and the Arts Center College of Design in Pasenda, CA. Jay was a pillar of his local support club (Nu Voices of Mount Sinai Hospital) and was involved in all aspects of its work. Especially active in Tobacco Awareness, he spoke to thousands of students over the years, primarily at Washington Irving High School. The mounds of letters from students who wrote him saying they would never smoke and would encourage family members to stop smoking was a source of great pride and joy for him. Also active in working to make New York's public places smoke-free, he participated in the famous demonstration with activist Michael Moore at the corporate headquarters of the Philip Morris Tobacco Company to protest their advertising, particularly to young people. The demonstration later moved to the home of the CEO of Philip Morris where demonstrators decorated trees with empty cigarette packages. Jay and his wife Jane loved the theater. When they attended the IAL's Annual Meeting and danced at the banquet, people loved to refer to them as ''Fred and Ginger.'' Jay helped new laryngectomees and their families learn that there is a life, and a full one, after a laryngectomy. Memorial Sloan - Kettering awarded Jay a Certificate of Recognition in honor of his constant devotion for his many years of compassionate service and expertise as a patient-to-patient volunteer. We celebrate the entire life of Jay LeMaster, especially his unselfish attention to his fellow laryngectomees whenever he found one in need of help, answers or inspiration. Donations may be sent in his honor to Post Treatment Resource Program, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021.

WOLF--Diane R. The Wolf Family is deeply saddened by the sudden loss of Diane R. Wolf on January 10, 2008. She was 53. Loving daughter of Erving and Joyce Wolf. Cherished sister of Daniel and Mathew Wolf. Dear sister-inlaw to Ann Wolf and Maya Lin. Adoring aunt to Daisy, Henry, Benjamin, Rachel and India Wolf. Diane was a woman of intelligence, beauty, grace and compassion. She was a philanthropist who served locally and nationally. Diane was on the boards of the U.S. Senate Preservation Board of Trustees, the Library of Congress Madison Council, the Foundation for the National Archives Board of Trustees, the National Public Radio Foundation Board of Trustees, the National Trust for Historic Preservation Council, the Georgetown University Law Center Board of Visitors, the Kennedy Center National Committee for the Performing Arts and the International Committee on the Arts, the National Symphony Orchestra National Trustees, the Washington National Opera Board of Trustees, and the Smithsonian Council of American Art. She was the past president of the Federal Bar Association, Capitol Hill Chapter. Diane was appointed by President Reagan to the U.S. Commission of Fine Arts, where she served as Commissioner from 1985 to 1990. She served on the Rockefeller University Council and was a benefactor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Diane received her undergraduate degree cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania, received a masters degree in education from Columbia University and obtained her juris doctorate degree from Georgetown University Law Center. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, January 13, 2008, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, the Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York. Burial services will be held on Monday, January 14, 2008, in Ridgway, Colorado. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Diane Wolf Fund at the New York Cornell Hospital.

GAISNER--Rhea. The friends and family of Rhea Gaisner mourn the loss of this beloved teacher, theater director and vivacious friend. She was an influential acting teacher at Carnegie, Cooper Union, City College and Emerson and an inventive director, from her days with the Open Theater through projects with contemporary playwrights and internationally with Exiles in Ireland and with companies in the Netherlands. We will miss her warmth, humor and feistiness. A private gathering will be held on Monday, January 14 at 6pm at New Dramatists. A memorial service is being planned for April 14th.

TANENBAUM--Elias, 19242008, composer, teacher, and longtime New Rochelle resident died on Thursday after a long illness. He composed over 140 works and was the Founding Director of the Electronic Computer Music Studio at the Manhattan School of Music. Mr. Tanenbaum served in the US Army during WWII and was awarded a purple heart. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, pianist Mary Tanenbaum, his brother Ray, two children, David and Jacob, and three grandchildren, Zachary, Simon and Nicky. 11:00am memorial gathering will be held on Sunday at the George T. Davis Funeral Home. 914632-0324.

WITH Jamie Hince now squiring Kate Moss about town, and blog-buzz that Alison Mosshart might be starring in the spring Miu Miu campaign (she isn't), the bluesy-rock duo known as the Kills have been getting a lot of attention lately. Fortunately, some of it is for their music. They recorded ''U R A Fever,'' the first single off their new album, in the late hours of the night. You can tell. It's a stark, sexy, slow-burner of a tune -- ''a perfect song,'' as Ms. Mosshart put it. But it is the video, shot by Sophie Muller, that's raising temperatures online. Inspired by Andy Warhol's ''Outer and Inner Space,'' a 16-millimeter split-screen film starring Edie Sedgwick talking to herself, the video, which was shot with the same type of Norelco camera that Warhol used, is the grittiest, grainiest, most glam-rock two minutes on YouTube. Shot in the old pub that the couple now call home, it is a stylized glimpse into their art-punk lives: the vintage jukeboxes; the tattered brocade couch; Ms. Mosshart, in a Sass & Bide sequin jacket, smearing lipstick across her mouth. You can't watch it just once.
Classical Daniel J. Wakin

COLE -Desmond on January 6. Director of the United Nations International School from 1964-1974 where he was a pioneer in the development of the International Baccalaureate and oversaw the relocation of the school to its permanent headquarters on F.D.R. Drive. Headmaster of the Allen - Stevenson School from 1974-1990. Desmond's refusal to close the school during the blizzard of 1978 was a defining moment in his tenure. Desmond was dearly loved by his family, friends and students for his compassion and humor and admired for his principles and fortitude. Born in London, Desmond served in the Royal Navy in World War II, and earned Bachelors and Masters Degrees at Oxford, which he attended on a merit scholarship. Headmaster of the British School and American School of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Well into his 50s, Desmond ran two New York City Marathons and completed two Outward Bound courses. He is survived by his wife, Charity, and their children, Tom, Peter and Sally; his son, Thomas Winsnes; brother Oswald; sister Annette; and six grandchildren. The family warmly welcomes all who knew Desmond to share their stories with us at desmond cole.lifequarters.com. Me morial service is Sunday, March 16th, 11am at the Doris Duke Center, The Sarah Duke Gardens, 426 Anderson St, Durham, North Carolina. Donations may be made to the Desmond Cole Memorial, The Sarah Duke Gardens, PO Box 90626, Durham, NC 27708, or to the Allen-Stevenson School, Desmond Cole Fortiter et Recte Award, 132 East 78th Street, NY, NY 10075.

The only thing standing between the occupants of 375 Pearl Street and some of the most commanding views in Lower Manhattan is three inches of limestone.Though the 32-story telephone company tower is not truly windowless, it might as well be. There are three-foot-wide slits running up and down the structure, some with glass in them. But, like the windows of the World Trade Center, these do little more than offer a tantalizingly small slice of what could have been an extraordinary panorama.

“Safe pigeon-feeding zones” may be designated around the city as part of the negotiations between animal rights groups and the Brooklyn city councilman who has proposed fining pigeon feeders as much as $1,000 as strategy to control New York’s pigeon population.Fines, which had been used successfully in Basel, Switzerland, to limit pigeon proliferation, were the most concrete proposal in a pigeon report issued by Councilman Simcha Felder’s office in November. Last month the film "Grizzly Man" debuted on Animal Planet, the cable channel owned by Discovery Communications. The 2005 documentary explored the life of a man who spent years with bears in the Alaskan wilderness before being mauled to death.

NBC's bare-bones version of the "65th Annual Golden Globes" attracted just 5.8 million viewers on Sunday, a small fraction of the 20 million who tuned in to the awards show a year ago, according to Nielsen's estimates. A two-hour "Dateline" that preceded the 9 p.m. announcement show and featured interviews with the nominees did not fare any better, attracting just 4.4 million viewers. Combined, the three-hour broadcast delivered a dismal 1.3 rating in the critical demographic of adults 18 to 49, a far cry from the 6.5 rating the show earned in prime time on a Monday last January.

I turned and saw a police car go sailing across the street and smash into the wall in front of the new Sheraton hotel, formerly the Pontchartrain. A pedestrian jumped out of the way of the police car and barely escaped being sandwiched between bumper and wall. I was impressed by the huge pile of debris in the middle of the street - and the black Vibe that it appeared had smashed into the back of the police car and sent it flying. This week's guest blogger is the Milan-based artist and satirist Francesco Vezzoli. Over the past decade, the diva-and-Prada-obsessed Vezzoli, 36, has at once defiled and genuflected at the altar of celebrity. His campy oeuvre includes everything from needlework portraits of Maria Callas and Anna Magnani to films like "Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidal's Caligula," starring Helen Mirren and Courtney Love, and live performances like Pirandello's "Right You Are (If You Think You Are)," starring - among others - Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Abigail Breslin, which he produced at the Guggenheim last October as part of the Performa 07 series. For more than two decades, the center has been treating women who have undergone these procedures, especially those with complications from the type called infibulation.

This week, the fashion circus pitches its tent in Milan, where the men's Fall 2008 shows are taking place. If you're like us, there's probably only so much talk about "cashmere 8-yarn tweed in ecru" you can take. Thankfully, a lot of the action during fashion week happens off the catwalk. The big scandale of the week has been over Tommy Fazio, the men's fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman, being unceremoniously asked to vacate his front-row seat at Saturday night's Versace show. We spoke to Fazio afterwards who said that he was asked by a clipboard Nazi to make room for one of Beyonce's posse. Not surprisingly, Fazio put away the check book and instantly canceled his Versace showroom appointment. Oops....Speaking of Beyonce, the singer and her boo, Jay-Z, walked in and straight out of the GQ party on Saturday when they realized there was no VIP room for them...Lots of "aw-shucks, he so deserves it" talk about John Bartlett's being given a lifeline by Liz Claiborne, which has signed Bartlett to oversee its men's line...The buzz late Sunday night had the Spice Girls showing up en masse to today's Roberto Cavalli show. (It would make sense as their concert in London last week may as well have been a Cavalli advertorial, given the number of shout-outs Victoria Beckham gave the designer.) We'll let you know later if the rumor pans out to be true. Till then, baci.Read all of The Moment's coverage of the Milan men's fashion shows and after-hours shenanigans.

BROD--Irven Jack, age 98, died January 6, 2008 at home in NYC. A memorial service will be held Tuesday January 15th at 5pm at the The Riverside, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St. in NYC. Donations in his memory may be made to the Greenwich Council Boy Scouts of America, 63 Mason Street, Greenwich, CT 06830.

KOLENIK--Alda Bosi. A native of New York's Upper East Side died at home on January 12th, 2008 at age 86. A report in The Caucus roundup on Saturday, about a planned recount in the New Hampshire primary, misidentified the type of electronic voting machines the state uses. They are optical-scan machines, not touch-screen ones.

McCUE--Ramon E., 86. Born in Windsor Locks, CT on December 31, 1921. Died January 9, 2008 after a year and a half long battle with cancer that he fought with grace and dignity. A model and actor known for many commercials in the 1950s and the 1960s. Owned and operated Chuck's Composite Restaurant in the 1960s, located on East 53rd St. Mr. McCue lived most of his life in Manhattan until he moved to Florida eight months ago to live with his devoted daughter and son-in-law, Cheryl and Raymond Parker. A television review on Thursday about ''Celebrity Rehab With Dr. Drew,'' on VH1, misidentified the channel that carried ''Hey Paula,'' another celebrity-oriented show. It was Bravo, not VH1.

As Republicans in Michigan prepared to vote in their Tuesday primary, many said their top concern was the economy. But recent polls in the state show Republican primary voters are still largely unsettled in their choice of candidate, with a significant number saying they have not yet decided or might still change their mind. A Detroit News/WXYZ-TV poll of Republican primary voters found that Senator John McCain of Arizona and former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts were essentially tied, but 45 percent of respondents were undecided or said they could switch preferences. A McClatchy-MSNBC poll found Mr. Romney supported by 30 percent of likely Republican primary voters, compared with 22 percent for Mr. McCain. And the Detroit Free Press-Local 4 Michigan Poll showed Mr. Romney with 27 percent and Mr. McCain with 22 percent. Four in 10 of those in both polls who expressed support for a candidate, however, said they could change their minds. Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas placed third in each poll.

A front-page article on Thursday about a contract awarded to the consulting firm of former Attorney General John Ashcroft misstated the year that Mr. Ashcroft was sworn in. It was 2001, not 2002. The article also misstated the year of the selection of Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney in New Jersey, who directed the contract to Mr. Ashcroft's firm. Mr. Christie was nominated on Dec. 7, 2001, not in 2002. (He was sworn in on Jan. 17, 2002.)

An article on Dec. 14 about misconceptions about Mormonism misspelled the given name of Hitler, whom an expert of Mormon theology referred to in explaining why Mormons do not believe Jesus and Satan are brothers. He was Adolf, not Adolph.

8 P.M. (TCM) MARTIN SCORSESE PRESENTS VAL LEWTON: THE MAN IN THE SHADOWS As a young Russian immigrant turned editorial assistant to the producer David O. Selznick, Val Lewton conceived the boom shot in ''Gone With the Wind'' in which Scarlett walks among dead and wounded Confederate soldiers. (Never mind that Lewton advised Selznick not to do the film in the first place because he thought ''Gone With the Wind'' was a lousy book.) But Lewton was also a prolific writer of everything from novels to pornography. This documentary says that when an RKO executive was told that he wrote ''horrible novels'' but heard ''horror novels,'' Lewton (above with a staff member) was put in charge of low-budget horror films. What could have been mere collages of shock and gore were, in Lewton's hands, transformed into psychological poetry built of shadow and sound. This 90-minute film, produced and narrated by Mr. Scorsese, is followed by a marathon of the films Lewton produced: ''Cat People'' (1942) at 9:30, ''I Walked With a Zombie'' (1943) at 10:45, ''The Leopard Man'' (1943) at 1:30 a.m., ''The Seventh Victim'' (1943) at 2:45, ''The Curse of the Cat People'' (1944) at 4, ''The Body Snatcher'' (1945) at 5:15, ''Isle of the Dead'' (1945) at 6:30 and ''Bedlam'' (1946) at 7:45. 7 P.M. (Nickelodeon) THE BACKYARDIGANS: TALE OF THE MIGHTY KNIGHTS Rock on, tiny viewers. In this hourlong prime-time episode of the animated preschool series, Uniqua and Tyrone are royal knights charged by their king with baby-sitting for his precious egg. Which doesn't sound all that difficult until it sprouts a pair of legs and runs away. Adam Pascal makes his voice heard as narrator and in the ballad ''Not an Egg'' on the rock-opera soundtrack.

Fibromyalgia is a real disease. Or so says Pfizer in a new television advertising campaign for Lyrica, the first medicine approved to treat the pain condition, whose very existence is questioned by some doctors. For patient advocacy groups and doctors who specialize in fibromyalgia, the Lyrica approval is a milestone. They say they hope Lyrica and two other drugs that may be approved this year will legitimize fibromyalgia, just as Prozac brought depression into the mainstream.

A picture caption with an article in some editions on Tuesday about the Waliyaya family of the Bronx, who received money for new furniture and clothing through The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, reversed the identities of the two Waliyaya sons. Yusef, 16, was standing second from left, and wearing a Sacred Heart T-shirt; Muntu, 14, was seated at the left.

An article on Thursday about reports of an investigation into the suicide of a 13-year-old Missouri girl after she received cruel messages from people posing as a boy on Myspace misspelled the surname of a spokesman for the United States attorney in Los Angeles, who declined to confirm whether subpoenas had been issued. He is Thomas Mrozek, not Mrozak.

A picture in some editions on Wednesday with an article about an agreement by New York City to temporarily rescind a restriction limiting the size of crowds on the Great Lawn in Central Park to 50,000 people was published in error. It showed the Sheep Meadow, not the Great Lawn.

An article in Business Day on Friday about dissension among striking screenwriters misspelled, in one instance, the surname of the executive producer of the Golden Globes telecast for Dick Clark Productions who thought he had a solution that would allow the show to be broadcast. It is Barry Adelman, not Adelson.

An article on Saturday about the effect of the cancellation of the Golden Globes award ceremony on the practice of giving lavish gifts to Hollywood celebrities misinterpreted a comment by the actor Isaiah Washington. When Mr. Washington said, ''When I commit to something, I stick with it like a bulldog,'' he was referring to his foundation to help people in Sierra Leone, one of several charities supported by fees paid by companies who want to give away their products. Mr. Washington was not referring to participating in the gift giveaway himself.

ROSNER--Jonathan L. A giant among men. Family man; dedicated friend; litigator; author. Graduate of Williston Academy and Wesleyan University. United States Army Honor Guard. Order of the Coif; Pomeroy Scholar; Associate Editor NYU Law Review. Adjunct Professor of Law, NYU School of Law. Pace University School of Law. Clerk to Honorable Alexander Bicks; Assistant US Attorney S.D.N.Y., Chief Counsel and Deputy Commissioner New York State Commission on Criminal Justice and the Use of Force; General Counsel Commission of Inquiry into the 1977 Energy Failure. Husband to Lydia Sokol Rosner of 51 years; father of Beth and Bibi Giokas, Marianne (Merf) and Garth Klimchuk, Joshua Rosner; grandfather of Aaron, Sasha, Niki, and Noah. Services Tuesday 10am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

LEDES--Allison Eckardt. The Victorian Society Scholarship Fund is deeply saddened by the death of Allison Eckardt Ledes. She served as a dedicated board member nearly since the inception of the Fund in 1974 and her presence will be sorely missed. Allison's leadership, generosity of spirit and keen sense of humor aided the Fund in providing several hundred scholarships to deserving scholars in the field of nineteenth-century American and British architecture, social and cultural history, and the decorative arts to the Victorian Society in America's Summer Schools in Newport and London. The Board sends their heartfelt condolences to her husband, George and their two daughters, Meredith and Abby, as well as to her extended family. Christopher Forbes and the Board Members of the Victorian Society Scholarship Fund

WOLF--Diane R. The Wolf Family is deeply saddened by the sudden loss of Diane R. Wolf on January 10, 2008. She was 53. Loving daughter of Erving and Joyce Wolf. Cherished sister of Daniel and Mathew Wolf. Dear sister-inlaw to Ann Wolf and Maya Lin. Adoring aunt to Daisy, Henry, Benjamin, Rachel and India Wolf. Diane was a woman of intelligence, beauty, grace and compassion. She was a philanthropist who served locally and nationally. Diane was on the boards of the U.S. Senate Preservation Board of Trustees, the Library of Congress Madison Council, the Foundation for the National Archives Board of Trustees, the National Public Radio Foundation Board of Trustees, the National Trust for Historic Preservation Council, the Georgetown University Law Center Board of Visitors, the Kennedy Center National Committee for the Performing Arts and the International Committee on the Arts, the National Symphony Orchestra National Trustees, the Washington National Opera Board of Trustees, and the Smithsonian Council of American Art. She was the past president of the Federal Bar Association, Capitol Hill Chapter. Diane was appointed by President Reagan to the U.S. Commission of Fine Arts, where she served as Commissioner from 1985 to 1990. She served on the Rockefeller University Council and was a benefactor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Diane received her undergraduate degree cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania, received a masters degree in education from Columbia University and obtained her juris doctorate degree from Georgetown University Law Center. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, January 13, 2008, at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, the Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York. Burial services will be held on Monday, January 14, 2008, in Ridgway, Colorado. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Diane Wolf Fund at the New York Cornell Hospital.

AT&T Considers Filtering Internet For the last 15 years, Internet service providers have acted -- to use a cliche -- as wide-open information superhighways, letting data flow uninterrupted and unimpeded between users and the Internet.

Traffic to the Web sites for Barack Obama (barackobama.com) and Hillary Clinton (hillaryclinton.com) has followed the ups and downs of the campaigns. After the debate on Jan. 5, the share of visitors to Mrs. Clinton's Web site climbed steadily through the New Hampshire primary. According to Hitwise, the ratio of new or recent visitors to both sites outnumbered returning visitors by about 3 to 1. Traffic to the sites is important as they provide news and boosterism, and a place to make donations.

MILLNER--Dr. Elaine Stone, of Fort Lee, NJ passed away on January 13, 2008. She was born on February 25, 1922 in Staten Island, NY to Joseph and Jeanette Elterman Stone. She was a devoted and beloved mother, grandmother, wife, and friend. Dr. Millner was a graduate of Cornell University (1943), majoring in bacteriology, Newark State College (now Kean University), earning a master's (1969) and professional diploma (1971) in school psychology, and Columbia University School of Public Health (1975), where she received a doctorate in psychiatric epidemiology. Among her academic honors were election to Phi Kappa Phi and Sigma Xi. Before her children were born she worked as a microbiologist at Wallerstein Laboratories. Her later career included positions as school psychologist in the Caldwell (NJ) schools, senior research scientist for the New York City Department of Health, program director for epidemiology at the National Cancer Institute, deputy chief of epidemiology at the American Health Foundation, and, finally, a clinical psychologist in private practice, specializing in health psychology and medical psychotherapy, including affiliation with several hospitals in northern New Jersey. She was predeceased by her husband, Walter Nathanson. Survivors include her brother, Leonard Stone, of New York; her children, Robert Millner, and his wife, Barbara Sepp, of Cherry Valley, New York, and Elisabeth Millner, and her husband, Joe Cantelmo, of Bergenfield, New Jersey; and her grandchildren, Alexander Millner, Dakin Campbell, Maggie Millner, Joseph Cantelmo, and Jason Cantelmo. Her first marriage, to the late A. David Millner, had ended in divorce. Funeral services conducted from Mt. Lebanon Cemetery Iselin NJ on Tuesday January 15, 2008. Services are by the Menorah Chapels at Millburn 2950 Vauxhall Road Union NJ. Please call 908-964-1500 for time of services.

William C. Thompson Jr., the New York City comptroller, has raised the most money so far in the quest for the Democratic nomination for mayor in 2009, but United States Representative Anthony D. Weiner raised the most in the past six months, according to numbers their campaigns provided on Monday. During that period, Mr. Thompson raised slightly more than $1 million, bringing the amount he has raised for the campaign to $4.2 million. Mr. Thompson’s campaign aides said that he would report having $3.6 million on hand, Jonathan P. Hicks reports.

In the No Good Deed Goes Unpunished category, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg came up with a plan to provide fresh fruits and vegetables to low-income New Yorkers, and he got hit with rotten tomatoes from city street vendors. The mayor’s plan — to provide an extra 1,500 cart permits for vendors willing to sell produce in neighborhoods underserved by grocery stores — has been widely hailed by public health advocates. The city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene says it will make it easier for an estimated 100,000 residents to buy vegetables.

Marcus Cederqvist, the executive director for the New York Republican Party in Manhattan, was selected this afternoon as the new executive director of the New York City Board of Elections. Mr. Cederqvist, 38, replaces John A. Ravitz, who stepped down in October to accept a position as chief executive of the American Red Cross in Westchester County. Mr. Ravitz, too, was a Republican, and a former member of the Assembly. The selection of Mr. Cederqvist was done unanimously by the 10-member Board of Elections, which includes two members from each of the five boroughs, a Democrat and a Republican.

This planet's extraordinary climate -- equable and potent, dramatic and sublime -- produces a remarkable number of magical moments. I'd like to share one with you, on video at least. I live up on a range of hills paralleling the Hudson River about 50 miles north of Manhattan, at an elevation about 800 feet above sea level. This is just high enough to turn what is a January rain nearby into sticky fluffy snow. As the first potent nor'easter of January rolled up the East Coast Sunday night and Monday, just enough snow fell, of just the perfect light-but-sticky consistency, to cloak a patch of woods near our house with cold cotton.

The Soil Association, Britain's largest certifier of organic products, issued a press release Tuesday proclaiming itself to be the "first organization in the world to ban nanoparticles." Most shareholders like dividends -- just ask a Citigroup investor -- but creditors generally aren't big fans. This is especially true of the "special" dividends that private equity firms like to pay to themselves, sometimes just a few months after a leveraged buyout is complete. This sudden outflow of cash can be deeply annoying to bondholders worried about the quality of their debt, which is why Moody's Investors Service decided to examine which private equity firms tend to be quickest on the draw when it comes to dividends.

[UPDATE, 2/15/09: Our Green Traveler column has provided an update assessing a long list of environmental impacts from cruise ships.] The cruise ship industry, Mexican government, and Conservation International have announced a plan to try to protect coral reefs and other ecosystems in Cozumel, the world's most-visited cruise destination.[UPDATED 1/15 below]In a joint news release, the industry, environmental group, and government officials said their goals are to boost environmental education of passengers, cruise operators, and local communities, curb traffic and waste-disposal problems, boost protection of the barrier reef, and work to more effectively enforce environmental laws and regulations.

A tidbit from the producer price index report today:The 2007 change in producer prices for motor vehicles and equipment was zero. Five years after his death, Fiat kingpin Gianni Agnelli is being commemorated in an exhibit here that blurs the boundaries between the myth and the man. The show runs until Jan. 30 at the Vittoriano Museum Complex, an exhibition space underneath the monument dedicated to the Italian king Vittorio Emanuele II that is usually unkindly compared to a wedding cake and/or gigantic white typewriter. History buffs may be interested to know that the monument commemorates Italian unification and includes a museum to the Risorgimento, as the unification movement is known, as well as the Altare della Patria, the altar of the fatherland.

A judge has rejected the date of a special election set by the governor to replace former Senator Trent Lott. Judge Bobby DeLaughter of Hinds County Circuit Court ruled that Gov. Haley Barbour, a Republican, erred when he set the special election for Nov. 4. State law says that after receiving notice of a Senate vacancy, the governor must schedule an election within 90 days if the vacancy announcement does not fall in the same year as a state or Congressional general election. Mr. Lott retired Dec. 18, after November’s general election.

A pastor who is the mayor of a small town was in jail on charges of soliciting sex over the Internet from a police detective posing as a 13-year-old girl. The mayor, Allen Kauffman of Collins, was arrested Friday on four counts of felony enticement of a child in the latest sting orchestrated by a police detective in Diamond, another southwest Missouri town. Prosecutors said in court filings that Mr. Kauffman, 63, believed he was communicating with a girl from the Joplin area in a Yahoo chat room last November and December. In online messages, Mr. Kauffman reportedly asked the girl for sex and nude pictures, and encouraged her to have sex with a female friend in front of a Webcam so he could watch, the authorities said. Collins, with a population of about 200, is in St. Clair County.

A man accused of killing a Miami police detective was arrested after prosecutors dropped attempted murder charges against another man. Andrew J. Rolle, 20, was taken into custody at the Miami police station and later taken to the North Miami Beach Police Department, a police spokesman said. Mr. Rolle, left, was named by North Miami Beach officials as the new suspect in the Jan. 8 slaying of James Walker of the Miami Police Department, who was shot with an assault weapon. Mr. Rolle had been arrested Jan. 5 on misdemeanor loitering and prowling charges but was released on $500 bail, jail officials said. Chief Rafael Hernandez of the North Miami police would not divulge details about how Mr. Rolle was identified as the gunman other than to say technology helped.

Plans to build the first offshore wind farm in the nation cleared a regulatory hurdle when a preliminary federal environmental review found that it would pose no major ecological risks. The $1 billion Cape Wind project, which would spread 130 wind turbines over 24 square miles of Nantucket Sound, would have some effect on the area’s birds and views, but not enough to block it, the review by a unit of the Department of the Interior said. Homeowners on Cape Cod and the islands of Martha’s Vineyard and Nantucket have complained that the 247-foot turbines, which would be about 4.7 miles offshore, would spoil their ocean views.

At least six child welfare workers will be fired for failing to properly address complaints about a woman’s care for her four daughters, who were later found dead in their home, Mayor Adrian M. Fenty said. The bodies of the girls, ages 5, 6, 11 and 17, were found Wednesday. Their mother, Banita M. Jacks, is charged with murder. A social worker at the oldest girl’s school tried twice in April to get city agencies to investigate. The employees being fired work for the Child and Family Services Agency and include a division director. More workers could lose their jobs as an investigation continues, Mr. Fenty said.

For Democratic candidates, the growing risk of a recession is an opportunity for action. For Republicans, it presents a dilemma.
The technology giant’s quarterly profit — up 24 percent — may not be as reliable an indicator of broader trends in the American economy as in the past.
Speaker Nancy Pelosi met on Monday with the Federal Reserve chairman to discuss potential action by Congress, the White House and the central bank to jump-start the economy.
In Montreal, Mike Komisarek and Christopher Higgins are young stars for the Canadiens. But at home they are a couple of 20-somethings who live five minutes from each other in Huntington.

Vice President Dick Cheney and his industry friends are not going to let the struggling polar bear stand in their way of locking up as many oil and gas leases as they can before the door hits them on the way out.
Congress opens its 2008 session Tuesday by returning to a major Pentagon policy measure that was rejected by President Bush late last year.
A clinical trial of Zetia, a widely used cholesterol drug, has raised questions about its effectiveness and the behavior of pharmaceutical companies that conducted the study.
Federal authorities expect to identify and deport more than 200,000 immigrants this year who are convicted criminals serving time in prisons across the country.
For the first time in a decade, new investors will be able to put money into a mutual fund that helped fuel Fidelity Investments’ rapid growth.
A worker who was pouring concrete at a condominium hotel in SoHo fell to his death when a wooden mold used to set the concrete collapsed, the authorities said.
Scott Stringer, the Manhattan Borough President, is seeking to change East Harlem’s unhealthy eating habits, starting with a cookbook.
Tysabri, a treatment for multiple sclerosis, received regulatory approval on Monday for use among patients with Crohn’s disease.
The home builder Levitt & Sons received approval to tap a $3.5 million loan to finish building homes across the Southeast.
Paul Truong faces allegations that he  posted messages under other people’s names to Internet bulletin boards to get elected to the board.
Eddie Pope, a defender who retired after the 2007 season, will further the interests of his former compatriots as the director of player relations for the union that represents M.L.S. players.
A Southampton law intended to stop the crowding of multiple families into single units has become the latest controversy involving illegal immigrants in Suffolk County.

Traveling from Israel to the Persian Gulf to Saudi Arabia, President Bush repeatedly cited monotheistic faith, saying it was the foundation for freedom, justice and representative government.
The Dallas Cowboys did not play well in December, scoring a total of 12 points in two losses and some players acknowledged that this could have carried into January.

Sheriff Michael S. Carona of Orange County resigned Monday to focus on his legal defense against charges that he traded his office for hundreds of thousands of dollars’ worth of cash and lavish gifts.
With Boeing and Airbus scrambling to meet orders, analysts said the lag time between order and delivery is likely to start slowing sales.
The asset management firm Legg Mason said on Monday that it had sold $1.25 billion in convertible senior notes to an affiliate of the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.
An exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York will feature political paraphernalia, much of it from the collection of a New York lawyer who has amassed over one million pieces of ephemera.
Citigroup is expected to announce on Tuesday 4,000 additional job cuts, a steep cut in its stock dividend, and another boost from foreign investors.
The deal will let striking writers work on projects for  Media Rights Capital, a production company that helped finance the film “Babel.”
In his first visit to the Detroit auto show, Toyota’s chief executive appealed to his employees to take personal responsibility for the quality of Toyota cars and trucks.
Investigators said Monday that the Interstate 35W bridge in Minneapolis, which collapsed into the Mississippi River on Aug. 1, came down because of a flaw in its design.
Johnny Podres became a celebrated figure in the storied history of the Brooklyn Dodgers in October 1955 when he pitched them to their only World Series championship.
Europe’s antitrust regulator has opened two new investigations into claims that Microsoft has abused its dominant market position.

A former top state commerce official was sentenced in State Superior Court on Monday to six and a half years in prison for public corruption. The official, Lesly Devereaux, left, former chief of staff to the Commerce, Economic Growth and Tourism Commission, was convicted in July of official misconduct and pleaded guilty in October to welfare and public records tampering charges. Ms. Devereaux, 49, of Piscataway, admitted creating fake documents to mask her role in steering $11,000 in state contracts to her mother and sister. Her lawyer, Jack Furlong, said she would be eligible for a tightly controlled parole program after six months.
If approved, the law would prohibit the importation of fuels derived from crops grown on certain kinds of land — including forests, wetlands or grasslands.

A security guard and his companion have been arrested in the shooting death of the companion’s estranged husband in a public park, the Bergen County prosecutor’s office said on Monday. Horrified onlookers fled Mackay Park shortly after 4 p.m. Sunday after the husband, Severino Cepeda, 45, was shot several times. The police arrested the security guard, Livio Antonio Morales, 46, as well as Mr. Cepeda’s estranged wife, Patricia Pichardo, 38, who prosecutors say has been living with Mr. Morales in Englewood. Mr. Morales, a security guard for the Supreme Oil Company in Englewood, has been charged with murder and weapons offenses. Ms. Pichardo is charged with hindering apprehension and obstructing an investigation. The two were being held on Monday, with bail set at $2 million for Mr. Morales and $50,000 for Ms. Pichardo.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed a law on Sunday that extends until June 3 the state’s deadline to create a paper trail for its 10,000 electronic voting machines, the governor’s office said on Monday. The original Jan. 1 deadline, set by the Legislature in 2005 as part of a law requiring all electronic voting machines to produce paper records, was established so the machines could be retrofitted with printers in time for the state’s Feb. 5 presidential primary. After it became apparent that the deadline could not be met, state officials pushed back the timetable for the printers to June 3, the date of the Congressional primary. Researchers at the New Jersey Institute of Technology are now testing the printers, said David Wald, a spokesman for the state attorney general.

A man’s body was found beneath a stairway at a subway station in Edgemere on Monday morning, the police said. The body, which appeared to be that of a Hispanic man in his 30s, was found about 8:30 a.m. at the A train station at Beach 44th Street and Rockaway Freeway, the police said. A police spokeswoman said she did not know the circumstances under which the body was discovered. The police said the city medical examiner would determine the cause of death.

Edward J. De Fazio, the Hudson County prosecutor, said on Monday that he would not seek indictments of Hoboken’s police chief and a lieutenant accused of forcing subordinates to perform work at their homes on police time. The Jersey Journal reported that Mr. De Fazio said there was not enough evidence to indict the chief, Carmen LaBruno, and the lieutenant, Angelo Andriani, who headed a SWAT unit, but “there were clearly administrative issues that should be addressed.” Lieutenant Andriani was sued in October by five officers who said he coerced four of them to work on his house when they should have been on duty. Lieutenant Andriani has denied the allegations. The SWAT unit was disbanded in November after racy pictures emerged from a trip to the New Orleans area to help Hurricane Katrina victims.
Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers has a sprained right knee and is listed as questionable for Sunday’s American Football Conference championship game against the undefeated New England Patriots.
A plan for Verizon’s tower in Lower Manhattan will add one million square feet of new office space and open up the facade on what is now a virtually windowless building.
The organizers of an exhibition on the history and importance of the Sanitation Department are hoping that it will plant the seed of a future museum.

A justice of the West Virginia Supreme Court and a powerful coal-company executive met in Monte Carlo, as the executive’s companies were appealing a $50 million jury verdict against them to the court.
Genentech reported a 6 percent rise in fourth-quarter profit, but its stock slipped after news that its cancer drug, Avastin, failed to meet sales expectations.
What happens when a state chooses to give criminal suspects more protection than the federal Constitution requires?

Evidence of an abrupt slowdown in consumer spending mounted Monday as Sears Holdings, the owner of Sears and Kmart, warned that its profit would most likely plunge as much as 57 percent for the three months ending in early February.
The $123 million deal is considered a mostly symbolic gesture, meant to bolster military relations with Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf states.
Craig Masback, who for the last 10 years has been the chief executive officer of USA Track and Field, resigned last week to become director of business affairs for Nike Global Sports Marketing.
The former Central Intelligence Agency official who ordered the destruction of interrogation videotapes will not be required to appear Wednesday at a closed Congressional hearing on the matter.
The board of GiveWell has disciplined the second of its two founders for promoting the organization by posing on the Internet as someone else.
Howell Raines, who lost the top newsroom job at The New York Times in 2003 amid public rancor and scandal, will become a media columnist at Condé Nast Portfolio.
An Illinois lawmaker wants to rescue a program in Chicago that offered teenagers rides home on weekend nights.
Zynga Game Network is one of a new cluster of Internet ventures capitalizing on the rapidly growing social networks like Facebook and MySpace.
Yale and other universities with large endowments have been under pressure from Congress to spend more and reduce charges for students.
Terra Firma plans to dismiss about a third of the staff at  EMI as it moves to streamline marketing operations and focus on the discovery of new artists.
A consortium of foreign companies has resolved a dispute over Kazakhstan’s giant Kashagan oil field.

The Messenger spacecraft dashed past Mercury on Monday, getting a glance at the solar system’s innermost planet, which it will eventually orbit for detailed studies.

For winemaker Piergiorgio Castellani Jr. “surfing is not that different from producing wine.”

BIG FARE INCREASES After United Airlines raised domestic fares across the board by $50 a round trip on Friday, most major carriers quickly followed with similar increases on many routes, according to FareCompare.com. The reason was sharply higher fuel costs. Delta Air Lines raised its round-trip fares by $50 immediately after United’s move. American Airlines also posted $50 round-trip increases on 55 percent of its route system, though "conspicuously absent" are increases on its routes that overlap with many Southwest Airlines routes, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive of FareCompare.com. Then on Monday, Northwest Airlines also joined in the $50 increase on most of its routes. Continental Airlines, which initially raised fares by $50 on some routes on Friday, withdrew the increases Monday morning, but Mr. Seaney said it was unclear whether Continental might reverse course again soon. This was the second broad fare increase in 2008, and the 10th since last Labor Day, Mr. Seaney said, adding: "It seems the legacy airlines, United in particular, are forgoing the nickel-and-dime strategy of increases every few weeks and are going for the whole enchilada at one time.".
To the Editor:.

When news surfaced over the weekend that 50 Cent, Wyclef Jean, Timbaland and other rap stars had been implicated in a steroids investigation, some hip-hop fans were shocked, but to many in the industry the accusations seemed inevitable.

Those of us who have always wondered why award shows have to be so infernally long got our answer on Sunday night at the Golden Globes: they don’t.

The Argentine-born Israeli pianist and conductor Daniel Barenboim has accepted Palestinian citizenship and an honorary Palestinian passport, Agence France-Presse reported. “I hope that my new status will be an example of Israeli-Palestinian coexistence,” he said after a concert in the West Bank town of Ramallah on Saturday. Among other posts, including Maestro Scaligero, a sort of principal guest conductor, at La Scala Opera in Milan, Mr. Barenboim is the founding director of the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, based in Seville, Spain, which mingles Israeli (Jewish and Palestinian) and Arab youths.

NBC’s bare-bones version of the “65th Annual Golden Globes” attracted just 5.8 million viewers on Sunday night, a small fraction of the 20 million who tuned in to the awards show a year ago, according to Nielsen’s estimates. A two-hour “Dateline” special, featuring interviews with the nominees and preceding the 9 p.m. announcement show fared no better, drawing only 4.4 million. Combined, the three-hour broadcast delivered a dismal 1.3 rating in the critical demographic of adults 18 to 49, a far cry from the 6.5 rating the show earned over prime time on a Monday last January. The big hit on Sunday was Fox’s premiere of “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles,” which attracted 18.3 million viewers at 8 p.m. and the highest ratings by far of any new series this season. Although “Terminator” benefited from following a football game on Fox that attracted more than 35 million viewers during the 7 p.m. hour, no other scripted series debut on any broadcast network has done better in the 18-to-49 set in three years. The last scripted series debut on a broadcast network to earn higher ratings among adults 18 to 49 was CBS’s “Numb3rs” on Jan. 23, 2005. Fox easily led the night’s ratings, followed by CBS and ABC. NBC ranked fourth. Part one of CBS’s “Comanche Moon” drew 15.8 million viewers.

Four man-made waterfalls, 90 to 120 feet high, will punctuate New York’s waterfront for three months starting in mid-July. The creation of the Icelandic artist Olafur Eliasson, the project is a collaboration between the city and the Public Art Fund, the nonprofit organization that presents art around the city. The waterfalls (above, in a rendering) have been designed to be environmentally friendly and will be in New York Harbor at Pier 35 in Lower Manhattan, at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge and between Piers 4 and 5 in Brooklyn and at Governors Island. Money for the project, estimated to cost about $15 million, comes entirely from private funds, and the Economic Development Corporation estimates that the waterfalls will bring more than $50 million to the city’s economy. “Throughout history we have always taken water for granted,” said Mr. Eliasson in a telephone interview from his Berlin studio. “Now people can engage in the physical nature of something as epic as a waterfall.”.

The John Newbery Medal for the most outstanding contribution to children’s literature was awarded on Monday to “Good Masters! Sweet Ladies! Voices From a Medieval Village,” by Laura Amy Schlitz. The American Library Association announced the prize at its midwinter meeting in Philadelphia. The book, a series of monologues and dialogues about characters in the Middle Ages, is illustrated by Robert Byrd and published by Candlewick Press. Its format is different from the more traditional novels that have characterized past Newbery winners. The winner of the Randolph Caldecott Medal for the most distinguished American picture book for children was “The Invention of Hugo Cabret,” by Brian Selznick. That book, published by Scholastic Press, is also different from the more traditional short picture books for young children that win the Caldecott medal. “Hugo Cabret” is a novel told in blocks of text interspersed with 284 pages of black-and-white drawings.

The Icelandic pop singer and songwriter Bjork was accused of attacking a news photographer, ripping his sweatshirt in half after he ignored a request not to take any pictures on her arrival on Sunday at Auckland International Airport in New Zealand, The New Zealand Herald reported. Glenn Jeffrey, above, a photographer for the newspaper, said Bjork was accompanied by a man who asked him not to take pictures. “I took a couple of pictures and I got about three or four frames of her,” Mr. Jeffrey said, “and as I turned and walked away, she came up behind me, grabbed the back of my black skivvy and tore it down the back. As she did this, she fell over. She fell to the ground. At no stage did I touch her or speak with her.”.

Roger Avary, who won an Academy Award as the co-writer of “Pulp Fiction” with Quentin Tarantino, was arrested on suspicion of manslaughter and driving under the influence after a single-car collision that injured his wife and killed a man on Sunday in Ojai, Calif., The Associated Press reported. The dead man was identified as Andreas Zini, 34, believed to be a visitor from Italy. Mr. Avary’s wife, Gretchen, 40, was ejected from the car and hospitalized in stable condition. Mr. Avary, 42, who was also a co-writer of “Beowulf,” was released on $50,000 bail.
St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn has announced its 2008 season, and one of the shows is so big that St. Ann’s has to set up another theater.
This intriguing but highly uneven anthology of reflections about Hillary Rodham Clinton by a spectrum of well-known female writers underscores the relentless media focus on her life.
