A decade-old sexual harassment lawsuit filed by a former player against North Carolina women's coach Anson Dorrance has been settled, athletic department officials said Monday. Melissa Jennings, the former player who had accused Dorrance of sexually harassing players, will receive $385,000, mostly for lawyer's fees. Dorrance had denied harassing his players, but in an apology letter sent in 1998 -- the same year the lawsuit was filed -- he acknowledged participating in banter of a ''jesting or teasing nature'' with groups of players.

BERMANT--Blanche, 95, formerly of Great Neck. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Devoted mother to Edward (Alison) and the late Diane Silverman (Warren). Cherished grandmother of Jason, Lyssa, Caroline, James, Steven, Robert and Lisa. Loving great-grandmother of four. Strong yet gentle. Ever devoted to her family. Services: Riverside Nassau North, Great Neck, 11:30am today.

A front-page article on Dec. 20 about numerous ''present'' votes by Barack Obama in the Illinois State Senate misstated the status of a bill to prohibit sex-related shops from opening near schools or places of worship. The bill did not get the required three-fifths majority, so it did not in fact pass. (Mr. Obama voted ''present'' on the measure.)

STREISFELD--Seymour S. and Evelyn, on January 11, 2008 in Florida. Beloved mother and father of Jeffrey and Dr. Neil Streisfeld, loving mother and father-in-law of Barbara and Donna, fond brother of Helen Kline and Frances Lieberman, fond sister of Lenore Rambach, cherished grandparents of Dr. Matthew (Esther), Karly, Ari and Gabriel, cherished great-grandparents of Samantha Rose. Funeral services Thursday, January 17, 2008, 12 noon at the Bay Terrace Jewish Center, 209th St. and Willets Pt. Blvd., Bayside, Queens. The family requests donations be made to the Bay Terrace Jewish Center. They will be deeply missed.

MEYEROWITZ--Ruth, be loved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Ellen Greenberg and Laurie Kopp. Cherished mother-in-law of Stephen and the late Bruce. Loving sister of Mort Maurer and Gerald Maurer. Adored grandmother of Emily and Brett, Abigale and David, Glen and Alexis, and Jared. Loving great-grandmother of Oliver and Cooper. Also survived by her loving companion Eva. Services Wednesday, 1:00pm, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.
FINKELSTEIN--George. Beloved husband of Shirley; devoted father of Susan (David) Gordon; loving grandpa of Sam and Miriam; beloved brother of Ed (Iris).

KAGEL--Murray Ira, 86, died on January 12, 2008 of complications of end stage Alzheimer's disease. He is survived by his loving wife, Connie Kagel, his adored children, Krishna Das (Jeffery) Kagel, Satrupa Kagel, his cherished stepdaughter, Nicole Moss, granddaughter, Janaki Kagel (the apple of his eye), his favorite brother, Robert Kagel and his loyal companion through his illness, Bert Kagel. Murray was a life force who brought intelligence to his early profession as an attorney (St. John's Law School 1948) which he combined with compassion and insight in his later career as a psychoanalyst (National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysis, 1959). An advanced amateur piano player himself, Murray loved jazz piano and was a regular at local Greenwich Village jazz clubs (especially Bradley's and the Knickerbocker) for the last 60 years. Tennis was his passion and he won the First Annual Sigmund Freud tennis tournament in 1985. Murray's humor is legend. His vital inner light shone through the ravages of Alzheimer's, until the end of his life. He is deeply missed. Memorial services will be held at the Knickerbocker (9th street and University Place) at 10:30am on Thursday, January 17, 2008.
BALLIN--Charlotte Pinco, 104, one time teacher at City and Country School, beloved friend, widow of Samuel Ross Ballin, died at home; 225 West 12th Street, New York City.

WOLF--Diane R. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Diane R. Wolf, beloved daughter of Joyce and Erving Wolf, whose enduring commitment and generosity have strengthened our ability to serve those in need, profoundly impacting millions of lives around the globe and enriching the New York Jewish community. We extend our deepest sympathies to Joyce and Erving and their entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO WOLF--Diane R/d. The Capitol Hill Chapter of the Federal Bar Association wishes to extend its deepest sympathy to the Wolf family. The Chapter and its members will miss her.

An article in Science Times last Tuesday about superconductivity, the flow of electricity without resistance, misinterpreted a comment by Vinay Ambegaokar, a physicist at Cornell. When Dr. Ambegaokar said he preferred approaches with ''less constant intellectual effort,'' he was praising a theory of superconductivity developed by Soviet scientists in the late 1950s after physicists at the University of Illinois had provided the first solution to superconductivity; he was not referring to an earlier ''phenomenological'' theory that described superconductivity's behavior but not its underlying cause.

GOTTLIEB--Sylvia, of Phoenix, AZ, and Great Neck, NY, born June 11, 1920, died January 14, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Leonard, and mother of Ellen, Amy, and Erica. Grandmother of David, Jeffrey, and Liana. Great-grandmother of Parker Lerman. Service Wednesday, January 16, 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, on Amsterdam Ave. and West 76th St. Contributions in Sylvia's memory maybe made to Hospice of Arizona, 2222 West Northern Avenue Suite A100, Phoenix, AZ 85021.

An obituary last Tuesday about Gilbert Harrison, former editor and publisher of The New Republic, misstated the year he met his wife during a trip to Chicago. It was 1950, not 1960. The obituary also misstated the given name of the co-founder of The New Republic. He was Willard Straight, not William.

ROSENBLUT--Linda. Special sympathies are extended to our friends and colleagues, Alan and Michael Rosenblut, to whom we offer our thoughts, prayers, and support. Our deepest condolences go out to the entire Rosenblut family. Audrey Weiner, Chair Scott Amrhein, President CCLC

Scott Rolen was traded from the St. Louis Cardinals to the Toronto Blue Jays on Monday for Troy Glaus in a swap of all-star third basemen that was completed after the two passed physicals.

BANISH--Charles Alexander, passed on January 10, 2008. Beloved son of Catherine Banish and the late Capt. Charles Banish; brother of Dorothy Banish Madden and Valerie Banish Bobosh; uncle to Jessica, James, Paul and Alex Madden and Julianna, John, Seth and Daniel Bobosh. Age 47 years. A native and resident of Jackson Heights, NY. He was a 1982 Tulane University graduate, a former New York City Police Officer and currently employed as a Tax Specialist with the IRS. The family would prefer donations to a children's organization of one's choice. Sign Guest Book online at: www.ejfieldingfh.com.

Emily Hughes will miss next week's United States Figure Skating Championships because of a hip injury. The injury has prevented her from training. She said Monday that she hoped to resume ''serious training'' in four to six weeks. Hughes has been in the top 10 at the last two world championships. The national championships are Jan. 23-27 in St. Paul.

An article on Saturday about a plan by the federal Citizenship and Immigration Services agency to hire retired employees to help clear a backlog of naturalization applications inaccurately described another measure the agency is taking to handle the applications. It is asking current employees to work voluntary overtime; it is not imposing mandatory overtime.

A Spare Times listing in Weekend on Nov. 16 about a Ukrainian event in Manhattan, using information provided by the New York Police Department and the mayor's Community Assistance Unit, referred to it incorrectly. It was a march to commemorate the death of millions of Ukrainians in the famine of 1932-33, which resulted from Soviet policies. It was not a Ukrainian Day Parade. A reader pointed out the error at the time and received a response from editors; the reader wrote to The Times again this week requesting a correction, which editors agreed was warranted.

8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL It's that time again, as if there were a time it ever really wasn't. The bedlam begins with the requisite freak audition footage, in two-hour episodes Tuesday night (filmed in Philadelphia) and Wednesday night (Dallas). Would-be contestants for the show's seventh season sing their hearts out before Randy Jackson, Paula Abdul and Simon Cowell, above from left, in hopes of becoming the next Jordin Sparks, Carrie Underwood or Fantasia. (Isn't America tired of this yet?) The real competition settles in next Tuesday at 8 p.m. The ubiquitous Ryan Seacrest is host. 7 P.M. (Cinemax) ANDREW JENKS, ROOM 335 When he was 19, on his summer break from Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, Mr. Jenks moved into an assisted-living facility in Florida, ostensibly to hang out. And, we're guessing, to make this documentary, which looks at the phenomenon of these facilities in a society that does not entirely embrace its older citizens. Among the stars is 95-year-old Tammy, who immediately informs Mr. Jenks that the medication in her pharmacy bag is ''birth-control pills.''

Darren McFadden, Arkansas's all-American running back, announced Monday that he would skip his senior season and enter the N.F.L. draft. McFadden was the Heisman Trophy runner-up in 2006 and 2007. He ran for 1,830 yards last season, second on the Southeastern Conference's single-season list. He is second on the conference's career list with 4,590 yards rushing. Felix Jones, the Razorbacks' other talented tailback, said he would also enter the draft a year early.

The Braves completed a trade for center fielder Mark Kotsay on Monday, sending reliever Joey Devine and a minor league pitcher to the Oakland Athletics. The deal became official after Kotsay was examined by the Braves' doctors.

A DRUG THAT DOESN'T WORK The cholesterol-lowering drug Zetia, which is prescribed to about 1 million people a week, did not show any medical benefits in a two-year clinical trial, the drug makers Merck and Schering-Plough said. GOOD NEWS FROM BIG BLUE Quarterly profit at I.B.M. rose 24 percent -- much more than analysts predicted. The news pushed Big Blue's stock price up 5.4 percent, to $102.93. [C1.]

The former Oklahoma State linebacker Chris Collins was sentenced to 10 years of probation by a Texas judge Monday for sexually assaulting a 12-year-old girl. Collins, 20, pleaded guilty Nov. 7 to an aggravated sexual assault charge. He was one of four men charged following an after-prom party in 2004, when he was 17. Collins was dismissed from the team five days after his plea.

ATLAS--Dr. Sheldon. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our member, Sheldon Atlas, beloved husband of Helen and father of Laura. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Roger Meltzer, President ATLAS--Sheldon M./d, world famous polymer chemist, died in New York on January 13, 2008 after a long illness at 83. He leaves devoted wife of over 40 years, Helen V. Atlas, daughter Laura Masurovsky, grandsons Alex, Adam and Jason, and sister Hazel Eisenstat. A pioneer in polymer chemistry, worked closely with friend and colleague, Nobel nominee, Dr. Herman Mark. They were the first American scientists invited to China in 1972. Received Ph.D. from NYU in 1961. Taught at Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn for years. Frequently lectured at Academy of Sciences Moscow, Weizman Institute Israel, consultant to NASA, Government of India, United Nations. An inventor, commercialized his patent on polyethylene, participated in development of oil and gas in France, and gas pipeline in China. Chaired scholarship committee of American Israel Cultural Foundation. Opened his home to dancers and musicians from Russia and Israel. Despite his success, Dr. Atlas remained unpretentious and principled, cared deeply for people and treated everyone as his equal. A family funeral service is being held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel in Manhattan and a memorial service will be announced at a later date. ATLAS--Sheldon/d. More than a friend, you were family. We love you. The Steinguts

Saturday morning would seem to be the perfect time to get voters to caucus. But for observant Jews or Seventh-day Adventists, Saturdays are the Sabbath, when many of them refrain from secular work. So some are not pleased that the Nevada caucuses are scheduled for Saturday morning.

The Mets completed their 2008 coaching staff Monday by selecting Tom Nieto, who had served the last three seasons as catching instructor, to be their first-base coach. Nieto replaces Rickey Henderson, who was hired during a midseason coaching shakeup but was not asked to return. Nieto, 47, will continue to work with the catchers.

In a surprise initiative, the conservative president-elect of South Korea, Lee Myung-bak, said he would meet with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, ''anytime'' if a meeting could help persuade Mr. Kim to abandon his nuclear weapons programs. Mr. Lee, who will be sworn in on Feb. 25, said he was willing to meet Mr. Kim as often as possible. Mr. Lee's two predecessors, the departing President Roh Moo-hyun and Kim Dae-jung, each met Mr. Kim only once.

A news analysis article on Dec. 28 about the impact of Benazir Bhutto's death on Pakistani politics attributed an erroneous distinction to the city of Karachi, near the site where her funeral was held. It is Pakistan's largest city -- not the second-largest, which is Lahore.

The government of Malawi announced that it had cut diplomatic ties with Taiwan and set up relations with China, prompting Taiwanese officials to accuse China of luring Malawi into the move with $6 billion in aid. In Africa, only Burkina Faso, Gambia, Swaziland and São Tomé and Principe still recognize Taiwan.

Byas, the victim, included incorrect information from a law enforcement official and a state senator about a 1994 attack on Mr. Parks in Queens. The fate of the America's Cup could be decided next week. New York State Supreme Court Justice Herman Cahn scheduled a hearing for Jan. 23, when he is expected to rule on Alinghi's appeal against Golden Gate Yacht Club's position as the challenger of record for the 33rd edition of the race. On Nov. 27, Cahn ruled that Desafio Español's Club Nautica Español de Vela was an invalid challenger and had no right to negotiate the format of the America's Cup with Alinghi, a Swiss syndicate. Alinghi filed a motion to reopen the case by claiming the challenge lodged by the Americans was invalid because the boat they proposed to race was flawed.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City and Mayor James J. Schmitt of Green Bay, Wis., just announced a “friendly wager” on the outcome of the National Football Conference championship game on Sunday evening, when the Giants visit the Green Bay Packers. The winner advances to the Super Bowl on Feb. 3.

Bedbugs continue to disrupt New Yorkers’ sleep. Since July, the city’s 311 hot line has registered 4,000 complaints about the nocturnal blood-sucking creatures, 1,700 of which resulted in violations issued to building owners across the city.

With the new World Trade Center rising clamorously around it, the last standing vestige of the old World Trade Center is about to be uprooted. In the last week, workers have cut openings into a concrete superstructure supporting 38 steps that once led from Vesey Street up to the north end of the sprawling Austin J. Tobin Plaza. Because hundreds of evacuees made their way down this route on Sept. 11, 2001, it is called the “survivors’ stairway.”Whether the stairway itself would survive was a question for the Pataki administration to ponder. It proposed to salvage individual steps but not the entire run of stairs, which stands where Tower 2 is to rise. Preservationists and survivors of the attack were dismayed by the plan.
The United States Supreme Court’s decision upholding the method of selecting State Supreme Court justices is reverberating throughout New York’s political world.

Sgt. Jonathan Silberstein has moved to Los Angeles since his New York Army National Guard unit last deployed to Iraq, in 2004, but today he was back in Manhattan, preparing for a new mission, this time in Afghanistan.

Supporters and opponents of congestion pricing converged on the auditorium of Hunter College this afternoon for a citywide public hearing on the interim report of the New York City Traffic Congestion Mitigation Commission, the state panel charged with weighing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to charge fees for driving in Manhattan against alternatives, like imposing tolls on the East River bridges.

A few business executives have dreamed up a private-sector solution to the problem of secure bicycle parking in New York: the city’s first bikes-only parking lot. They have a space on West 33rd Street. All they need is a corporation willing to pay as much as $200,000 a year to sponsor it.
David Grubin, a director, writer and cinematographer working in New York City, took questions from readers through Jan. 23 on his new three-part documentary, “The Jewish Americans.”

One lawsuit, 17 years, and 443 relieved users later, Douglas Lasdon is pleased that New Yorkers were able to use thepublic toilet that he had dreamed of in 1990.Mr. Lasdon, who has worked as a homeless advocate through the Urban Justice Center, first brought the issue of public toilets to the city’s consciousness, when his group filed a lawsuit in 1990 on behalf of three homeless men and one woman who, it was said, were “forced to endure continual embarrassment, humiliation, physical injury and hazardous conditions resulting from defendants’ violations.”

The robust growth in real estate values in New York, a trend that helped fuel years of record budget surpluses and city spending, has nearly skidded to a halt, and that shift could bring new pressure on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to raise taxes, Diane Cardwell and Ray Rivera report. The city estimates that when it conducts its annual valuation of all property in the city in May, it will be just 1.44 percent more than the last assessment, the smallest gain since the beginning of the Bloomberg administration. In recent years, the city seemed insulated from dips in the national real estate market, posting several double-digit gains, including an 18 percent increase in values last year. But now, according to data from the tentative annual assessment roll, which will largely determine taxes for the fiscal year beginning in July, declining values of small homes outside Manhattan are pulling down the overall market as the effects of the country’s mortgage trouble take hold.
What we’re looking at on the Web today…

Under what circumstances can a patient in an emergency room be forced to submit to a procedure that doctors deem to be medically necessary? That question — and the notion of informed consent — is at the heart of a civil case that is about to go to trial in March in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.Brian Persaud, a 38-year-old construction worker who lives in Brooklyn, asserts that he was forced to undergo a rectal examination after sustaining a head injury in an on-the-job accident at a Midtown construction site on May 20, 2003. Mr. Persaud was taken to the emergency room at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, where he received eight stitches to his head.

An activist group, Grandmothers Against the War, held a mock funeral procession this afternoon from the Times Square Armed Forces Recruiting Center to Rockefeller Center to protest the war in Iraq. The group has been holding weekly antiwar vigils for four years. Its founder, Joan Wile, is one of 18 women — all grandmothers — who were arrested in 2005 for trying to enter the recruiting station. They were acquitted of disorderly-conduct charges after a six-day trial. The protest today occurred without incident.

“Something’s going around.” The statement — a staple of water-cooler conversation and cubicle chitchat — appears to be grounded in truth, for the moment. The average daily number of flu-related emergency room visits increased by 19 percent from November to last week, the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced today. This is separate from the novovirus, or stomach flu, that the department warned about last month.

About one in seven New York City residents — some 1.1 million people — receive food stamps, the federally financed benefit created in 1964 to reduce hunger and malnutrition for the poor. The average monthly benefit in 2006 was around $113.

The economy may be teetering, but the personal computer business is still nimbly running at full speed, according to the tally of sales in the fourth quarter of 2007 from the International Data Corporation. Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and UAL's United Airlines are all very publicly flirting about a merger pairing either Northwest and Delta or Delta and United. The very public floating of these trial balloons is evidence of the difficulty that any such merger will face.

This week's guest blogger is the Milan-based artist and satirist Francesco Vezzoli. Over the past decade, the diva-and-Prada-obsessed Vezzoli, 36, has at once defiled and genuflected at the altar of celebrity. His campy oeuvre includes everything from needlework portraits of Maria Callas and Anna Magnani to films like "Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidal's Caligula," starring Helen Mirren and Courtney Love, and live performances like Pirandello's "Right You Are (If You Think You Are)," starring - among others - Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Abigail Breslin, which he produced at the Guggenheim last October as part of the Performa 07 series. In his third post of the week he writes about the actress Monica Vitti. To read all of Francesco Vezzoli's prior blog posts, click here.

Terry Pristin has an article in today's Times that should be must reading, about the havoc left by an apartment owner who amassed a lot of buildings, paying himself hefty fees and then letting the buldings rot. The bank that lent him the money securitized the mortgages into CMBS -- commercial mortage backed securities. The mortgages are now defaulting at a rapid rate.

Name: Lala GuimarãesHome base: Rio de JaneiroAge: 57Occupation: Public relationsRetail standbys: Osklen for everything, especially long dresses and accessories; Lenny for pre-, post- and during the beach. It's not that difficult to make a bikini, but she takes it to another level of sophistication.Provisions: My health is really important to me, so Zona Sul for the freshest organic vegetables and fruits.Escape route: Buzios. It has all different kinds of beaches: rocky, sandy, surfy, big, small. It's very close to Rio, so it's easy to get to, and once you're there it's magical.Party central: Londra at the Fasano. The décor is very dark and British, like an old club or library. The walls are decorated with old album covers, from bands like the Who and the Rolling Stones.Cocktail: Water.Restaurant: Fasano Al Mare . The food and service are excellent, but more importantly it's in front of the sea, which is rare for restaurants in Rio.Bookshop: Livraria Travessa. They have a huge variety and you can find most anything you need or want in one location.Flip-flops: Havaianas. I collect them. They're very democratic shoes. Whether it's the working class, or those who live in the favelas or those with money, everybody has them. I love them because you can wear them to a party and no one bats an eye.

I've written about weather alarmism and terrorphobia as examples of availability cascades, but there's an important distinction between these cascades. The environmentalists promoting fear of climate change sometimes use dubious tactics in exploiting images like Hurricane Katrina, but they can legitimately point to longer trends showing that the planet has warmed and is projected to warm further, affecting everyone on Earth.

I returned from a two-week vacation yesterday, and before I left I promised myself I was going to try to carry my holiday mood with me as I eased back into work. So I did something I thought would help. I wrote my post-vacation entry before I went on vacation. I did it for two reasons: I wanted to make sure I didn't have a deadline my first day back at work. But I also wanted to come home and read a good post on getting organized again.

Officers responding to a complaint of a foul odor found the body of a 39-year-old man on Tuesday morning in a bathtub of an apartment at 529 East 138th Street in Mott Haven, the police said. The victim’s identity was withheld pending notification of his relatives. The body was fully clothed, and the bathtub was dry, investigators said. The case remains under investigation, the police said, and the medical examiner’s office would determine the cause of death.

A former dentist will plead guilty next Tuesday to charges that he orchestrated a plot to plunder corpses and sell the body parts for transplants, his lawyer, Mario Gallucci, said on Tuesday. The case broke two years ago with accusations that the dentist, Dr. Michael Mastromarino, 44, of Brooklyn, was making millions by carving up corpses at a Brooklyn funeral home and selling the parts. Among the bodies was that of Alistair Cooke, the former host of “Masterpiece Theatre.” Dr. Mastromarino had been expected to go on trial as early as next month. Brooklyn prosecutors had no immediate comment.
Excerpts from remarks to supporters on Tuesday night after winning the Republican primary in Michigan:.

A front-page article on Tuesday about the challenge facing Barack Obama as he pursues Latino voters in his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination misidentified, in some editions, the former mayor of Los Angeles who defeated Antonio R. Villaraigosa for the post in 2001 and lost to him in a 2005 rematch. He is James Hahn — not Kenneth Hahn, who was his father.

An obituary on Thursday about the country record producer Ken Nelson erroneously included a band among his recording credits. While he produced Rose Maddox’s solo recordings for Capitol Records, the Maddox Brothers & Rose had disbanded by the time Mr. Nelson was handling the Capitol label.

An obituary on May 19 about Karen Hess, a food historian, gave an incorrect account of the career of her husband, John, and misidentified the city in which they met. He was a merchant marine and a journalist, but never a longshoreman. They met in Salt Lake City, where he was working as a reporter, not in San Francisco. The errors were pointed out in an e-mail message from the family last month.

An article on Jan. 3 about an announcement by the Suffolk County, N.Y., district attorney that he would not retry Martin Tankleff in the 1988 murders of his parents after his conviction was overturned by a state appellate court misquoted, in some copies, Judge Stephen Braslow of Suffolk County Court, who had refused Mr. Tankleff’s appeal, in which he cited new evidence and new witnesses. Judge Braslow called the new witnesses “a cavalcade of nefarious scoundrels” — not “characters.” (The error also appeared in articles on Dec. 22 about the voiding of the conviction and on Dec. 28 about Mr. Tankleff’s release.) The Jan. 3 article also misstated, in some copies, the length of time Mr. Tankleff was interrogated by the police and the timing of hearings before Judge Braslow. Mr. Tankleff was interrogated for about seven hours, not 18, and the hearings took place in 2004 and 2005, not last year.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the status of reality television shows affected by the writers’ strike referred incorrectly to the competition faced by the NBC show “Celebrity Apprentice” in its debut on Jan. 3. While its ratings that night were the strongest for the series since 2005, it was not until the next week, on Jan. 10, that the show faced “stiff competition” from original episodes of “C.S.I.” on CBS and “Grey’s Anatomy” on ABC. On Jan. 3, both of those shows were repeats.

A picture caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Saturday about an investigation by the New York attorney general related to subprime loans referred incorrectly to a sign in a photograph of a residential street in Queens. The sign was an advertisement for a company offering refinancing or credit services to those in danger of foreclosure. It was not a foreclosure sign.

The TV Sports column on Tuesday, about the impact of frigid weather on the N.F.L. playoffs, misidentified the position that Forrest Gregg played in the so-called Ice Bowl of 1967 in Green Bay. It was offensive tackle — not guard, a position he occasionally played.
An obituary on Dec. 25 about the choreographer Michael Kidd misstated his given name at birth and his birthplace. He was Milton (not Michael) Greenwald, and he was born in Manhattan, not Brooklyn.

An article in some editions on Sunday about the filing of murder charges against a Staten Island man in the death of his 3-week-old daughter misidentified the current Staten Island district attorney. He is Daniel M. Donovan Jr. — not William L. Murphy, who was the previous district attorney.

Because of a transcription error, an article on Monday about concern over personal safety in the Atlanta area following the killing of a hiker misspelled, in some editions, the name of the town in Georgia where the hiker’s dog and some of her clothing were found. It was Cumming, not Cummings. The article also misidentified the place where a suspect in the killing was apprehended. It was DeKalb County, not Cumming.

An obituary on Nov. 2 about Col. Aleksandr Feklisov, a Soviet spy, misspelled the surname of the Soviet prime minister for whom Mr. Feklisov handled security for a 1959 visit to the United States. He was Nikita Khrushchev, not Krushchev. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message last week.

A front-page article on Tuesday about the challenge facing Barack Obama as he pursues Latino voters in his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination misidentified, in some editions, the former mayor of Los Angeles who defeated Antonio R. Villaraigosa for the post in 2001 and lost to him in a 2005 rematch. He is James Hahn — not Kenneth Hahn, who was his father.
Pledging to renew the automobile industry, Mitt Romney defeated his principal rival, Senator John McCain.
The Nevada Supreme Court ruled that MSNBC was not required to include Dennis J. Kucinich in a debate with the leading Democratic presidential candidates.
A conservative group must abide by campaign finance laws if it wants to run advertisements promoting its anti-Hillary Rodham Clinton movie, a federal court ruled.

Inflation in Britain was above the Bank of England’s 2 percent target for a third month in December, adding to the case for fewer interest rate cuts this year. Consumer prices rose 2.1 percent from a year earlier, the same as in November, the Office for National Statistics said.

Samsung Electronics, the semiconductor and flat-screen maker, posted a smaller drop in fourth-quarter profit than analysts estimated as liquid-crystal display earnings countered a decline in chip prices. Net income fell 6.6 percent, to 2.21 trillion won ($2.4 billion), from 2.37 trillion won in the period a year earlier, the company said. Profit exceeded analysts’ estimate of 1.95 trillion won.

Belgian newspapers, emboldened by a court victory against Google last year, have started a preliminary copyright action against the European Commission over links on agency Web sites. Two Web sites owned by the commission, the Brussels-based executive for the 27 European Union nations, infringe copyright laws by linking to Belgian newspaper articles free, according to Copiepresse, a copyright group for French- and German-language newspapers. A Brussels court, asked by the group to look at its claim, appointed an expert to study how information is gathered for the E.U. sites. “Once the expert has submitted his report, we may decide to file a lawsuit,” said Margaret Boribon, the group’s secretary general. A Brussels court in February ruled Google had violated Belgian copyright laws by publishing links to the newspapers without permission and ordered the company to remove the links or pay a daily fine of 25,000 euros ($37,000).

Three German Internet entrepreneurs, the Samwer brothers, have taken a stake in the social networking site Facebook, Alexander Samwer said. Mr. Samwer, who declined to reveal the size of the stake, said the brothers would now become Facebook’s strategic partners in Europe. “We are going to support the expansion of Facebook in Europe,” he said. Alexander, alongside brothers Oliver and Marc, made their name in 1999 when they sold the German Internet auction site Alando.de to eBay for $50 million in stock.

Nokia, the Finnish phone maker, said it would close a manufacturing plant and automotive supply unit in Bochum, Germany, and was in talks to sell a research and development unit in Bochum to Sasken Communication Technologies. The three moves would reduce Nokia’s work force by 2,300 positions, or about 2 percent.
David Justice, who was cited in the Mitchell report, will no longer be a studio analyst for the YES Network but will contribute to the channel’s Web site.
Tomas Plekanec scored twice and Cristobal Huet stopped 17 shots for the Montreal Canadiens on Tuesday night in a 3-1 victory over the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum.
It would be best if the Supreme Court moved on its own to allow coverage of oral arguments similar to C-Span’s valuable coverage of the House and Senate.
Congress should pass without delay a bill proposed by Representative Rush Holt that would help address the weaknesses in electronic voting.
It was very disturbing to learn that a heavily promoted cholesterol-lowering drug had flunked a clinical trial of its effectiveness.

A baby, a toddler and their mothers were shot to death at their Indianapolis home while the women held their children in their arms, the police said. Officers were searching for two men seen running from the home. All four victims were shot repeatedly late Monday, said Assistant Chief Eva Talley-Sanders of the Indianapolis Police Department. The victims were Charlii Yarrell, 4 months; Charlii’s mother, Andrea Yarrell, 24; Jordan Hunt, 23 months; and Jordan’s mother, Gina Hunt, 24. A set of scales, several weapons, a safe and one pound of a what is believed to be marijuana were found in the house, Chief Talley-Sanders said.

The disgraced former prosecutor who led the debunked Duke lacrosse rape case filed for bankruptcy, citing more than $180 million in liabilities — the majority from the threat of two pending lawsuits. The prosecutor, Michael B. Nifong, reported $243,898 in assets of real and personal property to United States Bankruptcy Court. The filing came the same day that Mr. Nifong and other defendants were required to respond to a sweeping federal lawsuit filed in October by the three exonerated players whom he had falsely accused of rape.

After an outcry of objections, the California Energy Commission withdrew its proposal to require new buildings in the state to have radio-controlled thermostats that, in a power emergency, could be used to override customers’ temperature settings. Instead of making the proposal part of new state building requirements, the commissioners will discuss the use of the “programmable communicating thermostats” when considering how to manage electrical loads — with the understanding that customers would have the right to refuse to allow the state to override their wishes.

The government released Sameh Khouzam, an Egyptian citizen, from a Pennsylvania prison after a federal judge ruled last week that the United States could not deport him to Egypt. The Egyptian government said Mr. Khouzam was convicted of murder in absentia. But Mr. Khouzam, a Coptic Christian, has maintained his innocence and has said he was tortured in Egypt because he refused to convert to Islam. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials said the United States had received confidential assurances from Egypt that Mr. Khouzam would not be tortured upon his return. But a federal judge ruled that the government could not rely on secret assurances that could not be independently reviewed to deport Mr. Khouzam. The government was granted a short stay on Mr. Khouzam’s release, which elapsed Tuesday, and it then sought an emergency stay of his release from the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, which was denied on Monday.

A teenager who stabbed his girlfriend’s mother to death was sentenced to 40 years in prison, after he apologized to her family for causing “pain and tears and grief.” The woman, Linda Damm, 52, of Lafayette, was stabbed 18 times in February, and her body lay in her car for nearly a month while her daughter, Tess, and friends used her debit card, the authorities say. Prosecutors say Tess Damm told her boyfriend, Bryan Grove, to kill her mother. Mr. Grove, 18, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in November. He will be eligible for parole after 30 years. Tess Damm, 16, has pleaded not guilty to first-degree murder and is scheduled to go on trial in May.
Doling out credit, but with an eye on the balance sheet.
Instead of focusing on naming rights or pitching the building for political conventions, Peter Luukko’s main job is hiring the right people so the Flyers and Sixers can win championships.
We wish that Ratan Tata would focus his talents on creating transportation that is both affordable and doesn’t emit ever more greenhouse gases.
The chip maker reported revenue of $10.71 billion, up 10.5 percent from the quarter a year earlier, but about $100 million short of analysts’ forecasts.
Bouna Coundoul, a 25-year-old goalkeeper who has spent the past 11 years playing in the United States, is the only M.L.S. player at the African Cup of Nations, which begins Sunday in Ghana.

ALBANY — Even as Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s popularity plunged last fall, a star-studded group of donors that included Ivanka Trump, Christie Brinkley and Edward Norton, as well as wealthy developers, poured thousands of dollars into his campaign account, helping the governor to amass nearly $3 million.
Facing a $200 million operating deficit, the American Red Cross is preparing to cut as much as one-third of its headquarters staff, up to 1,000 employees, and pare regional management.
Todd Demsey’s odyssey back to the caviar circuit known as the PGA Tour has taken 10 years, bouncing along a path much longer and fraught with more peril than he ever imagined.
Keno Davis absorbed the lessons of his father, Tom Davis, well and applied them to the Drake Bulldogs, one of the nation’s most surprising teams.
The economy needs stimulating — on that much, at least, Congressional Democrats agree. But from there, things get complicated.
Despite the F.D.A. endorsement, the Agriculture Department has asked farmers to continue withholding clones from the food supply.
Apple’s Steven P. Jobs introduced an elegant new MacBook, and is betting he can mimic his digital music success with movies.
Figures that the administration cited to demonstrate progress in Iraq cannot be substantiated by Iraqi budget records, the Government Accountability Office reported.
Legal gaps and immunity may prevent Blackwater guards involved in a shooting in Iraq from being tried.
Pay-O-Matic is the subject of a takeover by Founders Equity, a private equity firm in New York, in a deal estimated at more than $500 million.
Declining values of small homes outside Manhattan are pulling down the overall market as the effects of the country’s mortgage trouble take hold, data show.
The 1961 and 1962 Green Bay victories over the Giants in the N.F.L. championship games gave the league much-needed celebrity.
While the economic weakness has been concentrated in the financial services, home building and related sectors, investors are growing fearful that it is spreading.
A contractor involved in Monday’s fatal construction accident in SoHo has a history of safety violations at projects in Manhattan.
Long a symbol of power for American car companies, the V-8 engine is sputtering as Detroit’s Big Three promote smaller engines and alternative-fuel vehicles.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine pocket-vetoed a controversial bill on Tuesday that would have expanded the state’s wrongful-death law and allowed families to sue for pain and suffering. The bill had been supported by trial lawyers and victims’ advocates, who argued that under current law, families cannot recover damages when the death of a child, disabled person or retiree could have been prevented. The bill had been opposed by business interests, including the pharmaceutical industry, which argued that liability insurance and property taxes would escalate as a result. In a statement, Mr. Corzine, above, said that he had allowed the bill to expire without signing it because of his concern about “a significant impact on state and local budgets.”.

In the latest shift in the competition for music fans this summer, the concert promoters behind the popular Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in California will stage a three-day event in Liberty State Park.

One person was killed in a fire at 89-03 91st Avenue in Woodhaven on Tuesday, the police said. The fire, on the second floor of a single-family house, was reported just after 4 p.m., the Fire Department said. Sixty firefighters responded and had the fire under control by 4:36 p.m., the department said. The victim was identified as Stephen Korovich, 51. The police said there was no indication of foul play, and the cause of the fire was under investigation on Tuesday.

Acknowledging that it had made major mistakes that drastically hurt its business, the Tropicana Casino and Resort said on Tuesday that it planned to rehire 150 workers and begin a major advertising campaign to improve its reputation. The casino is struggling to recover from a year in which the former owners, the Kentucky-based Columbia Sussex Corporation, eliminated 900 jobs and alienated customers with poor service and housekeeping. Those problems led the state’s Casino Control Commission to strip Columbia Sussex of its casino license in December, and the state is seeking a buyer for the property, which includes New Jersey’s largest hotel, with 2,129 rooms.
A spat between Garrison Keillor and a next-door neighbor is proving a good deal harder-edged than “The News From Lake Wobegon.”

A professional parachutist who tried to jump off the Empire State Building in 2006 filed a $30 million lawsuit on Tuesday against the Empire State Building Company. The parachutist, Jeb Corliss, 31, accused the building’s agents of defaming his character, unlawfully imprisoning him on the observation deck by shackling him to a fence when he tried to jump and causing him emotional distress and lost income. His lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, was a counterclaim to a $12 million suit filed against him last year by the company. That suit accuses Mr. Corliss of disrupting business, endangering bystanders and being motivated by money. A spokeswoman for the Empire State Building Company declined to comment on Tuesday.

The Village of Mamaroneck has agreed to pay $4.75 million to the Westchester Day School to settle a five-year lawsuit over the school’s attempt to erect a new building on its campus, representatives of the school and the village announced on Monday night. Westchester Day, a 60-year-old Orthodox Jewish school, sued after the village denied its application to add a fifth building to its 25-acre campus. The school will also be able to move forward with the project. In October, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit found that the village had shown “an arbitrary blindness to the facts” when it denied permission for the construction.

The State Assembly and Senate passed legislation on Tuesday authorizing an $8 million bailout of the 2,800-student Roosevelt school system in Nassau County. The legislation provides a one-time state grant of $8 million to the district, the only school system ever placed under state control, to settle a debt that had threatened to create a fiscal crisis. The legislation also doubles the amount of an annual state grant to the district for academic improvement, to $12 million from $6 million. The money will allow the district to raise its per-pupil spending. The legislation will now go to Gov. Eliot Spitzer for approval.
Buffalo Sabres goaltender Ryan Miller girded for a heavier workload this season, and Lindy Ruff, his coach, has had no choice but to take advantage.
Dr. Folkman championed the idea that cancer needs a growing network of blood vessels to survive and that blocking that process, called angiogenesis, would stop or even eliminate tumors.
Citing the N.A.A.C.P.’s dedication to social change, the guild agreed to make an exception for the February awards show.
Patriots Coach Bill Belichick set the tone for the week, delivering a blistering accounting to his players of the Chargers’ strengths in an effort to keep them focused.
The banking giant said it was scaling back its investment banking operations and shedding an additional 650 jobs.
First, hard-pressed Wall Street banks turned to rich foreign governments for help. Now, they are seeking aid from the likes of New Jersey and big mutual funds.
The Titans fired the offensive coordinator Norm Chow on Tuesday after reaching the playoffs for the first time since 2003 despite struggling to score points.
In California, a lawmaker has introduced a bill to create an online database of men and women convicted of domestic violence in that state.
Bitter opponents over the future of the Klamath River unveiled an agreement to pave the way for removal of four dams that re-engineered the watershed but the dams’ owner hasn’t agreed to remove them.
A man who the police believe had been living in his car was arrested on charges that he murdered a young Brooklyn woman who disappeared last spring while on vacation in Florida, the authorities said.
An environmental group says a Coca-Cola bottling plant in the drought-stricken state of Rajasthan is depleting scarce water supplies.
The vote was a setback for two hedge funds, which had hoped to obtain greater influence in the bank’s future and keep it from selling assets at “fire sale prices.”
Lawrence B. Salander, who filed for bankruptcy last year after his gallery was ordered padlocked by a judge, is seeking permission to sell his Upper East Side town house, for up to $25 million.

From the stylish streets of SoHo, where he labored on the rising frame of the newest condo hotel to bear the Trump name, to the modest three-story brick walk-up in Greenpoint where the sounds of his early departure for work served as a virtual alarm clock for his landlady, Yuriy Vanchytskyy was remembered on Tuesday as a reliable, hard-working and cheerful presence.
The mortgage lender IndyMac Bancorp said that it would cut its work force by 24 percent.
The bank’s net income slid to $942 million, or 53 cents a share, from $1.19 billion, or 66 cents a share, in the period a year ago.
LeBron James scored a season-high 51 points to lead the visiting Cleveland Cavaliers to a 132-124 victory over the Memphis Grizzlies.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has chosen the firm of a longtime friend to manage the investments of his multibillion-dollar fortune amid speculation that Mr. Bloomberg is considering a run for president.
A cartoon classic from the 1960s gets a makeover to suit  the tastes of 21st-century kids.
The nation’s retailers wrapped up the weakest sales year since 2002, according to a gloomy report that fanned fears of a recession.
Mr. Morrice shook up traditional British dance sensibilities by championing modern-dance choreographers and mentoring young talent.
Mr. Cohl and two other friends, Henk van der Kolk and Bill Marshall, started what was first called the Festival of Festivals in 1976.
A 52 year-old man was arrested for riding his lawn-mower on a public street while intoxicated.
Reversing its position, Australia’s new Labor government said it would not sell uranium to India unless it signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
The human rights organization called the executions “grotesque and horrific.”
The Italian and Dutch authorities arrested 66 Nigerians accused of smuggling compatriots into Europe to work as prostitutes and drug runners.
Álvaro Colom, a businessman who campaigned for social justice and a significant reduction in poverty, was sworn in for a four-year term.

A federal judge has approved a $6.2 million settlement for black and Hispanic sheet metal workers in a 37-year-old lawsuit against a union that critics have called one of the city’s most notorious for racial discrimination, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission announced on Tuesday.
In its most important securities fraud ruling in years, the Supreme Court placed a huge obstacle before shareholders looking to sue someone after a stock purchase turns sour.

After a five-year battle, the United States government has dropped its effort to prevent a volunteer firefighter killed at the World Trade Center from receiving a death benefit for public safety officers who die on the job.
Becky Saletan, publisher of the trade division of Harcourt, has been named publisher of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Adult Trade Books.
The scandal involving Volkswagen’s former chief executive involves charges of bribery and illicit sex.
While the vehicles have yet to go on sale in the United States, they  stole some thunder from the Big Three at the Detroit Auto Show.
Don Cardwell was a right-handed pitcher who helped propel the Mets to their stunning 1969 World Series championship as he neared the end of a long career.
A month after a Rice University student vanished with his car after withdrawing $500 from a bank machine, school officials disclosed information suggesting the disappearance might have been planned.
CARLSTADT, N.J. — An explosion at a small metal parts factory flung a man 30 feet, killing him and injuring nine others on Tuesday — three critically — according to the authorities here.
All economists know that when American jobs are outsourced, Americans as a group are net winners.
The United States remains the world leader in scientific and technological innovation, but its dominance is threatened by economic development elsewhere, particularly in Asia.

Michael E. Glascoe, the state-appointed superintendent of the Paterson Public Schools, said on Tuesday that he would step down in July because he did not have the “complete trust and support” of New Jersey’s education commissioner, Lucille E. Davy.
Federal officials told state authorities to re-examine roadway bridges to make sure they do not have the newly discovered design flaw that doomed a bridge in Minneapolis.
In  southeast Ohio, thousands of people who long had tough but sustainable lives are being wrenched into the working poor.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,912 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:.
Over the past dozen years, a Queens high school’s most notable architectural accouterment has been the quote-unquote temporary classroom.
Insurgency in the south of the country, a largely Muslim region, has taken almost three thousand lives since it began in 2004.
The company is expected to announce another delay in production of its popular 787 Dreamliner, which could frustrate some international airlines’ expansion plans.
At a critical phase of his career, Mardy Fish needs another big surge soon if he is to make the most of his ball-striking talent and terrific two-handed backhand.
Reporting a fourth-quarter loss of $9.83 billion, Citigroup also issued a forecast that the economy had not yet bottomed out.
Secretary General Ban Ki-moon spoke at the start of an international conference aimed at promoting understanding between Western and Islamic cultures.
Supporters of a third-party presidential bid by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg began a 50-state petition drive on Tuesday seeking to “draft” the mayor.
Almost 85 years after he died, the figure of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk continues to inspire the  millions of Turks who visit his mausoleum every year.

Michael B. Smuck was one of the leading real estate syndicators in New Orleans in the 1980s until his limited partnerships began unraveling, causing large losses and unleashing years of legal battles with unhappy investors.
To the Editor:.
In Ohio, dozens of factories and several coal mines have closed over the last decade, and small businesses are giving way to big-box retailers and fast-food outlets.

The Federal Highway Administration told state authorities to take a new look at bridges to make sure they do not have the kind of design flaw that doomed the I-35W bridge, which collapsed in Minneapolis last summer.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
The sales of more than a million acres of timberland in Northern Michigan have caused many people to worry about their jobs and their ability to hunt and fish.
“Hell at the Library, Eros in Secret,” which opened at the National Library in Paris last month, offers a peek at its secret archive of erotic art.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.

The archives of Cormac McCarthy, below, the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist, have been bought for $2 million by the Southwestern Writers Collection of Texas State University-San Marcos, The Associated Press reported. The university said the archives included correspondence, notes, drafts and proofs of 11 novels by Mr. McCarthy, 74, who won the Pulitzer for his 2006 novel, “The Road,” and a 1992 National Book Award for “All the Pretty Horses.”.

All the stars will be back again when “High School Musical” makes the jump from the Disney Channel to the big screen, Reuters reported. Zac Efron, Vanessa Hudgens, Ashley Tisdale, Lucas Grabeel, Corbin Bleu and Monique Coleman, seen in the hit “High School Musical” (2006) and its sequel, are confirmed to reprise their roles in the movie, “High School Musical 3: Senior Year,” when Troy (Mr. Efron) and Gabriella (Ms. Hudgens) face separation as they go off to college. Once again, Kenny Ortega will direct. The film is to be released in October.
Some voice their dissent as cafeterias in Washington go green.
Oprah Winfrey and Discovery Communications said on Tuesday that they would jointly create OWN, the Oprah Winfrey Network, a cable television channel to make its debut in 2009.

Facing some strong competition in prime time on Monday, NBC’s “Deal or No Deal” and “American Gladiators” managed to rank No. 1 and No. 2 in the night’s ratings. Nielsen estimated that “Deal or No Deal” delivered the largest audience overall, 15 million viewers at 9 p.m., while “American Gladiators” at 8 drew a less impressive 10.7 million viewers. Among adults 18 to 49, however, the two shows outpaced all other programming on the night, including Fox’s “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” at 9 p.m. That show, which made its premiere on Sunday to 18.4 million viewers, declined in the ratings substantially with its second showing, attracting just 10.1 million while matching the 10 p.m. leader, CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (14.7 million), for the third highest ratings on the night among the 18-to-49 set. Fox ranked second for the night in that demographic but third in total viewers behind both NBC and CBS, which broadcast repeats of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10. ABC was fourth over all, faring better earlier in the night with “Dance War” from 8 to 9:30 (10.5 million) but struggling later on with “Notes From the Underbelly” at 9:30 (4.8 million) and “October Road” at 10 (4.9 million).

Will Schwalbe is stepping down as editor in chief of Hyperion Books on Jan. 25 to pursue an unspecified Internet-related project. Mr. Schwalbe, who was at Hyperion for 11 years — seven of them as editor in chief — is also the author, with David Shipley, deputy editorial page editor at The New York Times, of “Send: The Essential Guide to Email for Office and Home.” “I’m really just incredibly excited by what is out there in new media,” Mr. Schwalbe said. “I’ve had some thoughts that I want to test and see if I can put them into practice.” Mr. Schwalbe’s shepherded authors included David Halberstam; Chris Anderson, the editor of Wired magazine; and the chef Jamie Oliver.

Card-catalog classifications hardly seem the subject of trans-Atlantic imbroglios, but the Library of Congress recently settled one when it agreed to reinstate a past policy of classifying works by Scottish authors under the heading “Scottish literature.” Early last year the library started classifying about 600 titles by Scottish writers as “English literature,” with subheadings like “Scottish authors” or “Scottish poets.” That offended the National Library of Scotland, which complained, enlisting the support of an American congressman, Mike McIntyre, Democrat of North Carolina. Early this month, the librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, wrote to the National Library of Scotland and the British Library, informing them that the Scots would get their own catalog distinction. As of now the Library of Congress is still classifying the works of Irish and Welsh writers under subcategories of English literature, but a spokesman, Matt Raymond, said the library has yet to receive any complaints.

The pianist and conductor Daniel Barenboim has won the Royal Philharmonic Society Gold Medal for outstanding musicianship. Mr. Barenboim will receive the medal at Royal Festival Hall in London on Jan. 28. ... Zaha Hadid Architects of London has been named the winner of the design competition for the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum at Michigan State University in East Lansing. ... From the estate of the hotelier Leona Helmsley, Impressionist and modern art, Old Master Paintings, Russian art, Chinese art and furniture and silver will be auctioned in 15 sales beginning on Thursday at Christie’s New York in Rockefeller Center. Net proceeds are to benefit the Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust. ... The Lebanese singer Mika, the boy band Take That and the reality television star Leona Lewis led the way with four nominations each when the shortlist for the Brit Awards, Britain’s version of the Grammys, was announced on Monday.

The right of Britney Spears to visit her two little boys remained suspended under a ruling issued at a closed-door hearing by the Superior Court commissioner, Scott Gordon, on Monday in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. Neither Ms. Spears, 26, nor her former husband Kevin Federline, 29, was required to attend. He did; she came late to the courthouse but never went inside. He retains custody of the boys, Sean Preston, 2, and Jayden James, 1. Another hearing is scheduled for Feb. 19.

The University of Heidelberg in Germany says it has identified the woman in Leonardo’s “Mona Lisa” (detail below), The Associated Press reported. She is Lisa del Giocondo, wife of Francesco del Giocondo, a Florentine businessman. In a statement on Monday, the college said its library expert, Armin Schlechter, found the answer in a copy of the works of Cicero, where, in 1503, Agostino Vespucci, a Florentine official and friend of Leonardo’s, wrote in the margins that the artist was working on a portrait of Lisa del Giocondo. Surprise? For centuries the Mona Lisa has been known in Italian as La Gioconda. Though anecdotal evidence pointed to Giocondo as early as 1550, vague references in 1517, 1525 and 1540 pointed to others.

“Shine a Light,” the Rolling Stones concert documentary by Martin Scorsese, right, will open the 58th Berlin International Film Festival on Feb. 7. Mr. Scorsese and the Stones will be in attendance, Paramount Pictures announced. The film, derived from more than half a million feet of concert footage, captures the band in two concerts at the Beacon Theater in New York, on Oct. 29 and Nov. 1, 2006, when guest performances were delivered by Christina Aguilera, Buddy Guy and Jack White of the White Stripes. The film will be released in North America by Paramount Classics on April 4.
Tens of thousands of notes hurtled by during the Mars Volta’s nearly nonstop two-and-a-half-hour set at Terminal 5 on Monday night.
What sets Chateau Mcely apart from other restored castle-cum-hotels and private residences are some features that few people ever see.
Several new Broadway-related Web sites have arrived with the potential and purpose of bridging the gap between the obsessed and the genuinely interested.
Since Jeffrey Richards debuted as a Broadway producer in 2000, he has been remarkably successful, particularly in the last couple of years.
Pope Benedict XVI has canceled a speech at the prestigious La Sapienza University in Rome amid opposition by professors and students who say he is hostile to science.
How far will chefs go to display their empathy and respect for the animals they cook? All the way, it seems, to the barnyard and the slaughterhouse.

To the Editor:.
Women who own small businesses have been pushing for years for a bigger piece of government contracts. And few are happy with the new rules created by the Small Business Administration.
The Culture Ministry has quietly banned the import of the film based on the best-selling novel about childhood betrayal, ethnic tension and sexual predation in Afghanistan.
Jean-Claude Vrinat was no ordinary restaurateur. Not only did he own perhaps the finest restaurant in Paris, but he also was a wine expert of long standing.
The United States is still the world leader in scientific innovation, but its dominance is threatened by economic development elsewhere, the National Science Board reported today.
Frustrated with the standard tools of his trade, a self-styled “rogue sociologist” befriended a gang leader and began a curious insider-outsider life at a notorious Chicago housing project.
The Thirsty Farm.
A researcher has traced the origins of fortune cookies to shops near Kyoto, Japan.
Listeners could forget about thematic unity at Radu Lupu’s Carnegie Hall recital on Monday night.

Because of an editing error, a calendar listing last Wednesday about a class on American whiskey followed by a dinner with whiskey cocktails at the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., misstated the date. It will be held Thursday; it did not take place last Thursday.
For a simple dish, pasta all’amatriciana is freighted with controversy.
Chop Suey, a pan-Asian restaurant, opens this week in Times Square. Also, Magnolia Bakery opens a branch on Columbus Avenue.
Gunmen assassinated three police commanders, along with the wife and two daughters of one of them, in Tijuana. The killings came after police arrested 11 people on organized-crime charges.
A bomb evidently meant to destroy an American Embassy car narrowly missed, but wounded its local Lebanese driver and a fellow passenger and killed at least three civilians.
Opposition leaders on Tuesday won their first political skirmish since Kenya’s disputed presidential election, garnering the most votes for the influential position of parliamentary speaker.
The four-day visit by Admiral Timothy Keating, head of the U.S. Pacific Command, followed a diplomatic spat last year.
During a surprise visit to Iraq, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice praised Iraqi leaders for approving a controversial new de-Baathification law.
The violence came a day after Israeli negotiators and their Palestinian counterparts started peace talks.
Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India described Tuesday an ascendant Asia in which India and China had a special opportunity to overcome historic hostilities.
Officials in Afghanistan said that three Americans and one French woman may have been among the six killed.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice visited Baghdad hoping to build momentum behind reconciliation efforts.
A variation of my friend Gary Danko’s pancake recipe, using 100 percent whole-grain flour.
Saudi Arabia’s oil minister appeared to rebuff the president’s appeal to consider the cost to the U.S. economy.
For some, the very strength of Senator Barack Obama’s campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination has dragged the thought of violence out of the shadows of the unspeakable.
For one woman who couldn’t throw anything out, her apartment became an archaeological study of a life in decline.
The details of the economic slump have changed since the ’92 presidential race, but the main story line remains much the same.
Tuesday felt like spring training in that it was a warm up for the real thing, coming Feb. 13, when Roger Clemens and other members of the Syringe Generation report to Camp Oversight.
A Colonial cottage in Newport, R.I.; a three-bedroom three-bath log-style home in Livonia Township, Minn.; and a two-bedroom two-bath condo in Park City, Utah.
The emergence of the economy as a prime voter concern played neatly into Mitt Romney’s strengths as a candidate and his retooled message.
Mitt Romney’s victory in Michigan means that three very different states have embraced three candidates.
The number of players making attention deficit disorder claims that let them use drugs like Ritalin has spiked.
Steven P. Jobs is rebooting Apple’s digital movie effort and putting the company squarely in the middle of an intensifying industry battle.
Bud Selig, the commissioner of baseball, promised Tuesday to impose “very serious discipline” on club officials who failed to act on evidence of illegal steroid use.
The House committee conducting hearings on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball wants to probe statements the shortstop made in 2005.
The cheap-chic designer is leaving the retailer for a more ambitious, and lucrative, role of making over the struggling Liz Claiborne label.
Producers said that the musical phenomenon, one of the longest-running shows on Broadway, will end on June 1.
A recipe for Seared Pork Chops with Kimchi.
A recipe for Whole-Grain Pancakes.

Some Greenmarket farmers are finding ways to offer new items, even in midwinter. Knoll Krest Farm in Clinton Corners, N.Y., known for its eggs, is using them to make fresh fettuccine. Plain pasta is $3 for 10 ounces, beet flavor is $4; other seasonal flavors, such as carrot, will be offered weekly. The farm has also introduced pumpkin and cheese ravioli. Knoll Krest is at Union Square on Wednesdays and Saturdays, Inwood on Saturdays and Broadway at 115th Street on Sundays.

An obituary on Nov. 2 about Col. Aleksandr Feklisov, a Soviet spy, misspelled the surname of the Soviet prime minister for whom Mr. Feklisov handled security for a 1959 visit to the United States. He was Nikita Khrushchev, not Krushchev. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message last week.

The major league pitcher Joe Kennedy, 28, had a condition that caused his heart to suddenly stop beating at his in-laws' home in November, when he collapsed and later died. A final report on Kennedy's Nov. 23 death has not been issued. But an autopsy found he had hypertensive heart disease, a condition that hardens the heart's walls and can cause it to stop beating, said Dr. Vernard Adams, the Hillsborough County medical examiner.Adams said Kennedy also had myxoid valvular disease, a condition that affects the way blood flows through a valve that separates the upper and lower chambers on the heart's left side. Both conditions can lead to a higher risk of cardiac arrest.

HUGE LOSS AT CITIGROUP Citigroup, the nation's largest bank, reported a staggering fourth-quarter loss of $9.83 billion and forecast that the housing market and the broader economy still had not bottomed out. DIFFERING GOALS As the Federal Reserve seems ready to lower interest rates once again in an attempt to give the economy a boost, Citigroup and many other banks are going in the opposite direction, seeking to reduce losses by raising rates on credit cards and restricting the amount of credit they extend. FRAZIER--Suzanne Gold man, 57, beloved wife of Jack Frazier, cherished daughter of Enid and George Goldman, died peacefully in Theodosia, Missouri, on January 7th, having gallantly fought cancer for seven years. She is survived by two dear aunts, Natalie Berger and Bonnie Robinson, 16 first cousins, 15 second cousins, a numerous extended family, and a large devoted circle of friends. A graduate of Hofstra University, she spent two years in France as an exchange student. She also graduated from the Gemological Institute of America in New York City. She was a friend to every living creature, an avid organic gardener, both professionally and personally, delighting in sharing her love of flowers. Her engaging eyes, bright smile and funloving personality endeared her to all. She was a great reader, a talented seamstress and an intense humanist. She will be forever in our hearts. Memorial donations may be made to Riverways Hospice, 114 E. Main St., West Plains, Missouri 65775.

CYPHER--Stanley J., 89, in Hanover, NH, on January 7. Born Ossining, NY, attended Brooklyn Tech (1936), Wesleyan University (1941) and NYU. Organizers of the American bid for the 2016 Summer Olympics unveiled details of their plan Tuesday, promising a ''spectacular'' lakefront experience in the heart of Chicago. The plan clusters the majority of sites in four areas near downtown and along the shore of Lake Michigan. Ninety-one percent of athletes would be within 15 minutes or less of their competitions, and the Olympic stadium would be a six-minute drive from the village.Details of the plan -- which includes 16 new permanent and temporary sites and money to upgrade existing sites to Olympic standards at an estimated cost of $900 million -- were included in a plan submitted to the International Olympic Committee and released by Chicago bid organizers.

President Bush urged the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries on Tuesday to take into account the toll that high oil prices are having on the American economy, gingerly touching on an issue that has begun to color the last year of his presidency and dominate the presidential election campaign. HARRIS--Henry U., Jr. The Board of Trustees medical staff, administration and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our heartfelt sympathy at the passing of Henry U. GUTMAN--Robert, of Princeton, NJ, 81, on November 23, 2007. Influential architecture professor and critic. Educated at Columbia, then taught at Dartmouth before moving to Rutgers sociology department in 1957. Joined Princeton architecture faculty in 1969. Retired from Rutgers in 1996. Still teaching at Princeton at the time of his death. With great curiosity, he explored relationships among architects, buildings, users, and public policy. A generous scholar, collaborator, and mentor, he brought social science into the heart of architectural education and practice. He maintained the demeanor of both student and professor, with an inquisitiveness matched only by his challenges to prevailing assumptions. Among his published work was Architectural Practice: A Critical View (1988). Husband of the late Sonya Rudikoff, writer and literary critic. Leaves son John, daughter Elizabeth, and three grandchildren. Memorial service Saturday, January 19 at 3 pm at Princeton University Chapel. Donations in his memory can be made to Society of Architectural Historians, Chicago, IL or Princeton Friends Meeting, Princeton, NJ.

Buffalo Coach Turner Gill received a contract extension on Tuesday that could keep him with the Bulls through 2012. Gill, who was a candidate for the Nebraska head-coaching position in December before the Cornhuskers chose Bo Pelini, was entering the third year of his original five-year deal, which paid him about $190,000 a season, before bonuses. In two years, Gill has turned around one of the worst programs in the country. The Bulls finished 5-7 in 2007 -- including a school-record 5-3 Mid-American Conference mark -- the most victories they have had since moving up to Division I-A in 1999. They had won only 12 games over all since 1999.

The Chilean government gave its support Tuesday for a bid by sports and tourism officials to stage the Dakar Rally in 2009. The rally, a grueling endurance race that was canceled because of terrorist threats along the route across the Sahara, had been run annually in Africa since 1979. If taken to Chile, the race would go through the northern Atacama Desert, the world's driest, where a local rally called Patagonia-Atacama is held yearly.
Another year, another high-powered gathering in Davos, Switzerland.

In a case that has exposed the division between owners and drivers in the pedicab industry, a state judge in Manhattan has struck down the system the city planned to use to distribute 325 licenses to operate the human-powered vehicles. The city said that it planned to appeal the decision. The legal dispute is another wrinkle in the city’s long-standing effort to regulate the pedicab industry for the first time.

Giuliani has plummeted from first to fourth — or worse — in some national polls, as he finished near the bottom of the pack in the nation’s earliest primaries, and as his lead evaporated even in Florida, the state on which he has gambled the most time and money, those Republican leaders are verging toward a grim new consensus: If Mr. Giuliani loses in the Florida primary on Jan. 29, they say, he may even have trouble defeating the rivals who are encroaching on his own backyard.” (See .)Mayor’s State of the City Today

The League of Women Voters of the City of New York, which was founded on June 2, 1919, as an outgrowth of the women’s suffrage movement and was the first of what are now 900 state and local leagues across the United States, is about to lose its office on East 33rd Street, its home since 1999, because the building has been sold to a developer and will be torn down to make way for a hotel.

Prosecutors in Queens are arguing against moving the trial of three detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell, according to in a new court filing [pdf] this morning that challenges the defense team’s claims that pretrial publicity has swayed the favor of potential jurors against the detectives. The defense is seeking to move the trial of the officers out of New York City.In the filing, in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, which includes Queens courts, the office of District Attorney Richard A. Brown discounted the results of a public opinion poll conducted by the defense by presenting its own polling statistics that showed that only 35.5 percent of potential jurors “report having formed an opinion about this case.”

Updated, 5:10 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used his seventh State of the City address this afternoon to make a wide-ranging array of major proposals for his final two years in office, while warning that spending cuts will be needed because “the economy appears headed for difficult times.”

Updated, 3:16 p.m. | In another sign that local governments are growing impatient with Washington’s timid approach to resolving environmental problems, New York City and three states today joined environmental advocacy groups in suing the Bush administration over new standards for gas-fired furnaces and other home heating appliances. The city’s Law Department, along with the states of Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York, argue that the new efficiency standards set by the federal Department of Energy last November are far too weak to significantly cut carbon dioxide emissions, or to help lower home heating costs that have hit people in the Northeast especially hard.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used his State of the City address to unveil two new education proposals aimed at two groups of students who continue to struggle: eighth graders who are unprepared for high school, and high school students who are unprepared for the working world.The mayor, who has staked his legacy largely on his effort to overhaul the public school system, said that students in the third, fifth and seventh grade “rose to the challenge” after being faced with new promotion policies based largely on test scores. Mr. Bloomberg said he would now extend that promotion policy to the eighth grade.

Nothing is more self-defeating in presidential politics than a candidate trying to be something he or she is not. Sometimes the incongruity is visual - Mike Dukakis photographed riding atop a tank - but more often it concerns a policy stand or a position that seems opportunistic and inauthentic. In such instances, the departure from form may produce some short-term political gain, but in the long run, it leaves voters confused and alienated.

This week's guest blogger is the Milan-based artist and satirist Francesco Vezzoli. Over the past decade, the diva-and-Prada-obsessed Vezzoli, 36, has at once defiled and genuflected at the altar of celebrity. His campy oeuvre includes everything from needlework portraits of Maria Callas and Anna Magnani to films like "Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidal's Caligula," starring Helen Mirren and Courtney Love, and live performances like Pirandello's "Right You Are (If You Think You Are)," starring - among others - Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Abigail Breslin, which he produced at the Guggenheim last October as part of the Performa 07 series. In his fourth post of the week he writes about the actress Anita Ekberg. To read all of Francesco Vezzoli's prior blog posts, click here.

One assumption in Ben Bernanke's testimony today was that if a recession happens, it will be over soon, so stimulus has to come fast or not at all. It's by no means clear that this is right. To be fair, I think it's right to caution Congress not to do anything now that won't come in quickly. But both recent history and the nature of our current problem suggest that we may be in for more than a few bad months.

I saw Donatella Versace on Italian television once when she was asked about her vision. With extravagant gestures, she cried, "Lusso, lusso, lusso!" ("luxury, luxury, luxury"), throwing her hands in the air as if seeding a catwalk with bits of cubic zirconia. Versace's perfume licensee, EuroItalia, has faultlessly translated her taste into scent using some of the biggest creative names in the business - Bertrand Duchaufour, Françoise Caron, Francis Kurkdjian, among others; these are some of the best perfumers working and authors in other contexts of very serious olfactory work. Donatella is a master of synthetic luxe, and her perfumes - in particular Bright Crystal and Crystal Noir - are paradigms of the school. Versace Eau de Parfum, however, takes the aesthetic to a new level.
