In theory, it should go like this: the more candidates withdraw from the nomination fights in both parties, the cozier and more manageable the debates become, and the better and more illuminating the exchanges. As the debates since New Hampshire have proved, though, the reality doesn't bear this out. The problem is that by this point in a campaign, the candidates have spent so many thousands of hours hammering away at the same points over and over again that they're practically on autopilot. There are a few sharp comments, a laugh here or there, but mostly the debates devolve into a familiar and unsatisfying contest of wills: moderators try to think up unexpected questions that might force the candidates to speak extemporaneously, while each candidate looks for a way, no matter how tortured, to turn every question into a recital of the same lines we heard in the last 400 debates.

It's never easy to capture the energy and dynamism of fashion on film, but the Yves Saint Laurent designer Stefano Pilati proved that it can be done. Working in tandem with the up-and-coming actor Simon Woods and Colonel Blimp, a peculiarly named team of video artists from London, Pilati traded the runway for a short video installation Wednesday night that had enough verve and style to keep even the most jaded moviegoers interested. Woods acted out - in one scene, smashing through a glass wall - wearing shiny David-Bowie-in-"The-Man-Who-Fell-to-Earth" blousons; rich jewel-toned "Velvet Goldmine" dinner jackets; a woolly lamb overcoat that can go directly from an art opening to the Himalayas; and '70s-inspired suits with cuffed wide-leg trousers. If '50s Americana is more your speed, check out the chunky brothel creepers or the pale yellow sports jacket worn over a baby blue turtleneck. (Trust us, if it worked for Bob Hope, it can work for you.) Pilati neatly tied up the assortment of references with his usual attention to dandyish detail: a silk foulard here, a bit of punkish eye makeup there, and colorfully printed pocket squares just about everywhere.

An article on Wednesday about a bomb that exploded next to an American Embassy vehicle in Beirut misstated the history of attacks on American interests in Lebanon. The attack was not the first one targeted at Americans since the 1983 truck bombing that killed 241 American service members at the United States Marine barracks in Beirut. There have been other attacks since on American interests and on Americans in Lebanon.

A report in the On Baseball column on Sunday about the fluid nature of voting for Hall of Fame candidates who remain on the ballot year after year misstated the number of votes that Jim Rice lacked for induction. It was 16, not 42. (A candidate must be named on 75 percent of all ballots to make the Hall of Fame.).

An article in The Arts last Thursday about Overture Films misstated the amount of its financing and bank loans. It has $325 million in financing, not $225 million, and its bank loans total $225 million, not $125 million. The article also misidentified the writer of “Mad Money,” an Overture film that is to open on Friday. The screenwriter was Glenn Gers — not Callie Khouri, who directed the film.

Islam A. Karimov, Uzbekistan’s authoritarian leader, was sworn in for a third seven-year presidential term despite a constitutional two-term limit.
Jonathan Motzfeldt, one of the country’s foremost politicians, resigned amid allegations that he groped a female civil servant.
The government said it had started deporting some of the country’s two million illegal immigrants.
A species of self-destructing palm trees that flower once every 100 years and then die has been discovered in Madagascar.
The governor’s $1 billion plan includes $350 million to promote business development by preparing development-ready sites and industrial parks, and related programs.
Why it took five years for the federal government to conclude that Glenn J. Winuk was, in fact, a first responder is one of those mysteries of the bureaucratic world.
John McCain is deploying a South Carolina Truth Squad to intercept attacks.
The last thing Americans need is a loony debate over whether it is more important to choose the first woman or the first African-American nominee for president.
The Republican contenders jockeyed for advantage across the state, as the outcome in South Carolina will most likely bear heavily on Florida’s primary.
With the new World Trade Center rising clamorously around it, the last standing vestige of the old World Trade Center is about to be uprooted.
As Rudolph W. Giuliani plummets in some polls, his rivals are encroaching on his own backyard.
Even if New York’s method of selecting judges is constitutional, it remains unfair and undemocratic. It needs to be replaced.
Once a member of the Packers, Dave Tollefson, a defensive end for the Giants,  will return to Green Bay and play for the National Football Conference championship on Sunday.
The former C.I.A. official who authorized destruction of videotapes of harsh interrogation of terrorism suspects had apparently been directed to save them.
Plug and play — a popular concept that allows buyers of computers and electronic games to avoid frustrating assembly — is proving hard to pull off for Boeing.
People who new Packers running back Ryan Grant when he coached high school football in North Arlington, N.J. now marvel at the improbability of his rise.
America’s interests demand that President Bush’s successor has maximum flexibility to plot a course regarding the war in Iraq.
Interior Secretary Dirk Kempthorne’s reasoning to deny permission to Indian tribes requesting more land in order to build casinos is sound.
Self-taught with a 10-finger baseball grip, Tommy Gainey hit his first golf ball at 15. Now he’s trying to make a name for himself on the PGA Tour.
Hillary Rodham Clinton is searching for the right personality to help her connect with voters while also emphasizing her competence and experience.
City officials have been trying to create more places where New Yorkers can ride their bikes safely, but finding secure places to park them remains an enduring problem.
In the trial of the man accused of murdering Nixzmary Brown, the defense lawyer portrayed the girl as someone who terrorized her siblings and refused to be disciplined.
The House on Wednesday approved a sweeping $696 billion military policy measure after revising a single provision in the 1,300-page bill that had prompted a surprise veto by President Bush.
Leaders of two key Olympic antidoping agencies rebuked Major League Baseball for its response to recommendations by George J. Mitchell on drug testing.
The Apollo Group Inc., the company that owns the University of Phoenix, fraudulently misled investors in 2004 about student recruitment policies.
There are already signs of nasty and false attacks as the presidential campaigns descend on the state.
The White House has acknowledged recycling its backup computer tapes of e-mail before October 2003 including those pertaining to the C.I.A. leak case.
Following results of recent clinical trials on popular cholesterol drugs, cardiologists are questioning whether a patient’s cholesterol should be all that matters.

It is a testament to the decline in party relations in the House that a simple private meeting Wednesday between Democratic and Republican leaders to discuss an economic stimulus plan was treated as remarkable.
In the first ruling of its kind for responsibility in maritime pollution, the oil company Total was fined almost $300 million in damages.
The United Negro College Fund’s slogan remains a powerful ad message 35 years after its debut. The group’s name, however, has become a source of alienation.
If your finger is tired of turning the wheel in the middle of a computer mouse to roll through a page, press down on the scroll-wheel button.
Every time I put a blank CD into my Mac, iTunes pops up, even if I just want to burn photos to the disc. How can I burn the pictures?
How much information from my Facebook profile can random people find out about me with a regular Web search?
Oracle has finally won its prize, the rival BEA Systems, after sweetening the offer by 14 percent, just three months after BEA rejected its original bid.
Federal prosecutors plan to introduce into evidence at least 29 recorded phone calls in the trial of retired General Re executives.
Despite not being able to practice Wednesday, Philip Rivers said he remained confident that he would be in the lineup Sunday when the Chargers play the Patriots.
Three weeks ago, Eli Manning’s unpredictable play was the biggest threat to the Giants’ championship hopes. But since then he appears to have become a different player.
A lawsuit involving the president, the treasurer and the former controller has opened for public viewing an internecine battle that has the usually staid league in an uproar.
Squeezed by rising costs and sharply falling revenues, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg intends to cut spending rather than raise taxes to balance the city budget next year.
The United States Supreme Court overturned a ruling that had found the system for choosing nominees unconstitutional.
Researchers have reported that a simple DNA test can help predict a man’s risk of getting prostate cancer.
Berkley Books, an imprint of Penguin Group USA, was scheduled to publish Jose Canseco’s second book on opening day this spring but withdrew from the project Tuesday.
Mr. Wolff was the last commander of the American volunteers who fought against Franco in the Spanish Civil War.
New York City’s Off-Track Betting Corporation unveiled a contingency plan to close its entire operation by summer, which would come with more than 1,500 layoffs.
A talk by Steven W. Running, a Nobel laureate and climate researcher, was canceled in Choteau, Mont., a small farming and ranching town.
Inflation crept up in December, but the rise in prices will likely do little to hold back another interest rate cut this month.
An attack on a 52-year-old white lawyer by six black teenagers has raised concerns about safety, race and integration in Shaker Heights, Ohio.

A federal judge has approved the State Board of Election’s latest plan for bringing New York into compliance with federal voting laws. New York is years behind federal deadlines to comply with the Help America Vote Act, which was enacted after the contested 2000 presidential elections to ensure better vote-counting accuracy and access for the disabled. On Wednesday, Judge Gary L. Sharpe of Federal District Court gave the state permission to follow through on plans to come into compliance. If the state meets the agreed-upon timeline, voting machines accessible to the disabled will be available in every polling place around the state by November’s elections. The state would then replace all pull-lever machines with high-tech machines by the fall 2009 elections.

State utility regulators said on Wednesday that Consolidated Edison had probably not managed its underground steam system properly before an explosion last summer. After reviewing utility consultant reports on the July 18 accident, in which a pressure buildup ruptured a pipe near Grand Central Terminal, the State Public Service Commission said the company “was, or should have been, aware of unsafe conditions,” particularly at that location. One woman died of a heart attack while running from the area, and two other people were seriously hurt. The commission told Con Ed that if it did not prove within 10 days that adequate system surveillance and response procedures were in place before the explosion, that the regulators will start an investigation that could ultimately bar the company from passing the repair costs on to consumers.

City investigators are examining whether officials at Stuyvesant High School followed proper procedures in the planning and aftermath of a trip to a New Hampshire sporting event that left at least one student with serious injuries. The Associated Press reported that on Saturday, a van carrying members of Stuyvesant’s girls’ track team and driven by the team’s coach overturned, leaving one student paralyzed. Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for the New York City school system, said on Wednesday that Stuyvesant’s principal, Stanley Teitel, had notified him of the accident that afternoon. Mr. Condon said he was “looking at the issue of whether there was school permission” for the trip, as well as “at the delay in reporting it to us.” Mr. Teitel did not return a telephone call seeking comment.

The Apollo Theater in Harlem is scheduled to close in January 2010 for a major expansion, which is scheduled to last nine months. After a bruising conflict that began in the late 1990s — in which a lawsuit against the Apollo by the state attorney general was narrowly averted — a new management team was installed in June 2003. The new leadership has successfully completed renovation of the lobby, the seats, the facade and the famous Apollo sign in front. The addition will add 4,000 square feet of usable space by moving offices elsewhere. Officials also plan a “Walk of Fame” out front. About $51.5 million of the needed $96 million has been raised, and public appeals are planned for the rest.

The region’s public transit agencies are drawing up contingency plans in case Amtrak workers strike in two weeks, which would force commuters in New Jersey and on Long Island to find other ways to get into Manhattan. Amtrak controls Pennsylvania Station, the Manhattan terminus for New Jersey Transit and Long Island Rail Road trains. Amtrak and unions representing about 7,500 workers have been in talks for eight years; on Jan. 4 a presidential panel recommended that the railroad pay $62 million in back wages. If the sides fail to agree by month’s end and Congress does not intervene, workers could strike.

A Queens man has been charged with illegally practicing medicine and endangering the life of a patient by injecting a substance that disfigured the man’s face. William Ramirez-Concepcion is accused of administering injections in January 2006 to a 46-year-old Manhattan man to correct the sunken appearance of his face, prosecutors said. They said the patient suffered pain, swelling, redness and lumps under his skin, and required operations to correct the condition.

Bausch & Lomb, DuPont, Eastman Kodak and Xerox are among eight private and public entities that will reimburse New York State nearly $1.6 million for cleaning up their hazardous waste, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, above, said on Wednesday. The state filed a lawsuit in 2005 after having to pay to clean up the Rochester Fire Academy, a hazardous waste site where the six companies, along with the University of Rochester and Monroe County, disposed of hazardous waste between 1954 and 1980. David Cook, a lawyer for the various entities, criticized Mr. Cuomo’s portrayal of them as polluters. The Rochester Fire Academy was opened in 1954 to train firefighters in handling a range of hazards. During its operation, the companies, university and county sent solvents, petroleum products and other substances to the site for training exercises.
Ward Melville High School in East Setauket on Long Island led the nation in semifinalists in the country’s most prestigious high school science competition.

The March of Dimes, one of the nation’s oldest nonprofit groups, is changing the name of Walk America, its biggest fund-raising event, to March for Babies as part of an effort to increase public awareness of its mission.
Mark D. Siljander, a former Republican congressman from Michigan, was indicted Wednesday on federal charges of money laundering and obstruction of justice.
Since August 2006, a team has spent countless hours getting the nearly 80-year-old clocks atop the former Williamsburgh Savings Bank in working order.
The Defense Secretary said that international troops in the south of Afghanistan, including Dutch military, were not properly trained to fight an insurgency.
After two other car bombings in Algiers in April, the United Nations asked Algeria to close off the street in front of their building in the country’s capital, but authorities never responded.
European regulators raided some of the Continent’s biggest drug makers in an inquiry over whether patent disputes and lawsuits are keeping generic products off the market.
Randy Moss, whose record-setting season seemed to indicate that he had put his troubled past behind him, has been accused by a woman of “battery causing serious injury.”
The attack raised the fear that foreigners could become targets, as the country struggles with political turmoil and assassinations.
Brocade Communications Systems’ former chief executive  received a 21-month prison sentence for designing a plan to tamper with the firm’s records of stock option grants.

The Federal-Mogul Corporation, the auto parts supplier that emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy last month, named the billionaire investor and shareholder Carl C. Icahn as nonexecutive chairman on Wednesday.
The resignation of Suzanne Rich Folsom is another blow to the already shaken organization, six months after its new president took office.
The French president signed deals in the United Arab Emirates to create a French military base there, as part of a strategy to project power in the region.
Wall Street staggered through another volatile session Wednesday, giving up gains of a modest rally in the last minutes of trading.
The makers of some antidepressants never published the results of about a third of the drug trials that they conducted to win government approval, a new study suggests.
If a friend’s digital music collection leaves you with playlist envy, instant gratification is one step closer.
AMR, the parent of American Airlines, posted a smaller-than-expected fourth-quarter loss on Wednesday, but the results showed the industry’s continuing vulnerability to high fuel costs.
Michael A. Callen will succeed Robert J. Genader as chief executive of the Ambac Financial Group, after the bond insurer cut its dividend 67 percent.

The Charles Schwab Corporation, the retail brokerage firm, said Wednesday that fourth-quarter profit fell 34 percent from the period a year ago, which included a tax gain and earnings from its U.S. Trust wealth management unit, which has since been sold.
Under a draft of the law, Volkswagen could make major  changes only with approval of shareholders representing one share more than 80 percent of its share capital.
Uruguayan scientists have uncovered fossil evidence of the biggest species of rodent ever found, more than eight feet long and weighing between 1,700 and 3,000 pounds.
Sun Microsystems, the large U.S. seller of open-source software, said it would buy MySQL, the world leader in open-source database software, for $1 billion.

Brad Renfro was a former child star who played a witness to a mob lawyer’s suicide in the 1994 legal thriller “The Client” and a suburban youth tutored in evil by an elderly Nazi war criminal in the 1998 film “Apt Pupil”.
Pete Candoli was a jazz trumpeter who made his mark as a high-note specialist in the big-band era and went on to become one of the busiest studio musicians in Hollywood.
Harvey Birdman may not be a bad game. Perhaps instead it is a surreal postmodernist dissection of gaming constructs.
The Fed chairman has said that he would back tax cuts or spending measures, so long as they are temporary.
A former Republican congressman from Michigan was indicted Wednesday on federal charges of money laundering and obstruction of justice.
Joe Ames was the deep-voiced anchor and eldest member of the 1950s singing group the Ames Brothers.
Bank officials said that the resignation of Suzanne Rich Folsom, Paul D. Wolfowitz’s top deputy in his anticorruption campaign, was stirring new bitterness.
As TVs grow larger, there is a concurrent trend in consumer electronics to shrink the screen and bring it closer to the viewer — within inches of the eyeball itself.
Pinnacle Video Transfer lets you record analog video directly onto an iPod or Sony PlayStation Portable device.
The new Vudu XL packs a terabyte of storage space under its stylish black hood — enough to store hundreds of digitized movies right on the TV altar.
The federal government released $450 million in emergency funds to provide relief to low-income homeowners struggling with rising costs of heating their homes.
The Garmin Forerunner 405 is a G.P.S.-enabled watch with an abundance of training features to keep runners and bikers motivated.

Three former agents of the New York office of the Drug Enforcement Administration filed a defamation lawsuit against NBC Universal studios, claiming the movie “American Gangster” libeled D.E.A. agents.
The Gen-X Game Console System, which looks like a cross between a sandwich maker and an old-fashioned answering machine, is here to give new life to the games of decades past.
John McCain is more likely than any of his rivals to offer conservatives what they want.

The hearts of highly trained, competitive athletes are different from yours and mine. They’re bigger, pump slower, and often churn out strange results during routine electrocardiograms (EKG), a test that assesses heart rhythm. These abnormalities have been dismissed for the most part as benign, adaptations to strenuous exercise. But a study published last week in the New England Journal of Medicine questions that wisdom.

On Tuesday, Bud Selig and Donald Fehr, baseball’s commissioner and union leader, testified before Congress about steroids in baseball. Roger Clemens and his former trainer, Brian McNamee, are scheduled to testify next month. Do expect anything good to come out of this Capitol Hill drama, or is it just a bunch of grandstanding?.

Anyone with a high-definition television and bowl exhaustion found themselves blessed with quite the optic gift on New Year’s Day: An outdoor hockey game played in Buffalo as snow fell gently onto the ice. NBC couldn’t have planned it better had they pulled a China and tried to manipulate the weather using their famous Beijing Weather Modification Office’s cloud-seeding aircraft, artillery and rockets, which fire chemicals into the air. There’s something about snow, sports and television.

Bill Belichick may have the best football team in creation, but that doesn’t stop the New England Patriots’ coach from reverting to pure reverie about another great team -- the Giants of the 1980s, when Belichick was the defensive coordinator and coached a linebacking corps that was among the best ever. Our colleague Judy Battista, who has covered the Patriots regularly this season, tells us that the old Giants defenses are one of the few subjects that the circumspect Belichick gets animated about. He shows film of them to his players, and talks about them so much that linebacker Mike Vrabel engaged in a give-and-take with Belichick during training camp that prompted the coach to leave a Giants helmet in Vrabel’s locker. (Vrabel wore it while warming up).
Agreements would include the deployment of radars in the Czech Republic and cooperation issues between American and Czech companies working on the research and development of the missile shield.
The makers of some antidepressants never published the results of about a third of the drug trials that they conducted to win government approval,  a new analysis has found.
To the Editor:.

As the Writers Guild maintained on Monday that it was unlikely to grant a request from Grammy producers for an interim agreement, talent managers and label executives worried over prospects of a gala drained of major stars.

Fox’s “American Idol” came roaring back to prime-time television on Tuesday, dominating the night’s ratings as usual, but in a sign that the series, now in its seventh season, might have reached a plateau this year’s premiere fell more than 4 million viewers short of last year’s record-breaking debut. Nielsen estimated that 33.2 million viewers tuned in for the first rounds of auditions from 8 to 10 p.m., compared with 37.4 million a year ago. Among adults 18 to 49, the show’s ratings were down by about 13 percent. CBS finished as runner-up for the night with the second most viewers, thanks to “NCIS” at 8 (15.9 million) followed by “Comanche Moon” from 9 to 11 (12.5 million). NBC ranked third with a two-hour “Biggest Loser” at 8 (7.2 million) and “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” at 10 (12.1 million). Despite modest audiences, the two shows lifted NBC well ahead of CBS for the night in the 18-to-49 group. Meanwhile, with a mix of reruns and new comedies, followed by “Boston Legal” at 10 (7.4 million), ABC lagged behind its competitors in fourth place overall.
The London theater’s 2008 season includes a stage turn by Jeremy Irons in “Never So Good,” a new play by Howard Brenton about the British prime minister Harold Macmillan.
A foundation established by the collectors Jane and Marc Nathanson has agreed to donate $10 million to  for purchases and exhibitions of contemporary art.

Music sales continue to plunge. This week Alicia Keys’s “As I Am” (J), below, is the top album with 70,000 copies sold, Nielsen SoundScan reported. That’s not a new low for the weekly sales of a No. 1 record — the “Dreamgirls” soundtrack earned that dubious distinction last January, with 60,000 — but it’s close. Radiohead’s “In Rainbows” (ATO), in its second week of CD sales, is No. 2 with 69,000. One of the few success stories on the Billboard chart recently, the “Juno” soundtrack (Rhino), rose five spots to No. 3 with 68,000 sales. Mary J. Blige’s “Growing Pains” (Geffen) is No. 4 with 64,000, and Taylor Swift’s self-titled album on the Big Machine label holds at No. 5 with 35,000. No new albums reached the Top 20.

The English poet Sean O’Brien has won the 2007 T. S. Eliot Prize for “The Drowned Book,” The Guardian of London reported. Established in 1993 to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the Book Poetry Society and to honor the group’s founding poet, Eliot, the award goes to the author of the best collection of poetry by an individual to be published in Britain or Ireland. Mr. O’Brien, a professor of creative writing at Newcastle University, received a check for £10,000 ($19,600) in ceremonies on Monday night at the Wallace Collection in London. Last year’s winner was Seamus Heaney.

The rapper Foxy Brown, right, citing concerns that damaged hearing could affect her career, appealed to a judge to let her out of prison, Reuters reported. In a four-page handwritten letter to Judge Melissa Jackson of Manhattan Criminal Court, Ms. Brown, 29, whose real name is Inga Marchand, said, “I ask you to please take into consideration that my health is in jeopardy.” Ms. Brown was sentenced in October 2006 to three years’ probation for assaulting two nail salon stylists over a $20 manicure, but in September she was sentenced to a year in jail when the judge decided that she had not taken probation seriously. In October, the authorities said, she received 76 days in isolation after a shoving match with another inmate and refusing to take a drug test. In a formal appeal submitted on Tuesday, Ms. Brown’s lawyer, Laura Dilimetin, said the only doctor who had treated Ms. Brown’s right ear successfully for “profound hearing loss” and complications arising from a surgical electronic implant is in California. Ms. Dilimetin said further damage to Ms. Brown’s hearing “will have dire consequences on her ability to maintain her profession and livelihood.”.

The stripper Dita Von Teese, above, former wife of the shock rocker Marilyn Manson, will accompany the Austrian socialite Richard Lugner on Jan. 31 to the annual Opera Ball in Vienna, the highlight of the Austrian social calendar, Agence France-Presse reported on Wednesday. Mr. Lugner, 75, who traditionally invites a star or starlet to be his guest, told a news conference that his daughter had begged him to invite Ms. Von Teese, 35, the former Heather Sweet of West Branch, Mich. Conservative members of Vienna society have complained that Mr. Lugner’s much-publicized invitations lower the tone of the ball. Last year his guest was Paris Hilton. ... This year Ms. Hilton will attend Harvard University. Just for a day. Ms. Hilton, whose new movie, “The Hottie & the Nottie,” is to be released on Feb. 8, will be in Cambridge, Mass., on Feb. 6 for the annual roast conducted by Hasty Pudding Theatricals, The Associated Press reported.

Zac Efron, 20, who starred as Troy Bolton in two Disney Channel “High School Musical” movies, underwent an emergency appendectomy on Tuesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. He was hospitalized a day after the announcement that he would appear in the feature film “High School Musical 3: Senior Year.” ... The period romance “Atonement,” starring Keira Knightley and James McAvoy, captured a leading 14 nominations, including best picture, actor, actress and director (Joe Wright), when competitors for the British Academy Film Awards were announced on Wednesday. The prizes will be awarded on Feb. 10.
Lee Siegel turns out to be an impressively tough, cogent and furious observer of the sinister side of Internet culture.

John Burnham Schwartz talks about his new novel, “The Commoner,” which is told from the point of view of a fictional doppelgänger for Empress Michiko of Japan.
Reviews of six shows at this year’s festival of plays and performance pieces.

IF you are unlucky enough to receive a diagnosis of cancer, the best to hope for is Movie Cancer, in which you become wiser, more assured and better-looking — and, in the case of the heroine of Amy Redford’s new movie, “The Guitar,” you furnish your newly acquired dream loft with no concern about money.
Architecture by Ban.

A glossary last Thursday with a story about energy-efficient light bulbs described induction technology incorrectly. In an induction light bulb, an electromagnetic field causes gas in a tube to emit ultraviolet radiation, which stimulates phosphors to produce light. The electromagnetic field does not vibrate, nor does the gas itself release visible light.
After a century of devoted minimalism, a turn toward ostentation.
Theater groups have been among the loudest protesters of cuts announced by Arts Council England, the government-financed body that doles out subsidies to the arts.
A writer’s journey from a Manhattan “silo” to antebellum Virginia.
The latest in this long line of winter journeyers is a British tenor, Mark Padmore, who sang Schubert’s song cycle at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday night with the pianist Ethan Iverson.
Ireland’s relatively new emphasis on entrepreneurs is the culmination of four decades of policies that have lifted the economy from centuries of poverty to modern prosperity.
New research challenges the notion that young Americans are the most self-absorbed.
Sandy Stewart and Bill Charlap turned the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel into a meditation room on Tuesday evening.
One of the best female players of all time, Marilyn Johnson, died last Oct. 31 in Houston.
The bombing, the fourth to have been carried out by a woman in Diyala Province since November, provoked Shiite militiamen to use mortars against a nearby Sunni village in retaliation.

A British cultural organization was forced to close its offices and its staff was questioned by Russian authorities, the latest twist in a downward spiral in relations since the death of a former Russian spy in London in 2006.
Reviews of new novels from Sara Paretsky, James Collins, Camilla Way, Barbara Delinsky, Meg Rosoff and Tahmima Anam.
Hundreds of Islamic militants attacked a paramilitary fort in the restive South Waziristan tribal region, killing 22 soldiers and taking several others hostage.
How do I choose a coffee table?
The move by the legislator, angered over the resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, leaves Prime Minister Ehud Olmert with a slimmer majority in Parliament.
Roger Federer and Venus Williams won in straight sets on Thursday against French players who rely much more on their minds than their muscles.

Q. My two very old and healthy Japanese camellias have outgrown their space, but I don’t want to remove them. Can I cut them back severely without killing them if I do it right after they bloom this spring?
President Bush praised Egypt’s president while avoiding mention of the government’s arrests of political dissidents.
The president of Canada’s nuclear industry regulator, embroiled in a dispute with the government over the closing and later reopening of a reactor, was fired.
Tracie Martyn, the almost invisible salon in Fifth Avenue, is the enemy of extra chins.
In Kenya’s third largest city, furious mobs hurled stones at police officers, who charged and fired their guns.
The president-elect of South Korea proposed  eliminating a government agency that has long led efforts to build reconciliation with North Korea.
Asian shares fell as subprime loan problems in the United States and soft economic data provoked international fear.
Joey Citera, 7, a snowboarder, tests five helmets at a new children-only snowboard terrain park in Vermont.
India’s schools have sunk to spectacularly low levels.
Another lesson in two may not be greater than one.
With numbers of college applications reaching new heights this year, promising another season of high rejection rates and dashed hopes for many more students.
Mortgage troubles are spreading to credit cards and auto loans.
Subsidized bread is part of making ends meet in Egypt, where about 45 percent of the population survives on just $2 a day.
The Sundance Film Festival, which opens with “In Bruges,” the playwright Martin McDonagh’s film debut, is one of the oddest ecosystems on earth.
Take away my access to e-mail and online databases, and I’m nothing but a lonely woman sitting in a cold basement.
Tony Sparano, who was a member of Bill Parcells’ Dallas Cowboys coaching staff in 2006-7, was named coach of the Dolphins on Wednesday.
A woman who is accustomed to helping other people must now rely on the help of others.
Apple holds its annual Macworld Expo and it’s chock-full of new high-tech goodies to be tried out.
In Connecticut’s win over St. John’s on Jan. 8, ESPN analyst Bucky Waters, while extolling Jerome Dyson’s nine steals, went too far with analogies of crime.
The disclosure at the Congressional hearing Tuesday that baseball is awash in a previously unknown epidemic brought two things to mind: Steve Howe and Officer Krupke.
After the clobbering Italian fashion has taken of late, Isabella Rossellini is making a stand for Milan.
A debate has broken out inside the White House over how hard to push Congress to make President Bush’s tax cuts permanent.
There’s a growing sense of urgency among educators that  every student should be on a college track.
A new director explores the role of shopping in the search for redemption.
In Milan, Prada unveils a new man. He’s already housebroken.
Michael London, the producer of the indie hit “Sideways,” got his feet wet with that movie. Now with three films at Sundance, he’s taken the plunge.

A new debate is emerging over whether breast implants constitute the kind of annuity medicine that will entail regular surgical tuneups, exposing patients to increased medical risk and out-of-pocket expenses.
Your mother was right about the hat. But bundling up is not advised.
The waiver exempts the Navy from the Coastal Zone Management Act, which allows states a voice in federal activities along their shores. The sonar is believed to harm whales.
Although John McCain is too conservative, and his temperament and age raise concerns, he is too honorable to dismiss at a moment so critical to America’s standing in the world.
If the Republicans were a movie, they’d be one like “The Dirty Dozen” in which a bunch of oddballs get thrown together to accomplish a dangerous mission.

ZIRINSKY--Juliana Fay, age 9, died peacefully in her own bedroom at home, in Ann Arbor, Michigan, on January 16th. She was our treasure, our faerie sprite, our beloved. Adored by her sister, Leela, and by her parents, Ruth Schekter and Bill Zirinsky. Cared for beautifully, and loved, by Maka Senderayi. Dear grandchild of Leon and Beverly Schekter. Loved deeply by many people. Juliana suffered from a degenerative neuro-metabolic disorder, and her health had been failing over the last few months. Her brother, Sam, also suffered from the same rare disorder, and he died four years ago. Juliana really loved her brother. Juliana was truly a child of the Divine, with the purest of spirits imaginable. She loved her life. She enjoyed school. She loved horses and books and the water. She thrived on family love. She was lots of fun. She was a determined little girl, and full of sparkle and mirth. Visitation with the family at Temple Beth Emeth on Thursday, January 17th, from 6 -9pm. The funeral service will be held at Temple Beth Emeth on Friday, January 18th, at 1:30pm. Located at 2309 Packard Road. Temple phone number: 734665-4744. In lieu of flowers, donations in her honor would be gratefully received by Therapeutic Riding, 4715 East Joy Road, Ann Arbor, MI 48105 (734-741-9402).

VOLKMAR--Christine M., died January 13, 2008. Executive VP, NYC Branch AAUW, Hunter College Phi Beta Kappa. Long time Manhattan resident, loyal Democrat and tireless volunteer. Beloved aunt of Jeanne Arzberger and Joanne Costello, greataunt to three nephews and two nieces. Friends may call from 12-2pm Saturday, January 19, at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Ave. (70th St.), NYC. Interment private.

MIRSKY--Ida Hade, died on January 14, 2008 in Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Lewis. Cherished mother of Robert (Barbara) and Jessica Bard (Leslie Corwin). Grandmother of Alison, Jonathan and Adam. Greatgrandmother of Ashley and Luke. Services on January 18, 2008, Star of David, Tamarac, Florida, 1-800-456-5252.

BARNEY--Elizabeth McDermott, loving wife of the late George J. Barney Jr., passed away on January 13. She is survived by her children, Elizabeth Lee Barney, Georgia Churchill Barney, Frederica Shelton Barney, and four grandchildren. A memorial mass will be held on Friday, January 18, 2008, at Saint Agnes Church, 143 East 43rd St, NYC at 10am. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations preferred to the ASPCA. For further information contact Krtil Funeral Home 212-744-3084.

The former Golden Gloves champion Sadam Ali's Olympic future is in jeopardy as he awaits the backup sample results from a doping test that came back positive for cathine, a banned stimulant found in some cold medicines.Ali, a 19-year-old lightweight from New York who won the 2006 national Golden Gloves, tested positive at an exhibition in China in November. Jim Millman, the chief executive of USA Boxing, said Ali and five other American boxers had flulike symptoms in China.Penalties could range from a warning to a two-year suspension.

Greg McMackin was hired as Hawaii's coach, after serving as the Warriors' defensive coordinator on a team that was 12-0 before losing to Georgia in the Sugar Bowl. He replaces June Jones, who resigned to coach Southern Methodist.

THE Apple store that opened last month in the meatpacking district of Manhattan is home to a new breed of urban wrangler. Parched for intelligence about the latest in high-tech gadgetry, its members -- rockers, artists, fashion folk and science geeks -- saunter into the store each week, lining up at the bar to take in the last word in laptop chic. Some dress to complement the sand-tone, desert-stark interior. Sparsely turned out in sneakers and jeans, banker stripes and biker coats, they snake up and down the glass spiral staircase or sit hunched over rows of iPods and glistening computer screens.

WOLF--Diane R. The Rockefeller University mourns the loss of Diane Wolf, a devoted friend and dedicated member of The Rockefeller University Council for the past 15 years. Through her generous commitment of time and resources, she helped to strengthen many of this country's cultural institutions. An intelligent and compassionate philanthropist, she supported cutting-edge research in investigative dermatology at The Rockefeller University Hospital. That her time was unexpectedly cut short is a profound loss and we extend our deepest condolences to her parents, Erving and Joyce, and to the entire Wolf family. Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Paul Nurse, President Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus

After several designer collaborations that have fallen short on style, J. C. Penney is trying something new. The company is working with Danny Seo, who describes himself as an ''environmental lifestyle expert,'' to create a designation that will make it easier for customers to identify home furnishings and accessories that J. C. Penney considers organic. Recently introduced products that will receive the ''Simply Green'' designation starting in March, left, include organic cotton bath rugs (top shelf and left side of second shelf, about $37), organic cotton and bamboo towels (second shelf on right, $11 to $18) and sheets (bottom shelf on right, $90 for a queen-size set), and bamboo bowls (medium size shown on counter, about $30), all of which are part of the company's Studio line. Information: www.jcpenney.com. RIMA SUQI

A glossary last Thursday with a story about energy-efficient light bulbs described induction technology incorrectly. In an induction light bulb, an electromagnetic field causes gas in a tube to emit ultraviolet radiation, which stimulates phosphors to produce light. The electromagnetic field does not vibrate, nor does the gas itself release visible light.

Marion Jones said Wednesday that seeing the pain her family and friends endured after she acknowledged using performance-enhancing drugs outweighed the impact of returning her Olympic medals.Jones, the former Olympic track gold medalist, appeared on ''The Oprah Winfrey Show,'' her first television interview since being sentenced last week to six months in prison for lying to investigators about steroid use and a check-fraud scam. ''I made a mistake,'' Jones said. ''I made the choice, at that time, to protect myself, to protect my family. And now I've paid the consequences dearly.''

A high school track star in Washington has been disqualified from a meet because officials said the custom-made outfit she wore to conform to her Muslim faith violated competition rules. Juashaunna Kelly, a senior at Theodore Roosevelt High School who has the fastest mile and two-mile times of any girl in Washington this winter, was disqualified from Saturday's Montgomery Invitational indoor meet.Kelly's blue and orange unitard covers her head, arms, torso and legs. The outfit allows her to compete while adhering to her Muslim faith, which forbids displaying any skin other than her face and hands. But the meet's director, Tom Rogers, said Kelly's uniform violated rules of the National Federation of State High School Associations.

RIKLIS--Judith Stern, a proud daughter of Israel, died January 15 in New York City where she lived. She was born 83 years ago to one of Tel Aviv's early families. Her grandfather was Aharon-Zelig Krinkin, an emigrant from Czarist Russia, who established one of Tel Avivs first pharmacies. (The phone number was ''23''.) Judith was raised in Tel Aviv and graduated from the Gymnasia Herzliya, the first school in what was then Palestine to teach exclusively in Hebrew. It was there that she met her future husband, Meshulam Riklis, the Israeli-American financier and philanthropist. With him and their first-born, the couple went to America to attend college. They settled for a time in Minneapolis where both Judith and Meshulam taught Hebrew school and Meshulam worked also as a stock broker. The couple eventually moved to the New York area where Judith raised her three children, Mona Ackerman, Marcia Riklis and Ira D. Riklis. After the Riklis marriage ended in divorce, Judith maintained homes in both New York and Jerusalem with Isaac Moyal, her companion until his death. Judith took a passionate interest in the Jewish state, contributing to many charities, including the Hadassah Hospital, the Bat Sheva dance troupe and the Soldiers Welfare Association. A building on the Mount Scopus campus of the Hebrew University is named for her. Judith was a warm woman, devoted to her family. She loved and supported the arts and had a keen eye for painting. In addition to her children and her daughter-inlaw, Diana Riklis, Judith is survived by six grandchildren, Ari Ackerman, Gila (and Roy) Steinbock, Jordana (and Ben) Cooperberg, Talia (and Andrew) Day, Daniella Hirschfeld and David Hirschfeld; four great - grandchildren, Layla, Ayelet, Leo and Leora. The funeral will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:45am, Thursday January 17. The family will sit Shiva at the Riklis home, 936 Fifth Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations will be greatly appreciated to American Friends of the Tel Aviv Foundation. RIKLIS--Judith Stern. A special woman who lived an interesting and full life. Always gracious and giving to her friends and generous to her charities. But at the end of the day, it was always about her family that she loved and adored. Our heartfelt condolences to Mona, Marcia, Ira and their families. Edi and Nancy Dunst RIKLIS--Judith. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the loss of Judith Riklis, who was the wife of Meshulam Riklis, a UJA-Federation honorary officer and life trustee, and the beloved mother of Marcia Riklis, Dr. Mona Ackerman, and Ira D. Riklis, and motherin-law of Diana Riklis, treasured and inspiring leaders of the New York Jewish community. Through their generosity, leadership, and commitment, they have strengthened our ability to serve those in need, making a lasting impact on all New Yorkers and the Jewish community in Israel and throughout the world. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Riklis family, including her six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO RIKLIS--Judith. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our cherished benefactor, Dr. Mona Ackerman. To Mona and to the entire family, our heartfelt sympathy. May Judith's memory be a source of blessing and inspiration. Rabbi Marc Schneier Morris Tuchman, President Martin Berman, Chairman Gerald Rausnitz, Secretary Seymour Siegel, Treasurer

In Manhattan, real estate is destiny. Consider Julia Trotta's new gallery: at about 100 square feet, Fake Estate, as Ms. Trotta calls it, began life as a utility closet for a photographer's studio in the Chelsea Arts Building. The photographer adopted three children from Ethiopa and eventually left the city, Ms. Trotta said, but kept his studio. The closet was advertised for rent on www.craigslist.org as a storage area, she said, for $650 (now $725). ''When I took it, the janitors were poking fun at me and that's how I found out,'' she said. Nonetheless, its proportions were good and it came with its own small foyer, a kind of anteroom of perhaps 20 square feet. So Ms. Trotta, who had been showing works of several artists at her apartment on Chambers Street, decided to turn it into a gallery. (Ms. Trotta, 25, is the granddaughter of Linda Nochlin, the feminist art historian, and shares her grandmother's general feistiness; she studied what she called ''naughty art history,'' or controversy in the arts, at New York University.)

An article on Jan. 5 about a California court hearing for the Democratic fund-raiser Norman Hsu misstated the judge's actions over the $2 million bail posted by Mr. Hsu. The judge ''exonerated'' the bail money by allowing it to be used at the court's discretion; he did not deny a motion for its return. (The judge ordered $1 million be held for restitution to victims in Mr. Hsu's 1992 case, and transferred the other $1 million to federal authorities in New York who had obtained a seizure order for the funds.)

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about Caroline K. Keck, an innovator in art conservation, misidentified the institution to which a conservation training program she and her husband founded moved and is now the art conservation department. It is Buffalo State College, part of the State University of New York -- not the State University of New York at Buffalo, another part of the SUNY system.

FOLKMAN --Judah, M.D. The University of Massachusetts Medical School (UMMS) and its Worcester Foundation for Biomedical Research (WFBR) mourn the passing of our friend Judah Folkman. A member of the WFBR Board and 1998 recipient of the Gregory Pincus Medal, Dr. Folkman gave the keynote address at the 2004 Investiture of UMMS Nobel Laureate Craig C. Mello as the Blais University Chair of Molecular Medicine. His pioneering contributions to science will endure. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife and family. Michael F. Collins, M.D., Chancellor, UMMS Craig C. Mello, Blais University Chair, UMMS John Herron, Chairman, WFBR Thoru Pederson, Director, WFBR John L. Sullivan, President, WFBR FOLKMAN--M. Judah. With great sadness and a deep sense of loss, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourns the death of M. Judah Folkman, its esteemed and active Fellow since 1986 and a pioneering cancer researcher at Harvard Medical School. Long before others appreciated the significance of his work, Folkman carried out pathbreaking and innovative research on angiogenesis-dependent tumor growth, developing one of the most influential concepts in cancer biology and founding the field of angiogenesis research, now pursued in laboratories worldwide. His contributions to medical technology, including his design of one of the first heart pacemakers, represent important advances that help sustain the quality of human life today. The Academy expresses its sincere condolences to his wife, Paula, his family, his colleagues, and all those who were fortunate to know his brilliance, kindness, and generosity. He embodied the ideals of the scientist physician. Emilio Bizzi, President Louis W. Cabot, Chair of the Academy Trust and Vice President Jerrold Meinwald, Secretary John S. Reed, Treasurer Leslie C. Berlowitz, Chief Executive Officer

Philip Gorrivan, a Manhattan designer known for colorful, tailored interiors, is introducing his first collection of fabric this month: 48 patterns, many of them modern interpretations of historical architectural elements. Available to the trade at the Duralee/Highland Court showroom at 979 Third Avenue (59th Street), (212) 752-4040. ELAINE LOUIE

An obituary on Dec. 24 about Douglas O. Morgan, a publisher whose collection of 19th-century wood type letterforms helped start a graphic design revival, referred imprecisely to the current location of the collection. The National Museum of American History in Washington, part of the Smithsonian Institution, holds the collection and makes some of it available to researchers; it is not at the Hall of Printing and Graphic Arts, a part of the museum that closed in 2003.

The former Texas quarterback Major Applewhite is rejoining the Longhorns as an assistant, leaving his job at Alabama. Applewhite, 29, was the youngest offensive coordinator in the Football Bowl Subdivision last season and returns to the campus where he was a fan favorite as a player from 1998 to 2001.

MOORE--Melita (Holly) Riley, passed away in Bloomfield, CT, on January 16, 2008. She was born in September 1909 in Joplin, Missouri, the daughter of the late William M. and Rose (Brunner) Holly. She graduated from Wellesley College 1932 (Phi Beta Kappa). Having received the Math Prize enabled her to continue her studies and she obtained a Masters Degree in Mathematics from the University of Michigan. She taught mathematics in private schools and Wellesley College until the war when she went to Washington D.C. to work in the Acoustics Division of the Naval Ordnance Laboratory. After the war, she joined the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics as head of the section that compiled the Consumer Price and Wholesale Price Indexes. In 1946, she married architect Chauncey W. Riley and lived in New York City and New Canaan, CT. She joined the Statistical Office of the United Nations as head of its research section. After 10 years of fulltime work, she changed to part-time work for 20 more years during which she visited over 80 countries all over the world. Chauncey Riley passed away in 1972. In 1975 Melita married the wellknown economist Geoffrey H. Moore. She co-authored one of his books, ''International Economic Indicators''. Dr. Moore passed away in 2000. In 1998, she initiated the ''Adopt a Minefield'' program in New Canaan, CT, that raised enough money to successfully clear mine fields in a village in Cambodia. For this project and for work in the United Nations she was awarded, with 140 others, the Ruth Steinkraus-Cohen memorial listing of ''outstanding women in Connecticut''. She is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, Bryant and Sandra Riley of Mount Sterling, OH, two granddaughters, Holly and Jeff Vigar of Lewis Center, OH, and Megan Riley of Asheville, NC; a greatgranddaughter, Alexa Vigar and six stepchildren and their families, Monica Riley of Richmond, CA, Karl Riley of Hampstead, NC, Stephen and Nancy Moore of Bluffton, SC, Peter and Tina Moore of Fort Thomas, KY, Kathleen and Leighton Holness of Somerset, NJ, and Pamela and Stephen Pelligrino of Moultenborough, NH. Private burial will be in Lakeview Cemetery, New Canaan. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry St., Philadelphia, PA 19102, www.afsc.org. Vincent Funeral Home, Simsbury, CT, has care of the services. For online condolences please visit www.vincent funeralhome.com.

STONE--James Hiram. Founder and Chairman of Stone Energy Corporation, Lafayette, LA, and sportsman of New Orleans and Houston, died peacefully surrounded by his wife and six children on January 14, 2008. Born in New York City in 1925, son of Isabel Greenbaum and Jacob C. Stone, he is survived by his wife, Joelle Rogers, brothers Robert L. (Sheila) of Williamstown, MA. and Donald (Jean) of Scarsdale, NY, sons Andrew (Katie) of Albuquerque, Thomas (Robin) of Steamboat Springs, CO, and James R. of New Orleans, daughters Suzanne of Santa Fe, NM, Margaret of Chicago, and Elizabeth H. of New Orleans, and eight grandchildren. He attended the Harvey School, and graduated from Deerfield Academy and Williams College. During WWII he served in the US Marine Corps as a Lieutenant in the First Marine Division in the Pacific. Following college he worked for the oil department of Lehman Brothers. While studying geology at Texas A.&M., he was recalled by the Marine Reserves during the Korean conflict, discharged from the service as a Captain. He married Elizabeth Asbury, settled in Cincinnati and established The Stone Oil Company there in 1952. The company went public on The New York Stock Exchange as Stone Energy Corporation in 1993. In the early 1970s he was involved in the urban renewal of the downtown business district of Cincinnati in joint venture with John Galbraith through the Cincinnati Redevelopment Corporation. Through his wife's family he developed a life-long interest in thoroughbred breeding and racing. Notable successes included Ardross, winner of The Gold Cup in England, and in partnership with Arthur B. Hancock III, Menifee, winner of the Blue Grass Stakes and second in the Kentucky Derby and Preakness in 1999. Living in New Orleans since 1981, he served as a director of the Hibernia National Bank of New Orleans and Newpark Resources, and was a founder of The D-Day Museum, now known as The National World War II Museum. He retained his association with the Marine Corps as a founding member and director of the Marine Corps Heritage Foundation in Quantico, VA and as a board member of the Toys For Tots Foundation. In New Orleans he also served on the Business Council of New Orleans and the River Region and was a past trustee of the Tulane Medical Center, The New Orleans Museum of Art, the New Orleans Symphony and the New Orleans Opera Association. Additionally, he served as a director of the NFL Rams. His club affiliations included the Krewe of Hermes of which he served as King in 1994, The New Orleans Country Club and The Reading Room in Saratoga, NY. For over 60 years he maintained a strong and lasting connection to Williams College as alumnus, active committee member, donor, and father and grandfather of five graduates. There will be a private burial. Memorial contributions are suggested to The National World War II Museum, 945 Magazine St., New Orleans, LA 70130, or Toys for Tots Foundation, P.O. Box 1947, Quantico, VA 22134.

GUTMAN--Robert, of Princeton, NJ, 81, on November 23, 2007. Influential architecture professor and critic. Educated at Columbia, then taught at Dartmouth before moving to Rutgers sociology department in 1957. Joined Princeton architecture faculty in 1969. Retired from Rutgers in 1996. Still teaching at Princeton at the time of his death. With great curiosity, he explored relationships among architects, buildings, users, and public policy. A generous scholar, collaborator, and mentor, he brought social science into the heart of architectural education and practice. He maintained the demeanor of both student and professor, with an inquisitiveness matched only by his challenges to prevailing assumptions. Among his published work was Architectural Practice: A Critical View (1988). Husband of the late Sonya Rudikoff, writer and literary critic. Leaves son John, daughter Elizabeth, and three grandchildren. Memorial service Saturday, January 19 at 3 pm at Princeton University Chapel. Donations in his memory can be made to Society of Architectural Historians, Chicago, IL or Princeton Friends Meeting, Princeton, NJ.

Storage is sometimes a problem in apartments or small houses. But small places get just as dusty as big ones do, even though there may not be much room to store cleaning equipment. To address this problem, next month Dyson is to bring out its smallest full-power upright vacuum cleaner. The DC24 All Floors ($399.99) is a third smaller than its full-size Dyson equivalent and weighs five pounds less, but has the same power and suction. It maneuvers on a rotating ball, making cleaning in corners easy, and it comes with attachments for stairs, upholstery, rugs and hard floors. After sucking up the dust, this compact machine can be stored in the corner of a closet. To order, for delivery in February: (866) 693-9766 or www.dyson.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

On Jan. 16, 2004, Jodie S. Lane, a 30-year-old graduate student walking her dogs, was electrocuted after she stepped on an electrified metal plate in the East Village. Improperly insulated wire beneath the plate had sent 57 volts of electricity running up the side of an underground service box to the plate above.

PARK CITY, Utah — The Sundance Film Festival feels like Brooklyn. Wherever you go, you are surrounded by people who say they were here before everyone else was here. And everyone else is still coming, hordes of them, an estimated 50,000 attendees this year, up from 36,000 just two years ago.

I have several thoughts about recent posts here, notably on Prada and Jil Sander, and some observations about the men's shows we saw today. There is no trace of self-conscious in Junya Watanabe's clothes, as there is with so many designers, no gender manipulation that blows up in his face and only makes the rest of us laugh sadly with disappointment. He showed the shrunken blazer, a style he has done before (before Mr. Browne), as if to express the general distaste and contempt that young men have for this formal look. They scorn it, and so does Junya, now showing the coat with ties and shirts that are so glossy and colorful as to perhaps tempt the militant boys into an establishment uniform. A number of the jackets combined classic tweeds with bits of other fabrics, seemingly from a rag bin. OK, he made his point, and didn't sit on it proudly or for too long.

WASHINGTON -- Bidding to seize control of the accelerating debate over economic stimulus, former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney is proposing a package with something for everyone. In an interview this afternoon for CNBC, Mr. Romney said he will propose: -- A permanent cut in the lowest income tax bracket to 7.5 percent from 10 percent. The Immediate Retroactive Tax Credit for 2007 applies to employees who earned less than $97,500 in 2007.-- Make that cut immediately retroactive to 2007 tax liabilities.-- Permanently eliminate Social Security payroll taxes for workers over 65.-- Provide 100 percent expensing of new equipment purchased by businesses over two years retroactive to Jan 1 2008.-- Permanently reduce the corporate tax rate to 20 percent from 35 percent over two years.-- Permanent eliminate capital gains and dividends taxes on households earning under $200,000 a year, an idea he has previously proposed.

People who have been close to political campaigns will tell you that the spouse always takes things more personally than the candidate; it's just easier to be attacked yourself than it is to watch the person you love get hurt. That probably explains why Bill Clinton, who was as publicly unflappable a candidate as you will ever find in American politics, lost his cool yet again Wednesday (it's been happening every six days or so) while lecturing a television reporter on the inherent unfairness of the Nevada caucus system. Of course, Clinton is a persuasive man, but his tirade would have been more convincing had anyone in the Clinton camp complained about Nevada's system before the powerful culinary unions endorsed Barack Obama. And that probably explains why a judge in Nevada ruled Thursday that the caucuses should go on as planned. (Clinton's opposition to the plan would also have been more credible, by the way, had Hillary Rodham Clinton herself not noted, after the Iowa caucuses, that a lot of Iowa's shift workers hadn't been able to take part. Fair enough, but can you really advocate helping workers caucus in Iowa, where you think they would have voted for you, and then argue against exactly that in Nevada, where you fear they might not?)

The selling strategy for the first Bush tax cut relied heavily on "tax families" -- photogenic families who would supposedly be the big beneficiaries of the tax break. In fact, they were mainly beneficiaries of the child tax credit and the "cutout", the reduction of some peoples' rates from 15% to 10% -- and they were carefully chosen to give a misleading picture both of how the typical family would fare and who the real main beneficiaries were.

This week's guest blogger is the Milan-based artist and satirist Francesco Vezzoli. Over the past decade, the diva-and-Prada-obsessed Vezzoli, 36, has at once defiled and genuflected at the altar of celebrity. His campy oeuvre includes everything from needlework portraits of Maria Callas and Anna Magnani to films like "Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidal's Caligula," starring Helen Mirren and Courtney Love, and live performances like Pirandello's "Right You Are (If You Think You Are)," starring - among others - Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Abigail Breslin, which he produced at the Guggenheim last October as part of the Performa 07 series. In his fifth post of the week he writes about -- and links to -- the favorite T.V. moments of his childhood years in Italy. To read all of Francesco Vezzoli's prior blog posts, click here.

Before I reveal the Figaro Factotum regimen for greater personal productivity, let me explain how it came about. Maintaining a blog while doing other things has reminded me of how bad I am at juggling different jobs. I've tried to excuse this as a consequence of my gender. I've tried consoling myself with the theories of evolutionary psychologists who say that male hunters on the savanna needed to focus intently on one job -- kill or be killed -- while women evolved to be better multitaskers because the survival of the species depended on their being able to keep an eye on children while doing other work.

1. I was pleased to see this story, "On-ramping not just for women anymore," by Maggie Jackson in The Boston Globe earlier this week. On-ramping programs that focus on helping women return to work after taking years off for child rearing have been getting a lot of attention, but few people have been writing about the men who go through this same experience. It is a good sign for all of us when something moves from being a women's issue to an everyone issue. And that usually happens once the men start speaking out.

Although he essentially quit chess after winning [...].

Bobby Fischer, the mercurial American champion, has died in Iceland, his adopted home. In his later years, he had become a pariah in the chess world because of his strident anti-Americanism and antisemitism, but even that could not detract from his contributions and impact on the chess board. Although he essentially quit chess after winning the title in 1972 in his epic match with Boris Spassky (coming back only in 1992 for another match with Spassky that drew worldwide interest), he raised interest in chess to unprecedented levels and changed the game profoundly. Garry Kasparov, the former world champion, in the fourth book of his series "My Great Predecessors," a volume largely devoted to Fischer, wrote, "He abandoned the game at the age of 29, and only really played for just ten years, but he succeeded in achieving more in chess than anyone else!"
