The growing crisis at Ambac Financial, one of the biggest bond insurers, is raising questions about Wall Street's exposure as counterparties to the bond-insurance industry coming off a period in which the big banks are reeling from more than $100 billion in write-downs of mortgage-related securities, according to Forbes.
A major shareholder in Kellwood, whose brands include Phat Farm, has come out to support Sun Capital Securities Group's hostile bid for the struggling apparel maker.

Borders Group said it has given a board seat to a partner from Pershing Square Capital Management, an activist hedge-fund firm that is one of the bookseller's largest shareholders. The partner, Richard McGuire, is one of five people responsible for managing about $6 billion for Pershing, Borders said in a statement.
Dodging the rocky investments that have damaged many Wall Street banks, BlackRock, the giant asset management firm, said on Thursday that fourth-quarter profit rose 90 percent.
An insurance broker, Willis Group Holdings, has approached its bigger rival, Marsh & McLennan about a possible takeover of Marsh & McLennan, CNBC reported.
A Chinese financial conglomerate, the China Everbright Group, intends to list its commercial banking arm on the Shanghai A share market and then possibly Hong Kong, state media said on Friday.
Williams Pipeline Partners said late Thursday that its initial public offering of 16.25 million common units had priced at $20 per unit, the midpoint of the anticipated price range.

Announcing a long-rumored deal, NYSE Euronext said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the American Stock Exchange for $260 million in stock to increase its business in options, exchange-traded funds and cash products.

The conventional wisdom over the past two decades is that in a merger and acquisition boom, buyers pay too much, leading to value destruction and leaving shareholders to suffer a hangover after bouts of frenetic dealmaking.

Hudson Bay Capital Management, the hedge fund founded by ex-proprietary trader Sander Gerber, hired Amaranth Advisors' former chief operating officer, Charles Winkler, according to a report in HedgeWorld.

The world's next big beer deal could be struck in the next few days, after British brewer Scottish & Newcastle agreed Thursday to sit down with Carlsberg and Heineken, whose approach S&N had resisted for three months,

Google announced a plan on Thursday that begins to fulfill the pledge it made to investors when it went public nearly four years ago to reserve 1 percent of its profit and equity to "make the world a better place." The beneficiaries of Google's money range from groups that are fighting disease to those developing a commercial plug-in car.
The mortgage lender Countrywide Financial may have to pay Bank of America a fee of $160 million if a deal to buy it falls through, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday.
The owners of Somerfield Stores, a British grocery chain, have put the company up for sale and brought in Citigroup to conduct an auction, The Deal reported.

Bank of New York Mellon said Thursday that fourth-quarter profit declined 68 percent because of its exposure to assets backed by mortgages and a strong quarter a year ago, when the bank gained $1.4 billion after unloading its retail operations.

The auto parts supplier Delphi said Thursday it had won approval from nearly all of its creditors and cleared away an objection by bondholders for its plan to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
Independent News & Media said late Thursday it would pay 86.6 million euros ($127 million) for the 50 percent of Clear Channel Independent, an African advertising firm, that it doesn't already own.
A Texas cable provider, Grande Communications Holdings, has tapped Waller Capital to evaluate its strategic opportunities, according to The Deal.com.
The London Stock Exchange opened a Beijing office Friday, stepping up its rivalry with United States markets to attract listings by fast-growing Chinese companies expanding abroad.
Is the performance of Comcast's chief executive, Brian Roberts, a "Comcastrophe"?

Special-purpose acquisition vehicles have become increasingly popular in the last year or so, with well-known deal-makers such as Ronald Perelman and Nelson Peltz sponsoring SPACs of their own. The latest to hit the market is Sapphire Industrials, which is backed by the investment bank Lazard.
This earnings season on Wall Street was like the Mitchell Report for baseball, David Weidner of MarketWatch wrote: We found out who was on the juice.

Anagran, a maker of devices that control data flow on computer networks, raised $12 million in a third venture capital round as it begins commercial sales of a new type of router that is positioned as an add-on device to allow for greater network traffic on existing equipment.
The Royal Bank of Canada said it plans to drop the Centura name from its United States banking unit in April, and will rename it the RBC Bank.

The Kumho-Asiana Group, owner of South Korea's largest builder and second-biggest airline, bid more than 4 trillion won ($4.3 billion) for control of the Korea Express Company to add cargo delivery and warehousing services.

The British mining company Anglo American is in exclusive negotiations to pay $5.5 billion for control of iron ore projects owned by the Brazilian mining concern MMX Mineração e Metálicos, the companies said.
McDonald's to protesters: Fine, have it your way! From today's Times:
“Breaking Bad,” a new seven-part series on AMC about a middle-aged chemistry teacher in Albuquerque who becomes a methamphetamine dealer, wants no part of the Hollywood formula.
A steep rise in prices for palm oil has forced many families in Dharavi, a sprawling slum in Mumbai, India, to use less oil or even cut back on food.
First, take a look:
The Democratic presidential candidates campaigned in California and Nevada, while the Republicans focused on South Carolina.

“She suspects there’s trouble coming. But she feels if they can just hold on to the easy camaraderie and sexual heat of their early days, then they can find a way to keep talking about all this, a way of shaping their marriage to suit them both.”
If the abysmal reception so far for films about the war in Iraq is any indication, “Day Zero” is the last thing movie audiences will want to consume.
Teenage horror-movie spoof, John Waters parody, No Nukes protest movie: Mitchell Lichtenstein’s clever, crude comedy, “Teeth,” is all these and more.
If recent American history is ever going to be discussed with the necessary clarity and ethical rigor, “Taxi to the Dark Side” will be essential.
In “Still Life,” the blood and the sweat run directly into the Yangtze River, where they mingle with more than a few tears.
Lou Ye’s “Summer Palace” examines youthful idealism and its unhappy aftermath.
In the breezy, amoral heist comedy “Mad Money,” “Fun With Dick and Jane” meets “9 to 5” on the way to recession.
“27 Dresses” makes the point that modern American weddings are all pretty much alike. The same could be said about modern American romantic comedies.
“Cloverfield” is nominally a monster movie, but mostly it’s a feature-length gimmick.
“Cassandra’s Dream,” Woody Allen’s latest excursion to the dark side of human nature, is good enough that you may wonder why he doesn’t just stop making comedies once and for all.
“Beaufort” may be, strictly speaking, a war movie, but for long stretches it feels more like science fiction.
Jonny Greenwood’s 20-minute work was by far the most viscerally exciting and intellectually engaging of the three at the Wordless Music series concert on Wednesday.
John McCain knows that a win in South Carolina is the only way that might allow him to mount a serious effort in the next primaries.
Fred Thompson’s style is playing well in rural South Carolina, where his poll numbers show a tease of life.
General Electric said its fourth-quarter profit rose 4 percent as surging overseas sales more than offset the fallout from domestic woes.
The C.I.A has concluded that the assassins who killed Benazir Bhutto were directed by Baitullah Mehsud, a Pakistani militant leader.
The 25-minute ferry ride doesn’t help with the image of Staten Island as a remote destination within New York City.
Chief Justice Elliott E. Maynard of the West Virginia Supreme Court disqualified himself  from further participation in a case involving a powerful coal executive.
The candidates made their closing arguments in a state that did not previously have a starring role early in the race.
Michael Golden, publisher of The International Herald Tribune, said he was leaving the position to focus on his position as vice chairman of The New York Times Company.
Serena Williams has yet to drop a set in three matches at the first week of the Australian Open. On Friday she defeated Victoria Azarenka, 6-3, 6-4.
The document appears to contradict the public stance of Canada, which accepts U.S. assurances that it does not mistreat prisoners.
A House committee chairman said Thursday that White House statements about missing e-mail records conflicted with what Congressional staff members were told four months ago.
Wayne Chism scored a season-high 18 points and had a career-high 18 rebounds to help No. 6 Tennessee beat No. 16 Vanderbilt, 80-60, Thursday night.
It wasn’t an easy start, but the once-porous defense of the Giants finished the season ranked seventh in the N.F.L., thanks in part to Steve Spagnuolo.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled strict new criteria for promotion to high school that could put nearly a quarter of New York City’s eighth graders in danger of spending an extra year in middle school.
Andrei Kostitsyn scored in the second period, then came through again in the shootout to lead the Montreal Canadiens past the host Atlanta Thrashers, 3-2, Thursday night.

The number of abortions in the United States fell to 1.2 million in 2005, down 25 percent from the all-time high of 1.6 million in 1990, dropping the abortion rate to its lowest level since 1974, a report says.
The National Science Foundation dedicated its third Amundsen-Scott research building at the South Pole on Saturday.

A sports article on Thursday about the surprising emergence of running back Ryan Grant of the Green Bay Packers referred incorrectly to his classroom performance at the University of Notre Dame. The university said he was never ineligible to play for academic or other reasons; he did not miss one season because of academic trouble.

A sports article on Wednesday about Coach Bill Belichick’s efforts to motivate the New England Patriots for their playoff game against San Diego misstated the Chargers’ record through the first five games this season. It was 2-3, not 1-4.

An article in some editions on Dec. 30 about Nyiga Tenzin Nordon, a Tibetan refugee whose son was badly injured by a hit-and-run driver in Queens and who received help through The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, misidentified the hotel where Ms. Nordon works as a maid. It is the Hilton Garden Inn in Times Square, on Eighth Avenue at 48th Street — not the Hilton Times Square, on 42nd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

An article in some editions on Monday about the simultaneous departure of three luxury ocean liners — the Queen Mary 2, the Queen Elizabeth 2 and the Queen Victoria — from New York Harbor misstated the context of a quotation from Peter Knego, co-editor of a Web site devoted to the history of passenger ships. When Mr. Knego said, “They would only meet in the Atlantic and were never in port together,” he was referring to the Queen Mary and the Queen Elizabeth — not their successors. (The Queen Mary 2 and the Queen Elizabeth 2 were both in port in New York in 2004.).

An article on Dec. 18 about the escape of two inmates from the Union County Jail in Elizabeth, N.J., included an erroneous age from law enforcement authorities for one of the escapees, Jose Espinosa. He was 19 at the time, not 20; he has since turned 20.

One of five former lawmakers convicted of bribery or extortion in an F.B.I. sting was sentenced to two years’ probation by a judge who indicated that the defendant’s heart ailment had kept him out of prison.

The Public Lives column in some editions last Friday, about Nicholas Sprayregen, a businessman and Bruce Springsteen fan who is fighting efforts by Columbia University to seize property he owns in Upper Manhattan, referred incorrectly to the shows Mr. Sprayregen attended during Mr. Springsteen’s 2002-3 “Rising” tour. He saw six of the multiple-night shows at Giants and Shea Stadiums in 2003; Mr. Springsteen did not give a “10-night stand” at Madison Square Garden during that tour.
Responding to concerns about high levels of formaldehyde in its disaster trailers, the Federal Emergency Management Agency said it would offer refunds to people who bought the units.

An article in Business Day on Jan. 7 about Big Think, the Web site that has interviews with public intellectuals from a variety of fields misspelled the surname of a politician cited in an example. He is Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, not Spector.
The Calabasas City Council adopted an ordinance regulating smoking in apartments.
Gov. Donald L. Carcieri proposed deep budget cuts to close a $151 million deficit.
The American Civil Liberties Union sued the state and its most populous county to block the county from switching to a paper voting system in time for the March 4 presidential primary.

A chart in Business Day on Thursday with an article about the casino mogul Sheldon G. Adelson misidentified, in some copies, the company controlled by Lawrence J. Ellison, whose wealth was compared with Mr. Adelson’s. It is Oracle, not Sun Microsystems.

A picture caption on Monday with an article about inns and hotels in the New York region that cater to new mothers, pregnant women or couples who want to become parents misstated, in some editions, the given name of a man who recently stayed with his wife and their new son at the Parrot Mill Inn in Chatham, N.J. He is Mark Sodano, not Dan.

A headline in Business Day on Thursday with an article about research involving two widely used cholesterol-lowering drugs misstated the issue raised by the results. It is whether using drugs to lower cholesterol at all costs is always medically effective, or even safe; there is no question that cholesterol itself can pose dangers.

An article on Dec. 18 about the escape of two inmates from the Union County Jail in Elizabeth, N.J., included an erroneous age from law enforcement authorities for one of the escapees, Jose Espinosa. He was 19 at the time, not 20; he has since turned 20.

The cars came from all over — upstate New York and Maryland, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The owners brought them to middlemen who would deliver them for a fee to a nondescript garage in Queens. The cars, the owners thought, would be stripped down for parts, and they could then claim the vehicles as stolen and recoup tens of thousands of dollars from insurance companies.
The military said most of the 27 people killed in a bus ambush in the central town of Buttala on Wednesday were shot as they tried to flee, rather than in the blast that struck the bus.

A special tribunal of the army-backed emergency government adjourned the start of the corruption trial of Sheik Hasina Wazed, a former prime minister and the leader of a top political party, until next week.
A boomerang stolen from a museum in Mount Isa, in Queensland, more than two decades ago has been returned.
The government of President Robert G. Mugabe, battered by hyperinflation, said it would begin issuing new currency beginning Friday: $1 million, $5 million and $10 million notes.
A set of lyrics proposed only last week for Spain’s wordless national anthem have been withdrawn amid criticism that they harked back to the country’s right-wing past.
The military government’s Press Scrutiny Board ordered the Burmese-language edition of the weekly Myanmar Times not to publish this week for having run an article that was not approved.
Candace Parker scored 23 points and No. 2 Tennessee weathered a sloppy start to pull away from host Kentucky, 65-40, Thursday night.
The owner of South Korea’s largest builder and second-biggest airline bid for control of the Korea Express Company to add cargo delivery and warehousing services.
The British mining company Anglo American is in exclusive negotiations to pay $5.5 billion for control of iron ore projects owned by a Brazilian mining concern.
Australian employment rose for a 14th month in December, adding to the longest hiring boom in almost three decades.
The Royal Bank of Canada said it plans to drop the Centura name from its United States banking unit.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s State of the City speech was at one level a recitation of what he saw as accomplishments and hopes. But at another level, it practically screamed, “Hey, don’t rule me out in 2008.”

Mike Lowell, the most valuable player of the World Series, said he was willing to give blood if that is what it takes to be tested for human growth hormone — but only if the test is 100 percent accurate. “If it’s 99 percent accurate, that’s going to be seven false positives,” Lowell said Thursday before the annual dinner of the Boston chapter of the Baseball Writers’ Association of America. “Ninety-three percent is 70 guys. That’s almost three whole rosters. You’re destroying someone’s reputation. What if one of the false positives is Cal Ripken? Doesn’t it put a black mark on his career?”.

Jason Jennings, a Dallas native who grew up watching Nolan Ryan pitch for Texas, was introduced as the newest addition to the Rangers’ rotation. Jennings, a free-agent right-hander, agreed to a one-year deal worth $4 million. Jennings, 29, is coming off an injury-plagued season in Houston, where he was 2-9 with a career-worst 6.45 earned run average. He missed three months with elbow problems.

Mia Hamm retired in 2004 as one of the greatest players in women’s soccer. Now she is the image of a new league. Hamm’s silhouette is featured in the logo unveiled Thursday by Women’s Professional Soccer, a league that plans to begin play in the spring of 2009 in seven American cities. Hamm is about to strike a ball with her right foot in the navy, red and gold W.P.S. logo. The formation of the league was announced in September, with teams expected in Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles, New Jersey/New York, St. Louis and Washington. The league offices are in San Francisco.

Bobby Petrino landed his first major recruit for Arkansas — Ryan Mallett, the former Michigan quarterback. Mallett has transferred to Arkansas and will have three years of eligibility after sitting out the 2008 season. Mallett, a 6-foot-7 freshman who played in 11 games for the Wolverines, left Michigan after Rich Rodriguez replaced the retiring Lloyd Carr as the coach.

A 14-member British-Irish rowing crew set a record for rowing across the Atlantic on Thursday, when they landed in Barbados 33 days 7 hours 30 minutes after it left the Canary Islands. During the 3,000-mile crossing, its boat, La Mondiale, also became the first ocean rowing boat to travel more than 100 miles a day for nine consecutive days, according to the Ocean Rowing Society International. The crew beat the previous record — set by the same French rowboat in 1992 — by more than two days.

The seven-time Tour de France winner Lance Armstrong plans to run the Boston Marathon in April to raise money for his foundation. Armstrong, 36, qualified for Boston by completing the 2007 New York City Marathon in 2 hours 46 minutes 43 seconds, finishing in 214th place. The Boston qualifying time is 3:15 for men ages 35 to 39.In 1996, Armstrong had a diagnosis of testicular cancer that had spread to his lungs and brain. But he recovered to win the Tour from 1999 to 2005.The Lance Armstrong Foundation supports cancer research, prevention and better care for cancer survivors. Armstrong and others running for the foundation raised about $500,000 at last year’s New York City Marathon.
Stephon Marbury has decided to have surgery for bone spurs in his left ankle, and he will be out indefinitely, the Knicks said.
Americans with prostate cancer are traveling abroad for a treatment that is not approved in the United States.
If any election can prove that Southern blacks are not a monolithic voting bloc, it is the 2008 Democratic contest.
Hollywood’s movie and TV directors have agreed to a new contract with production companies in a settlement that also sends a message to striking screenwriters.
Wall Street sent Washington a message: the recession that Ben S. Bernanke said can be averted is already here.
The Republican presidential candidates moved to appeal to different types of conservative voters before the South Carolina primary.
Over the last year, illegal immigrants and their families have retreated from community life under the pressure of tougher federal and local enforcement.
BlackRock, the giant asset management firm, dodged the rocky investments that have damaged many Wall Street banks.
John Edwards said Barack Obama used Ronald Reagan “as an example of change,” with which Mr. Edwards strongly disagreed.

New York officials said that two tax preparation firms that offer high-interest loans against income-tax refunds had targeted low-income black and Hispanic families and military families in violation of antidiscrimination laws.
The Golfweek cover, featuring a noose, showed that the Golf Channel’s Kelly Tilghman comment that one way for young golfers to stop Tiger Woods is to “lynch him in a back alley” is not fading away.
Using e-mail solicitations that promise high pay US HIFU is trying to build and train a network of American urologists for its offshore prostate cancer treatments.
Justin Leonard started this season with a tie for eighth place at the Mercedes Championship and he is now in the hunt at the same tournament he won in 2005.
Secretary Gates praised allies for their work in Afghanistan, after negative comments inflamed close military partners of Washington earlier this week.
Advanced Micro Devices inched closer to profitability despite posting a huge loss as it struggled to absorb the huge cost of its acquisition of ATI Technologies.
Pressed into emergency service before the Giants thought he was ready, cornerback Geoff Pope may be the least likely participant remaining in the N.F.L. playoffs.
The departure appears to signal that Mitt Romney is ceding South Carolina to John McCain, Mike Huckabee and Fred D. Thompson.
Defense and military officials have been asked to prepare projections so that President Bush can balance troop requests for Iraq against other needs.
Merrill Lynch’s stock plummeted after it took a $16.7 billion write-down and had a $9.8 billion fourth-quarter loss.
Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees and David Wright of the Mets both play third base in New York City. They will also both be honored with Munson Awards on Feb. 5.
Authorities said at least six people have been killed in the fighting, which terrorized the city for several hours.
The city’s Campaign Finance Board imposed a stiff penalty on City Councilman Miguel Martinez because he cannot show he actually spent $27,506 that taxpayers reimbursed him.
In the aftermath of the Rich Rodriguez era at West Virginia, Bill Stewart, the head coach for about two weeks, is looking for closure, which does not seem to be in reach.
The Republican stance on immigration leaves an opening that opponents could drive a truck through.
The New York philanthropist Shelby White has ceded 10 classical antiquities from her private collection that Italy contends were looted from its soil.
On Wednesday owners of the 30 major league baseball teams voted unanimously to extend Bud Selig’s contract as commissioner by three years, through 2012.
The General Motors Corporation said Thursday that high fuel prices and declining consumer confidence would be a drag on sales this year in the United States.
GENEVA (AP) — The Swiss pharmaceutical maker Novartis said on Thursday that its profit dropped 45 percent in the fourth quarter, citing revamping costs and a weak performance in the United States.
Before the 2006 season, Charles Woodson landed with the Green Bay Packers, the one team he did not want to play for. But the move has worked out far better than expected.
Mayor Michael Bloomberg has earned the right to preach at least a little optimism in the annual State of the City speech.
Just days after being told that milk and meat from cloned livestock were safe for human consumption, Europeans were warned that cloning causes suffering to the animals.

Eight people were injured on Thursday in a crash in Laurelton involving a United States Postal Service tractor-trailer, a taxicab and a fire engine responding to an emergency, the Fire Department said. The injured, five firefighters and three civilians, were taken to area hospitals. The Fire Department said the accident, which occurred about 3:15 p.m. at 225th Street and Conduit Avenue, was under investigation. The truck driver, who was not identified, was in critical condition Thursday evening, the police said. The injuries to the firefighters and the other civilians were said not to be life-threatening.

A Queens man has been charged with shouting racial slurs before severely beating a Sikh man in New Hyde Park, prosecutors said on Thursday. The man, David C. Wood, 36, of 263rd Street, was arraigned in Criminal Court on Wednesday evening on charges of second-degree assault as a hate crime and aggravated harassment, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Prosecutors charged that the Sikh man, Chadha Bajeet, 63, had just parked his car on 95th Avenue on Monday when Mr. Wood shouted, “Arab, go back to your country!” and punched him in the face, breaking his nose and jaw.

A man arrested in connection with the killing of a 34-year-old orthodontist in Queens was arraigned on murder charges in State Supreme Court on Thursday, prosecutors said. The man, Mikhail Mallayev, 50, an immigrant from Uzbekistan who has a family tie to the victim’s widow, has been charged with killing the orthodontist, Dr. Daniel Malakov, on Oct. 28 at a Queens playground. Michael Siff, Mr. Mallayev’s lawyer, said his client pleaded not guilty. The killing occurred as Dr. Malakov’s estranged wife, Dr. Mazoltuv Borukhova, and their daughter, Michelle, 4, looked on, the police said. In a statement on Thursday, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said Mr. Mallayev was “acting in concert with another person” when he shot Dr. Malakov twice in the chest. But he did not identify the second suspect and did not elaborate.

A late-night fire tore through a two-story home in western New York on Wednesday, killing two children, their mother and grandmother, officials said on Thursday. The fire was in the town of Ridgeway, about 35 miles northeast of Buffalo. The victims were April Hausler, 31; her daughter, Dawn, 7; her son, James, 10; and her mother, Anna Monagan, 56, Orleans County sheriff’s officials said. The fire did not appear to be suspicious, fire officials said. Ms. Hausler’s husband, David, is a truck driver and was on the road when the fire occurred.

Federal aviation officials are investigating what they described as an error by an air traffic controller that put two planes landing at Newark Liberty International Airport within 600 feet of each other on Wednesday. The minimum vertical separation allowed for flights landing at the airport is 1,000 feet, according to Federal Aviation Administration officials and air traffic controllers. “This was a very difficult and dangerous situation,” said Ray Adams, vice president of the air traffic controllers’ union at the airport. According to Jim Peters, an F.A.A. spokesman, the error occurred when an air traffic controller mistakenly gave one of the planes the frequency for the tower at nearby Teterboro Airport. As a result, the Newark tower was temporarily unable to contact the crew as both planes approached Newark. Compiled by John Sullivan.
Mr. Knerr produced products that for two decades virtually defined frivolity in postwar America, from the Hula Hoop to the Frisbee to the SuperBall.

The United States Labor Department announced on Thursday that two Bronx carwashes, Tremont Car Wash and Webster Car Wash, and their corporate president had agreed to pay $707,298 in back wages and damages to 237 employees. The department’s investigators found that many carwash employees were required to work more than 70 hours a week without being paid the federal minimum wage or time and a half for overtime. The department said the carwashes had also failed to maintain adequate and accurate records. Judge Barbara Jones of Federal District Court in Manhattan said that if the carwashes failed to make the payments, she would appoint a receiver to seize and liquidate their assets to satisfy the order.
Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers said his sprained right knee felt good, but the training staff decided to keep him out of practice at least one more day.

In a sign that local governments are growing impatient with Washington’s approach to solving environmental problems, New York City and three states on Thursday joined environmental advocacy groups in suing the Bush administration over new standards for gas furnaces and other home heating appliances. In a lawsuit filed in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, the City Law Department, along with the States of New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts, argued that the efficiency standards set in November by the federal Energy Department were far too weak to significantly cut carbon dioxide emissions or to help lower home heating costs, which have hit people in the Northeast especially hard.
With roaring growth expected to continue this year, Macao is poised to overtake all of Nevada as the biggest gambling territory in the world.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg revealed crime measures and praised immigration at his State of the City address.
Prosecutors in the Nixzmary Brown trial showed jurors items that were found in the room where the child died, entering them into evidence.
A judge unsuccessfully sought to have the Pakistani American, a minority rights campaigner, taken to the hospital as he risked losing his sight.
McDonald’s has decided to stop sponsoring Happy Meals as rewards for children with good grades and attendance records in elementary schools in Seminole County, Fla.
Escalating political tension has made the Pakistani city  a target of Islamic militants from nearby tribal areas.
NYSE Euronext said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the American Stock Exchange for $260 million in stock.
Washington Mutual, the savings and loan, said on Thursday that it had swung to a $1.87 billion loss in the fourth quarter, hurt badly by the sinking value of its mortgage portfolio.
Scientists at a small biotechnology company say they have used cloning to create human embryos from the skin cells of two men.
The man behind the New Jersey Performing Arts Center now wants to bring downtown Newark its first new residential construction in at least four decades.
Continental Airlines Inc. reported strong traffic, helping it cope with rising jet fuel prices.
A Texas Supreme Court justice and his wife were charged on Thursday in an arson fire that destroyed their suburban Houston home last June.
The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that it “strongly recommends” that over-the-counter cold remedies not be used in children under 2.
A group of former patients of New Orleans’s shuttered public hospital filed a lawsuit saying that medical care for the poor is still woefully inadequate in the city.
Amtrak and nine of its unions have reached a tentative contract agreement, according to industry experts, and plan to announce the settlement on Friday.
In an unusual public acknowledgment, Chinese officials said that pollution and water-quality problems had become the biggest challenges facing China’s fish farming.
Pennsylvania’s Agriculture Department has backed off its plan to ban milk-container labels stating that the milk comes from cows not treated with bovine growth hormone.
Investors responded by bidding I.B.M. shares above $106 in after-hours trading.
The nation’s fourth-largest coal producer, the Massey Energy Company, was fined $20 million for a pollution violation under the Clean Water Act.
American Apparel, known for its tight-fitting jersey T-shirts and brazen attitude, is getting political, running an ad campaign for immigration reform.
New-home construction fell again in December as builders scrambled to cut back in the face of rising inventories and fewer orders.
Michael Hirschorn is leaving VH-1 to form his own production company, which will develop shows initially for that channel and others owned by MTV Networks.
New Jersey’s attorney general has begun investigating whether the biotechnology giant violated patient confidentiality laws in its effort to sell its drug Enbrel.
Roger Clemens has hired a powerhouse Washington lawyer, Lanny A. Breuer, who represented former President Clinton during his impeachment hearings.
Perhaps the N.F.L.’s most anonymous starting running back, Laurence Maroney has existed on the margins of New England’s potent offense.
Sandra E. Timmons’s mission is to identify, cultivate, and help educate future Barack Obamas when they are adolescents.
An unprecedented surge in immigration applications last summer means legal immigrants will have to wait much longer during the next two years to receive visas or naturalization papers.
A forgotten space used for storage at San Quentin was identified as a 19th-century dungeon and what is believed to be the oldest surviving building constructed by the state.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled a mix of tough education and anticrime measures while warmly embracing the virtues of immigration on Thursday at his annual State of the City address.
Mr. Otis, a songwriter and record producer, was one of the first black executives at a major record company.
The state has an unusually high number of people with no health insurance, doctors are hard to come by and safety nets are eroding.
Shares of two bond insurers, MBIA Inc. and the Ambac Financial Group, fell sharply on concern they would lose their AAA credit ratings.
The former N.H.L. player Rob Ramage was sentenced for a 2003 car crash that killed the ex-Chicago Blackhawks player Keith Magnuson.
The question of whether prosthetic limbs confer an advantage over able-bodied runners remains shrouded in confusion.
A baby sitter who told the police that she tied a toddler in a sleeping bag and ran through her apartment with him slung over her shoulder as part of a game was charged with murder.
A requirement that students pass a series of state exams before being allowed to graduate from Pennsylvania’s public high schools was unanimously approved by the State Board of Education.
Scientists have discovered a previously unknown virus and strongly linked it with the most aggressive form of skin cancer.
Regulation and oversight has not kept pace with the development of new genetic tests and efforts to sell them directly to consumers.
Rudolph W.  Giuliani and his consulting company were part owners of a start-up company that says it has developed a sensor capable of monitoring illegal border crossings.
In reaction to the latest surge of violence, which started after an Israeli military operation on Tuesday, the Israeli defense minister ordered the closing of the border with Gaza.
An international team of scientists found evidence that Polynesians and Micronesians were more closely related to East Asians, and had few links to western Pacific islanders.
Lehman Brothers Holdings will cease wholesale mortgage lending in the United States, a move that includes 1,300 job cuts.

Some are challenging earlier ideas about how water naturally flows because the streams studied then were not “natural archetypes” but rather the artifacts of 18th and 19th century dam-building and deforestation.

Long associated with EMI, the Rolling Stones have signed an exclusive recording agreement to release their next album — the soundtrack for Martin Scorsese’s documentary concert film “Shine a Light” — through Universal Music Group, The Associated Press reported. The album is scheduled for March. The announcement prompted speculation that after 16 years the band could part ways with EMI, which has changed ownership and plans to cut as many as 2,000 jobs. Radiohead and Paul McCartney have already left the label. EMI, pointing out that Universal Music is affiliated with Universal Pictures, producers of the film, said its relationship with the Stones would be unaffected.

Charlie Rose, the PBS interviewer, will moonlight as a contributor to the CBS newsmagazine “60 Minutes” beginning this season, the network announced Thursday. Mr. Rose is expected to provide several reports each season for the program. He served as a correspondent for the spinoff series “60 Minutes II” for six years until it was canceled in 2005. “It will be great to have Charlie working with us again,” Jeff Fager, the executive producer of “60 Minutes,” said in a statement. “His considerable talents will make our all-star team even better.” Mr. Rose will continue to produce and be the host of his long-running public television series.

UMANS--Donald. A man who enjoyed his life more than anybody, died January 15, 2008 after a courageous five year battle with pancreatic cancer. Successful business man, loving father and husband and eternal optimist, he is survived by his wife, Victoria, sons, Cliff, Allan and Andrew, and sister Susan, in loving memory.

A. A. BRONSON'S SCHOOL FOR YOUNG SHAMANS Some group shows, like this one organized by A. A. Bronson, feel atmospherically of a piece. Mr. Bronson is the surviving member of General Idea, a group of three artists and lovers who were together from 1969 to 1994. Since his partners, Jorge Zontal and Felix Partz, died of AIDS in the 1990s, Mr. Bronson has worked alone, but not really alone. As an artist, mentor of artists, healer and gay role model, he remains, in one way or another, a collaborator. That's what this rich show is about. Photographs in the front room form a recap of Mr. Bronson's creative life so far, from nude self-portraits made in 1969, to a General Idea poster, to a 2001 portrait of his current partner, the architect Mark Jan Krayenhoff de Leur. (Above, ''Self Portrait, August 2, 2007.'')

MARKET PLUNGES The stock market plunged again, falling 3 percent on bad economic news. Investors took little comfort from reassuring words by the chairman of Federal Reserve or an emerging consensus from President Bush and Democrats in Congress about a stimulus plan that many worry could be too late. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 300 points, capping a 15 percent free fall from its all-time high in October. The Standard & Poor's 500 index has had the worst start to a year since records began. [C1.]

A new element of instability shook Italy's government as the justice minister, Clemente Mastella, resigning over corruption allegations against him and his wife, withdrew his small party from the already fragile center-left governing coalition. He did not seem intent on immediately bringing down the government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi, who now holds just a one-seat majority in the Senate. Mr. Mastella, left, said he would use his crucial three Senate seats largely to support Mr. Prodi, even if outside the coalition. But amid much tension in a government nearly two years old, political experts said Mr. Mastella's withdrawal weakened a loyalty to Mr. Prodi that was never absolute anyway -- signaling that a full-bore crisis may not be far off. Underscoring the unsteady state of affairs, Mr. Mastella, who leads a small Christian Democratic party that has also supported the center-right, said he would pledge his votes only case by case. ''We will be demanding, not like before when we accepted compromises,'' he said. Mr. Prodi, who said he would temporarily serve as justice minister, had asked Mr. Mastella to reconsider his resignation when he originally tendered it on Wednesday after his wife was put under house arrest. Mr. Mastella said Thursday that he would step down so he could face any charges ''like a common citizen before the law.''

FRAME--Dr. John D., died at home on January 16, 2008 at the age of 90, beloved husband of Veronica Foldes for 45 years, father of David Frame, Sally Kazaks, and Deborah Frame Smith, brother of Charles, who predeceased him, and Jeanette Gottlieb of Chicago, and half brother of Margie Frame, and beloved stepfather to Matthew Erdelyi and a loving extended family. Born in Resht, Iran of Presbyterian medical missionary parents, he also served there as a missionary doctor in Hamadan. He was associated with St. Luke's Hospital, Manhattan, and retired as clinical professor emeritus from Tropical Medicine Division in the Public Health School of Columbia University. He also was medical director of the National Council of Churches of Christ, and several non-denominational mission societies. During World War II he served in Europe with the U.S. Army. He was co-discoverer of Lassa fever in West Africa. Funeral services are Saturday, January 19, at 9:30am at the First Presbyterian Church of Forest Hills, 70-35 112th Street, Forest Hills, NY 11375. Viewing Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, Friday 2-4 and 79pm. Donations may be made to the church in his memory.

RICKEL--Alvin Milton, founder and President of Rickel Home Centers died January 15th, 2008 at the age of 90. After serving in the Army Air Corps during World War II, he and his brothers, Bob and Mort, opened the first Rickel Home Center, in Union, NJ. with a G.I. loan. Rickel Home Centers swiftly became the first ''Do it Yourself'' plumbing, heating, electrical and hardware retailer in the United States, paving the way for today's industry giants, Home Depot and Lowe's. Throughout the 1960s Rickel Home Centers experienced tremendous growth, opening stores throughout New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut touting their slogan ''Do It Better With Rickel.'' In 1969, the business was purchased by Supermarkets General Corp., the parent company of Pathmark. Mr. Rickel is best remembered as a generous soul, providing for family and friends. His vast capacity to love and be loved was infectious and will be carried on by generations to come. Alvin M. Rickel was born in Cleveland, raised in Newark, lived in Maplewood and moved to Short Hills in 1959. He is survived by his wife of 62 years Ailene, children Kyle and Tom Einhorn and Stephanie and Larry Rickel, grandchildren Emily and Lewis Liebert, Joshua, Lindsay and Zachary, brother Robert and sister Miriam. A leader in his community, Rickel served on the board of trustees of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, Short Hills. For additional information, please call ''Bernheim-ApterKreitzman'' at 1-800-938-6372.

HANSON--Carl Thor, Vice Admiral, USN (Ret.), born in Amarillo, Texas May 7, 1928 and raised in Tucson, Arizona, graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1950 and subsequently attended Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar, receiving a Master of Arts in Philosophy, Politics and Economics. His 36 year Naval Career included many assignments at sea, among them commands of a minesweeper, a destroyer, a Cruiser Destroyer Group and an Attack Carrier Battle Group. His senior shore assignments were as Naval Aide and Executive Assistant to the Secretary of the Navy, Commanding Officer of U.S. Naval Station Pearl Harbor, Chief of Naval Mission to Brazil, Executive Assistant to the Secretary of Defense and Director Joint Staff, Organization of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. On retirement from the Navy in 1982, he served as Military Analyst for Cable News Network prior to becoming President and CEO of The National Multiple Sclerosis Society. He served on several Boards of Directors including the National Association for Research in Schizophrenia and Depression, Research! America, AUSA Life Insurance Company, Tucson Boys Chorus and The Empire Ranch Foundation. He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, The Century Association, the New York Yacht Club and the Orient Yacht Club. His decorations include the Defense Distinguished Service Medal with Oak Leaf Cluster, the Legion of Merit, the Bronze Star with Combat V, the Vietnam Navy Distinguished Service Medal and the Brazilian Navy Order of Merit. In 2004 Admiral Hanson moved to Arizona. He is survived by his wife Charlotte Edens Hanson and their five children, Inge Pierce-Jones of Cardiff, Wales, Erica Hanson of Los Angeles, CA, Lars Hanson of NYC, NY, Ivor Hanson of the Solomon Islands, Ursula Friedlander of Portland, ME. Donations can be made to Sarver Heart Center, University Medical Center 1501 N. Campbell Ave., Tucson, AZ 85724-5037.

PANORAMAS OF THE MOVING IMAGE Wonder and beauty are the ruling deities in the Titus Lobby Galleries of the Museum of Modern Art, where artifacts from persistence-of-vision toys and a video installation of magic-lantern slides are on view. Here are the intricately colored discs and paper strips of images that needed only devices like a zoetrope or phenakistiscope to become animated spectacles: a horse will jump through a hoop; a sailor will blow a bubble that becomes the moon. Magic-lantern slides are among the oldest of these technologies, and they form the basis of the exhibition's centerpiece, ''Panoramas of the Moving Image,'' a video installation by the experimental filmmaker Ernie Gehr. Made up of synchronized loops of animated slides (an example is above), lined up five across, like a panorama, the 15-minute piece is a hypnotic reminder of cinema's nonnarrative origins. The creation of ''Panoramas'' was an appropriately low-tech, one-man job, Mr. Gehr said on a recent morning at MoMA: He turned on a camera and, using only natural daylight, filmed the slides as he manipulated their brass mechanisms. The far left panel of ''Panoramas'' demonstrates how the mechanisms work, while the others cycle through slides with simple movement (a ghostly spirit comes out of a cauldron); dissolving views (a snowy night scene becomes day); eccentric motion (a ship and waves move at a rhythm different from the background's); and chromatropes (colors change kaleidoscopically).

BOWERS--Malcolm Baker, Jr., M.D. beloved husband of Natalie (Natasha) deLeuchtenberg Bowers, M.D., died Sunday, January 13, 2008 at his residence, 17 Yowago Avenue, Branford, Connecticut. He was born September 1, 1933, in Dallas, Texas, son of Malcolm Baker Bowers, Sr. and Virginia Lovejoy Bowers. He grew up in Dallas, attending Highland Park High School where he was valedictorian. He graduated Summa Cum Laude in philosophy from Southern Methodist University in 1954 where he was a member of the varsity football team and Phi Beta Kappa. He received his M.D. degree from Washington University in St. Louis in 1958 and completed his internship at Fitzsimons General Hospital in Denver. He served in the Army, 1959-1962, at Edgewood Arsenal in Maryland where he was acting chief of the Clinical Investigative Branch of the Directorate of Medical Research. He completed his residency in psychiatry and postdoctoral fellowships in basic science and psychopharmacology at the Yale School of Medicine, joining the faculty as Assistant Professor of Psychiatry in 1965. He conducted groundbreaking studies on hallucinogenic exposure and the emergence of psychotic disorders and studied the effect of monoamine biology in psychosis and affective disorders. He was the founding Clinical Chief of the Research Unit at the Connecticut Mental Health Center, chief of psychiatry at Yale-New Haven Hospital (1973-1986), and director of the department's residency training program (1986-1990). He was promoted to Professor of Psychiatry in 1976. A creative and resourceful investigator, he became a master clinician and was recognized as one of the great experts in psychopharmacology within the department. He served on numerous editorial boards and was the recipient of many professional honors including the Stephen Fleck, M.D. Award (Yale University), and the Yale Psychiatric Alumni Association Distinguished Alumni Award. He was the author of several books on the impact of mental illness on the lives of patients. As a senior member of the department, he served as an exemplary role model for younger clinicians by demonstrating that it was possible to provide outstanding, individualized continuity of care, in spite of the administrative con straints imposed by evolving systems of care. He was an outstanding teacher, inspiring residents to establish a clinical teaching colloquium in his honor. He retired from the department in 2002 as an Emeritus Professor of Psychiatry. Until his medical leave of absence in the fall of 2007, he was a senior research scientist and continued to work tirelessly on behalf of his patients, trainees and mental health colleagues. During his 45-year career at Yale, he touched many lives and contributed greatly to the advancement of science, clinical practice and psychiatric training. He is survived by his wife Natasha, children Stephen Malcolm, Andrea Lee, Robert Sloan, Alexandra (Sasha) Anna, Nadia Lovejoy, grandchildren Rosalee Fae, Ian Malcolm, Rebecca Frances and Tea Lovejoy, brother William Bowers, M.D. and sisters Arden Showalter and Carol Menkiti. Memorial services will take place on Saturday, January 19, at 11am at the First Congregational Church, 1009 Main Street, Branford, CT. Memorials for the Malcolm Bowers, Jr. Teaching Fund may be made out to Yale University and mailed to the Department of Psychiatry, c/o Connie Ferguson, Yale School of Medicine, 300 George St, New Haven, CT 06511. Memorials may also be sent to Fellowship Place, 441 Elm Street, New Haven, CT 06511.

RIKLIS--Judith Stern, a proud daughter of Israel, died January 15 in New York City where she lived. She was born 83 years ago to one of Tel Aviv's early families. Her grandfather was Aharon-Zelig Krinkin, an emigrant from Czarist Russia, who established one of Tel Avivs first pharmacies. (The phone number was ''23''.) Judith was raised in Tel Aviv and graduated from the Gymnasia Herzliya, the first school in what was then Palestine to teach exclusively in Hebrew. It was there that she met her future husband, Meshulam Riklis, the Israeli-American financier and philanthropist. With him and their first-born, the couple went to America to attend college. They settled for a time in Minneapolis where both Judith and Meshulam taught Hebrew school and Meshulam worked also as a stock broker. The couple eventually moved to the New York area where Judith raised her three children, Mona Ackerman, Marcia Riklis and Ira D. Riklis. After the Riklis marriage ended in divorce, Judith maintained homes in both New York and Jerusalem with Isaac Moyal, her companion until his death. Judith took a passionate interest in the Jewish state, contributing to many charities, including the Hadassah Hospital, the Bat Sheva dance troupe and the Soldiers Welfare Association. A building on the Mount Scopus campus of the Hebrew University is named for her. Judith was a warm woman, devoted to her family. She loved and supported the arts and had a keen eye for painting. In addition to her children and her daughter-inlaw, Diana Riklis, Judith is survived by six grandchildren, Ari Ackerman, Gila (and Roy) Steinbock, Jordana (and Ben) Cooperberg, Talia (and Andrew) Day, Daniella Hirschfeld and David Hirschfeld; four great - grandchildren, Layla, Ayelet, Leo and Leora. The funeral will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Avenue, at 11:45am, Thursday January 17. The family will sit Shiva at the Riklis home, 936 Fifth Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations will be greatly appreciated to American Friends of the Tel Aviv Foundation. RIKLIS--Judith. Park East Synagogue and Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School mourn the passing of our devoted member Judith Riklis, beloved matriarch of the Riklis family, mother of our dedicated member and benefactor Ira (Diana) Riklis, Mona Ackerman, Marcia Riklis, grandmother and great-grandmother. To them and the entire family our deepest sympathy. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President RIKLIS--Judith Stern. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our beloved friend and family member, Judith Stern Riklis. Our hearts go out to Mona, Marcia, Ira and Diana, Ari, Gila, Jordana, Talia, Daniella and David. Linda, Michael, Samuel, Roni, Jonathan and Maya Jesselson RIKLIS--Judith Stern. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our beloved friend and family member, Judith Stern Riklis. Our hearts go out to Mona, Marcia, Ira and Diana, Ari, Gila, Jordana, Talia, Daniella and David. Lee and Egon Rausnitz RIKLIS--Judith. The Board of Trustees of the Israel Cancer Research Fund expresses deepest sympathy to Dr. Mona Ackerman upon the loss of her mother, Judith. Passionate and charitable in her commitment to Jewish life both here and in Israel, Mrs. Riklis will be greatly missed by all who had the privilege of knowing her. We extend sincerest condolences to Dr. Ackerman, her family and the families of Marcia Riklis and Ira Riklis. Harriet Elisofon, President Dr. Yashar Hirshaut, Chairman Mitch Orlik, Chief Professional Officer RIKLISJUDIT ST#

McINTYRE--Randall P., 83, Oyster Bay Cove, NY, died Thursday, January 10, after a brief illness. An advertising executive and amateur pilot, McIntyre was a life-long resident of Long Island. He was President of O.E. McIntyre, a direct mail supplier in Westbury, NY. He later served as President of McIntyre and Dodd Marketing in Montreal and Toronto. He served as chairman of the board of trustees of Adelphi University and as Adelphi's acting president in 1971-1972. McIntyre is survived by a daughter, Virginia McIntyre of Concord, MA; a son, Mark P. McIntyre of Brooklyn, NY; a son, Archie McIntyre, of Winchester, MA; a brother, Angus P. McIntyre, of Oyster Bay Cove; a sister, Sally Lewis, of Santa Barbara, CA; and seven grandchildren. He was predeceased by his late wife, Helen Pond McIntyre in 2002. A service will be held February 23rd at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, NY. Donations may be made to the McIntyre Fund, a scholarship fund McIntyre established at the Philips Exeter Academy, Exeter, NH.

KEVIN LOCKE NATIVE DANCE ENSEMBLE Tap is honored as a great American dance tradition, and rightly so, but it isn't the only one to develop on North American soil. On Saturday several indigenous forms will be celebrated at Symphony Space, when the Kevin Locke Native Dance Ensemble performs American Indian dances like the Hoop and the Eagle during the program ''The Dream Is the Thunder, the Flute Is the Wind.'' Mr. Locke's Lakota name is Tokeya Inajin, meaning ''the First to Arise,'' fitting for an expert practitioner of the Hoop dance, right, a tradition among Plains Indians and a celebration of nature's rebirth each spring. When performing the acrobatic Lakota version of the dance, Mr. Locke works with 28 hoops of wood or reed (each represents a day in the lunar cycle) while he sings to the accompaniment of powwow drums and ancient flute melodies.

(Sundance) A GUIDE TO RECOGNIZING YOUR SAINTS (2006) A writer thinks back on his childhood in a rough neighborhood in Astoria, Queens, in this coming-of-age drama from Dito Montiel, based on his memoir. Shia LaBeouf, above, plays the artist as a young man who dreams of flight with his new best friend, Mike (Martin Compston); Robert Downey Jr. is Dito as a grown-up. ''What sets the film apart, and makes it one of the more remarkable American directing debuts in recent years, is Mr. Montiel's passionate, almost reckless engagement with the possibilities of the medium,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Working with a large, mostly young cast, he has made a picture so full of life and feeling that the screen can hardly contain it.'' 7:30 P.M. MAVIS STAPLES The civil rights movement never ended for Mavis Staples, who has been politicizing gospel music since her days as the teenage lead singer of the Staple Singers. That group's best-remembered songs, including ''I'll Take You There,'' a No. 1 hit in 1972, preached hope and tolerance amid racism and injustice. The Staple Singers traveled and performed with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and when Dr. King was assassinated in 1968, they released the song ''Long Walk to D.C.'' as a memorial. Now a husky-voiced 68, Ms. Staples, above, is as powerful a singer as ever, and she has never taken her eyes off the prize. Her latest album, ''We'll Never Turn Back'' (Anti-), is a gorgeous and determined collection of ''freedom songs'' -- classic protest and inspirational material -- like ''This Little Light of Mine'' and ''I'll Be Rested,'' reworked with gritty funk. Hope remains the central message, but her anger is palpable in ''99 and 1/2,'' which she updates with references to Hurricane Katrina: ''It's the 21st century/It feels like it's 1960/Broken levees, lying politicians.''

Born on October 3, 1927 to Robert Graham Heiner and Frances Eliot Cassidy, he attended St. Bernard's School in Manhattan, Harvard University, Yale University and the School of Medicine of the University of Paris. He is survived by his stepdaughter Clarita Ricketts, his loving grandchildren Linda W. Jackson of Sherwood Forest, MD and Michael Ricketts of Annapolis, MD, and three great-grandchildren. Visitation will be held on Friday, January 18, 2008 at The Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th Street, NYC from 7pm to 9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10am on Saturday, January 19, 2008 at The Church of Our Saviour, 59 Park Avenue, NYC. Interment to follow in the Heiner family plot at The Memorial Cemetery of the Church of St. John, Laurel Hollow, NY. Funeral services entrusted to Josephine M. Dimiceli, Dimiceli & Sons.

My Sunday column looks at the accusations that Barack Obama lacks the experience to be a strong president. I argue that the value of traditional Washington experience is overrated as a prerequisite for the presidency: Experience itself is useful, but that includes unorthodox kinds such as growing up in Indonesia. And history suggests that governors often make better presidents than senators, because they gain executive experience. Please post your comments here.

The season of Rangers defenseman Marek Malik might have hit a nadir in Saturday afternoon's loss to Boston. Last night, the Bagger went to Reaction Lounge on Main St. for the after-party for "Transsiberian," the Brad Anderson directed psycho-thriller. There was a bit of a flow problem in the middle of the room at a narrow hallway near the stars - Emily Mortimer and Woody Harrelson. The Bagger wanted to pay his respects, but a large man on a cell phone was using his backside to push the him away, and a seated woman, who was now being stepped on by the Bagger, began pummeling his lower back with fists. He could not move. Just then, a young woman who was also pinned in front of him, managed to get out a business card and slime the Bagger, saying she had a client that she'd like him to speak to. If the Bagger had a grenade on him at that instant, he would have pulled the pin.
Random balls of lint in the Bagger's notebook: A teeny little dog wearing homemade booties prancing up Main St., who was being follow by an improbably tall woman who was also prancing.

Emily Mortimer, the winsome, friendly star of "Transsiberian," told the audience at the premiere that the film, the result of an arduous, vodka-infused shoot with Sir Ben Kingsley and Woody Harrelson, was the best set she had ever been on. The Bagger reminded her that she had said the same thing about "Lars and the Real Girl," another movie that benefited from her talents. "But I really was being sincere this time," she said, managing not to bat her eyes. "I love these guys."

"Sunshine Cleaning" was a tidy, crowd-pleasing hit, with much of main street bubbling about its charms. IndieWire liked it a bunch, calling it "an affecting, well-acted drama that casts an even brighter spotlight on rising starlet Amy Adams." At the party afterwards, Harvey Weinstein was out front, chatting about the film -- the Bagger did not lean in, so shame on him -- and inside Marc Turtletaub was not gloating, but you could tell he knew he had a winner on his hands. Look for the film, which also stars Emily Blunt, to be part of the story of movies that got a nice start at Sundance.

Branding is a constant at Sundance. Everything is brought to you by someone. In the MySpace Celebrity Lounge at the bottom of the chair in Park City, there was a nice place to check e-mail messages and get some vittles. Even though the Bagger is a few rungs belong a celebrity - he doesn't even write about them that much - Lisette, who runs the joint, let him and his camera crew in for a latte and a warm-up. The Bagger was enjoying the high life for the moment, sipping the froth of another galaxy, and then he noticed that both the ketchup and the mustard were branded. My Space Ketchup and My Space Mustard. Rupert Murdoch, chieftain of MySpace owner News Corporation, is clearly at the top of his game, grabbing every opportunity to remind the rest of us that there is not much that he won't eventually own, including the condiments of life. Now, you want fries with that?

An inmate charged in nine killings in four states in the 1970s and 1980s pleaded guilty to stabbing and strangling a woman in 1978 in the Southern Illinois town of Marion. The inmate, Timothy Krajcir, was sentenced to 40 years in prison in the death of the woman, Virginia Lee Witte, whom he admitted singling out after seeing her driving. Mr. Krajcir, 63, said in a videotaped confession that he had followed Ms. Witte home and sexually assaulted her. He said he choked her but was not sure she was dead, so he stabbed her as well. The authorities say Mr. Krajcir’s confessions to killing Ms. Witte and eight other women were given in exchange for assurances that he would not face the death penalty. Mr. Krajcir will next be prosecuted in Cape Girardeau County, Mo., where he was charged last month in the killings of five women.

Carbon monoxide fumes killed a hotel guest and sickened four others after a construction canopy blocked venting from the building’s water heaters, officials said. Levels of the gas were so high that rescuers were forced to retreat until the hotel, the Best Western Allentown Inn and Suites, could be ventilated. The dead hotel guest was identified as Philip D. Prechtel, 63, of Hilton Head Island, S.C. Four guests were taken to a hospital, said Pete Nickischer, a Berks-Lehigh Regional Police spokesman. Five emergency workers were also taken to the hospital as a precaution.

A Detroit jury convicted a 911 operator of willful neglect of duty after the authorities said she did not take seriously a boy’s calls to report that his mother had collapsed. The misdemeanor charge against the operator, Sharon Nichols, is punishable by up to a year in jail. She will be sentenced March 11. Ms. Nichols, 45, testified that she could not hear the boy on the other end of the line. The authorities said the boy, Robert Turner, now 7, called 911 twice on Feb. 20, 2006, to report that his mother had passed out. Robert testified that Ms. Nichols accused him of playing games and hung up on him. The police found Robert’s mother, Sherrill Turner, 46, dead three hours after the first call. Charges were dismissed against another operator, Terri Sutton, who took the boy’s second call.

One man arrested in the killings of two police officers in Decatur was cleared of involvement, and a fourth man was in custody, the authorities said. The DeKalb County police said the three suspects — Herbie D. Durham, 32; Mario O’Brian Westbrook, 31; and William M. Woodward, 26 — were arrested on warrants charging them each with two counts of murder. Officers Ricky Bryant Jr., 26, and Eric Barker, 33, were killed Wednesday in a parking lot at the Glenwood Gardens apartment complex in the eastern suburbs of Atlanta. The officers were wearing their uniforms and had been hired as part-time security guards.
A man carrying a shotgun outside the Capitol was arrested.
The first secretary of homeland security says waterboarding is torture.

José Valentín, a vital member of the Mets’ 2006 division champion team who missed the majority of last season because of leg injuries, agreed to a minor league deal. Valentín, 38, sustained a season-ending broken leg July 20 in Los Angeles, less than two weeks after he returned from a two-and-a-half-month absence because of a partial tear of the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee.The Mets and Aaron Heilman avoided salary arbitration by agreeing on a one-year deal worth $1.2 million. The team exchanged contract figures with the five remaining arbitration-eligible players — Endy Chávez, Ryan Church, Pedro Feliciano, Oliver Pérez and Jorge Sosa — and are still negotiating. Sosa and Pérez have requested a 2008 salary that is more than $1 million higher than what the Mets offered. Sosa asked for $2.75 million, and the Mets submitted $1.7 million; Perez asked for $6.5 million, and the Mets offered $4.725 million.

The Yankees exchanged salary arbitration figures with three players on Friday and signed another, infielder Wilson Betemit, to a one-year, $1.165 million deal.The biggest difference in figures was with second baseman Robinson Canó, who asked for $4.55 million while the Yankees offered $3.2 million. Starter Chien-Ming Wang asked for $4.6 million, $600,000 more than the Yankees’ offer; and reliever Brian Bruney asked for $845,000 while the Yankees offered $640,000. The Yankees are likely to settle with Bruney before a hearing. They believe their offer to Wang is fair, but a settlement seems possible because the figures are not far apart. Canó’s case is trickier, since the salary he is seeking would be higher than the $4.5 million earned by Justin Morneau of the Twins last season, after Morneau had won the Most Valuable Player award. The Yankees are unlikely to sign any of the players to long-term contracts, because their general policy is to make one-year deals until players reach free agency.

A father and son from Paramus, N.J., have been charged with lying to the police about a motor vehicle accident that killed a University of North Carolina student who was the mascot for the university’s basketball team. Authorities said Friday that Gagik Hovsepyan, 52, was covering for his son, Armen, 25, when he told the police last March that he was driving the car that struck the student, Jason Kendall Ray, as he was walking along Route 4 in Fort Lee. Armen Hovsepyan, whose driver’s license was suspended at the time of the accident, was actually behind the wheel, authorities say.

Michigan Coach Rich Rodriguez, who is being sued by West Virginia in an attempt to collect on a $4 million buyout clause in his old contract, received a $287,000 incentive payment from W.V.U. on Friday for goals reached during the 2007 season. Among the incentives was a one-time $150,000 payment for winning the Big East championship and receiving a Bowl Championship Series berth, and $25,000 for finishing in the top 10.

Joker Phillips, the Kentucky offensive coordinator, will eventually become the Wildcats’ coach after Rich Brooks’s retirement. Brooks, 66, has not set a timetable for his retirement, the university said. He signed a contract extension through 2011 on Friday that will pay him $1.6 million a season. Phillips would become the university’s first black head football coach.

The Colorado Rockies, hoping to lock up Matt Holliday for the long term, settled for a two-year deal with him. Holliday agreed to a two-year, $23 million contract to avoid arbitration. He hit .340 with 137 runs batted in last season, the first player since 1967 to lead the National League in both categories.
A banner week that began with victories against Detroit, Washington and the Nets — all without the injured Stephon Marbury — turned sour Friday night.
Coach Tom Coughlin said Friday the Giants spent considerable time this week revisiting their home opener against the Packers that amounted to a forgettable 35-13 defeat.
Dwyane Wade scored 37 points, and that still was not enough for the hapless Miami Heat.

Radek Dvorak and David Booth scored 1 minutes 17 seconds apart early in the third period and the backup goalie Craig Anderson made 31 saves Friday night for the Florida Panthers in a 2-1 victory over the Devils in Newark.

An article in The Arts on Thursday about cultural groups in England that face funding cuts from the government-financed Arts Council England included a quotation from Louise Wylie, the council’s director of media relations, that misstated the plans of the Bush Theater in West London, which faces a cut. The theater, in fact, does not plan to scale back productions in the next three years.

An article on Tuesday about plans by the federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency to deport immigrants convicted of crimes misstated how soon the agency would complete some deportations. Although the agency expects to start deportation proceedings this year against more than 200,000 immigrants serving criminal sentences in prisons and jails, the individuals will be removed when they complete their terms — not necessarily in 2008.

An article on Jan. 3 about the death, apparently by suicide, of Rudolph Zurick, a corrections officer at the Union County Jail in Elizabeth, N.J., who had been mocked in a note left by two escaping inmates, Jose Espinosa and Otis Blunt, misstated Mr. Blunt’s age. He is 33, not 32; he was 32 at the time of his escape. (The error was repeated in related articles on Jan. 8 and Jan. 9.).
A court in Palermo convicted the governor of Sicily of helping a Mafia boss by providing him with confidential investigator’s information.
India’s third outbreak of avian flu among poultry is the worst it has faced, the World Health Organization said.

A Week in Review article on Jan. 6 about Pakistan’s history of difficulty in sustaining democracy misidentified the military leader under whom Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who would later become prime minister, served as foreign minister in the 1960s. The leader was Gen. Ayub Khan, not Gen. Yahya Khan. The article also misstated the timing of the disputed parliamentary election that left Mr. Bhutto in a position to emerge from a civil war in 1971 as the first civilian head of government of a truncated Pakistan. The election was held before the war in 1970, not after the war.
A convicted killer released early from prison has been appointed to a high-level government post in southern Russia.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the thriving illegal trade in fish to Europe included an incorrect conversion from euros to dollars for the value of the European market for fish. It is worth more than 14 billion euros a year, or about $20.6 billion — not $22 billion.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about some New Yorkers’ recollections of the city’s more violent past, prompted by a knife fight during a mugging in Harlem, referred imprecisely in some editions to state statutes concerning the possession of knives. Although the state classifies possession of any “dangerous” knife as a crime provided there is intent to use it, it does not address the length of the blade. (Under city law, it is legal to carry knives with blades shorter than four inches, except for some that are specifically outlawed, including switchblades.).

HANSON--Carl Thor , Vice Admiral, USN (Ret.), born in Amarillo, Texas May 7, 1928 and raised in Tucson, Arizona, graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1950 and subsequently attended Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar, receiving a Master of Arts in Philosophy, Politics and Economics. His 36 year Naval Career included many assignments at sea, among them commands of a minesweeper, a destroyer, a Cruiser Destroyer Group and an Attack Carrier Battle Group. His senior shore assignments were as Naval Aide and Executive Assistant to the Secretary of the Navy, Commanding Officer of U.S. Naval Station Pearl Harbor, Chief of Naval Mission to Brazil, Executive Assistant to the Secretary of Defense and Director Joint Staff, Organization of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. On retirement from the Navy in 1982, he served as Military Analyst for Cable News Network prior to becoming President and CEO of The National Multiple Sclerosis Society. He served on several Boards of Directors including the National Association for Research in Schizophrenia and Depression, Research! America, AUSA Life Insurance Company, Tucson Boys Chorus and The Empire Ranch Foundation. He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, The Century Association, the New York Yacht Club and the Orient Yacht Club. His decorations include the Defense Distinguished Service Medal with Oak Leaf Cluster, the Legion of Merit, the Bronze Star with Combat V, the Vietnam Navy Distinguished Service Medal and the Brazilian Navy Order of Merit. In 2004 Admiral Hanson moved to Arizona. He is survived by his wife Charlotte Edens Hanson and their five children, Inge Pierce-Jones of Cardiff, Wales, Erica Hanson of Los Angeles, CA, Lars Hanson of NYC, NY, Ivor Hanson of the Solomon Islands, Ursula Friedlander of Portland, ME. Donations can be made to Sarver Heart Center, University Medical Center 1501 N. Campbell Ave., Tucson, AZ 85724-5037.

Senator Barack Obama appears to be the man of the month in South Carolina, at least when it comes to the newsstands. He smiles on the covers of a number of magazines intended for African-American readers, including Jet, Black Enterprise and How We Live, a South Carolina lifestyle magazine geared to black homeowners. The pro-Obama display comes at a fortuitous time -- right before South Carolina Democrats go to the polls on Jan. 26. With blacks making up more than half of the state's Democratic electorate, it is an infusion of free media coverage for Mr. Obama in what is expected to be another tight race with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

TIGHTER CREDIT IN EUROPE The European Central Bank said that lenders had sharply tightened credit standards in response to turmoil in financial markets, meaning that less money was likely to be available to companies for investment and to consumers for purchases. The finding, from the bank's latest quarterly survey of lending conditions was the clearest sign yet that convulsing credit markets would take a bite out of growth in the euro zone, possibly leading the central bank to cut interest rates later in the year. The survey showed that 41 percent of the banks in the 15-country euro zone were imposing tougher conditions on corporate borrowers. ''The sharp tightening reflects the deterioration of financial market conditions since the start of the financial turmoil last summer and a worsening of banks' situation,'' the central bank wrote in the survey. Losses linked to subprime mortgages and volatility in financial markets have forced many banks in the United States to seek recapitalization from foreign investors. European banks, though faced with write-downs, have not been hit as hard as their American rivals. CARTER DOUGHERTY

For anyone stuck in traffic or just driving down the highway in any of four South Carolina cities on Saturday night, there will be no avoiding the results of the Republican primary: As the returns come in, they will be posted on electronic billboards. Similarly, the results of next Saturday's Democratic primary will unfold digitally before drivers' eyes. The billboards will show the top four candidates and the percentage of the vote each is getting and will flash the winner at the end.

The Supreme Court appeared to clear the way for a new elected government, dismissing a challenge to the party backed by Thaksin Shinawatra, the former prime minister whose return to the country now seems more likely. Barring any last-minute intervention by the military, Mr. Thaksin's allies in the six-party coalition dominated by the People Power Party, which won a large plurality in elections last month, will form a government next week, ending 16 months of rule by the generals who overthrew Mr. Thaksin in 2006.

Game 6 of the 1972 World Championship match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky was a turning point. After losing the first game and forfeiting the second, Fischer had stormed back to tie the match after five games. In Game 6, he played an opening that he had never played before and one that Spassky had never lost. In a masterly display, he pushed Spassky off the board, took the lead and never looked back on his way to the title.
