CAVALIERE--Mary Mirabito Livornese . Radiant and beloved mother, grandmother, great-grandmother and aunt after a short illness on January 15, 2008. Mary was 108 years old, the oldest living resident of New York City, and the second eldest in a family of 13. She was predeceased by her husbands, John B. Livornese, Thomas Cavaliere and son Thomas J. Livornese, her brother and nine sisters. She is survived by her daughter Maria Halpern Fitzgibbon, her sisters, Gladys Mirabito Zodda and Gloria Mirabito Musella, her grandsons, John Halpern, Alexander Halpern and Timothy L. Halpern; her granddaughters - in - law Katrin Roos, Caryn Horowitz and Dana Halpern; great-grandchildren Roman, Preston, and Savannah Rose, and many nieces and nephews. She has inspired us and has created a legacy that will continue to grow.

8 P.M. (Logo) BROTHER OUTSIDER: THE LIFE OF BAYARD RUSTIN (2003) Long before the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. rose to national prominence, Bayard Rustin was putting his life on the line in pursuit of racial equality. His advocacy of pacifism and Gandhian nonviolence made him a pioneer in the 1940s and, a decade later, an inspiration to Dr. King (above left, with Mr. Rustin). But because he was gay, he was also a political liability and eventually shunned within the civil rights movement. In The New York Times Elvis Mitchell wrote that this film by Nancy D. Kates ''moves through the complications of Rustin's life -- a black man who stayed out of the spotlight because he knew his homosexuality would cost the movement mainstream credibility -- like a lunar cycle, tracking all of the turbulence around him and the power of his own gravitational pull.'' 8 P.M. (TCM) PRIDE AND PREJUDICE (1940) The Jane Austen classic, directed by Robert Z. Leonard and performed to perfection by Greer Garson as Elizabeth Bennet and Laurence Olivier as Mr. Darcy.

O'CONNELL--Helen . The attorneys, staff and alumni of Snow Becker Krauss P.C. are deeply grieved by the sudden and untimely loss of our beloved friend, co-worker and office manager, Helen O'Connell. Few people are truly indispensable; Helen was one of those people. Few people leave positive indelible imprints on those they touch; Helen had that gift. Helen served the firm devotedly from its inception in 1977. She exuded an array of unique talents. Her humanity and sunny optimism formed the glue which bound the firm together through the passage of decades. Possessed of a generosity of spirit, a pervasive warmth and innate decency and integrity, she treated all with respect, and was in turn respected by all those whom she met. Quick to laugh, yet slow to anger, these were among the attributes of her mature and complex mind. Her face was open and honest, but her spine was forged steel. In her personal life, Helen took great joy from her special relationship with her beloved family, and her close bond with her pets. Deeply religious, she never wore her faith on her sleeve. We can never replace her, for we shall not see her like again. Rather, we seek to honor her memory by striving to conduct ourselves in the gracious and dignified manner in which she lived life. On behalf of our colleagues, we extend heartfelt condolences to her husband Ed, their daughter Cathy, son-in-law Doug, granddaughters Courtney, Claire and Leah, her brother John McInerney and the entire O'Connell family.

We're in that season now when we hear the same things being said over and over again, and nothing is said more often by political pundits than this election (it doesn't matter which one) will be decided by independent voters. Accompanying this announcement is the judgment - sometimes implicit, sometimes explicit - that this state of affairs is to be welcomed, even encouraged: it's good that the independent voters are making themselves heard and forcing candidates to think outside their partisan boxes. And this judgment itself implies another: independent voters are better, in the sense of being more reflective and less ideological, than voters who identify themselves strongly with one or the other of the two major parties. The assumption is that if we were all independent voters, the political process would be in much better shape.

In a village full of fish-out-of-water fables, the 50 Cent gig at Tao in Park City last night stood out. During Sundance, the toughest ticket draws the most massive crowds, and the hopefuls spilled out onto Main St., blocking traffic while trying to BlackBerry their way past the door. Those who did make it inside underwent further taxonomy: A hierarchy of wrist bands told them where they could and could not go. For the wired but unwashed who made it in to the main mosh, 50's imperative that they put their hands in the air was met with compliance, in part because there was no where else to put them. Servers had to be flanked front and back by burly security guys with winking flashlights to make their way. Smoke from tobacco and other products filled the place while toes were crushed and egos were in conflict. "I would not have given that wrist band to you if I had known you were going to be such a jerk about it," shouted one guy to another. Six cameras panned live shots, feeding back to the crowd what they already knew. They were there, they saw the thing, they had juice. "What's up, Park City?" 50 Cent shouted. Only you man, only you. (As it turns out, Fiddy might have some skin in the movie game after all.)

50 Cent was not the only must-have ducat. There was a massive crush outside the Eccles Theater at Park High for "U2 3D," a movie using the latest in 3D film technology to capture a concert in Buenos Aires. The guy next to the Bagger said that he had heard of offers of $1,000 for a $15 ticket. To a movie. The keening and posturing that went on as people tried to make their way inside brought to mind plenty of painful high school lessons about who the cool kids were. Robert Redford was there. Al Gore was there. U2? All four members were there. They entered to a huge, rock concert roar. There was a mad scramble for seats: "Does any one have a single anywhere?" The internationally recognized symbol of a saved seat at Sundance - a bulky parka left to warm the seat - lost salience as people fought to plop down somewhere and put on their specially issued 3D glasses.

The Bagger has been guided, manhandled, ushered and led the whole time he has been at Sundance. There is either something in the water spilling out of the Wasatch mountains or in the training of volunteers that leads them to feel the need to lay hands on whomever they are in proximity to. It is sort of creepy and endearing at the same time, but leaves the Bagger longing to get back to NYC, where grabbing a stranger is a social felony. But they are a relentlessly cheery lot, and according to Gregg Goldstein, their special tribal membership does have it privileges. Apparently, a few film executives tried to muscle their way into a volunteer-only screening of "Adventures of Power," a comedy starring Ari Gold and Adrian Grenier on Friday night. Goldstein said they were left cooling their heels in Friday night's 1-degree temperature. No doubt, the natural order of things will be restored soon enough and the machers will get what they want when they want it.

An article last Sunday about an analysis by a New York University food studies professor of seven Indian restaurants in the city inaccurately described the Indian state from where the professor, Krishnendu Ray, emigrated in 1989. The state, Orissa, is a neighbor to the Indian state of West Bengal; it is not part of Bengal, which is a region that comprises West Bengal and Bangladesh. The article also misidentified the cuisine of Saravanaas, a restaurant on Lexington Avenue at 26th Street. Saravanaas serves southern Indian food — not Bengali-Indian.

STEWART--Charles Thorp, of Gulf Stream, Florida, formerly of New York City and North Berwick, Scotland, died on January 19, 2008. Cause of death was a heart attack. He was born in Pittsburgh, PA on February 14, 1918. He is survived by his wife, Patricia Carry Stewart, a daughter Jenifer J. Stewart of Falmouth, ME and a son, C. Even Stewart of New York, NY, a granddaughter, Charlotte Stewart, and two brothers, George B. Stewart of Kennebunk, ME and Edwin C. Stewart of Savannah, GA. He was divorced from his first wife, the former Jenifer Barbour. He was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Cornell University and Yale Law School. He was associated with the law firm of Cravath, Swaine and Moore before becoming General Counsel of R.H. Macy and then Senior Vice President, General Counsel and a member of the Board of Directors of J.C. Penney Company, Inc. He also served on the Board of Directors of Inmont Corporation. During World War II he served first as a private in the U.S. Army and then as a lieutenant junior grade in the U.S. Navy where he was assistant counsel in the Bureau of Aeronautics and later was special assistant to the General counsel of the Navy Department. He served as a trustee of Cornell University for 20 years where he was Vice Chairman of the Board and Chairman of the Executive Committee. He chaired the Yale Law School Fund and was a visiting professor at Yale Law School and an adjunct professor of law at New York University School of Law. He was also chairman of the YMCA of Greater New York. He was a director of the Legal Aid Society in New York City and the United States Chamber of Commerce. In the 1950s he was active in the Young Republican Club of New York, serving as its Chairman in 1952. He was a member of the American Bar Association, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the American Law Institute and the American Arbitration Association as well as a Fellow of the American Bar Foundation. He was an avid curler and golfer. He belonged to the University and Cornell Clubs in New York City, The Country Club of Florida in the Village of Golf, FL, The St. Andrews Club in Delray Beach, FL, the Little Club in Gulf Stream, FL and the North Berwick Golf Club in North Berwick, Scotland. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Delray Beach on Saturday, February 9 at 2pm. Contributions may be made to Cornell University, Ithaca, NY or to Yale Law School, New Haven, CT.

HANSON--Thor. The National Multiple Sclerosis Society mourns the loss of Admiral Thor Hanson who led the organization as President and CEO between 1982-1992, after founder/ director Sylvia Lawry retired. Adm. Hanson's desire to serve was strong and after spending a little more than a third of his life serving his country, he decided to devote himself to another cause -that of ending MS. Under his leadership, the Society doubled its research budget and expanded the funds it could devote to serving people with MS by an annual rate of 10% a year. Adm. Hanson had a way of inspiring people to excel not because he ordered it but because it was just expected. The Society's condolences go out to his family. Contributions in his name can be made to the Society at www.nationalMSsociety.org

LOW TIDE AT NADA BEACH IN OITA ON THE ISLAND OF KYUSHU Shizuka Minami, 27, a photographer from Japan who splits time between her home country and Astoria, Queens. ''I was in Japan one month because I had a photo exhibition in Tokyo. My friend who took the picture, she also had an exhibition with me. After the opening, we went to Oita, which is my hometown, just to relax. I was there one week, to spend time with my family, go to the beach and drink sake, that's very important. The Nada shore is a part of the Japan Sea: it's totally mild, there are no big waves, the sand is white. This wasn't a weekend, so only us and a fisherman were there. Usually we can't go to these rocks because there's too much water, but the tide was out. It's no big deal for me to go back to Japan; I often go back. But the good thing is drinking sake and eating Japanese food with my friends. And they speak Japanese -- I think I can speak Japanese very well.'' As told to Seth Kugel

OUTPOSTS For a while, it looked as if Obama could be the rare African-American leader whose race was nearly invisible -- and he may still be. He's post-civil rights, Oprah-branded, with that classically American blend of a mother from the heartland and a father from a distant shore. And after that Iowa victory speech, people felt something had passed into our collective rear-view mirror, without actually saying what that something was. Now it looks as if every mention of race -- from the overblown dust-up with Senator Hillary Clinton to the calculated comments comparing him to Sidney Poitier -- is bad for Obama. ...He needs people to look at him and see John Kennedy, or the Beatles, or Tiger Woods in his first Master's tournament. He needs people to see youth, a break with the past, style under pressure. When they see black this or black that -- even a positive black first -- it's trouble.

MEAGHER--Robert F. Prof., expert on International Law and Development, dies at age 80. Robert F. Meagher, Professor Emeritus of International Law and Development at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, Tufts University, died in Boston on December 31, 2007 at the age of 80. Death was caused by heart failure. One of the first scholars to define the role of law in the development process, Prof. Meagher was born in New York on May 13, 1927. He graduated from City College of New York in 1949 and from Yale Law School in 1951. He also served in the Army in Germany. He joined the Wall Street law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam and Roberts in 1951. In 1957 he joined the United Nations Relief and Works Agency. He then became an Associate Professor at Columbia Law School where he taught about legal systems and economic development. In 1967, he joined the faculty of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy as a co-founder of the school's program for development studies, where he taught until retirement in 1992. Prof. Meagher was married twice and divorced. He is survived by a brother, Harold Meagher, of Chicago. Contributions can be made to the Robert F. Meagher Scholarship Fund through Tufts University.

Can You Count On These Machines? Clive Thompson's article (Jan. 6) on voting technology and election administration was superb. It very much suggests that the Help America Vote Act of 2002 actually might have worked as intended if there had been more election administrators like Ion Sancho and Jane Platten to advise Congress when HAVA was devised. HAVA offered no assistance to inadequately financed election administrators as to what kind of machine to buy. The way out of this impasse may well be the development of professional programs in elections administration at university graduate schools of public policy -- M.A. programs that would teach best-practice methods of the sort used by Sancho and Platten, as well as the history of voting technology and election administration, principles of good ballot design and the operation of open-source systems for code development.

SCHNITZER--Robert C., former actor, producer, educator and theater administrator died January 2 in Stamford, Connecticut at the age of 101. Born in New York City, he was educated at the Horace Mann School and Columbia University. He was Chairman of the Westport Arts Center upon its inception. He began his career with the Walter Hampden Company at Hampden's Theatre on Broadway. In 1935, he joined the WPA Federal Theatre Program and became Assistant to National Director Hallie Flanagan. Mr. Schnitzer volunteered with the International Red Cross during World War II and served in China. He was General Manager for Broadway producers Lawrence Langner, Cheryl Crawford, Gilbert Miller and Guthrie McClintic, for Martha Graham and for the New School's Theatre Division. In 1954 Mr. Schnitzer established the American National Theater Academy -State Department International Cultural Exchange Program. In 1961 he was invited by the President of the University of Michigan to establish a professional theatre program which became a major regional theatre center. Professor Schnitzer also served on the Smith, Vassar College and Columbia University drama faculties. He was a member of Actors Equity, ATPAM, the National Theatre Conference, International Theatre Institute, the Players Club and the Century Association. He was married to producer/ director Marcella Cisney until her death in 1989. He resided in Weston, CT and most recently at the Edgehill Retirement Community in Stamford. Contributions in lieu of flowers to The Actors Fund of America, 729 Seventh Avenue, New York, New York 10019 or The Westport Arts Center, 51 Riverside Avenue, Westport, Connecticut 06880. A memorial gathering will take place at a date to be announced. Services by Harding Funeral Home, Westport, CT.

WHEN lenders issued mortgages to anyone who asked, borrowers could largely ignore their credit scores, the most important and most incomprehensible determinant of a loan's interest rate. But now that banks have tightened their lending standards considerably, borrowers must sometimes search for ways to eke out a point or two more on their credit scores to qualify for loans or for more favorable rates. Mortgage professionals say that some knowledge about the scoring system helps.

THE NEWS Leaders of two major Olympic antidoping agencies sharply criticized Major League Baseball's response to its doping problems as ''baffling'' and ''frustrating.'' BEHIND THE NEWS John Fahey, head of the World Anti-Doping Agency, described as ''fiction'' comments by Bud Selig, baseball's commissioner, and Donald Fehr, of the players' union, on the independence of the league's drug program and the difficulty of testing for human growth hormone. Travis T. Tygart of the United States Anti-Doping Agency agreed: ''The only logical conclusion is they don't truly want effective drug testing.'' Said Selig: ''WADA does not have a monopoly'' on drug testing.

KENNY--J. Kevin, January 15, 1936-January 15, 2008. J. Kevin Kenny of North Palm Beach, Florida, passed away on January 15th, 2008 in New York City, on his 72nd birthday after a valiant battle against lung cancer. Mr. Kenny was born in New York City in 1936 to Margaret Connaughton Kenny and John J. Kenny and grew up in Manhasset, NY. He is survived by his wife of 43 years, Martha Morgan Kenny, sons, J. Kevin Kenny Jr., James M. Kenny, John J. Kenny II, daughters Christina C. Kenny, Eileen Kenny Araskog, and her husband, William Araskog, and grandchildren, Rand, Christina, Caroline and Jack; sister, Eileen Cullen, brothers Fred P. (Ted), Brian, Michael, his aunt Rita Connaughton, and many nieces and nephews. Kevin graduated Georgetown University in 1958 and served as a 1st Lieutenant in the US Air Force. In June 1961, right out of the Air Force he joined J.J. Kenny Co., Inc., which was founded by his father in 1949. At the age of 31, he became President and CEO , and through his leadership, grew the company into the the largest inter-dealer broker of municipal bonds in the United States, and established the first municipal bond database in the U.S., which was the leading provider of information, evaluation and other services to the municipal securities industry, with over 700 employees in the United States. He sold the firm in 1990 to McGraw-Hill and retired from J.J. Kenny in 1992 whereupon he relocated to North Palm Beach, Florida, continuing his professional career in Real Estate and Private Investments. During his 31 year career on Wall Street he was known for his professionalism and integrity and actively participated on numerous regulatory and rulemaking Boards and Committees for the industry in New York and Washington, DC, including the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, the Securities Industry Association, Public Securities Association, the National Securities Clearing Corporation, and the Securities & Exchange Commission. In recognition of his service to the municipal industry and his outstanding career accomplishments, he received the Municipal Forum of New York award in 1994. Philanthropy was extremely important to Kevin and during his lifetime he devoted himself to many charitable interests, always lending his time and resources to further education, Catholic charities, and medicine. Recognizing the importance of education for all children, he was a pioneer in starting and furthering the Inner-City Scholarship Fund in NYC, providing scholarships, classrooms, and computers for children and serving as patron when needed for rebuilding schools. In 1994 he received the Irish Man of the Year Award for his extraordinary generosity and unselfish commitment of personal and financial resources to St. Thomas Aquinas and other inner-city schools. Georgetown University was extremely close to Kevin's heart. He served on the Board of Trustees and numerous other committees where he actively promoted funding for student aid, academic initiatives and sports. His contributions to the betterment of society and the nation through community service and career accomplishments were recognized in 2000 when he received the John Carroll Award. He actively served on the Boards of St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, NY and schools including the Green Vale School in New York, and The Benjamin School in North Palm Beach, FL. He tirelessly volunteered his time and resources when a need presented itself. He created endowments at Georgetown University, Duke University, and Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. He was a school patron for the Catholic Inner - City Scholarship schools. Kevin was an avid sportsman. While golf was his favorite sport, he enjoyed any activity that involved members of his large family. He was a patient instructor and fantastic coach. Most importantly, he was a devoted husband and father. Throughout his life he believed faith, family, honesty and integrity were the cornerstones of his success. Services: Monday January 21 from 5-7pm; Tuesday January 22 from 4-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave.; Wednesday January 23 Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Catholic Church, 980 Park Ave. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Our Lady of Florida Spiritual Center, 1300 US Highway One, North Palm Beach, FL 33408.

QMy wife and I had bedbugs in our New York City apartment last summer. Needless to say, it was a trying ordeal. Thankfully, though, we have not had any problems for the last six months. Now we are considering selling the apartment. Are we required to tell prospective buyers about the bedbugs? A Edward I. Sumber, a White Plains lawyer whose clients include the Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Boards of Realtors, said the state's Property Condition Disclosure Act, which mandates that house sellers give buyers a disclosure statement about the property's condition, does not apply to co-op and condominium owners.

MAUKE--William W., 86, died Wednesday, January 16, 2008 at St. Joseph of The Pines Health Center in Southern Pines, North Carolina. He leaves his wife of 57 years, Elizabeth (Cahill) Mauke, a son, William II and his wife Heather (Caswell) Mauke of W. Simsbury, CT, four grandsons, William III, Christopher, Tucker and Colby, three sisters, Mary Mollicone of Newport Richey, FL, Jane Kelleher of Ormond Beach, FL, and Eleanor Caffrey of Worcester, MA. A sister, Gertrude, predeceased him. He was born in Worcester, MA son of William Alfred and Mary (McClosky) Mauke. Mr. Mauke graduated from the University of Iowa and was an officer in the U.S. Coast Guard. He was the Executive Vice-President of Guardian Life Insurance Co. in New York City before retiring in 1986. He served Guardian for over 30 years and was instrumental in building the company's employee benefit operation. Mr. Mauke lived in Upper Montclair, NJ for many years before retiring to Pinehurst, NC where he lived for the past 18 years. He was an avid tennis player, world traveler and devoted husband and father. A Memorial Service will be held at 11am on Tuesday, January 22, 2008 at Belle Meade, 100 Waters Dr., Southern Pines, NC. Donations may be made in his memory to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Tribute Gifts, Church St., P.O. Box 780, New York, NY 10008-0780 or online at www.michaeljfox.org.

In a match that sounds more like a final, Justine Henin and Maria Sharapova will face each other in the quarterfinals of the Australian Open on Tuesday. Both advanced in convincing fashion Sunday. Henin, the No. 1 seed, won by 6-2, 6-2 against the qualifier Hsieh Su-wei, the first Taiwanese woman to reach the fourth round of a Grand Slam tournament. FRANZ--Adele Longmire, age 89, died in the home of one of her daughters, Gina Martenson, in Taos, NM on January 15, 2008. For many years she was involved in the literary area of show business as a writers' agent in Beverly Hills with AshleySteiner and later in New York with IFA and ICM. Mrs. Franz also served as Administrator of the Television Academy for three terms. Interim affiliations were as Story Executive with Universal Pictures in New York and Daytime Editor with Producer Tony Converse. As Adele Longmire, her career began as a Broadway actress in Eye on the Sparrow, Abe Lincoln In Illinois, Two On An Island, Old Acquaintance, Outrageous Fortune and Nine Girls. She toured as Stella in the Australian Company of Streetcar Named Desire and with Paul Muni in Counselor At Law. Survived by two daughters, Melissa Franz and Gina Martenson, and a grandson, Benn Martenson and granddaughter, Hallie Martenson.

REID--Laura R., 52, died January 15, 2008 after a courageous battle with cancer. She will be forever missed by her beloved husband Andy, her children Sarah and Rachel, her father David Ritchie, her in-laws Rhoda and Daniel Reid, Addie and Bradford Powell, Ivy Reid, Robin and Paul Mickey and her nephew Adam. She lived her life with love and grace and was a source of inspiration to all those who knew her. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, NY, NY 10087.

The opening panel of the World Economic Forum traditionally gives a macroeconomic weather forecast for the coming 12 months. This year, expect black clouds to gather over Davos when the panel kicks off on Wednesday morning.

Almost exactly one year ago, in this space, we observed that Tony Blair, then British prime minister, had celebrated a “valedictory moment” at Davos – “his final appearance at the World Economic Forum as Britain’s prime minister after almost 10 years in office.” In parentheses we added: “but probably not his last time at the conference.”

With John McCain and Bill Clinton otherwise engaged this year, Davos will be without two of its most reliable draws. While both thrived in this talk shop, there was no mistaking the status gap between a former president and a potential future president.

For some, scoring an invitation to the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum is like getting asked to the prom. For others, it is just another invitation to blow off. (Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. just bailed out at the 11th hour.) This year, the guest list is a heady mix of egos, personalities and leaders. Some have been here before, while others are making their first pilgrimage.

A team of us from The New York Times and The International Herald Tribune will be here at the annual conference of the World Economic Forum, a high-wattage powwow for bigshots of all stripes — think Tony Blair, Bill Gates and Bono — to rub elbows and talk big ideas.

Remember September 2006? It was a little over a month before Election Day when Bill Clinton gave an interview to Fox News Channel's Chris Wallace. The peg for the interview was a summit held by the Clinton Global Initiative, one of the former president's many philanthropic activities. Wallace asked several questions about the initiative, but four minutes into the interview also brought up criticisms of the Clinton administration's counterterrorism policies that had been aired in Pulitzer-prize winning journalist Lawrence Wright's history of Al Qaeda, "The Looming Tower." Whereupon Clinton went ballistic. His face turned red. His voice rose. He tore into Wallace, accusing the veteran journalist, who over the decades has worked for several "mainstream" networks and whose credibility seldom has been questioned, of being a right-wing shill. He claimed the "neocons" who now say he did too little to capture or kill Osama bin Laden had in fact during the 1990s been highly critical of his administration's emphasis on counterterrorism, that they "thought I was too obsessed with bin Laden" and "had no meetings on bin Laden for nine months after I left office."

Lucas Ossendrijver, the 37-year-old Dutch-born Lanvin men's wear designer, has an international resume to rival most diplomats. After graduating from the Fashion Institute Arnhem (ex alumni include Ossendrijver's compatriots Viktor & Rolf), he skipped from Kenzo, to the German-Greek Kostas Murkudis, and then to Dior Homme in the Hedi Slimane years, before being charged in 2006 with translating Alber Elbaz's success at Lanvin to the men's market. He hasn't missed a step, as yesterday's Lanvin's Fall 2008 show, one of the week's hottest tickets, proved once again.

Rereading "The Moviegoer" was a revelation to me, as rereading usually is. Some book has left an imprint, often an indelible one, but it naturally gets fainter and fainter as time goes by, till it's more an impression, a shadow on one's consciousness. One of my heroes once wrote that "true culture is what remains in a man when he's forgotten everything he's learned." In that sense, "The Moviegoer" was part of my "culture," but in such a generalized way as to be virtually indescribable. I found I really remembered very little of it. And so the reread book is, in fact, a new book, only better than new, because there are neural pathways somewhere that can somehow be reopened...

The big problem with attempts to provide temporary economic stimulus is how to ensure that the money gets spent. As Milton Friedman pointed out 50 years ago, consumers tend to base their spending on "permanent income" -- the income they expect to have over the long run -- rather than their income in any given year. So an $800 check from the Treasury tends, other things equal, to be mostly saved rather than spent.

A game Sunday between Nigel Short of England and Ivan Cheparinov of Bulgaria in the B section of the Corus tournament in the Netherlands ended in a forfeit win for Short after Cheparinov refused to shake Short's hand at the start of the game. According to a report on Chessbase.com, Short immediately complained to the tournament's referee who consulted the World Chess Federation's rules and decided that Cheparinov's conduct merited that he forfeit the game. It was an unprecedented decision, which was appealed and later reversed, although Cheparinov was required to apologize and shake Short's hand before playing the game on Monday, which Short won.

To the Editor: ''A Terror Threat in the Courts,'' by John Farmer (Op-Ed, Jan. 13), advocates for legislation allowing so-called preventive detention, in which terrorism suspects can be taken into custody because they are believed to be harboring certain thoughts or ideas that the government considers dangerous.

To the Editor: It is deeply troubling that a legally mandated and urgently needed decision to protect polar bears under the Endangered Species Act has been delayed by one agency of the Interior Department even as another agency rushes ahead with plans to sell oil and gas leases across a huge expanse of critical polar bear habitat in Alaska's Chukchi Sea (''Regulatory Games and the Polar Bear,'' editorial, Jan. 15).

The most effective TV product placements, according to iTVX, which measures brand marketing, are those in which the product is woven into the show's story line. iTVX's Q-Ratio is a score measuring 50 criteria, like whether a character is holding the product when talking about it, or if the logo is clearly shown in a foreground shot. The Guitar Hero placement on ''South Park,'' above, involved a story in which Stan and Kyle's high scores on the video game gained them entry into the rock 'n' roll world, and contestants on ''The Apprentice'' had to create a commercial for Renuzit. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Jennifer Rosales and Dorothy Delasin of the Philippines shot a seven-under-par 65 Sunday to beat South Korea by two strokes at the Women's World Cup of Golf in Sun City, South Africa.Ji-Yai Shin and Eun-Hee Ji of South Korea were comfortably in the lead after nine holes, but Rosales and Delasin had five birdies and finished at 18-under 198 at Gary Player Country Club.Juli Inkster and Pat Hurst of the United States tied for 10th.

SIEGEL--Leah, of Great Neck, NY, beloved wife of the late Martin Siegel, died at age 85 on January 19, 2008, from complications of Alzheimer's Disease. She is survived by son Peter Siegel of Brooklyn, daughter Deborah Siegel Cosentino of Los Angeles and sister Zora Essman of Larchmont, NY. Mrs. Siegel resided at the Motion Picture Home in Woodland Hills, CA. She ran the AmRuss Literary and Photo Agency in NYC from 1975 to 1992.

9 P.M. (13) THE LOBOTOMIST Championed by Walter J. Freeman, above left, a neurologist, the lobotomy came to be seen as a groundbreaking medical procedure offering hope to severely mentally ill patients. In time Freeman was accused of being a moral monster, and the surgery was seen as one of the most barbaric blunders of modern medicine. ''American Experience'' interviews historians, psychiatrists and people who worked with Freeman to tell a tale of medical intervention gone wrong. Campbell Scott narrates. 7 P.M. (Cartoon Network) CODENAME: KIDS NEXT DOOR Not only are the kids all right, they're all grown up in ''Operation: I.N.T.E.R.V.I.E.W.S.,'' the final episode of this animated series. Now adults, the operatives reminisce about their last mission: to find a stolen birthday cake meant for the Delightful Children. Then some codes are broken, and some secrets revealed.

Neumann correctly characterizes the increasingly volatile conditions in Afghanistan by noting the presence of a ''growing Taliban resurgence'' (''Afghans, Report for Duty,'' Op-Ed, Jan. 14). SIMON--Selma Breidner. Beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, who passed away on January 18, 2008 at the age of 96. Her's was a life well lived; a daily celebration of the joys of family, friendship and faith. We were touched by her generosity and extraordinary spirit; we will be inspired by her memory forever.

In America's poorest ghettos, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s portrait is one of the most popular subjects of public art. These images, which I have been documenting since 1977, regularly appear on the walls of the liquor stores, auto-repair shops, fast-food restaurants, mom-and-pop stores and public housing projects of Chicago, Detroit, Los Angeles, New York and many other cities across the country. The majority are the work of amateur artists. Though Dr. King is usually front and center, he is often accompanied by other inspirational figures: Nelson Mandela, John Paul II, Malcolm X, Rosa Parks, Mother Teresa, Pancho Villa. He is also often accompanied by his famous phrase, ''I have a dream'' -- a reminder that in many of the communities where these murals exist, the gulf between hope and reality remains far too wide. Top to bottom, left to right: Compton Avenue at 55th Street, Los Angeles; Mount Elliott Street at East Warren Avenue, Detroit; 9330 Broadway, Los Angeles; South Avalon Boulevard at 51st Street, Los Angeles; 219 East Martin Luther King Boulevard, Los Angeles (two photographs); North Warwick Avenue at West North Avenue, Baltimore. For additional photos, nytimes.com/opinion.

KENNY--J. Kevin January 15, 1936-January 15, 2008. J. Kevin Kenny of North Palm Beach, Florida, passed away on January 15th, 2008 in New York City, on his 72nd birthday after a valiant battle against lung cancer. Mr. Kenny was born in New York City in 1936 to Margaret Connaughton Kenny and John J. Kenny and grew up in Manhasset, NY. He is survived by his wife of 43 years, Martha Morgan Kenny, sons, J. Kevin Kenny Jr., James M. Kenny, John J. Kenny II, daughters Christina C. Kenny, Eileen Kenny Araskog, and her husband, William Araskog, and grandchildren, Rand, Christina, Caroline and Jack; sister, Eileen Cullen, brothers Fred P. (Ted), Brian, Michael, his aunt Rita Connaughton, and many nieces and nephews. Kevin graduated Georgetown University in 1958 and served as a 1st Lieutenant in the US Air Force. In June 1961, right out of the Air Force he joined J.J. Kenny Co., Inc., which was founded by his father in 1949. At the age of 31, he became President and CEO , and through his leadership, grew the company into the the largest inter-dealer broker of municipal bonds in the United States, and established the first municipal bond database in the U.S., which was the leading provider of information, evaluation and other services to the municipal securities industry, with over 700 employees in the United States. He sold the firm in 1990 to McGraw-Hill and retired from J.J. Kenny in 1992 whereupon he relocated to North Palm Beach, Florida, continuing his professional career in Real Estate and Private Investments. During his 31 year career on Wall Street he was known for his professionalism and integrity and actively participated on numerous regulatory and rulemaking Boards and Committees for the industry in New York and Washington, DC, including the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, the Securities Industry Association, Public Securities Association, the National Securities Clearing Corporation, and the Securities & Exchange Commission. In recognition of his service to the municipal industry and his outstanding career accomplishments, he received the Municipal Forum of New York award in 1994. Philanthropy was extremely important to Kevin and during his lifetime he devoted himself to many charitable interests, always lending his time and resources to further education, Catholic charities, and medicine. Recognizing the importance of education for all children, he was a pioneer in starting and furthering the Inner-City Scholarship Fund in NYC, providing scholarships, classrooms, and computers for children and serving as patron when needed for rebuilding schools. In 1994 he received the Irish Man of the Year Award for his extraordinary generosity and unselfish commitment of personal and financial resources to St. Thomas Aquinas and other inner-city schools. Georgetown University was extremely close to Kevin's heart. He served on the Board of Trustees and numerous other committees where he actively promoted funding for student aid, academic initiatives and sports. His contributions to the betterment of society and the nation through community service and career accomplishments were recognized in 2000 when he received the John Carroll Award. He actively served on the Boards of St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, NY and schools including the Green Vale School in New York, and The Benjamin School in North Palm Beach, FL. He tirelessly volunteered his time and resources when a need presented itself. He created endowments at Georgetown University, Duke University, and Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. He was a school patron for the Catholic Inner - City Scholarship schools. Kevin was an avid sportsman. While golf was his favorite sport, he enjoyed any activity that involved members of his large family. He was a patient instructor and fantastic coach. Most importantly, he was a devoted husband and father. Throughout his life he believed faith, family, honesty and integrity were the cornerstones of his success. Services: Monday January 21 from 5-7pm; Tuesday January 22 from 4-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave.; Wednesday January 23 Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Catholic Church, 980 Park Ave. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Our Lady of Florida Spiritual Center, 1300 US Highway One, North Palm Beach, FL 33408.

FREAS--Jean, 78, a pioneering TV journalist and writer who was once married to the American sculptor David Smith, died on January 12 after a brief illness. Born February 13, 1929, in Washington, DC, to S.A. Freas and Katherine Reinhardt. Jean Freas was graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in 1950. After marrying David Smith in 1953, she moved to Bolton Landing, NY, and had two daughters, Rebecca Smith and Candida Smith, who survive her. In the mid-1960s as Jean Smith she became the first woman to anchor a local news show for a network affiliate, at WRCTV in Washington, DC. As Jean Pond, she published a memoir, Surviving (Hill & Wang). Ever young and always beautiful, Jean will be deeply missed by her adoring family, grandchildren Emma, Sam, Luke, Hudson and Gabe; and extended family of beloved friends. A memorial will be held in New York City at a later date.

To the Editor: Re ''Two Old Friends Arraigned in Dead-Man's-Check Case'' (news article, Jan. 11):

Americans have lived with either a Bush or a Clinton in the White House since 1989. And that pattern will continue if Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York captures the Democratic nomination and goes on to win the presidency. How do voters feel about that? According to a recent New York Times/CBS News poll, most are indifferent, saying each election is about individuals and not families. But the national survey found that about a third of all voters -- and similarly, a third of all Republican primary voters -- consider the pattern bad for the country, because it concentrates too much power among a small group of people. Democratic primary voters were divided on whether it is bad or makes no difference. But Democrats who support Mrs. Clinton's nomination are more likely to say it makes no difference. The telephone poll was conducted Jan. 9-12 with 1,061 registered voters.

GAMING FREELY In a major departure from its traditional business model, Electronic Arts, the video game industry bellwether, plans to announce that it is developing an installment in its hit series Battlefield that will be distributed on the Internet as a free download. E.A. hopes the game can help point the way for Western game makers looking to diversify beyond appealing to hard-core players with games that can cost $60 or more. Page C1. BLOGGING FROM IRAQ As a blogger, Michael Yon writes detailed, mostly admiring accounts of frontline soldiers' daily work. Mr. Yon, however, does not work for any organization, even as a freelancer; he publishes his work on his own Web site And like most bloggers, Mr. Yon has an agenda, writing often that the United States' mission to build a stable, democratic Iraq is succeeding and must continue. C1.

RIKLIS--Judith Stern. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of American Friends of Tel Aviv University are deeply saddened by the loss of our cherished friend, Judith Riklis. Judith's passionate devotion to the State of Israel and enduring love for her native Tel Aviv inspired many of her numerous philanthropic activities. She served on the International Board of Governors of Tel Aviv University, and was an honorary member of the Board of the American Friends organization. Her generosity of spirit will continue to touch the lives of many for years to come through her creation of the Krinkin-Stern Wing for Research in Chemical Pathology at the university's Sackler Faculty of Medicine in honor of her parents and grandparents. We will miss her warmth and artistic vision, and extend our deepest sympathies to Judith's children, Dr. Mona Ackerman, Marcia Riklis and Ira D. Riklis, and the entire family. William F. Cohen, Chairman Roni Krinsky, President

ELKES--Terrence. Mr. Terrence Elkes passed away on January 18, 2008. He was 73 years old. Terrence was the devoted husband of Ruth Elkes, nee: Jerkowsky, who died in November, and whom he faithfully and ceaselessly cared for until her final day. He was the beloved father of Steven, David, and Daniel, and their wives, Mitzi, Elizabeth, and Sonia, and grandfather of seven grandchildren: Claire, Charlotte, Jacob, Joshua, Katharine, Madeline, and Sarah. Terrence was born and raised in the Bronx, and graduated from the City College of New York. He then received a scholarship to the University of Michigan Law School, from which he received his J.D. He served in a legal capacity at companies such as Norwich Pharmaceuticals and Parsons and Whittemore, before becoming the general counsel at Viacom. He rose at Viacom eventually serving as President and CEO. Terrence boldly redefined the company, setting it on the path to becoming one of the largest names in media today. In recent years he served as one of the principals at Apollo Parners, an investment group in New York, and established the Elkes Foundation, which has supported organizations such as the University of Michigan, City College of New York, the Jewish Outreach Institute, the Center for Security Policy, the Yiddish Book Center, and the New Haven Academy. Terrence set an example of philanthropy and caring that is inspiring to us all. He will be sorely missed. The Elkes family will be receiving visitors on Monday from 1pm to 8pm at the family home with a brief service at 4:30. A date for a more formal memorial service will be announced shortly for late spring. Funeral services were handled by Harrison Funeral Home located at 329 Halstead Avenue in Harrison, New York, 10528 telephone 914-835-0284. ELKES--Terrence. My business partner and closest friend, I will miss you. May your children and grandchildren continue to exhibit the qualities and characteristics that made you and Ruth so special. May you both rest in peace. Ken Gorman

She is survived by devoted daughter Linda, beloved son Richard and his wife Lynne, and her adoring grandchildren Dara, Debra and Michael. She will be greatly missed.

BECKERMAN--Lester. Born April 12th, 1927, deceased January 19th, 2008. Devoted son of Max and Rose Beckerman. Beloved husband to Charlotte and beloved father of Roy Beckerman. Graduated from The University of Michigan with a masters of science degree. A simple, soft spoken man with high moral values who was loved by everyone. Loved children, sports, music and dancing, but family most of all. Passionate fan of the Colts and the Michigan Wolverines. Good friend to anyone who knew him. A thoughtful, gentle, intelligent man of honesty, integrity, patience, and understanding. A testament to the fact that a great father makes all the difference. Visiting period 69pm Monday, January 21st. Funeral services Tuesday 9:30am both at Menorah Chapel, 2145 Richmond Ave. Staten Island, NY.

Sulley Muntari scored in the 90th minute to give host Ghana a 2-1 win over Guinea in the opening match of the African Cup of Nations in Accra. Ghana, a four-time African champion, took the lead in the 54th minute on Asamoah Gyan's penalty kick, but Guinea tied it in the 64th when Oumar Kalabane scored.

STEWART--Charles Thorp, of Gulf Stream, Florida, formerly of New York City and North Berwick, Scotland, died on January 19, 2008. Cause of death was a heart attack. He was born in Pittsburgh, PA on February 14, 1918. He is survived by his wife, Patricia Carry Stewart, a daughter Jenifer J. Stewart of Falmouth, ME and a son, C. Even Stewart of New York, NY, a granddaughter, Charlotte Stewart, and two brothers, George B. Stewart of Kennebunk, ME and Edwin C. Stewart of Savannah, GA. He was divorced from his first wife, the former Jenifer Barbour. He was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, Cornell University and Yale Law School. He was associated with the law firm of Cravath, Swaine and Moore before becoming General Counsel of R.H. Macy and then Senior Vice President, General Counsel and a member of the Board of Directors of J.C. Penney Company, Inc. He also served on the Board of Directors of Inmont Corporation. During World War II he served first as a private in the U.S. Army and then as a lieutenant junior grade in the U.S. Navy where he was assistant counsel in the Bureau of Aeronautics and later was special assistant to the General counsel of the Navy Department. He served as a trustee of Cornell University for 20 years where he was Vice Chairman of the Board and Chairman of the Executive Committee. He chaired the Yale Law School Fund and was a visiting professor at Yale Law School and an adjunct professor of law at New York University School of Law. He was also chairman of the YMCA of Greater New York. He was a director of the Legal Aid Society in New York City and the United States Chamber of Commerce. In the 1950s he was active in the Young Republican Club of New York, serving as its Chairman in 1952. He was a member of the American Bar Association, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the American Law Institute and the American Arbitration Association as well as a Fellow of the American Bar Foundation. He was an avid curler and golfer. He belonged to the University and Cornell Clubs in New York City, The Country Club of Florida in the Village of Golf, FL, The St. Andrews Club in Delray Beach, FL, the Little Club in Gulf Stream, FL and the North Berwick Golf Club in North Berwick, Scotland. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Delray Beach on Saturday, February 9 at 2pm. Contributions may be made to Cornell University, Ithaca, NY or to Yale Law School, New Haven, CT.

What makes a good teacher? The city’s Education Department has come up with one answer: Use standardized reading and math test scores to measure how much a teacher’s students improve from one year to the next. In a new pilot program at 140 city schools, the city has used a complicated statistical analysis to predict how much students should improve, then measure that against how well they actually do. Teachers are measured against other teachers with similar experiences and students. The outcome: Teachers will be rated to measure how well they taught their students in any given year.

On my way to the Armani couture show, I dropped by Chanel to see Karl Lagerfeld in his studio. The first person I saw was Amanda Harlech, sitting by the windows overlooking the Rue Cambon, and then I seemed to see everybody at once-Odile Gilbert, who always does the hair, Michel, who does the music, Elsa, who deals with VIPs who want to wear Chanel, Madame Jacqueline, who presides over the ateliers, and Sebastian, who drives Lagerfeld. Right away, Lagerfeld got down to business and said the collection had been inspired by shell patterns. He had never really thought about shells before, he said, and, as he opened a picture book of shells-"Coquillages" by Paul Starosta and Jacques Senders-he described it as an unknown world of color and texture.

The Ambac Financial Group, the second-largest bond insurer, has been accused in two lawsuits of misleading investors and artificially raising its share price.
General Electric confirmed Monday that it is studying a possible deal with Colonial, in a move that could spark a bidding war for the Spanish real estate firm.
The Japanese electronics maker Kyocera said it would buy Sanyo Electric's money-losing cellphone business for as much as $468 million, creating the world's sixth-largest cellphone maker.

The billionaire hedge fund investor Edward Lampert is playing an old tune for Sears Holdings: break up to make up. Make up for the beating that Mr. Lampert's portfolio has taken on the retail giant he forged out of the merger of Sears and Kmart, that is.
Roche Holding has overcome Ventana Medical Systems' resistance to its takeover bid by raising the price, acquiring the diagnostics maker for $3.4 billion to expand its cancer testing business.
Everyone wants to know who is to blame for the losses paining Wall Street and homeowners.
Quebecor World, the second-largest commercial printer in the world, filed for bankruptcy protection in Canada and the United States on Monday.
It's been only a month since Samuel Zell took control of Tribune and already he's facing the fallout from rebellion in the ranks.
Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the world's largest producer of iron ore, said on Monday that it was in talks with a rival, Xstrata, about a merger.
Three-quarters of corporate travel managers said in a recent survey that they expect airline mergers to result in higher fares and more than half expect the quality of service to suffer.

Teva Pharmaceutical Industries of Israel said on Tuesday that it plans to acquire CoGenesys, a privately held biopharmaceutical company, for $400 million in cash.
Emaar MGF Land, a real estate developer, started an initial public offering in India on Monday.

A social network software maker, Slide, said on Friday it had closed a $50 million institutional financing round, marking the rising valuations of start-ups riding fast-growing Facebook's wave of popularity.
ACA Capital Holdings, the troubled bond insurer, has received an additional month to unwind an estimated $69 billion of credit exposure stemming from the subprime mortgage crisis.
Both the ivory-billed woodpecker and a thriving local economy are hard to find in the bayou of Arkansas.

(An Associated Press video report is on YouTube.) It turns out things were not quite as they appeared.
Should the Patriots be favored by 14 points if Tom Brady is hobbling around on a walking boot?
