The endowment of Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire last year surpassed $1 billion, making it richer than many universities.

A recently published compendium of Robert Frost's personal notebooks is coming under attack from two critics who say that the editor of the volume mistranscribed hundreds, if not thousands, of Frost’s words.
“The Life of Ryan” is a reality television milestone for one good reason: after years of commoners’ showboating, here comes a showboat who wants to be common.

As a seemingly endless series of presidential candidate debates have proven this election cycle, the posture of the debate moderator can make the difference between a forgettable evening and a feisty one.
Williams, the tournament’s defending champion, lost to third-seeded Jelena Jankovic.
A massive palm tree discovered on the island of Madagascar represents a new genus and species, researchers say.
Seabirds who survive an oil spill can help track the spread of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons from the event.

The Soay sheep of St. Kilda, a group of small Scottish islands, have been living free and unfettered for millennia. While these primitive sheep are still unmanaged, detailed records have been kept on them for the past 20 years. That makes St. Kilda a kind of natural evolutionary experiment, an island-scale Petri dish where sheep, not fruit flies, are the subjects.
Some brainy animal species, besides humans, campaign across sophisticated and far-flung social networks.
Weight-loss surgery works much better than standard medical therapy as a treatment for type 2 diabetes in obese people, a study found.
The bank cited huge write-downs of mortgage-related securities and higher provisions for future losses in credit card and home equity loans.
The giant discount retailer said that, after it introduced a revised health plan last fall, the number of workers who signed up reached 50.2 percent of its 1.4 million employees.
"Of all the subway lines I have been on so far, the L train was by far the flashiest."
Monetary policy usually takes some time to bite. That may explain why the European Central Bank has given no indication that it will follow suit after the Federal Reserve’s emergency rate cut.

Four New York City police officers are facing criminal charges as part of an ongoing criminal investigation into corruption among officers assigned to a unit of narcotics investigators in Brooklyn, officials said on Monday.
Successful entrepreneurs say that success can breed complacency and failure underscores the need to take chances.
Jose Padilla’s detention became the centerpiece of a debate over the Bush administration’s prosecution of terrorism.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed $1 billion in health care cuts and scaled back plans for new education aid and property tax relief in his second executive budget.
A dramatic sell-off that has sent share prices here plummeting more than 10 percent over the past two days is raising fears that China’s spectacular stock market boom may be coming to an end.
Editor’s Note: This newsletter is coming to you today because of the Dr. King holiday yesterday. Next week, look for In Advertising on its usual day, Monday.
U.S. stocks opened sharply lower in volatile trading, but made up much of their losses.
Responding to fears of a U.S. recession, the Federal Reserve slashed its benchmark interest rate Tuesday morning.
The Federal Reserve, responding to an international stock sell-off and the likelihood of a sharp drop in the U.S., cut its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point.
Markets in Tokyo, Hong Kong and Sydney on Tuesday extended the losses they suffered Monday as fears of a recession roiled markets worldwide.
Nonetheless, some investors expect the bank to cut borrowing costs this year, backtracking from its pledge to raise interest rates gradually.
With an 82-71 victory over North Carolina, the Huskies answered questions about whether they could hold their own against an elite team after losing two key starters to season-ending injuries.
Officials said that more than 95 percent of registered voters turned out at the polls on Sunday to endorse a slate of parliamentary candidates, including Fidel Castro and his brother Raúl.

North Korea has postponed the first inter-Korean dialogue of this year, citing time constraints, the Unification Ministry in South Korea said. The countries were to hold talks Tuesday and Wednesday on repairing a cross-border railway and transporting a joint cheering squad to the Beijing Olympics this year by train. No new date was set. “We don’t know exactly why North Korea decided to suspend this week’s inter-Korean meeting,” a ministry spokesman said. He refused to confirm a report by the Yonhap news agency that the suspension was a sign of uneasiness over the South’s new hawkish president, Lee Myung-bak, who takes office Feb. 25 and intends to make aid packages conditional on nuclear compliance under the six-nation talks. Last week, Mr. Lee unveiled plans to abolish the Unification Ministry, which he has accused of being too soft on the North.
More than half of the 2,711 pillars that make up the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe in Berlin have cracked, the magazine Cicero reported.
Parliament convened for the first time since last month’s election and since Thaksin Shinawatra was ousted as prime minister in a military coup in 2006.

The runoff election between Serbia’s pro-Western president, Boris Tadic, and the ultranationalist challenger Tomislav Nikolic, who wants closer ties with Russia, will take place on Feb. 3, the state electoral commission said. First-round results of voting on Sunday gave Mr. Nikolic 39 percent and Mr. Tadic 35 percent.
Zambia was plunged into darkness in what appeared to be the second nationwide power failure in three days. The country relies on hydroelectricity, and national blackouts are rare.

An article on Saturday about last-minute Republican campaigning before the South Carolina primary referred imprecisely to the schedule for Feb. 5. There will be more than 20 nominating contests for Republicans, including primaries and caucuses — not more than 20 primaries.

Fujitsu said that it would spin off its semiconductor division in a move that could make it easier for the new company to establish alliances with other chip makers and to share the significant development costs expected as the industry gears up for bigger silicon wafers. The company wants to spin off the semiconductor division by March, a company spokesman, Toshiyuki Fukuoka, said. The spinoff will begin as a 100 percent Fujitsu-owned subsidiary.

The Brazilian state oil company said it had discovered a natural gas reserve off the coast of Rio de Janeiro that could be as big as the recently discovered giant Tupi oil field. The company, Petróleo Brasileiro, said the potential reserves were about three miles below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean, 23 miles west of the Tupi field. The release did not provide figures as to the size of the reserve but said its structure could have dimensions that are similar to Tupi’s. Late last year, Petrobras announced the discovery of as much as eight billion barrels of light crude oil in the ultra-deep Tupi field.

Antitrust regulators in the European Union have stepped up a review of International Business Machines’ proposed $4.9 billion bid for Cognos, a maker of business-analysis software. The European Commission said in a statement that the transaction’s combined market share was above certain thresholds for a simplified review. The commission did not change its Jan. 29 deadline to rule on the deal. The transaction “no longer fulfills the criteria for simplified procedure,” said Jonathan Todd, a commission spokesman.

Negotiators for the European Union and the United States said that they hoped a meeting of trade ministers in Davos, Switzerland, this week could help restart global trade talks and pave the way for a deal. Begun in 2001 to help increase trade and develop the economies of poorer countries, the talks have already missed a succession of deadlines. The European trade commissioner, Peter Mandelson, sought to increase pressure for a breakthrough after a meeting on Monday with Susan C. Schwab, above, the United States trade representative. “We are rapidly moving toward a moment of truth,” Mr. Mandelson said.

Sanyo, the electronics maker, will sell its troubled cellphone operations to a rival, Kyocera. The companies said the value of the business is about 40 billion yen ($374 million). Including debt, the deal — set for completion April 1 — is worth about 50 billion yen ($467 million), although the companies have yet to agree on a final price. The long-anticipated sale of the unit comes months after Goldman Sachs and other investors saved Sanyo in a 300 billion yen ($2.8 billion) bailout.

The Brazilian airline TAM said it had signed a contract to buy 46 Airbus jets, including 22 extra-wide-body A350s. The European-made A350 is a rival to the Boeing 787 Dreamliner. TAM said that the order is worth $6.9 billion at list prices, although most airlines obtain deep discounts. The addition of the A350s to TAM’s fleet represents the first time that the plane will be used in South America, TAM said.

Royal Philips Electronics, the lighting and health care giant, said that fourth-quarter profit doubled to 1.39 billion euros ($2.03 billion) from 680 million for the same quarter a year ago, while sales rose 3.8 percent to 8.37 billion euros ($12.2 billion). Philips said its profit included gains from the 1.09 billion-euro ($1.60 billion) sale of stakes in several other companies, offset by 404 million euros ($591 million) in one-time charges. The medical equipment unit remained the most profitable, with earnings up 9.9 percent to 322 million euros ($471 million), despite a 2 percent fall in sales. The unit’s operating profit rose 34 percent to 170 million euros ($249 million) on a sales rise of 14 percent.
A government-ordered evacuation at a factory converted into a commune of creative types led to concern as to whether tenants would be able to return soon — or ever.

Fire destroyed the studios of two television stations in a shared building in Grand Junction, blocking local broadcasts, officials said. The fire started Sunday morning in the studios of KREX-TV and KFQX-TV. Five people inside escaped safely, but the building was a total loss. Damage was put at about $6 million. It was not clear when the stations, which have separate owners, would broadcast again. KREX is a CBS affiliate, and KFQX is a Fox affiliate. City fire investigators said they were still looking into the cause. The building, which was several decades old, did not have a sprinkler system, a Fire Department spokesman said. The general manager of KREX, Ron Tillery, said it was the first television station in western Colorado.

A fire started in an empty nightclub in downtown Lawrence and spread quickly through 16 buildings, destroying homes and businesses and forcing residents to flee in their pajamas into the bitterly cold night. One person suffered minor injuries. The fire started in a nightclub that was being renovated and spread quickly on a stiff wind through the block that included wood-frame buildings from the early 1900s. Three of the buildings were being rehabilitated by Habitat for Humanity. Fire officials in Lawrence, which is about 30 miles north of Boston, said the cause was suspicious. State and city fire officials were investigating with agents from the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. Some people were clad only in pajamas as they ran outside into the 12-degree weather, with wind chill below zero. Water sprayed by firefighters froze, covering buildings and streets with ice. About 150 people were evacuated from the area, said Lt. Scott McNamara of the Lawrence police.

California, the nation’s largest agricultural producer, is trying to increase its share of the hundreds of millions of dollars in food products that Cuba buys every year from the United States under a loophole in Washington’s trade embargo against the island. A. G. Kawamura, California’s secretary of food and agriculture, is leading a delegation of 18 business officials to Havana this week to promote products like nuts, citrus fruits and wine. California sold about $700,000 in products to Cuba in 2007, but the state predicted that the figure could be increased to $180 million. Pedro Alvarez Borrego, chairman of the Cuban government company that imports food products, said the biggest thing Cuba wanted from California was help in lifting what Havana calls an economic blockade.

Michigan will no longer let illegal immigrants obtain driver’s licenses, a practice just seven other states continue to allow. The secretary of state, Terri Lynn Land, who oversees the motor vehicle department, announced the policy and said it would take effect Tuesday. The policy also bars people who are legal but not permanent United States residents from obtaining licenses. Legislation to allow those on temporary work or student visas to get licenses is pending in the Legislature. The policy applies to first-time applicants for a Michigan driver’s license or identification card. Updated procedures for renewals will be released soon. Hawaii, Maine, Maryland, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah and Washington do not require drivers to prove legal status to obtain a license.
No. 9 Georgetown had to rally from a 7-point deficit over the final five minutes of regulation, then outscored Syracuse, 4-2, in a ragged overtime to escape with a 64-62 victory.
Cory Stillman scored the winning goal on a power play in overtime as the Hurricanes defeated the Islanders by 3-2 on Monday.
South Carolina is a disturbing example of how difficult it is for people of good will to dispose of toxic layers of bigotry.
We’d be so much happier about all the good things America’s moneyed elite pay for if the government made needed public investments.
The Navy continues to resist efforts to constrain its activities no matter the harm to marine life.
A report in The New York Times last week is one more alarming sign of instability in Pakistan, the nuclear-armed state that is supposed to be America’s leading ally in the war on terrorism.
The ousted editor of The Los Angeles Times on Monday argued that cost cuts, a lack of investment and an aversion to serious news is damaging the newspaper industry.
Quebecor World, the second-largest commercial printer in the world, made the move after its banks failed to approve a rescue plan.
The first bomb fatality in one of the U.S. Army’s new armored vehicles has raised questions on its design.
In the wake of a suicide bombing near Falluja, Iraq, in Anbar Province, local tribesmen burned the house of the young bomber’s family and prevented them from collecting his head for burial.
Far more than his predecessors, Rudolph W. Giuliani’s toughness as mayor of New York City edged toward ruthlessness.
The Utah Capitol gets a much-needed structural overhaul -- bridges in its basement to safeguard the dome on top.
The early-season dominance that set the bar so high for the Patriots has eased and they have found themselves in more close calls in the last month.
We hope that Mayor Michael Bloomberg sticks with his antipoverty plan, and that other mayors around the country follow his admirable lead.
Police say that a man who was arrested for keeping a cache of weapons in a Brooklyn Heights brownstone admitted to being behind a spree of anti-Jewish vandalism.
Referrals by the city are helping to fill illegal rooming houses, according to advocates for the homeless, turning neighborhoods into new, hidden kinds of skid rows.
Lachlan Murdoch and the gambling magnate James D. Packer have made an offer of 3.3 billion Australian dollars ($2.9 billion) to buy Consolidated Media Holdings.
Virgilio Cintron, forever to be remembered in the public imagination being wheeled down Ninth Avenue in an office chair, was remembered in a private ceremony Monday.
What makes the current correction dangerous, analysts say, is that selling is being driven by hedge funds and investment banks, not panicky retail investors.
Senator Barack Obama’s biographical advertisement is aimed to show his bipartisan strengths, but there are only a few specifics.
As difficult as the loss to the Giants was, as much as it stung Sunday, the Packers, who have seven starters younger than 26, appear poised for another run next season.
As Hillary Rodham Clinton focuses elsewhere, her husband has been engaged in a war of words with her rival Barack Obama in South Carolina.
After being named the 2007 Horse of the Year on Monday, Curlin appears on track to take another run at the title.
The Republican candidates began grappling with the complicated electoral landscape of the state.
After four years of trading subprime mortgages, Jason Rew jettisoned his job at the investment bank Goldman Sachs and founded an off-shore business.
Many resentful buyers may seek redress from the agents who found them a home and arranged its purchase.
Red Bulls Coach Juan Carlos Osorio is headed to South America this week on a scouting trip with scheduled stops in Colombia, Argentina and Brazil.

The auction for rights to a highly valuable swath of the nation’s airwaves will begin Thursday and is expected to include multibillion-dollar bids from the nation’s two biggest wireless phone companies.
Mitt Romney gave a shout out that left no doubt that he had spent little time listening to hip-hop.
At a rally protesting Starbucks’ labor policies, evidence of   the labor disputes that have become familiar at the retail outlets that serve upscale customers in New York.
In his latest ad, Mitt Romney reaches out to Spanish-speaking voters, who make up a large proportion of the electorate in Miami.
Anheuser-Busch, which buys more commercial time each year in the Super Bowl than any other marketer, is likely to run seven spots in Super Bowl XLII on Feb. 3, all of them for Budweiser or Bud Light.
Mr. Sorenson overcame a learning disability and built a fortune in innovative medical devices and real estate.
ACA Capital Holdings Inc. has received an additional month to unwind an estimated $69 billion of credit exposure stemming from the subprime mortgage crisis.
Ms. Nettleton’s dramatic and comic dexterity in theater, film and television earned her wide public recognition and deep professional respect for more than a half century.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s plan to name the Triborough Bridge after Robert Kennedy is a reminder of our tendency to slap the names of popular figures on places that have nothing to do with the lives they led.
Authorities are combing through debris trying to learn why two small planes collided Sunday about 45 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles.
Joe Burk was a single sculls champion of the 1930s who became a leading figure in American rowing and a highly decorated PT boat skipper in World War II.
Hundreds of couples have been left with no visual record of their wedding day after a regional photography service closed earlier this month and filed for bankruptcy.
Accusations of favoritism toward Gov. Joe Manchin III’s  daughter have created a controversy that could cast a shadow of cronyism over West Virginia University.
A new publisher, Simon Spotlight Entertainment, has picked up Jose Canseco’s new book on steroids in baseball  and will publish it in time for opening day.
The turmoil in the mortgage markets has incited a wave of legal tangles, as homeowners are suing lenders, lenders are suing banks, banks are suing loan specialists. And investors are suing everyone.
On the one day every year when Nascar officials announce the changes coming to the sport, a news conference was held Monday to declare there would be no changes.
Congressman Charles B. Rangel is putting his muscle and prestige behind Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential bid, even as her standing among African-Americans is plunging.
Indianapolis Colts Coach Tony Dungy, who last year became the first black head coach to win a Super Bowl, will coach at least one more season before retiring, he announced Monday.
As global warming brings less snow, lower-altitude stations must rely more on costly snow machines as Swiss ski resorts struggle with new economic hardships.
Business is booming at Siemens under the new chief executive. Yet the coming trials of some former executives have kept the company operating under a cloud.
His best-known song was “Nice ’n’ Easy,” the title tune of a Frank Sinatra album and later a staple of Sinatra’s repertory.
The British Treasury said it would facilitate a sale of the troubled mortgage lender while trying to ensure that taxpayers will not have to pay for the bank’s rescue.
Three-quarters of corporate travel managers said they expect airline mergers to result in higher fares and more than half expect the quality of service to suffer.
City officials have decided to try again to have a 122-year-old pier near Battery Park restored so that it can serve to link parks and attractions around the harbor to the rest of the city.
Eli Manning said he had trouble sleeping Sunday night, so he sat up in bed and watched various cable-sports television shows and talked with his brother, Peyton.
While government-controlled funds swear up and down that their investments are purely financially motivated, they just can’t be.
Celebrity has its perks, but in Beijing, large families are not one of them.
Rashard Lewis made a 12-foot jumper as time expired Monday night and the Orlando Magic ended a nine-game losing streak against the visiting Detroit Pistons with a 102-100 victory.
The maneuvering over the sale of the 50-story tower is only the latest example of how the blood sport known as real estate is played in New York.
A 20-year-old  man was stabbed to death early Monday after a shoving match at a restaurant spilled out onto the sidewalk and turned into a brawl, the police said.
Many of the reader-generated reviews of travel services on the Web are taking an ever-growing piece of the market from print guides.
After a month out of the public eye, Tiger Woods addressed the controversy that has swirled in the news media about the inappropriate racial remarks made by a Golf Channel anchor.
Aviation executives are sharing a list of steps they can take to make passengers’ lives easier the next time a blizzard or another event strands planes on the ground.
The supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, intervened after Iran’s president had refused to carry out a measure that required his government to supply gas to remote villages.
Italy’s former justice minister said he would no longer support Prime Minister Romano Prodi, who holds a one-vote majority in Parliament’s upper house.
European Union officials this week will aim to reduce corporate influence and make polluting more expensive.
Women given implants immediately after mastectomies were twice as likely to acquire infections as those whose own tissue was used in breast reconstruction.
There is something wonderful about being 35,000 feet in the air, looking down on the earth, that gives an artist a new perspective.
Major airlines have raised fares again, a week after a round of $50 round-trip fare increases collapsed when Continental Airlines rescinded its increases, causing all the others to back off as well.
Yahoo plans to lay off hundreds of employees to increase profitability, prop up its deflated stock price and focus on a smaller number of key areas, people close to the company said.
Pakistan’s most popular private television news channel was allowed to resume broadcasts within Pakistan on Monday, ending a blackout that had lasted more than two months.
American viewers will again have the chance to see, after many years of unavailability, Agnès Varda’s astoundingly original first three features.

Time’s up for Kiefer Sutherland. After 48 days Mr. Sutherland, the star of Fox television’s “24,” walked out of jail in Glendale, Calif., at 12:05 a.m. Monday, The Associated Press reported. He was sentenced to 30 days after he pleaded no contest in October to driving with a blood alcohol level above the legal limit, and 18 days were added for violating probation in connection with a drunken driving arrest in 2004. He spent his jail time on laundry duty, cleaning sheets, pillowcases and blankets. John Balian, a police officer, said: “He was very humble, never complained. He didn’t give us any problems at all.”.

Gary Glitter, the 1970’s glam rocker jailed in Vietnam in 2006 for sexually molesting two young girls, has been treated at a prison hospital for intestinal problems and an irregular heartbeat, the BBC reported. Mr. Glitter, 63, whose real name is Paul Francis Gadd, is scheduled to complete his sentence in August.

MySpace Comic Books, the comics corner of this online social network, and Meltdown Comics, a store in Los Angeles, have teamed up to commemorate the end of “Y: The Last Man,” the comic book series created by Brian K. Vaughan, above, and Pia Guerra. The event, “Y: The Last Party,” will be held on Friday, Feb. 8, and will benefit the Comic Book Legal Defense Fund. The organization, founded in 1986, is dedicated to the preservation of First Amendment rights for members of the comic book business. Of late the defense fund has been involved in the case of Gordon Lee, a comic book retailer in Rome, Ga., who has found himself in court over the distribution of obscene material to a minor. The material in question depicted Picasso in the nude. Mr. Vaughan, who is also a writer on ABC’s “Lost,” is a firm believer in the defense fund. “It’s obviously a completely different situation from the writers’ strike, but, similarly, it’s creators taking care of their community, which I always support,” he said in a telephone interview. The $100 V.I.P. tickets have sold out, but a limited number of $25 tickets will be available the day of the event. More information:www.myspace.com/cbldf.

Jack Johnson, My Morning Jacket, Kraftwerk and Portishead will be among the headline acts at the Coachella Valley Music & Arts Festival in California, when the event’s ninth edition takes place in California. Tickets for the festival, from April 25 to 27, will cost $269 as well as fees for all three days; a single day’s ticket will cost $90, according to the details released by Coachella’s organizers, Goldenvoice and AEG. The organizers also said they were planning another three-day event, All Points West, at Liberty State Park in Jersey City, from Aug. 8 to 10. That lineup, not yet announced, is expected to include Radiohead and Mr. Johnson. Paul Tollett, promoter of Goldenvoice, said that unlike Coachella, which takes place on a polo field in the desert about two hours east of Los Angeles, the All Points West will “have its own personality,” incorporating the area’s urban setting and local art scene. Several of this year’s Coachella headliners will be touring in connection with new releases. Portishead, for example, is expected to release its first album in about a decade internationally in April. “They’ve been one of the most requested bands to play Coachella” among fans, Mr. Tollett said. “Talent is still king.”.

Hot and bothered by a steamy new soap opera about airborne love and lust, Thai Airways flight attendants urged Thailand’s culture ministry on Monday to nip the show in the bud, The Associated Press reported. After broadcasts of three episodes of the series, “The Air Hostess War,” the Thai Airways International union protested the story about an affair between a married pilot and a tall, slim flight attendant, featuring sex at stopover cities and love triangles that lead to fighting in the aisles. Viewers were captivated, but Noppadol Thaungthong, a Thai Airways flight attendant leading the union’s action, said: “This soap opera is insulting and damaging to the reputation of flight attendants. It’s all about sex and air hostesses beating each other up in the cabin because of love and jealousy. This kind of thing never happens. We are demanding that the station and the producers immediately stop airing this ugly soap opera.” A culture ministry spokesman withheld comment until officials saw the letter of complaint, and the broadcaster, Channel 5, said it had no plans to pull the soap opera but would consider asking the producer to edit scenes found to be offensive.

Oliver Stone isn’t a fan of the decision to invade Iraq, but in his next film he wants to render “a fair, true portrait” of President Bush, Variety reported. “How did Bush go from an alcoholic bum to the most powerful figure in the world?” Mr. Stone asked. “It’s like Frank Capra territory on one hand, but I’ll also cover the demons in his private life, his bouts with his dad and his conversion to Christianity, which explains a lot of where he is coming from. It includes his belief that God personally chose him to be president of the United States, and his coming into his own, with the stunning, pre-emptive attack on Iraq. It will contain surprises for Bush supporters and his detractors.” If financing materializes, “Bush,” starring Josh Brolin, above, as the president in a screenplay written by Stanley Weiser, who wrote “Wall Street” with Mr. Stone, will go before the cameras in April and could be in theaters by Election Day or by the inauguration of the next president. “I’m a dramatist who is interested in people,” Mr. Stone said, “and I have empathy for Bush as a human being, much as I did for Castro, Nixon, Jim Morrison, Jim Garrison and Alexander the Great.”.

What would Walt Disney say? Mickey and Minnie Mouse, left, have gotten a makeover that put him in a bright red Mao suit and her in a cherry-blossom red dress — all in an effort to appeal to Chinese tourists at Hong Kong Disneyland, The Associated Press reported. Mickey and Minnie strutted along a red carpet on Monday to display their new outfits, designed by Vivienne Tam, while nine other models showed off red and black dresses featuring Mickey Mouse patterns. “I’ve liked Mickey Mouse since I was very little,” said Ms. Tam, who was reared in Hong Kong and works in New York. Amid disappointing attendance at Hong Kong Disneyland, which opened in 2005, Ms. Tam was brought in to help attract more tourists from the mainland, which has become the park’s biggest market. Bill Ernest, the park’s managing director, said, “Our mission is to be very connected with the local culture — with mainland China, Hong Kong.”.
“Fragments for the End of Time,” the program Benjamin Bagby brought to the Music Before 1800 series at Corpus Christi Church on Sunday, concerned itself with apocalyptic visions.
“Beauty and the Beast,” by the American composer Vittorio Giannini, provided a charming, undemanding entry point for children at the Dicapo Opera Theater on Saturday.
The cholesterol drug Vytorin is now getting attention that is anything but funny.
“Growing Up Online” asks an increasingly important question: What does it mean to be part of the first generation coming of age steeped in a virtual world seemingly outside parental control?
Rebels in a get-thin world are blogging away at the mainstream.
The Knicks had trouble stopping Kevin Garnett and Ray Allen in the fourth quarter on Monday, and even more trouble stopping Kendrick Perkins in the first half.
In this hasty and very lumpy volume John Allen Paulos proposes to expose the irrational basis of religious thinking, much the way he exposed rampant mathematical illiteracy in “Innumeracy.”
The Bronx Opera presented an amusingly camp staging of “Orpheus,"  directed by Royston Coppenger, at the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College on Saturday.
For all their sophistication and invention, Brahms’s string quartets are tough love.
An estimated 1.6 million deaths a year are attributed to toxic indoor air. A new clean-burning wood stove could help decrease that number.
A recent outbreak of avian cholera was especially potent, killing about 15,000 birds.
Women who suffer from irritable bowel syndrome may respond to pain signals differently from other women, a new study suggests.

Norm Chow, who tutored two Heisman Trophy-winning quarterbacks at Southern California, is returning to Los Angeles as offensive coordinator at the Trojans' crosstown rival, U.C.L.A. On Monday, Chow, fired last week by the Tennessee Titans, joined the staff of Coach Rick Neuheisel, the former Bruins quarterback who took the job late last month.Before going to U.S.C. and working with the Heisman winners Carson Palmer and Matt Leinart, Chow groomed Ty Detmer, another Heisman winner, at Brigham Young. His coaching résumé includes working with six quarterbacks who were first-round picks in the N.F.L. draft: Palmer, Leinart, Philip Rivers, Jim McMahon, Steve Young and Marc Wilson.

STEWART--Charles Thorpe. Cornell University mourns the passing of devoted alumnus, trustee emeritus, Presidential Councillor, former Vice Chair of the Board of Trustees, and life member of the Weill Cornell Medical College Board of Overseers, Charles Thorpe Stewart, 1940. His stalwart leadership, commitment to philanthropic interests, and ardent dedication to Cornell University will long be remembered. Mr. Stewart and his wife, Patricia Carry Stewart, 1950 (emeritus trustee and life overseer), were honored by Cornell with the Frank H. T. Rhodes Exemplary Alumni Service Award in 2002. The Board of Trustees recognized the Stewarts as Foremost Benefactors of Cornell in 1995. Mr. Stewart was a remarkable leader and friend who will be missed by the entire Cornell community. We express our deepest sympathy to his wife, Pat, his daughter, Jennifer J. Stewart, his son, C. Evan Stewart, 1974, his granddaughter, Charlotte Stewart, his brothers, George B. Stewart, 1954, and Edwin C. Stewart, and all members of the family. Peter C. Meinig Chairman of the Board of Trustees, Cornell University David J. Skorton President, Cornell University

SEVERE RECESSION ANXIETY Fear that the United States is in a recession is reverberating around the world as stock markets plummeted and took with it the hopes of many investors that Europe and Asia will be able to avoid an American downturn. [Page 1A.] For investors lured to overseas markets by the promise that growth and solid economic fundamentals in Asia and the Middle East would protect them from the credit squeeze in the United States, a realization that an American recession and the fallout from subprime loans will have global repercussions. [C1.]

ELKES--Terrence. My business partner and closest friend, I will miss you. May your children and grandchildren continue to exhibit the qualities and characteristics that made you and Ruth so special. May you both rest in peace. Ken Gorman ELKES--Terrence. The National Yiddish Book Center mourns the passing our friend and benefactor Terrence Elkes. Z''L: May his memory be for a blessing. ELKES--Terrence (Terry). ''Now cracks a noble heart. Goodnight, sweet prince, and flights of angels sing thee to thy rest!'' Eugene and Emily Grant ELKES--Terrence. President Gregory H. Williams and the faculty, staff and students of The City College of New York wish to express their deep sadness at the sudden passing of Terrence Elkes, one of CCNY's most eminent and dedicated alumni. He received his bachelor's degree in Economics and Political Science from The City College of New York in 1955 and earned his Doctor of Laws degree from the University of Michigan in 1958. He went on to a distinguished career in law and business, but always kept a warm place in his heart for his alma mater. A leading member of the City College 21st Century Foundation Board, Terry also served on its Investment Committee. In addition, the commitment Terry and his dearly loved wife Ruth made to the College earned them honored places in its President's Circle. Through his visionary support of science, he has helped to advance the scientific leadership of the College. This past fall, he was elected to membership in the Townsend Harris Society, receiving the highest award the CCNY Alumni Association can bestow. Terry's own eloquent words tell it best: ''For me, what City College really represented was the only opportunity where someone with my background could obtain a first class education. It was a system that was based strictly on merit and tuition-free, and it was the gateway towards a career which I would not have been able to achieve. Today's students deserve nothing less than that opportunity as well''. Our heartfelt condolences to Steven, David, and Daniel, their wives and children on the loss of Terry, so soon after losing their beloved mother Ruth. They were a very important part of the CCNY family. We will miss them both very much. ELKES --Terrence. The University of Michigan, and President Mary Sue Coleman, express their deepest sympathy to the family of Terry Elkes. As a graduate of Michigan Law, he continued to provide generous time and support to both the Law School and the University, serving on the Law School's Campaign Steering Committee, and the University's President's Advisory Group, and the Investment Advisory Group. We will miss him greatly. President Mary Sue Coleman The University of Michigan

Peter Crouch scored in the 88th minute to give Liverpool a 2-2 tie against Aston Villa in the English Premier League on Monday. Crouch entered with 10 minutes remaining against his former club and scored his first league goal of the season. The result was a fourth consecutive draw for Liverpool, putting it fifth with 40 points but still 14 behind league-leading Manchester United. Aston Villa also has 40 points.

Morocco scored twice in the opening five minutes en route to a 5-1 rout of Namibia in Group A. Soufiane Alloudi scored three goals in the first half.

BAKER--Charles Arthur, 73, Died Thursday, January 10, 2008, of complications from Alzheimer's Disease, in Columbia County, NY. Born in Warren, Arkansas, on July 27, 1934, Baker was the son of Arthur Lee Baker and Gladys Thompson Baker. Baker came to New York City in 1957, where he designed window displays at Bloomingdale's and Delman Shoes. One of his windows for Delman's was done in the style of Renee Magritte. Magritte's wife saw the display and congratulated Baker on his superb execution. In the early 1960s, Baker opened a store in the East Village called Paper Moon, selling only objects made from paper. Among them were paper chairs Baker constructed from large paper cylinders, which were the subject of an article in The New York Times. The business soon moved uptown to Madison Avenue, where it became a well-known gift shop, frequently visited by Salvador Dali and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. In the early 1970s, Baker left Paper Moon to devote himself to gardening and, in 1975, purchased, with Dr. Norman Ames Posner, Hudson Bush Farm in Greenport, NY. The house, which was built by Henry I. Van Rensselaer in 1785, is listed in the National Register of Historic Places and is frequently included on historic house tours in the Hudson Valley. At Hudson Bush Farm, Baker created a nationally recognized garden, which is part of the Garden Conservancy Open Day Program and has been the setting for numerous charitable events. Baker is survived by his partner, Dr. Norman Ames Posner; his Jack Russell terrier, Soames; his sister, Carolyn Baker Allen of Mt. Pleasant, SC; his brother, Thomas Oliver Baker of Tuscaloosa, AL; two nieces, a nephew, and several grandnieces and grandnephews. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Research Institute at Albany Medical Center. A memorial service is planned for the spring, to take place in his garden.

The Masters offered special invitations Monday to three players from Asia, part of a plan by its chairman, Billy Payne, to help broaden the appeal of golf and the tournament around the world. Invitations were awarded to Liang Wen-Chong of China, Prayad Marksaeng of Thailand and Jeev Milka Singh of India, who will be making his second consecutive appearance in the tournament. Singh tied for 37th last year.Liang last year became the first Chinese player to win the Order of Merit on the Asian Tour. Marksaeng has won six times on the Asian Tour. Singh won twice on the European Tour in 2006, including the Volvo Masters at Valderrama. None are among the top 75 in the world rankings.

PASTOR--Richard. Lifelong journalist with the labor press, dedicated union man and tireless fighter for progressive causes died at age 89 on Sunday, January 20, 2008. Dick will be remembered with love and admiration for his wit, intelligence, integrity and devotion by his wife of 60 years, Naomi; his son Michael; sister Joyce; daughter-in-law Ella; and grandchildren Kate and Julia.

EDSEL--Alpha Ray (Ray), born March 5th, 1926 in Seiling, Oklahoma and passed away Saturday, January 19, 2008. Veteran of World War II. Survived by Norma, his loving and devoted wife of 56 years; daughter Anne Jones, her husband John and their daughters, Jennifer and Brooke; son Jim, his wife Nancy and their children, James, Jr., Philip, and Catherine; son Robert and his son Diego; and sisters Margaret Fitch and Norma Jean Henderson. After high school Ray enlisted as a Marine and served his nation in the Pacific Theater including Saipan, Okinawa, and Nagasaki. Following his four years of military service Ray attended Oklahoma State University where he served as president of his fraternity, Sigma Alpha Epsilon. He graduated in 1951 and married his college sweetheart, Norma Louise Morse. He returned to Canton, Oklahoma, and joined his beloved brother, Houston, in the family business. Ray was elected and served as mayor of Canton before moving to New York City to join the training program of Smith Barney in 1955. In 1960 he moved his family to Dallas to open Smith Barney's first office in the southwest. His lengthy career with Smith Barney extended more than 33 years during which he served as office manager and director before his retirement in 1988. During his lifetime he was a member of Highland Park Presbyterian Church, Brookhollow Golf Club, Dallas Country Club, and The Dallas Club, among others. Ray was a devoted husband, father, and friend whose positive attitude and eternal sense of good humor touched the lives of everyone he greeted. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Monuments Men Foundation for the Preservation of Art, 3811 Turtle Creek Blvd, Suite 330, Dallas, Texas 75219.

ENG--Zama, 1958-2008. Longtime personality at the NYC Kate's Paperie stores, Zama died January 18, 2008 after a sudden stroke, leaving a legion of friends and family. Donations may be made in her name to the New Jersey Sharing Network.

If anything, the speed at which market turmoil swept across the globe demonstrates how much globalization has taken root. But at the same time, that erosion of national boundaries has also been reflected in the rise of sovereign wealth funds and their major investments in western financial institutions.

There’s no doubt that times are tough for private equity firms. But few men are in a better position to speak about what’s next than Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chairman and chief executive of the Blackstone Group. In speaking with CNBC’s Maria Bartiromo at the World Economic Forum, he said it was still too difficult to call an end to the credit markets’ tightening.
Contrary to the stereotype, the folks at Davos are impressed by people other than hedge fund managers or captains of industry. They just might not always show it.

It was an aptly named dinner debate on this first day of gloom and doom at the World Economic Forum: “Recession,” the title read in the forum’s program folder in bold red letters as if to drive home the point. After a day of debates dedicated to (or inevitably turning to) the United States economy’s sorry outlook, two high-profile chief executives joked that it felt like an act of masochism to end the day like this (rather than at the simultaneous wine-tasting or story-telling dinners).

With the future of private equity looking cloudy right now, pundits have speculated on what awaits the industry. CNBC’s Maria Bartiromo interviewed Glenn Hutchins, the head of Silver Lake, at the World Economic Forum in Davos and got his thoughts.

An increasing number of economists are predicting a recession in the United States, but some top executives here in Davos appear to be less dour. One of these executives is Sir Howard Stringer, chief executive of Sony, whom I interviewed as the World Economic Forum got underway on Wednesday.
Getting an invitation to the annual meeting at the World Economic Forum is considered an honor for most — but it sure doesn’t come cheap.
When a government official starts talking about good economic fundamentals, you know something has gone wrong.

“This is not a normal crisis,” George Soros, the hedge fund pioneer turned philosopher, said today to a group of reporters he had invited to lunch at the World Economic Forum. “It is the end of an era.”

In Silicon Valley, it may be all-iPhone-all-the-time, but here among the world’s business elites in Davos, it’s still very much a RIM Blackberry world. Indeed, if you pull an iPhone out of your pocket, it still creates a mild sensation here, because unlike in the United States, most Europeans have yet to touch Apple‘s six-month-old handheld phenomenon.

After the geopolitics session saw a Chinese panelist offering lessons in democracy and an American speaker underscoring modesty, Chinese and American experts clashed — if good-naturedly, for the most part — during an economics-laden discussion Wednesday on whether the rest of the world still catches a cold if the United States sneezes.
The sharpest focus of the World Economic Forum may be on the future of the beleaguered economy, but there is still room for some of the world’s most influential financiers to talk politics.

The day before the official kick-off of the World Economic Forum in Davos Switzerland, it seemed like just another meeting of the world’s most exclusive talk shop, held each January in this Alpine ski resort.

The world must be changing when on a World Economic Forum panel on geopolitics you have three Asians, two Europeans and just one American (even though that American was called Power — the Harvard professor Samantha Power).

Davos may seem like it is all about the big theatrically produced panels and presentations, like Bill Gates’ planned speech this year schedule titled “A New Approach to Capitalism in the 21st Century.” But the hottest tickets — and the hardest to come by — aren’t on the schedule at all.

Updated, 6:31 p.m. | Mostly intact skeletal remains from at least four people were discovered this morning by city archaeologists doing soil testing as part of a restoration of Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village, city officials said. The discovery could have significance for scholars studying the history of the early United States; the area of the park was used as a common burial ground, or potter’s field, from 1797 to 1826.

In recent years, New York and London have been dueling for the title of capital of the 21st century. Now Monopoly — that’s right, the Hasbro board game — is allowing the world to cast a vote in an online contest that will determine which 22 cities will be immortalized in a new global edition of the 75-year-old board game.The contest began at midnight Greenwich Mean Time, or about 7 p.m., on Monday night. As of today, London and New York are in the top two positions, with Paris just a smidgen behind New York. The top winner will be awarded the Boardwalk position, while No. 2 will get Park Place. The new game is scheduled to be unveiled in August.

Among the hundreds of proposals contained in Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s second executive budget, which he unveiled on Tuesday in Albany, is a provision that would impose a $3.50-a-gram tax on marijuana and a $200-a-gram tax on other illegal drugs, like cocaine.We took a look at the fine print to better understand the details of this legislative proposal — which, incidentally, is very similar to a proposal that Mayor Edward I. Koch put forward in 1988. (That proposal, to tax illegal drugs in New York City, also at a rate of $200 a gram, did not come to fruition.)

A state appellate court has rejected an effort by defense lawyers to move the trial of three New York City police detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell, who was fatally shot in Queens on Nov. 25, 2006, hours before he was to be married.

Marian Burros reported in The Times on Wednesday that recent laboratory tests of tuna sushi from a sampling of stores and restaurants in Manhattan found high amounts of mercury. There was so much that a regular diet of six pieces a week would exceed the levels considered acceptable by the Environmental Protection Agency.
The vaguely threatening sign against menus that attracted attention this month is now available in an improved (and more grammatical) pentalingual version at Dangernomenus.com.

Updated, 9:17 p.m. | The masseuse who discovered the body of Heath Ledger in a Manhattan apartment on Tuesday twice called a friend of his, the actress Mary-Kate Olsen, before calling 911, New York City police officials said on Wednesday. The officials, who provided new details about Mr. Ledger’s death, emphasized that no illegal drugs were found in the apartment and that there were no obvious signs of suicide. Tests on a rolled-up $20 bill that was found in the apartment found no evidence that the bill had been used to handle drugs, they said.

Today's Formula One testing times in Valencia are enough to get the mouth watering and the heart beating hard in anticipation for the start to the season on 16 March. At the top of the time sheets we find Heikki Kovalainen, followed by the two Ferraris, Felipe Massa and then Kimi Raikkonen...and then Lewis Hamilton in fourth. And the pattern of the teammates who were supposed to be faster but weren't does not stop there: In fifth in a Williams we find Kazuki Nakajima, with Nico Rosberg in the other Williams finishing behind Fernando Alonso in the Renault.

Flailing around Florida, Rudolph Giuliani is getting different results, just not the ones he wants. Call him a lot a things - weird, imperious, self-aggrandizing - but crazy he is not, at least by Einstein's notion.

The ovation was still going as I moved toward the backstage, slowly and then at a brisk walk. I passed Marisa Berenson and Marie-Chantal of Greece, who was with her husband Pavlos and her in-laws, Queen Ann-Marie and King Constantine. I saw Uma ahead of me. I caught up with Uma in the backstage and asked her what she thought of the show, half embarrassed that I bothered. "I have no comment to make at this time," she said, as if she had said it a million times before. Okay. Wouldn't "beautiful" have worked just as well? I turned away, toward the mob of photographers and models, all of them in identical red dresses, gathering with intensity around Valentino. Natalia V. had tears welling in her eyes. I saw Carlos Souza, who has done the press for Valentino for years, and I asked him if the girls were going to keep their red dresses. They'd all came out in red for the finale. "For sure!" he said, watching Valentino and the mob. Later, I asked one of the models about it and the look she gave me said, "Are you kidding?"

I'm not at Davos. Partly this is because my wife and I really needed some quiet time together, before the semester starts. Partly it's because textbook revision deadlines loom. But I also have to say that the scene at Davos, with all the great, good, wise, and, especially, rich gathered together to celebrate their greatness, goodness, wisdom, and, especially, wealth, has always made me uncomfortable. I usually end up skipping a couple of big dinner affairs and sneaking off to feast on the modern Swiss national dish -- which is, of course, spaghetti carbonara.

It's widely agreed that Al Gore, private citizen, has done more to move the global political debate than Al Gore, elected official, ever did. Now Gore, who as vice president supported the Defense of Marriage Act, has put up a video on his Current TV Web site in which he stands up for gay marriage: "Gay men and women ought to have the same rights as heterosexual men and women -- to make contracts, to have hospital visiting rights, to join together in marriage, and I don't understand why it is considered by some people to be a threat to heterosexual marriage..."

The United States is less green than Russia, according to a new global scorecard of environmental performance.

We all love lists of winners and losers, and an obliging research team at Yale and Columbia has been trying to refine one that regularly ranks countries on their environmental performance. Switzerland is on top; Niger is dead last at 149th. The United States ranks 39th, below all of the other Group of 8 industrialized nations. By comparison, Albania is 25th, Russia 28th. Felicity Barringer's story on the list, called an Environmental Performance Index, is online here.

Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for "soft news" - coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma'am.As the global economy enters a tailspin, what better time to announce production of the Maybach 62 Landaulet - a convertible sports-car limo - that resembles a "marshmallow" and costs $1.19 million? ... Here's one amenity Maybach engineers graciously omitted: a La-Z-Boy jacuzzi in the trunk ... If you can't drown your economic sorrows in the hot tub, drink a cup of joe from a $20,000 coffee-maker... Maybe the economy is okay after all - in Brooklyn a chic independent bookstore, Melville House, has just opened. Take that, Fox Books! ... When times are hard, sometimes the only recourse is, well, shopping! White Lighting is crushing on lace-up wedge boots from Chloë Sevigny's Opening Ceremony collection... Speaking of footwear fetishism, two dudes from New Jersey were (are?) camped out in the freezing cold in front of a Foot Locker in Herald Square awaiting the new Air Jordan XX3 (23 get it?) ... If you'd like to remember more prosperous times, Allure's Jessica Matlin has a notion: go for glitter! Like Mariah Carey, "it's back"... And so are we, tomorrow.

In my column in today's newspaper I wrote about the wine panel's recent tasting of some inexpensive Napa cabernets, if you can call wines $50 and under inexpensive. They are by Napa standards, where mediocre cabernets run $50 to $150 as a matter of course. Although we found wines we liked the tasting was disappointing on the whole. Not because so many wines were bad but because so many were boring and innocuous, with a sort of generic plush, smooth fruitiness.

Last week, before I left the United States, my friends in Ghana had been trying to explain to me the frenzy over tickets. My friend John Rue, who has been living in Ghana and had been searching for tickets nearly full-time, said last Thursday in an e-mail that the Ghanaian Embassy in Washington was selling tickets and that I needed to get there ASAP. Getting tickets in Ghana, especially for games involving the host team and countries in West Africa such as Ivory Coast, Cameroon and Nigeria, has been extremely difficult, my friend told me.

More campaign-related opinion for Wednesday, Jan. 23:

Even by election-year standards, the current field of Republican candidates has been doing some truly ambitious pandering. First, Mitt Romney told the autoworkers in Michigan that he could get all their jobs back-no problem, consider it done. Then, Mike Huckabee told South Carolinians that it was nobody's business but theirs if they wanted to wallpaper their public buildings with the Confederate flag. And now here comes Rudolph W. Giuliani to show these amateurs how it's done. Campaigning in his make-or-break state of Florida last week, Mr. Giuliani released a statement promising to "make space a priority." Apparently, America is facing a crisis far greater than health care or education reform: when the current fleet of space shuttles is retired in 2010, it's going to take as much as five years-five years, people!-before we can send another guy into orbit. "This is not acceptable," Mr. Giuliani said. "America should be number one in space. We have been. We shouldn't lose that position." In other words, it would be as if a guy had the number one position in all the national polls and then suddenly well, you get the idea.
DAVOS, Switzerland

My desk, clean when I left, quickly became a jumble of work stuff and personal bills, all vying for my attention. In the next three weeks, I have business travel, family responsibilities and a few more deadlines than usual. For many years, Donald G. McNeil has been covering the grim toll wrought by infectious diseases in developing countries, and the global threat some pathogens pose in our increasingly interconnected world. In Science Times this week, he provides a valuable update on the H5N1 virus behind recent outbreaks of avian flu. While out of the headlines, it remains a simmering threat that, experts say, needs far more attention than it is getting. He took some time to explore the issue with me for Dot Earth readers. Please feel free to post any additional questions you may have, or comments, and I'll forward them to him.Q. That was a fine summary today of the bird flu situation, which seems to be on simmer, not boil, but hardly a non-threat at this point. This is a risk I want to explore on Dot Earth because it's one of the potential "hard knocks" we face in a world of growing populations and mobility.

Back at Heathrow: I must have angered the travel gods. Right after I criticizedHeathrow, I found myself back there, waiting for another delayed flight.It was an incremental delay, meaning the departure time kept inching back. Ground staff blamed "communications between Heathrow and Zurich" and added, disparagingly, that "Everything's delayed today anyway."I am spoiled by Hong Kong International Airport, which has free wifi for those with laptops, and free computer terminals for those who don't.At least the electricity at Heathrow's i-Pod and laptop charging stations is free. But an hour on a T-Mobile connection, which was about as quick as the security queue, cost me 5 pounds, or nearly U.S. $10.

The low-scoring defenseman Johnny Oduya had a goal and three assists Tuesday night for the Devils, who scored five power-play goals in a 7-3 victory over the Flyers in Philadelphia.
Jessica McEntee has become a basketball star at New York University while gaining an education without having to go far from her home in Flushing.

An article on Tuesday about a new television advertisement in Spanish for the Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney misstated the value of his company, Bain Capital, at the beginning of his tenure there. It was $36 million, not $6 billion.
Providing the Rangers nice flashbacks to last season’s first-round playoff sweep and playing a dreadful stretch of their own, the Thrashers ran into an angry and energized Rangers team.
The State of Missouri must provide transportation to clinics for inmates who want to have an abortion, a federal appeals panel ruled.
A member of the Kansas City Parks Board resigned after amidst controversy concerning her membership in an anti-illegal-immigration group.
The Bush administration threatened to veto Senate legislation designed to improve health care on Indian reservations.
Dozens of victims of the bridge collapse last summer in Minneapolis have filed preliminary paperwork to sue the state.
A Swedish businessman who crashed a $1.5 million Ferrari in Malibu in 2006 will be soon released from a detention center near Los Angeles and deported to Sweden.

The Buick Invitational will have the top two players in the world after all. After three days of bed rest and antibiotics for respiratory problems, Phil Mickelson said Tuesday he was feeling better and will play in the pro-am Wednesday at the Buick Invitational, paving the way for him to make his 2008 debut at Torrey Pines. He also has a practice session planned with his swing coach, Butch Harmon.
Larry Brown has broken an apparently self-imposed silence to accuse the Knicks of espionage. The spying, Brown said, was directed at him.
As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York continues to dance around a presidential run, news media interest in the maneuverings of his chief political deputy, Kevin Sheekey, has intensified.
Don Mattingly has told the Dodgers that he cannot be their batting coach and has decided to spend more time with his wife and his youngest son at home in Evansville, Ind.
Steve Nash scored 15 of his season-high 37 points in the fourth quarter, leading the visiting Phoenix Suns past the Milwaukee Bucks, 114-105, on Tuesday night

The Indy Racing League will use a four-lap qualifying procedure similar to the Indianapolis 500 at all its oval-track races this season. The pole winner and lineup at those events will be determined by the overall times for all four laps, rather than the fastest of two qualifying laps as in the past. The format for road and street courses will remain unchanged, with single-lap qualifying for all cars followed by a 10-minute group session with the six fastest qualifiers to determine the pole position.

Mike Kelly retired Tuesday after 27 years as coach at Dayton. Kelly compiled a 246-54-1 record for an .819 winning percentage, fourth-best among coaches with at least 25 years of experience. Rick Chamberlin, the defensive coordinator, will take over as head coach, Athletic Director Ted Kissell said. Kelly will remain at the university, expanding his duties as an associate athletic director.

A judge refused to force an auction of an ownership stake in Curlin, the Horse of the Year, saying the request has been made too soon. Special Judge Roger Crittenden left the door open for 418 people to pursue a 20 percent ownership stake. The judge made his decision during a hearing on Tuesday after concluding that the plaintiffs did not have enough information about the assets of the lawyers William Gallion and Shirley Cunningham Jr. The two men are accused of bilking former clients out of at least $42 million in a $200 million settlement involving the diet drug Fen-phen.

Egypt opened the defense of its African Cup of Nations title by defeating Cameroon, 4-2, Tuesday as Mohamed Zidan and Hosni Abd Rabou scored two goals each. In Tuesday’s other game, Sudan beat Zambia, 3-0.

The Tour of California, a 650-mile, eight-day race that is expected to attract some of cycling’s top international teams next month, announced Tuesday that it would increase testing of riders before and after each day’s event, and contribute its results to an antidoping database sponsored by the sport’s governing body.

The Olympic sprint champion Justin Gatlin has appealed his four-year doping suspension in an attempt to return to the track for the Beijing Games in August. The notice was filed Monday to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, the international body that has the final say in such matters. A United States arbitration panel earlier this month reduced Gatlin’s potential eight-year ban to four, but Gatlin wants a further reduction.

Stacy Dragila, who dominated American women’s pole-vaulting for more than a decade, and Jenn Stuczynski, her successor, were matched Tuesday for the 101st Millrose Games on Feb. 1 in Madison Square Garden.Dragila, 36, is competing again after chronic Achilles’ tendon problems. In a two-week period last summer, Stuczynski broke Dragila’s American record of 15 feet 10 inches, then became the second woman in track and field history to clear 16 feet.

The Mets avoided arbitration with their best defensive outfielder Tuesday by signing Endy Chávez to a two-year, $3.85 million contract. Chavez, 29, will make $1.8 million this season and $2.05 million in 2009. Chávez, who was limited to 71 games last season because of a left hamstring strain that knocked him out for nearly three months, batted .287 and scored 20 runs while playing his customary strong defense.
John McCain scooped up $1 million on Rudolph W. Giuliani’s turf and announced the support of a swath of New York Republicans.
As global markets swooned, Washington’s goal of projecting calm to the public crosses party lines.

The Italian fashion-model-turned-singer Carla Bruni said in an interview that she and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France are not married, quashing rumors that there had been a secret wedding ceremony in the Élysée Palace.

The military council that ousted former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra in 2006 disbanded, promising “no more coups.”
The government has announced it will make cooking lessons mandatory for youths at British schools starting in September as a way to counter obesity.

The president of Cuba’s National Assembly said he expected Fidel Castro to be nominated for president on Feb. 24 when the new Parliament meets, but expressed uncertainty over whether he would accept the post again.

Longer skirts and shorter catfights were promised on Tuesday by the producers of a steamy Thai soap opera about airline crews that drew a protest from the Thai Airways International union, The Associated Press reported. At a news conference, executives from the Exact Company, which produces the show, said they were sorry if they had offended anyone and would tone down some of the raciness.

NBC led every hour of prime time in Monday night’s ratings, buoyed by the successful combination of its new hit “American Gladiators” followed by the game show “Deal or No Deal.” Those shows earned the night’s top ratings among adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen’s estimates, with “Deal or No Deal” also drawing the largest audience of the night, 14.1 million viewers at 9 p.m. “American Gladiators,” meanwhile, delivered a more modest 10.1 million viewers at 8. NBC’s “Medium,” which also drew 10.1 million viewers, led the 10 p.m. hour in the 18-to-49 group. Fox finished second for the night in that demographic, thanks to its new show “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles,” which attracted 8.6 million viewers while tying CBS’s comedy repeats in the 9 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 49. CBS, which broadcast reruns all night long, ranked third in that age group, but second in total viewers behind NBC. ABC was a distant fourth. Its “Dance War” averaged 9.8 million viewers from 8 to 9:30, but its “October Road” continued to struggle during the 10 p.m. time slot with just 5 million viewers.
The Theater Hall of Fame has announced its new inductees.

A best-selling author who is the world’s leading spokesman for child soldiers strongly defended himself against an Australian newspaper’s accusation that he had distorted the account of his service in Sierra Leone’s civil war during the 1990s. In a statement released on Tuesday, the author, Ishmael Beah, above, said: “I am right about my story. This is not something one gets wrong.” His publisher, Sarah Crichton Books, a Farrar, Straus & Giroux imprint, also defended the accuracy of his book, “A Long Way Gone: Memoirs of a Boy Soldier.” The Weekend Australian reported that his ordeal had lasted one year, not the three that he had stated. Mr. Beah, now 27, said the newspaper may not have understood that rebels first attacked his village in 1993, two years before they closed a village mine.

Descendants of two prominent czarist-era art collectors demanded compensation as a major exhibition of Russian art was previewed on Tuesday at the Royal Academy of Arts in London, Bloomberg News reported. The descendants, André-Marc Delocque-Fourcaud, grandson of Sergei Shchukin, and Pierre Konowaloff, great-grandson of Ivan Morosov, did not seek the return of paintings. Instead, they asserted a moral right to a portion of the proceeds from the show, to open on Saturday. A spokeswoman for the Russian Federal Agency of Culture and Cinematography declined to comment. Fears of legal claims to some of the 120 works in the show, “From Russia: French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925 From Moscow and St. Petersburg” cast doubt over the exhibition for several weeks until Britain satisfied Russia that the paintings, including art by Gauguin, Kandinsky and van Gogh, would be returned after it ends on April 18.

In a grainy video that circulated online Tuesday Amy Winehouse, 24, left, appears to smoke crack and claims to have taken “about six Valium.” It was posted on the Web site for The Sun, a British tabloid (thesun.co.uk), and an accompanying article, inset, said the video was taken early Friday morning at Ms. Winehouse’s London home, and that the two-minute clip follows “a 19-minute binge in which she snorted powdered ecstasy and cocaine.” Her record label, Universal, said in a statement: “We are deeply disappointed and upset by these latest revelations and are doing everything we can to offer Amy our full support in dealing with her problems.” Contradictory reports circulated online on Tuesday about whether Ms. Winehouse had been taken to a rehab clinic. (She had a hit with “Rehab,” in which she sings about refusing treatment.) A spokeswoman for her label declined to comment on that issue.

MILLS--William P., Jr., 70, of Bronxville and Westhampton Beach, NY, retired attorney and former partner of Chadbourne & Parke and Sage Gray Todd & Sims, passed away on January 21, 2008. He is survived by his beloved wife, Constance, sons William P., III, and Edward, daughter Melissa, sister Mary, brother John, daughters-in-law Suzanne and Jodi, and grandchildren William P., IV, Anne, Sarah, Megan and Tyler. Contributions may be made in his memory to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, NYC, or Lawrence Hospital Center, Bronxville. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 7-9pm Wednesday, Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, Friday, January 25 at 11am.

FLIGLER--Carlos, passed away on January 20, 2008 in New York City. He was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina, where he became a lawyer. He was also a graduate of Harvard University's Master of Law (LLM) Program. Carlos was associated with the law firm Sullivan & Cromwell and then the World Bank in Washington, D.C. and JP Morgan in New York. Most recently, he financed multinational corporate transactions with his firm, Delta Capital Corporation. Carlos was an avid painter, was interested in world affairs and led the Foreign Policy and National Affairs group at the Harvard Club of New York City. He was a cultured, well-read and refined gentleman who lived his life with dignity and integrity. His thoughtful advice, friendship, fine character and wisdom enriched us all. He will be greatly missed by friends and family in the U.S. and Argentina, Jeanette Fligler, Harry and Marta Fligler, Norberto Fligler, Felisa and Mario Gradowczyk, Diego, Isabella and Bettina Gradowczyk, Elise Kapell, Dita, Leo, Alissa and David Makower, and their respective families. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering, P.O. Box 27106, NY, NY 10087 or Manhattan Insitute for Cancer Research, 24 E. 64th St., NY, NY 10021. He will be laid to rest with his family at La Tablada, Buenos Aires. A memorial tribute for Carlos will be held at 5:30pm on Monday, Janaury 28, at the Harvard Club, 35 W. 44th St., New York City.

CRESCENZI--Armand (Chris) M.D., 82, of Pocantico Hills passed away on January 18th, 2008. He is survived by his wife Margaret Brown, his daughters Caroline, Susan and Debra. He is predeceased by his wives Caroline Lydecker, M.D., and Katherine Louise Friedmann, M.D. There will be a memorial service, Saturday, January 26th at 11am at the Presbyterian Church in Irvington, NY. There are flower teas that gently unfurl in a glass pot. Now exotic flowers can adorn your Champagne, kir or cosmopolitan, or even replace a maraschino cherry in your Manhattan. The flowers, ruby-colored Australian wild hibiscus, bear a slight resemblance to sea anemones. Preserved in syrup, they have a slightly tart berry flavor. They can go beyond drinks, to top a panna cotta or a scoop of vanilla ice cream or raspberry sorbet, with some of the rich syrup poured over.

Wine sets the scene at Alain Ducasse's restaurant in the St. Regis, Adour Alain Ducasse, which is to open on Monday. David Rockwell, the designer, said he studied glasses of Burgundy to select the dining room's dominant color. Chardonnay-gold accents lighten the somewhat clubby look. Glass-front wine storage units are positioned around the room, and there are four decanting stations for the sommeliers. Thomas Combescot-Lepère, the wine director, has been working with Tony Esnault, the executive chef, to select wine-friendly dishes like Berkshire pork given an earthy edge with black truffles, and lobster thermidor with an intensified sauce friendly to red wine, so that a party of four, each ordering a different main course, can choose a bottle that's compatible with everything. Above, Mr. Combescot-Lepère checks for sediment as he decants a bottle.
ROM--William N., died in Ely, MN, January 20, 2008 at age 90. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness bears witness to his tireless conservation efforts.

BOWKER--Albert H. The City University of New York deeply mourns the loss of Chancellor Emeritus Albert H. Bowker, a giant in the history of public education in the nation. He was deeply committed to the education of students regardless of their income or background. CUNY Chancellor from 1963 to 1971, he built CUNY from four senior colleges and a few small community colleges to 18 campuses offering associate and baccalaureate degrees, a graduate school of social work and a graduate school and university center for doctoral studies. He put in place numerous academic programs and facilities that have benefited millions of New Yorkers. Before joining CUNY, he was Dean of Stanford University's graduate school. He served as the Chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley from 1971 to 1980 and was appointed Assistant Secretary of Postsecondary Education by President Jimmy Carter. A graduate of MIT, he was a distinguished mathematician, educator and beloved mentor to educational administrators, faculty and students throughout the nation. His legacy will long endure. We offer our deepest condolences to his children, Paul, Nancy and Caroline Bowker. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr., Chairman Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor BOWKER--Albert H. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of the Research Foundation/CUNY mourn the loss of our former board member and vice president, Albert H. Bowker. As Chancellor of The City University of New York he demonstrated extraordinary vision and courage in promoting access and excellence in public higher education. He continued to exhibit that vision and courage during his years as Chancellor of UC Berkeley, as Assistant Secretary at the U.S. Department of Education, and as Executive Vice President at the University of Maryland. The Research Foundation was fortunate, indeed, to have had the benefit of his wisdom, intellect, compassion, and advice from 1986 to 1993 as Vice President for Planning and subsequently as a member of the board until 2002. He will be missed by those who knew and admired him and by the many more generations of students past, present, and future whose lives are better thanks to him. Our heartfelt condolences to his family and friends and to the entire higher education community. Matthew Goldstein, Chairman of the Board Richard F. Rothbard, President

A fortuneteller told Dorina Yuen, above, that she needed to have more gold in her life. So as she began planning a pastry shop and cafe, she decided to name it Oro, which means gold in Spanish. She decorated this sliver of a brick-walled storefront in Little Italy with gold-toned tables, banquettes upholstered in gold and a shiny golden swath of countertop (actually brass).

FED ACTS WITH BIG RATE CUT The Federal Reserve, confronted by deepening panic in global financial markets about a possible recession in the United States, struck back with the biggest one-day reduction of interest rates on record and at least temporarily stopped a vertigo-inducing plunge in share prices. The Fed's dramatic move took shape Monday afternoon when the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, had apparently seen enough turmoil in overseas markets and called a meeting. [C1.]

RADNAY--Dr. Leslie S., 95, of Melrose, MA, died January 20. Born in Szolnok, Hungary, hewas son of the late Ferenc and Ida (Varsa) Radnai. He was a Holocaust survivor who spent the duration of the war in forced labor camps. In February of 1957, he and his family escaped from Hungary and ultimately settled in Melrose, MA, where he resided until his death. He was a systems engineer at Raytheon, retiring in 1977. An active amateur radio operator for over 80 years (WA1FHU and then W1PL), he was a generous mentor and friend to generations of HAM radio operators throughout the world. He was predeceased by wife, Olga (Friedmann), and is survived by daughters Eva Rajczyk (Haverhill, MA) and Katalin Baltimore (Orange, CT) and their families. A celebration of his life is being planned for the late spring. Donations may be made in his name to: Lighthouse International: www.lighthouse.org/donate/ Condolences may be made at www.W1PL.org.

LIEBESKIND--Arie. As we always said to each other CHAZAK! Marvin Weitz LIEBESKIND--Arie, devoted husband, father, and grandfather, died on January 22, 2008 at age 70. He is survived by his children Marc, David, and Elise, and grandchildren Alexander, Bernard, Kayla, Stella, and Mia; his wife Dori passed away in 2007. Arie was raised in Israel and graduated from college and medical school in New York. He and Dori, both caring physicians specializing in neuroradiology, worked together throughout their careers in a radiology practice they co-founded. They enjoyed and continually celebrated a 42 year marriage encircled by many friends. Arie's charming character pervaded every aspect of his life, always sustaining a positive outlook. Arie will be greatly missed by his family and friends and will always be remembered for his unique spirit, warmth, joyous nature, and love of music, art, and travel. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday, January 23, at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St., at 1pm.
